question_html: Alkanes can react with halogens in a photochemical reaction under conditions involving UV light. What type of mechanism is involved in this reaction?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: This is a free-radical substitution reaction because one of the hydrogen atoms in the alkane is being substituted by a halogen atom. It occurs in 3 stages - initiation, propagation and termination.

question_html: What is the correct molecular geometry of the XeF5+ ion?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The central xenon atom has 8 valence electrons, -1 due to the charge, which gives a total of 7 valence electrons. It uses five to bond to the F atoms, and thus has a lone pair left over. The six electron domains generate an octahedral distribution, creating a square pyramidal molecular geometry for the actual ion.

question_html:
Two propagation steps of a free-radical substitution reaction are shown below.

Cl• + X → •CH3 + HCl

•CH3 + Cl2 → CH3Cl + Y

Which of the following are the correct species for X and Y?

X Y
I •CH4 Cl
II CH4 Cl•
III •CH3 Cl
IV CH3 Cl•

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
The correct propogation steps are as follows:

Cl• + CH4 → CH3• + HCl

CH3• + Cl2 → CH3Cl + Cl•

X is an alkane which is methane, CH4. Y is a chlorine free-radical, Cl•.

question_html: Identify which of the following Group 16 hydride compounds has the highest boiling point.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The boiling point is determined by the strength of the intermolecular forces between molecules. All of these molecules are polar, so they have dipole–dipole forces in addition to the London dispersion forces present in all molecular compounds. Water (H2O) is the only one of these molecules that also has hydrogen bonding, the strongest intermolecular force, therefore it has the highest boiling point.

question_html: What is the correct IUPAC name for the following molecule?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
The longest sequence of C–C bonds is 5, making the parent chain 'pent-'. There are only single C–C bonds, so the molecule is based on an alkane structure: 'pentane'.

There are two identical functional groups, -OH, hydroxy, making this molecule an alcohol, so the name ends in ‘-ol’.

Since there are two hydroxy groups, the ending will be '-diol'.

The positions of the hydroxy groups on the carbon chain must be chosen to give the lowest combination of numbers. Depending on which end of the chain the numbering starts, it is either ‘2,5’ or ‘1,4’. The lower combination is ‘1,4’.

This molecule is therefore named pentane-1,4-diol or 1,4-pentanediol (note that both are accepted IUPAC names and that there must be a dash between the numbers and the letters).

question_html: Which of the following oxides is amphoteric?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Aluminium oxide is amphoteric which means it is able to act as both an acid and a base. MgO and Na2O are basic oxides and P4O10 is acidic.

question_html: Which of the following is the correct rate expression for an SN1 reaction involving the substitution of a halogenoalkane, RX?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: An SN1 reaction is a unimolecular nucleophilic substitution reaction, meaning there is only one molecule in the rate-determining step. This molecule is the halogenoalkane as the nucleophile only takes part in the subsequent fast step following the rate-determining step. The reaction is first-order with repsect to the halogenoalkane. Remember you must use square brackets for concentration.

question_html: What type of reaction results in the formation of the polymer Teflon, otherwise known as PTFE or polytetrafluoroethene?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: This polymer, poly(tetrafluoroethene), made by polymerising CF2 = CF2 monomers, is an addition polymer made from many tetrafluoroethene molecules. The type of reaction is an addition reaction.

question_html: Some atoms are stable with less than eight electrons in the valence shell. There are two such elements in period two of the periodic table, one being boron. What is the name of the other element?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Beryllium is stable with less than eight electrons in its outer shell. In BeCl2 the central beryllium atom just has four electrons in its valence shell, for example.

question_html: In examining the Maxwell-Boltzmann distribution curves at different temperatures on the graph below, which variable in the graph remains the same?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Since the number of particles remains constant, the area under each curve will also remain the same. The change of shape to the curve occurs because the distribution of particles at different amounts of energy will change, but the area under the curve, representing the total number of particles, does not change.

MCQ_set.answer_html: the average kinetic energy of the particles

section_title: Collision theory and rates of reaction

question_html:
Which of the following statements is correct for 2-methylbutane?

I.   The ratio of areas under each signal in the 1H NMR spectrum would be 6:1:2:3
II.  In the infrared spectrum, a broad peak would be observed at 3200 cm−1
III. In the mass spectrum, the molecular ion M+ would have a peak at \(\rm{\dfrac{m}{z}=72}\)

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
In 2-methylbutane, the three hydrogen atoms on the first carbon and on the methyl group would be equivalent, giving a relative area of 6. The hydrogen on the second carbon would give a unique signal, giving a relative area of 1. The signal from the two hydrogen atoms on the third carbon would give a relative area of 2. The signal from the three hydrogen atoms on the fourth carbon would give a relative area of 3. This would create a 1H NMR spectrum with four peaks with a ratio of areas of 6:1:2:3.

In infrared spectroscopy, a broad peak at approximately 3200 cm−1 is characteristic of O–H bonds in alcohols and phenols. 2-methylbutane is not an alcohol or a phenol, this statement would not be correct.

The molar mass of 2-methylbutane is 72 g mol−1, meaning that the molecular ion of
2-methylbutane, C5H12+ would give a signal at \(\rm{\dfrac{m}{z}=72}\).

question_html: Which statement is always correct for the molecular ion M+ in a mass spectrum?

MCQ_set.answer_html: The peak for the M+ ion gives the molar mass of the compound.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
One of the stages in the mass spectrometer is ionization, where the sample encounters a beam of high energy electrons, removing an electron from the molecule, forming an ion of the molecule with a 1+ charge.

Upon interaction with the high energy electrons, the molecule can further fragment into smaller pieces, this is why a fragmentation pattern is observed in a mass spectrum. Different fragments will vary in their stability and the M+ parent ion will usually not be the most stable.

Since M+ represents the molecule with a 1+ charge, it will have the largest mass-to-charge ratio, in comparison with its fragments.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The m/z ratio of the M+ ion peak gives the molar mass of the empirical formula.
The peak for the M+ ion has the highest intensity.
The M+ ion is the most stable fragment produced in the mass spectrometer.

question_html:
Reaction 1:
1-chloropropane reacts with sodium hydroxide via a nucleophilic substitution reaction to form product A and sodium chloride.

Reaction 2:
Some of product A is heated under reflux with acidified potassium dichromate(VI) to form product B.

Reaction 3:
Product A and product B are reacted together in the presence of a concentrated sulfuric acid catalyst to form water and product C.

Identify the number of peaks (number of signals) in the 1H NMR spectrum for product C.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Reaction 1 is the reaction of a primary halogenoalkane to form a primary alcohol, product A would be propan-1-ol.

Reaction 2 is the oxidation of a primary alcohol under heat and reflux, indicating full oxidation to form a carboxylic acid. Product B would be propanoic acid.

Reaction 3 is the condensation reaction of an alcohol and a carboxylic acid to form an ester. Product C would be propyl propanoate.

There is a unique chemical environment of the hydrogen nuclei on each carbon atom. Since one of the carbon atoms contributes to the ester linkage, this would create five signals in the 1H NMR spectrum.

question_html:
Which of the following compounds would have the same ratio of areas under each signal in their 1H NMR spectrum?

I.   propan-2-ol
II.  propan-1-ol
III. butanal

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
The area under a signal curve in an 1H NMR spectrum is proportional to the number of equivalent protons in a chemical environment.

Propan-2-ol has a hydroxyl group on the second carbon atom. This gives a unique proton signal from the hydrogen environment on the hydroxyl group and a unique signal from the hydrogen attached to the second carbon atom. The proton signal from each –CH3 group on either end of the propan-2-ol molecule would be identical, contributing to six equivalent protons. The ratio of areas under each signal for propan-2-ol would be 1:1:6.

Propan-1-ol has a hydroxyl group on the first carbon atom. This gives a unique proton signal from the hydrogen environment on the hydroxyl group. The remaining hydrogen atoms attached to the first carbon atom would contribute two equivalent proton signals. The two hydrogen atoms on the second carbon atom would contribute two equivalent proton signals. The three hydrogen atoms on the third carbon atom would contribute three equivalent proton signals. The ratio of areas under each signal for propan-1-ol would be 1:2:2:3.

Butanal has a unique proton signal from the hydrogen on the first carbon atom (carbonyl). The two hydrogen atoms on the second carbon atom would contribute two equivalent proton signals. The two hydrogen atoms on the third carbon atom would contribute two equivalent proton signals. The three hydrogen atoms on the fourth carbon atom would contribute three equivalent proton signals. The ratio of areas under each signal for propan-1-ol would be 1:2:2:3.

question_html:
A student collected the following data to determine the density of aluminium using the water displacement method.

Which of the following would be the volume of water displaced when 4.00 g of aluminum is placed into a graduated cylinder?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Using the line of best fit the value for volume (x-value) can be interpolated using the value of mass (y-value) of 4.00 g.

question_html:
Which of the following statements are correct regarding the comparison of drawn and sketched graphs?

I.   Sketched graphs are used to show qualitative trends
II.  Drawn graphs are used in quantitative measurements
III. Sketched graphs have unlabelled and unscaled axes

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Sketched graphs have labelled but unscaled axes, and are used to show qualitative trends, such as variables that are proportional or inversely proportional.

Drawn graphs have labelled and scaled axes, and are used in quantitative measurements

section_title: Uncertainties and errors in measurement and results

question_html:
Which of the following shows the molar mass and amount, in mol, to the appropriate number of decimal places and/or significant figures for 7.84 g of CuSO4・5H2O?

\(\qquad\qquad\begin{align}\text{M}\left( \text{Cu} \right)&=63.55\text{ g mol}^{-1}\\ \text{M}\left( \text{S} \right)&=32.07\text{ g mol}^{-1}\\ \text{M}\left( \text{O} \right)&=16.00\text{ g mol}^{-1}\\ \text{M}\left( \text{H} \right)&=1.01\text{ g mol}^{-1}\end{align}\)

Molar mass (g mol−1) Amount in moles (mol)
A 249.72 0.03
B 250 0.0314
C 250 0.03
D 249.72 0.0314

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
The number of significant figures in a result is based on the significant figures given in the data.

When adding or subtracting, the final answer should be given to the least number of decimal places. Since all the molar masses provided were given to two decimal places, the molar mass for the compound should be reported to two decimal places.

When multiplying or dividing the final answer is given to the least number of significant figures. When calculating the amount, in mol, of CuSO4・5H2O, the mass of 7.84 g is reported to 3 significant figures, and the molar mass used is reported to 5 significant figures. This implies that the amount, in mol, for the compound should be reported to three significant figures. 

The calculation is as follows:

n(CuSO4 5H2O) = 7.84 g / 249.72 g mol-1 = 0.0314 mol (to three significant figures).

section_title: Uncertainties and errors in measurement and results

question_html:
A student collected data using the water displacement method to determine the density of aluminium. The density of aluminium was found to be 2.70 g cm−3.

Deduce the absolute uncertainty to two decimal places in the density of aluminium using the following data.

Measurement Absolute uncertainty
Mass (g) \(15.50\) \(±0.01\)
Initial volume (cm3) \(15.73\) \(±0.05\)
Final volume (cm3) \(21.57\) \(±0.05\)

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Since density is \(d=\frac{m}{V}\), in order to calculate density measurements with different units are being used. This means that the absolute uncertainties must first be converted to percentage uncertainties which will then be added together.

Measurement Absolute uncertainty Percentage uncertainty
Mass (g) \(15.50 \) \(± 0.01\) \(\dfrac{0.01}{15.50}\times 100\% =0.0645\%\)
Initial volume (cm3) \(15.73 \) \(± 0.05 \)
Final volume (cm3) \(21.57\) \(± 0.05 \)
Volume (cm3) \(5.84\) \(0.05 +0.05 = 0.10\) \(\dfrac{0.10}{5.84}\times 100\%=1.71\% \)
Density (g cm-3) \( d=\dfrac{m}{V}\\ d=\dfrac{7.75}{18.60-15.73}\\ d=2.70 \)

\(\dfrac{1.77%}{100%}\times 2.70=0.0478 \)

\( ±0.05 \)

 \(0.0645\% + 1.71\%=1.77\% \)

Therefore the density of aluminium is 2.70 ± 0.05 g cm−3. Note that the reported value and absolute uncertainty should be stated to the same number of decimal places.

section_title: Uncertainties and errors in measurement and results

question_html: A student believes there is an error with the calibration of a digital balance they are using. Which of the following methods would reduce the error from this balance?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Taking the difference between the mass of the container and reagent and the mass of the container on its own.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A calibration error is an example of a systematic error. Systematic errors result in a consistently higher or lower measurement than the true value. By taking a difference between readings, this systematic error is eliminated as the error will be the same for both readings and the difference will be only from the mass of the reagent.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Repeating the measurement multiple times and taking an average.
Ensuring there is no breeze around the balance during time of use.

section_title: Uncertainties and errors in measurement and results

question_html:
Which conditions are needed to obtain a high yield of ethanal when ethanol is oxidized using acidified potassium dichromate(VI), K2Cr2O7 (aq)?

I.   React with an excess of ethanol
II.  Reaction mixture heated under reflux
III. Distillation of product during the addition of the oxidizing agent

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Potassium dichromate(VI) is a good oxidizing agent for alcohols when acidified. The addition of an acid is required for potassium dichromate to act as an effective oxidizing agent.

\(\qquad\qquad\rm{Cr_2O{_7}^{2−}(aq) + 14H^+(aq) + 6e^− → 2Cr^{3+}(aq) + 7H_2O(l)}\)

Since ethanol is a primary alcohol, it can be oxidized to form ethanal and ethanoic acid. Partial oxidation is required to form the aldehyde, ethanal. If oxidized in the presence of excess alcohol, the aldehyde product can be removed as it forms through distillation. This process heats the mixture and separates compounds based on their boiling points. Since ethanal has a lower boiling point than ethanol or ethanoic acid, the reaction mixture can be heated above the boiling point of ethanol but below the boiling points of ethanol or ethanoic acid, collecting ethanal as the distillate.

If the reaction mixture is heated under reflux with excess oxidizing agent, the conditions will favour complete oxidation, forming ethanoic acid as the dominant product.

question_html:
Which of the following is the correctly balanced chemical equation for the oxidation of propan-2-ol in the presence of acidified potassium dichromate?

Half-equation for the reduction of the dichromate ion:

\(\qquad\qquad \rm{Cr_2O{_7}^{2−}(aq) + 14H^+(aq) + 6e^− → 2Cr^{3+}(aq) + 7H_2O(l)}\)

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
It is often helpful to separate out the oxidation and reduction half equations and then combine to form the overall reaction.

               Oxidation: \(\rm{CH_3CH(OH)CH_3 → CH_3COCH_3 + 2H^+ + 2e^{−}}\)
               Reduction: \(\rm{Cr_2O{_7}^{2−} + 14H^+ + 6e^− → 2Cr^{3+} + 7H_2O}\)

Balancing for charge, the overall equation becomes:

\(\qquad\qquad\rm{3CH_3CH(OH)CH_3 + Cr_2O{_7}^{2−} + 8H^+ → 3CH_3COCH_3 + 2Cr^{3+}+ 7H_2O}\)

question_html: Identify the monomer to the following polymer:

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Looking at the repeating unit of the polymer, there are four carbon atoms, this would indicate that the monomer also contains four carbon atoms, therefore either but-1-ene or but-2-ene are the options.

Addition polymerization involves one of the bonds breaking in the double bond of an alkene monomer in order for monomers to add together, forming the repeating unit. Looking at where repeating units are linking, this would indicate that the double bond of the monomer would be found between the two central carbon atoms. Therefore the monomer is but-2-ene, indicating that the double bond is in the position of the second carbon atom.

question_html: Identify the most likely product for the reaction of Br2 with benzene using an aluminum bromide catalyst.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Due to the stability provided by delocalized electrons in benzene, the molecule is highly unlikely to undergo addition reactions breaking the stability from the loss of one of the double bonds in the structure. A structure missing one of the double bonds from the benzene reactant is unlikely due to the loss of stability. 

Benzene can, however, undergo electrophilic substitution reactions to produce bromobenzene and hydrogen bromide as products. In an electrophilic substitution reaction, one hydrogen atom is replaced with an electrophile (in this case one bromine atom).  It is unlikely to substitute two hydrogen atoms with two bromine atoms, as the electrophile is a positively charged species. Br2 in the presence of the AlBr3 catalyst is capable of forming a Br+ electrophile, indicating that only one bromine atom would substitute a hydrogen atom.

question_html:
Which of the following provides an explanation as to why halogenoalkanes undergo substitution reactions?

I.   Halogenoalkanes contain an electron-rich carbon atom.
II.  Nucleophiles are attracted to an electron-deficient carbon atom in the halogenoalkane molecule
III. Halogenoalkanes have a polar carbon–halogen bond.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Halogenoalkanes are alkanes that contain a halogen atom bonded to the carbon skeleton of the molecule. Since halogens are quite electronegative elements, the halogen exerts a stronger pull on the shared electrons creating a polar carbon–halogen bond. This polarity is responsible for the reactivity of halogenoalkanes. As the halogen attracts the shared electron pair towards itself, it leaves the carbon electron deficient (not electron rich) and then susceptible to nucleophilic attack.

question_html: Which of the following organic molecules will not react with Cl2 in the dark?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
CH3CH2CH3  is an alkane, whereas CH2CH2, CH2CHCH2CH3 and CH3CHCHCH3 are all alkenes.

Alkanes can undergo reaction with a halogen via the free radical mechanism; however, initiation of this reaction is required using UV light to form.

Alkenes on the other hand are more reactive than alkanes and undergo addition reactions.

question_html:
Which of the following combinations is not correct for the classification of organic molecules?

Class Functional group
A ester ester 
B arenes amino
C carboxylic acid carboxyl
D alcohol hydroxyl

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Arenes are organic molecules that contain a benzene ring as a part of the molecule. The functional group that contains the benzene ring is known as a phenyl ring, or the phenyl functional group.

The amino functional group is the –NH2 part of an amine.

question_html:
Which of the following statements correctly describes a functional group?

I.   Part of a molecule responsible for the reactivity of an organic compound.
II.  Part of a molecule responsible for the solubility of an organic compound in various solvents.
III. Part of a molecule responsible for the boiling point of an organic compound.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
A functional group is the part of an organic compound that gives it its characteristic properties.

For example, in a carboxylic acid, the carboxyl functional group is the part of the molecule that can react with a hydroxyl group of an alcohol to form an ester. The carboxyl functional group is the reactive part of the molecule, where the alkyl chain remains intact. This indicates that the functional group is responsible for the reactivity of the compound.

Similarly, the carboxyl group of a carboxylic acid, is capable of hydrogen bonding to neighbouring molecules; this allows solubility of carboxylic acids in solvents that are capable of hydrogen bonding, such as water. This indicates that the functional group gives rise to the solubility in different solvents depending on the polarity of the solute and solvent.

A functional group can also determine the boiling point of an organic compound because it determines the type of intermolecular forces that exist between molecules of the compound.

question_html:
Amino acids are the individual units that make up proteins. Essential amino acids are ones that cannot be made by the body and must come from the diet instead. Lysine is one of these essential amino acids. The structure of lysine is shown below.

Identify the functional group(s) present in lysine.

I.   Amine
II.  Carboxyl
III. Carboxamide

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
In the structure of lysine, it can be observed that there are two –NH2 and one –COOH functional groups. The –COOH functional group is part of the carboxylic acid family and contains the carboxyl functional group. The –NH2 functional group is a part of the amine family and contains the amino or amine functional group.

It is easy to confuse the amine and carboxamide functional groups. The carboxamide functional group looks like –CONH2 where a carbonyl is immediately adjacent to the amine functional group. These adjacent functional groups make up the carboxamide functional group.

question_html:
Identify which pair of compounds belong to the same homologous series.

W propanal
X

Y

Z butan-2-ol

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
A homologous series is a series of compounds of the same family, with the same general formula, which differ from each other by a common structural unit. A homologous series has the same functional group.

W is a part of the aldehyde family, containing an aldehyde functional group (carbonyl located at the end of the molecule),  with the general formula CnH2n+1CHO.

X is a part of the alcohol family, containing a hydroxyl functional group, with the general formula CnH2n+1OH.

Y is part of the ketone family, containing a ketone functional group (carbonyl located in the middle of the molecule), with the general formula CnH2n+1COCxH2x+1.

Z is a part of the alcohol family, containing a hydroxyl functional group, with the general formula CnH2n+1OH.

Therefore X and Z are a part of the same homologous

question_html: Rank the following lab equipment by increasing precision.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The uncertainty of the measurement decreases from beaker to graduated cylinder to volumetric flask.

question_html:
You are performing a reaction involving the collection of a gas at SATP (298 K and 100 kPa). If 5.00 g of magnesium is added to 100.0 cm3 of 0.100 mol dm−3 HCl, determine the volume of hydrogen gas that will be collected at SATP.

\(\qquad\qquad\rm{Mg(s) + 2HCl(aq) → MgCl_2(aq) + H_2(g)}\)

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
When the quantities of both reagents are given, you must determine which are the limiting and excess reagents.

The first step is to convert each quantity to an amount in mol,

               Mg:\( \dfrac{\text{5.00 g}}{\text{24.31 g mol}^{−1}} = \text{0.206 mol Mg}\)

               HCl: \(\left(\dfrac{\text{100.0 cm}^3}{1000}\right) × 0.100\text{ mol dm}^{−3} = 0.0100\text{ mol HCl}\)

Then find the limiting reactant, divide each amount (in mol) by its coefficient in the balanced equation:

               Mg: \(\dfrac{0.206\text{ mol Mg}}{1} = 0.206\text{ mol}\)

               HCl: \(\dfrac{\text{0.0100 mol HCl}}{2} = 0.00500\text{ mol}\)

The lowest value is the limiting reactant, in this case, the HCl. The highest value is the excess reactant, in this case the Mg.

Use the limiting reactant to determine the quantity of product made using the mole ratio and the conditions at SATP using the ideal gas law equation.

\(\qquad\qquad\dfrac{\text{0.0100 mol HCl × (1 mol H}_2)}{\text{2 mol HCl}} = 0.00500\text{ mol H}_2\)


\(\qquad\qquad\begin{align}\text{PV}& = \text{n RT}\\ \text{V}& = \dfrac{\text{(0.00500 mol H}_2\text{)(8.31)(298 K)}}{\text{(100000 Pa)}}\\ \text{V}& = 0.000124\text{ m}^3\end{align}\)

Convert from m3 to dm3 by multiplying by 1000:

0.000124 × 1000 = 0.124 dm3

question_html: A dilute solution of sodium chloride was prepared with a concentration of 50.0 ppm. Convert this concentration to a molar concentration in mol dm−3.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Recall that 1 ppm = 1 mg dm−3. Therefore,

\(\qquad\qquad \text{50.0 ppm = 50.0 mg dm}^{−3}\)

Convert the 50.0 mg NaCl to an amount in mol,

\(\qquad\qquad\begin{align}\dfrac{\text{50.0 mg}}{1000} &= \text{0.0500 g}\\ \dfrac{\text{0.0500 g}}{\text{58.44 g mol}^{−1}} &= \text{0.000855 mol}\end{align}\)

The total volume of the solution is 1 dm3, therefore, the molar concentration is
0.000855 mol dm−3.

question_html:
Which of the following changes to a system at equilibrium will result in no change to the magnitude of the equilibrium constant, Kc, for the Contact Process as shown in the equation below?

\(\qquad\qquad\rm{2SO_2\,(g) + O_2\,(g) ⇌ 2 SO_3\,(g)\quadΔH= -197\;kJ\;mol^{−1}}\)

I.   An increase in the concentration of SO2 

II.  A decrease in temperature

III. An increase in temperature

IV. An increase in pressure

V.  Addition of a catalyst

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: According to Le Chatelier’s Principle, a change in concentration will shift the position of equilibrium to use up the excess substance, but the value of Kc will remain unchanged as equilibrium is re-established. Changes in temperature will always affect the magnitude of Kc. A change in pressure is similar to a change in concentration, in that there will be a shift in the position of equilibrium, but the ratio of products : reactants remains the same, making Kc unaffected. The addition of a catalyst affects both the forward and reverse reactions equally, so Kc is also unaffected.

question_html:
Identify which of the following statement(s) is/are correct regarding a system at equilibrium.

I.   The system is closed.

II.  The concentrations of reactant(s) and product(s) are equal.

III. The rates of the forward and reverse reactions are equal.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
For a system at equilibrium, the system must be closed as the concentration of all species must remain the same. With an open system, there could be the loss of one of the substances in the reaction, especially for gases.

At equilibrium, the concentrations of reactants and products remain constant, although both forward and reverse reactions are still occurring. The concentration of the reactant(s) may be less, equal or greater than the concentration of the product(s), just depending on the position of equilibrium.

The rates of the forward and reverse reactions are equal at equilibrium, making this the defining characteristic of a system at equilibrium.

question_html:
Which of the following change(s) for a catalysed reaction?

I.   The activation energy for the forward reaction only.

II.  The activation energy for both the forward and reverse reactions.

III. The enthalpy change for both the forward and reverse reaction.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A catalyst decreases the activation energy for both the forward and reverse reactions (by providing an alternative reaction pathway with a lower activation energy), but does not affect the enthalpy of either reaction.

section_title: Collision theory and rates of reaction

question_html:
An experiment was conducted for the reaction below between excess calcium carbonate and
100.0 cm3 of hydrochloric acid:

CaCO3(s) + 2HCl (aq) → 2CaCl2(aq) + H2O(l) + CO2(g)

Which factor(s) would cause a greater decrease in mass?

I.   Conducting the reaction at a higher temperature

II.  Using the same volume of HCl but with a higher concentration

III. Sealing the flask

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
When using a change in mass to measure the rate of reaction involving the production of a gas, the mass will decrease if the reaction is conducted in an open container, so sealing the flask and trapping the gas inside would result in no mass changes.

Conducting the reaction at a higher temperature will result in the same mass change, but more rapidly.

Using a high concentration and same volume of HCl, the limiting reagent, will cause a greater quantity of carbon dioxide to be produced, therefore a greater mass change will be observed.

section_title: Collision theory and rates of reaction

question_html: How will the presence of a catalyst affect the Maxwell Boltzmann distribution curve below?

MCQ_set.answer_html: The shape of the curve remains the same, but the activation energy shifts to the left, increasing the fraction of particles that have energy equal to, or greater, than the activation energy.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
The presence of a catalyst provides an alternate reaction pathway with a lower activation energy, shifting the level of Ea on the graph to the left. The shape of the curve remains the same, since the catalyst does not have an effect on the amount of kinetic energy present in the reacting particles.

As shown in the diagram below, the newly shaded area shows a greater number of particles that have energy equal, or greater to, the activation energy of the catalysed reaction, increasing the proportion of effective collisions and the rate.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The shape of the curve shifts to the right, increasing the fraction of particles that have energy equal to, or greater, than the activation energy.

The shape of the curve remains the same, but the level of activation energy shifts to the right, increasing the fraction of particles that have energy equal to, or greater, than the activation energy.
The shape of the curve shifts to the left, increasing the fraction of particles that have energy equal to, or greater, than the activation energy.

section_title: Collision theory and rates of reaction

question_html: How is the rate of reaction affected by an increase in temperature compared with an increase in concentration?

MCQ_set.answer_html: An increase in temperature increases both the frequency of collisions and the average kinetic energy of the particles, whereas an increase in concentration only increases the frequency of collisions.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: An increase in temperature causes an increase in the average kinetic energy of the particles and an increase in the frequency of collisions between reactant particles. An increase in concentration causes more frequent collisions, as the particles are closer together, but does not increase the average kinetic energy of the particles.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Increases in temperature and concentration both increase the frequency of collisions and the average kinetic energy of the particles.
An increase in concentration increases both the frequency of collisions and the average kinetic energy of the particles, whereas an increase in temperature only increases the frequency of collisions.

An increase in temperature changes the activation energy of the reaction, which increases the fraction of effective collisions, whereas an increase in concentration only increases the frequency of collisions.

section_title: Collision theory and rates of reaction

question_html:
Examine the graph below for an experiment involving the collection of carbon dioxide gas over time according to the reaction equation below.

\(\qquad\qquad\rm{Na_2CO_3(aq) + 2HCl(aq) → 2NaCl(aq) + H_2O(l) + CO_2(g)}\)

Trials I and II were for the same reaction, but under different conditions.

Identify the correct statement below.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Trial I was conducted with a higher concentration of acid but with the same amount of the limiting reactant.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Trial I has a greater initial rate of reaction compared with Trial II (because of the higher concentration of acid), but the average rates of both experiments are the same, indicating that the same quantity of gas had been produced over time. Therefore, both trials must have had the same quantity of the limiting reagent.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Trial I was conducted with a lower concentration of acid and the same amount of the limiting reagent compared with Trial II.
Trial I was conducted with a higher concentration of acid and a greater amount of the limiting reagent compared with Trial II.
Trial I was conducted with the same concentration of acid and a greater amount of the limiting reagent compared with Trial II.

section_title: Collision theory and rates of reaction

question_html:
The following Maxwell-Boltzmann distribution curve is for a variety of different gases at the same temperature.

Identify the correct statement about this graph.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The graph shows that, as the molar mass of the gas increases, the average molecular speed decreases. All of these gases have the same amount of kinetic energy.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: At the same temperature, all particles have the same amount of kinetic energy, but the speed of the particles will vary with mass. Gas particles with smaller masses will have a greater speed and particles with a larger mass will have a lower speed.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The graph shows that, as the molar mass of the gas decreases, the average molecular speed decreases. All of these gases have the same amount of kinetic energy.
The graph shows that, as the molar mass of the gas increases, the average molecular speed decreases. These gases do not have the same amount of kinetic energy.
The graph shows that, as the molar mass of the gas decreases, the average molecular speed decreases. These gases do not have the same amount of kinetic energy.

section_title: Collision theory and rates of reaction

question_html:
Complete the following sentence.

The activation energy of a reaction…

MCQ_set.answer_html: …is equal to the difference in the potential energy of the reactants and the transition state.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The activation energy is the difference in potential energy of the reactants to the transition state, the highest peak, of a chemical reaction. The transition state, sometimes referred to as an activated complex, is where the bonds are partially broken and partially formed. If a collision does not have this minimum amount of potential energy, the reaction cannot proceed and the collision does not result in a successful reaction.

MCQ_set.answer_html: …is equal to the difference in the potential energy of the reactants and products.
…is equal to the difference in the potential energy of the products and the transition state.
…is equal to the difference in the kinetic energy of the reactants and the transition state.

section_title: Collision theory and rates of reaction

question_html:
The combustion of ethane occurs by the following reaction equation:

\(\qquad\mathrm{C_2H_6\,(g) + \tfrac{7}{2} O_2\,(g) → 2 CO_2\,(g) + 3 H_2O\,(l)\quadΔH = ?}\)

You have the following formation equations for which Hess’s Law may be used to calculate the enthalpy of combustion for ethane.

\(\qquad\qquad\begin{align}\rm{2 C\,(s) + 3 H_2\,(g)}\;&\rm{ → C_2H_6\,(g)\quadΔH = -84.0\;kJ\;mol^{−1}}\\ \rm{C\,(s) + O_2\,(g)}\;&\rm{→ CO_2\,(g)\quadΔH = -393.5\;kJ\;mol^{−1}}​​​​​​​\\ \rm{H_2\,(g) + \tfrac{1}{2} O_2\,(g)}\;&\rm{→ H_2O\,(g)\quadΔH = -241.8\;kJ\;mol}^{−1}\end{align}\)

Identify the correct statement regarding these three equations.

MCQ_set.answer_html: This set of equations is not suitable. The formation equation for water is in the gaseous state, whereas the combustion equation has water in the liquid state.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The equations used for Hess’s Law must combine to have the same mole ratios for all of the same reactants and products, which means that the correct states of matter must also be followed.

MCQ_set.answer_html: This set of equations is not suitable. The three equations do not balance correctly to make the combustion reaction.
This set of equations is not suitable. There is no formation equation for oxygen.
These three equations are suitable. They can form the target equation correctly.

question_html:
Identify the missing reaction required to solve for the enthalpy of the unknown equation below using Hess’s Law:

\(\qquad\qquad\mathrm{2 A + B}\;\mathrm{→ A_2B \quadΔH} = x-y \)

Given:

\(\qquad\qquad\mathrm{2 A + C → A_2C\quadΔH} = x\)

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
The unknown, target equation must be the sum of the individual, known equations.

The given equation:

\(\qquad\qquad\mathrm{2 A + C → A_2C\quadΔH} = x\)

requires the reactant C to be cancelled and product A2C to also be cancelled. There must also be a reactant B added and product A2B added to make the target equation.

The only equation that satisfies these requirements is:

\(\qquad\qquad\mathrm{A_2B + C → A_2C + B\quadΔH} = y\)

However, this reaction must be reversed in order to cancel out the reactants and products correctly.

The missing known equation is therefore:

\(\qquad\qquad\mathrm{A_2C + B → A_2B + C\quadΔH} = -y\)

These two equations now add to make the target equation

\(\qquad\qquad\begin{align}\mathrm{2 A + C}\;&\mathrm{ → A_2C \quadΔH} = x\\ \mathrm{A_2C + B}\;&\mathrm{ → A_2B + C \quadΔH} = -y\\ \mathrm{2 A + B}\;&\mathrm{→ A_2B \quadΔH} = x-y\end{align}\)

question_html: A sample of a hydrocarbon was found to contain 62.02% carbon, 10.43% hydrogen and the remainder oxygen by mass. Determine the empirical formula for this hydrocarbon.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Using the percentage composition of each element in the compound, the percentage of oxygen can then be calculated as:

\(\qquad\qquad \text{100% – 62.02% – 10.43% = 27.55% O}\)

Assume a 100 g sample for each element to convert % to g:

\(\qquad\qquad \text{62.02% C = 62.02 g C}\)

\(\qquad\qquad\text{10.43% H = 10.43 g H}\)

\(\qquad\qquad\text{27.55% O = 27.55 g O}\)

Now convert each mass into an amount in mol by dividing by the molar mass of each element:

\(\qquad\qquad \dfrac{62.02\text{ g C}}{12.01\text{ g mol}^{-1}} = \text{5.164 mol C}\)

\(\qquad\qquad\dfrac{10.43\text{ g H}}{1.01\text{ g mol}^{-1}} = \text{10.33 mol H}\)

\(\qquad\qquad\dfrac{27.55\text{ g O}}{16.00\text{ g mol}^{-1}} = \text{1.722 mol O}\)

If the molar ratio of elements in the compound is not clear, divide all values by the lowest amount in mol.

\(\qquad\qquad\dfrac{5.164\text{ mol C}}{1.722\text{ mol}} = \text{2.999 mol C}\)

\(\qquad\qquad\dfrac{10.33\text{ mol H}}{1.722\text{ mol}} = \text{5.999 mol H}\)

\(\qquad\qquad\dfrac{1.722\text{ mol O}}{1.722\text{ mol}} = \text{1.000 mol O}\)

Round each to a whole number, giving the empirical formula of C3H6O.

question_html: A compound is found to contain 24.0 g carbon, 4.00 mol hydrogen and 1.204 × 1024 atoms of oxygen. What is the empirical formula of this compound?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
The molecular formula can be calculated using the data from the question:

\(\qquad\qquad \dfrac{\text{24.0 g carbon}}{ \text{12.01 g mol}^{-1}} = \text{2.00 mol C}\)

\(\qquad\qquad \text{4.00 mol H}\)

\(\qquad\qquad \dfrac{1.204 × 10^{24}\text{ atoms of oxygen}} {6.02 × 10^{23}\text{ atoms mol}^{-1}} = \text{2.00 mol O}\)

The molecular formula is therefore C2H4O2. Since the empirical formula is the simplest ratio of atoms in the compound, the empirical formula is therefore CH2O.

question_html:
Identify the statement(s) below that is/are not correct.

I.   Compounds contain two or more different elements bonded together.

II.  Mixtures contain two or more different elements bonded together.

III. Mixtures can contain two or more different elements or compounds mixed together.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Compounds contain two or more elements bonded together, for example hydrogen and oxygen forming water, H2O. Mixtures contain two or more substances that are mixed together, but not chemically bonded, and those substances can be either elements or compounds. For example, alloys are mixtures of two or more metals, which are elements, while air contains a mixture of various gases, such as oxygen (element), carbon dioxide (compound), water (compound) and many other substances.

question_html: Which changes of state do not involve the release of energy (are not exothermic)?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Both sublimation and evaporation are endothermic processes as energy is absorbed as a substance changes from a solid to a gas or from a liquid to a gas. Deposition, condensation and freezing all involve the release of energy (are exothermic) as a substance changes from gas to solid, gas to liquid or liquid to solid, respectively.

question_html:
Which of the following reactions would occur for the electrolysis of molten magnesium chloride?

I.   Cathode: \(\rm Mg^{2+}(l) + 2e^− → Mg(l)\)

II.  Anode: \(\rm Cl^−(l) → \tfrac{1}{2}Cl_2(g) + e^−\)

III. Overall: \(\rm Mg^{2+}(l) + Cl^−(l)→ Mg(l) + \tfrac{1}{2}Cl_2(g)\)

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
While magnesium chloride is in its molten form, the individual ions are free to move. The Mg2+ ion will be attracted to the negative electrode (cathode) where reduction will occur and the Cl− ion will be attracted to the positive electrode (anode) where oxidation will occur. I and II both represent properly balanced half-reactions to show these processes occurring. 

The overall equation is balanced for mass but not charge. Since two electrons are transferred in the reduction half-reaction and one electron in the oxidation half reaction, the properly balanced overall equation would be:

\(\qquad\qquad\rm ​​​​​​​Mg^{2+}(l) + 2Cl^− (l)→ Mg(l) + Cl_2(g)\)

question_html:
Which of the following combinations correctly describes how the mass of the anode and cathode change over time in a voltaic cell and electrolytic cell used for electroplating?

Voltaic cell Electrolytic cell
Anode Cathode Anode Cathode
A increases decreases increases decreases
B increases decreases decreases increases
C decreases increases increases decreases
D decreases increases decreases increases

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
In both a voltaic cell and an electrolytic cell, the anode is the site of oxidation whereas the cathode is the site of reduction. The mass of the electrode for the site of oxidation (anode) will always decrease, whereas the mass of the electrode for the side of reduction (cathode) will always increase.

(Note that during electrolysis of molten electrolytes, when using inert electrodes (graphite or platinum) the mass of the electrodes is dependent on the substance formed at the surface. If a gas is formed at the surface, the mass of the electrode would be assumed to be unchanged.)

question_html: For the following voltaic cell, identify the correct cell diagram convention.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Comparing nickel and lead on the activity series (section 25 in the IB chemistry data booklet), it is observed that nickel is placed higher on the series than lead, meaning that nickel will have a stronger tendency to undergo oxidation than lead.

This would make the nickel electrode the anode, or site of oxidation. This would make the lead electrode the cathode, or site of reduction.

The cell diagram convention places the anode on the left and the cathode on the right. The aqueous solutions containing the metal ions are separated by a boundary line and the two half cells are separated by a double vertical line indicating a salt bridge.

Metal A (anode) | aqueous solution containing positive A ions || aqueous solution containing positive B ions | Metal B (cathode)

\(\qquad\qquad\rm Ni(s) \,| \,Ni^{2+}(aq)\, ||\, Pb^{2+}(aq) \,|\, Pb(s)\)

question_html:
A voltaic cell consists of two separate half-cells connected by an external circuit and salt bridge. Which of the following is correct for a voltaic cell?

I.   Oxidation and reduction reactions will release energy in the form of electrical energy instead
      of thermal energy.

II.  Oxidation and reduction reactions are spontaneous.

III. Electrical energy can be converted to chemical energy.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Voltaic cells convert energy from spontaneous, exothermic chemical processes to electrical energy. If the half-reactions were contained within one reaction vessel, oxidation and reduction reactions would occur spontaneously, releasing their chemical energy as thermal energy. By physically separating the half-reactions (but still connecting using a wire and salt bridge), the energy generated from the spontaneous reaction can be converted to electrical energy instead.

question_html:
Which of the following combinations of potassium halides and halogens result in a reaction?

Cl2(aq) Br2(aq) I2(aq)
KCl(aq) A B
KBr(aq) C D

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
A: \(\rm KCl(aq) + Br_2(aq) → No\;reaction\)

Chlorine is a stronger oxidising agent than bromine (halogens higher up in group 17 are stronger oxidising agents), meaning that it is the element more likely to reduce. Since chlorine is already in its reduced form in KCl, it will not transfer that extra electron to the bromine.

B: \(\rm KCl(aq) + I_2(aq) → No\;reaction\)

Chlorine is a stronger oxidising agent than iodine, meaning that it is the element more likely to reduce. Since chlorine is already in its reduced form in KCl, it will not transfer that extra electron to the iodine.

C: \(\rm 2KBr(aq) + Cl_2(aq) → 2KCl(aq) + Br_2(aq)\)

Since chlorine is a stronger oxidising agent than bromine, each bromide ion will transfer an electron to each chlorine atom forming the chloride ions in the process.

D: \(\rm KBr(aq)+ I_2(aq) → No\;reaction\)

Bromine is a stronger oxidising agent than iodine, meaning that it is the element more likely to reduce. Since bromine is already in its reduced form in KBr, it will not transfer that extra electron to the iodine.

question_html:
Ozone (O3) is known as a strong oxidising agent that can kill microbial pathogens. In an acidic solution, ozone can oxidise the iodide ion to the iodate ion (IO3−), forming oxygen gas in the process.

Deduce the number of electrons transferred in this process.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
The information above tells us the iodide ion (I−) oxidises to form the IO3− ion. By placing I− on the reactant side, IO3− on the product side and following the steps for balancing redox reactions we can find:

Oxidation half-reaction:

\(\qquad\qquad\rm I^−(aq) + 3H_2O(l) → IO_3{^−}(aq) + 6H^+(aq) + 6e^−\)

The information above tells us that ozone (O3) reacts to form oxygen gas (O2). By placing O3 on the reactant side, O2 on the product side and following the steps for balancing redox reactions we can find:

Reduction half-reaction:

\(\qquad\qquad\rm O_3(g) + 2H^+(aq) + 2e^− → O_2(g) + H_2O(l)\)

In order to combine to create the overall reaction the two half-equations need to be balanced for electrons. The reduction half-reaction should be multiplied by 3 in order for the same number of electrons to be transferred.

Overall:

\(\qquad\qquad\rm I^−(aq) + 3O_3(g) → IO_3{^−}(aq) + 3O_2(g)\)

(6 electrons transferred in the process).

question_html:
Using the following reactions, identify the strongest reducing agent. 

\(\rm [1]\;Y + X^+ → Y^+ + X\)

\(\rm[2]\;X + Z^+ → X^+ + Z\)

\(\rm[3]\;W^+ + Z → no\;reaction\)

\(\rm[4]\;X + W^+ → X^+ + W\)

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
To identify the strongest reducing agent, the species that is most likely to oxidise (higher up on the activity series) needs to be deduced.

In reaction [1] it can be observed that Y is more likely to oxidise than X.

In reaction [2] it can be observed that X is more reactive than Z.

In reaction [3], since there is no reaction, this would indicate that W is more reactive than Z.

In reaction [4] it can be observed that X is more reactive than W.

Ranking the elements in order of reactivity:

\(\qquad\qquad \rm Y > X > W > Z\)

This would indicate that Y is the strongest reducing agent (the most likely to oxidise).

question_html:
Identify the oxidising and reducing agents in the following reaction:

\(\qquad\qquad\rm Cl_2(g) + H_2O(l) → HCl(aq) + HClO(aq)\)

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Assigning oxidation states to each element in each compound:

Cl2
Cl: 0

H2O
H: +1
O: −2

HCl
H: +1
Cl: −1

HClO (note that O is more electronegative than Cl)
H: +1
Cl: +1
O: −2

It is apparent that the only element changing oxidation numbers is Cl. Chlorine decreases in oxidation states as it starts as Cl2 and forms HCl (reduction) and also chlorine increases in oxidation number as it starts as Cl2 and forms HClO (oxidation). This is an example of a disproportionation reaction.

This would indicate that Cl2 is acting as both the oxidising and reducing agent in this redox reaction.

question_html: The definitions of oxidation and reduction have evolved over time. Which of the following would not be considered an aspect of oxidation?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Oxidation can be considered in terms of gain of oxygen atoms, loss of hydrogen atoms, loss of electrons or an increase in oxidation number.

Reduction can be considered in terms of loss of oxygen atoms, gain of hydrogen atoms, gain of electrons or a decrease in oxidation number.

question_html:
Which of the following are the correct oxidation states for sodium and hydrogen in sodium hydride?

Na H
A \(-1\) \(+1\)
B \(+1\) \(-1\)
C \(0\) \(+1\)
D \(+1\) \(0\)

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Sodium hydride, NaH, is an example where hydrogen gains an electron instead of losing one. This is because in this particular compound, hydrogen is interacting with an element more electropositive than itself. This indicates that sodium would lose one electron, which hydrogen would gain, making the oxidation state of sodium +1 and the oxidation state of hydrogen −1.

question_html:
Which of the following are the correct oxidation states for hydrogen and oxygen in a hydrogen peroxide, H2O2, molecule?

H O
A \(+1\) \(-1\)
B \(+2\) \(-2\)
C \(+1\) \(-2\)
D \(+2\) \(-1\)

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Hydrogen peroxide has the formula H2O2. Since the molecule overall is neutral, the sum of the oxidation states must be zero. The tricky part here is deciding whether to assign the oxidation state of hydrogen or oxygen first.

If oxygen is assigned the oxidation state of −2 first then

\(\qquad\qquad2\left( \text{H} \right)+2\left( -2 \right) = 0\)

\(\qquad\qquad2\left( +2 \right)+2\left( -2 \right) = 0\)

This would mean that the oxidation state of hydrogen would have to be +2, indicating that each hydrogen has lost two electrons. But this is not possible, since each hydrogen atom only contains one electron.

If hydrogen is assigned the oxidation state of +1 first then

\(\qquad\qquad2\left( +1 \right)+2\left( \text{O} \right)\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ }=0\)

\(\qquad\qquad2\left( +1 \right)+2\left( -1 \right)\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ }=0\)

This would mean that the oxidation state of oxygen would have to be −1 rather than −2.

question_html: You have four different samples of compounds that are liquids at room temperature: BCl3, CCl4, NCl3 and OCl2. Identify which correct pairs of molecules are capable of forming a solution.

MCQ_set.answer_html: BCl3 with CCl4 and NCl3 with OCl2
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Solubility is determined by the polarity of the molecule. Molecules that are polar are capable of forming solutions with other polar molecules and non-polar with non-polar. BCl3 and CCl4 are both non-polar whereas NCl3 and OCl2 are both polar molecules.

MCQ_set.answer_html: BCl3 with NCl3 and CCl4 with OCl2
BCl3 with OCl2 and NCl3 with CCl4
All of these molecules are capable of forming a solution.

question_html: Identify the correct statement regarding London dispersion forces and dipole–dipole forces.

MCQ_set.answer_html: London dispersion forces involve both temporary and induced dipoles, whereas dipole–dipole forces involve a permanent dipole.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: London dispersion forces are a weak intermolecular force that occurs in all molecules due to the presence of temporary and induced dipoles. Dipole–dipole forces occur only in polar molecules where there is a permanent dipole.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Dipole–dipole forces involve both temporary and induced dipoles, whereas London dispersion forces involve a permanent dipole.
London dispersion forces involve both temporary and permanent dipoles, whereas dipole–dipole forces involve an induced dipole.
London dispersion forces involve a temporary dipole, whereas dipole–dipole forces involve both induced and permanent dipoles.

question_html:
Identify why the use of bond enthalpy values would not be valid for the combustion of benzene, as shown in the following reaction equation: 

\(\qquad\qquad\rm 2C_6H_6(l) + 15O_2(g) → 12CO_2(g) + 6H_2O(l)\)

MCQ_set.answer_html: Benzene and water are both liquids and bond enthalpy values are measured for gaseous bonds.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Bond enthalpy is the amount of energy required to break, or form, one mole bonds in the gaseous state. Since benzene and water are both liquids in this reaction, the bond enthalpy values are not valid because they do not take into consideration any of the intermolecular forces between molecules that would have to be overcome during the chemical reaction that would influence the total enthalpy of the reaction.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Bond enthalpy values are averaged for many different molecules and are not accurate.
Bond enthalpy values differ from experimental enthalpy values.
The equation is not balanced to reflect one mole of benzene.

question_html: Identify which reaction is likely to have the greatest positive enthalpy change.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
The decomposition reactions involve the breaking of chemical bonds, which is an endothermic process and a positive enthalpy change. The reactions involving the synthesis of a single compound involve bond formation, which is exothermic and therefore a negative enthalpy change.

The decomposition of PCl5 involves breaking five P–Cl bonds, whereas the decomposition of PCl3 only involves breaking three P–Cl bonds, therefore requiring more energy.

question_html:
You have samples of the following compounds.

Identify the correct statement.

MCQ_set.answer_html: These compounds have the same m/z ratio for the molecular ion.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: All three molecules have the same molecular formula (and molar mass), so the m/z ratio for the molecular ion will be the same. Since these compounds have the same molecular formula and types of bonds, they will have the same IHD and similar IR and mass spectra. For their 1H NMR spectra, but-1-ene has four different hydrogen environments, and but-2-ene and 2-methylpropene have two different hydrogen environments. The IR spectrum will be similar for each, since there are the same types of bonds present. With one double bond per molecule, all three compounds have the same IHD, 1.

MCQ_set.answer_html: All of the compounds have three different hydrogen environments that contain protons.
These compounds can be easily distinguished using IR spectroscopy.

question_html: You have three unlabelled samples of the compounds below. Identify the best method to quickly and accurately determine the identity of these samples.

MCQ_set.answer_html: These compounds are best distinguished using 1H NMR spectroscopy.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
1H NMR is the best method to distinguish these compounds from each other, since each compound has a different number of hydrogen environments. Ethoxyethane has 2 environments, 1-methoxypropane has 4 and 2-methoxypropane has 3.

The IR spectra will be similar for each compound, since all contain the same types of bonds. IR spectroscopy alone would not be able to distinguish between these three molecules.

Mass spectrometry will also be similar for each compound, since the relative molecular masses are the same and many fragments will also be the same. The three molecules cannot be easily distinguished using this technique.

IHD is the same for all molecules, 0, as there is no unsaturation.

MCQ_set.answer_html: These compounds are best distinguished using IR spectroscopy.
These compounds are best distinguished using mass spectrometry.
These compounds are best distinguished by calculating the index of hydrogen deficiency (IHD).

question_html: Use the diagram below to help you identify the correct statement.

MCQ_set.answer_html: 1H NMR uses lower energy radiation than IR spectroscopy.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: 1H NMR uses radio waves, which are lower in energy compared to infrared waves. Mass spectrometry does not use electromagnetic radiation; it uses a beam of high energy electrons to produce ions.

MCQ_set.answer_html: 1H NMR uses higher energy radiation than IR spectroscopy.
1H NMR uses lower energy radiation than mass spectrometry.
Mass spectrometry uses lower energy radiation than IR spectroscopy.

question_html: Identify the correct statement regarding ethoxyethane.

MCQ_set.answer_html: 1H NMR spectrum will show two signals with a ratio of 2:3.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: When the carbon atoms in the molecule are symmetrical, their hydrogen atoms will be equivalent, showing up as one environment in the 1H NMR spectrum. For ethoxyethane, there is symmetry around the oxygen atom, so there are two environments with a ratio of 4:6 H atoms, therefore 2:3.

MCQ_set.answer_html: 1H NMR spectrum will show four signals with a ratio of 2:2:3:3.
1H NMR spectrum will show one signal.
1H NMR spectrum will show ten signals, one for each H atom.

question_html: A molecule has an index of hydrogen deficiency (IHD) of 3. Identify the incorrect statement.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The molecule might contain a benzene ring
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A C=O and a C=C bond each have an IHD of 1. A C≡C bond has an IHD of 2. A benzene ring has an IHD of 4 (3 for the three pairs of delocalised electrons and 1 for the fact that it is a ring structure).

MCQ_set.answer_html: The molecule might contain a C=O bond
The molecule might contain a C=C bond

question_html: What relationship can you draw about the dependent and independent variable in the graph below?

MCQ_set.answer_html: The data show that there is a weak positive correlation between these two variables.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The data overall show a positive correlation, but the relationship between the variables is weak, since there is no consistent increase. The graph below shows a strong, positive correlation.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The data show that there is a strong positive correlation between these two variables.
The data show that there is a weak negative correlation between these two variables.
There is a consistent systematic error in this experiment.

question_html: Identify the correct statement about this graph.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The line of best fit is incorrectly drawn as the relationship between the variables is not directly proportional.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: These data would be best presented with a curve of best fit, as the relationship between the variables is not directly proportional. Using graphing software, the equation of the line can be determined.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The line of best fit is correctly drawn as the relationship between the variables is directly proportional.
The line of best fit is incorrectly drawn as the relationship between the variables is inversely proportional.
The line of best fit would be correctly drawn if it went through the origin.

question_html:
A student performed a calorimetry experiment to examine the temperature changes over time for a chemical reaction. To determine the rate of the heat loss, the data must be extrapolated back to the start of the experiment.

Identify the correct statement.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The y-intercept of the extrapolated line is 32.5 and the gradient of the line is –0.5.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Following the extrapolated line back to the y-axis, it appears to be the midpoint between 30.0 and 35.0, so 32.5 for the y-intercept.

The gradient of the line is calculated as:

\(\qquad\qquad m = \dfrac{(y_2 - y_1)}{(x_2 - x_1)}\)

using two points from the line.

Two points that are easily read and fall on the line are (5.0, 30.0) and (0, 32.5).

\(\qquad\qquad\begin{align}m &= \dfrac{(32.5 - 30.0)}{(0 - 5.0)}\\ m &= -0.5\end{align}\)

MCQ_set.answer_html: The y-intercept of the extrapolated line is 32.5 and the gradient of the line is 0.5.
The y-intercept of the extrapolated line is 32.5 and the gradient of the line is –2.0.
The y-intercept of the extrapolated line is 32.5 and the gradient of the line is 2.0.

question_html:
The following graph was recorded with a data logger during an experiment investigating the relationship between pressure and volume.

This inverse relationship can be made linear by graphing _____. The resulting graph will show a _____ relationship.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: For an inverse relationship, the data can be made linear by graphing y versus \(\dfrac{1}{x}\). This produces a directly proportional relationship – linear with a positive slope.

question_html:
You are performing an experiment and have calculated the following volumes:

Volume /cm3
Theoretical yield \(46.00\)
Experimental yield

\(\text{Trial 1: 52.00} \)

\( \text{Trial 2: 51.85} \)

\( \text{Trial 3: 51.35}\)

Identify the statement that best describes the data.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The average volume collected has 12.4% error, which is likely to be caused by systematic error.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
The three trials are consistent with each other, showing high precision, even though the accuracy is low. This would indicate that the errors are systematic, rather than random.

The percentage error is calculated by taking the mean of the three trials, determining the absolute difference from the theoretical value, then dividing by the theoretical value.

The mean of the three trials is:

\(\qquad\qquad\dfrac{(52.00 + 51.85 + 51.35)}{3} = 51.73\text{ (rounding to two decimal places)}\)

\(\qquad\qquad\dfrac{\big|51.73 - 46.00\big|}{46.00 × 100\%} = \text{12.4% error}\)

MCQ_set.answer_html: The average volume collected has 12.4% error, which is likely to be caused by random error.
The average volume collected has 11.1% error, which is likely to be caused by systematic error.
The average volume collected has 11.1% error, which is likely to be caused by random error.

section_title: Uncertainties and errors in measurement and results

question_html:
You are preparing a solution and you record the following data.

                Mass of NaCl = 9.93 g ± 0.01 g
                Volume of volumetric flask = 200.00 cm3 ± 0.15 cm3

M  NaCl = 58.44 g mol-1

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
The calculation of the concentration involves converting the mass of the solute, including the uncertainty, to moles.

\(\qquad\qquad\rm\dfrac{{(9.93\,g\,±0.01\,g)}}{\rm{58.44\,g\,mol^{–1}}} = \text{0.170 mol ± 0.00017 mol}\)

The volume must also be converted into units of dm3, including the uncertainty, without gaining or losing significant digits.

\(\qquad\qquad\dfrac{(200.00\text{ cm}^3 ± 0.15\text{ cm}^3)}{1000} = 0.20000\text{ dm}^3 ± 0.00015\text{ dm}^3\)

\(\qquad\qquad\begin{align}c &= \dfrac{n}{V}\\ c &= \dfrac{\rm{(0.170\,mol\,±\,0.00017\,mol)}}{\rm{(0.20000\,dm^3\,±\,0.00015\,dm^3)}}\\ c &= \rm{0.850\,mol\,dm^{–3}}\end{align}\)

The uncertainty must be propagated by adding the percentage uncertainties for the amount in mol and the volume, then converting back to an absolute uncertainty to match the units of
mol dm–3 for the concentration.

Convert each absolute uncertainty to a percentage:

\(\qquad\qquad\begin{align}\text{amount} &= \left(\dfrac{0.00017\text{ mol}}{0.170\text{ mol}}\right) × 100 \\ &= \text{0.101% unrounded}\end{align}\)

\(\qquad\qquad\begin{align}\text{volume} &= \left(\dfrac{0.00015\text{ dm}^3}{0.20000\text{ dm}^3}\right) × 100 \\ &= \text{0.75% unrounded}\end{align}\)    

Add the percent uncertainty together:

                0.101% + 0.075% = 0.176%

Convert the percentage uncertainty back to absolute:

                0.176/100 × 0.850 mol dm–3 = 0.001 mol dm–3

Since the original uncertainty for the mass had one significant figure, the final propagated uncertainty must be rounded to one significant figure.

                c = 0.850 mol dm–3 ± 0.001 mol dm–3

Note: for most calculations, the precision in the final calculated answer generally matches the precision in the uncertainty.

section_title: Uncertainties and errors in measurement and results

question_html:
You collected the following data from a titration experiment using a weak acid and strong base with phenolphthalein indicator.

Trial Initial volume /cm3
± 0.05		 Final volume /cm3
± 0.05		 Colour at end point
1 0.00 10.20 pale pink
2 10.20 20.45 pale pink
3 20.45 30.65 pale pink
4 30.65 41.20 dark pink

Identify the trial that has a systematic error.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Trial 4 contains the systematic error in that volume of titrant is higher than the other trials – all other trials had 10.20 or 10.25 cm3, but Trial 4 had 10.55 cm3. This was likely due to the addition of excess base, shifting the colour of the indicator to a dark pink. Overshooting the endpoint of a titration is an example of a systematic error.

section_title: Uncertainties and errors in measurement and results

question_html:
The following data are presented from an experiment.

Mass of product / ±0.01 g
Theoretical yield \(5.00 \)
Experimental yield

\(\text{Trial 1: 5.01 } \)

\( \text{Trial 2: 5.02 } \)

\( \text{Trial 3: 5.02}\)

Identify the correct statement regarding the errors in this experiment.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The data indicate that there were systematic errors
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Systematic errors can be higher or lower than the theoretical value, but not both, and will be similar to one another. The mass for all three trials is higher than the theoretical value indicating a systematic error (such as forgetting to zero the mass balance). Random errors are always present but can be reduced by conducting repeat trials.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The data indicate that there were systematic errors but no random errors
The data indicate that there were random errors only
The types of errors cannot be determined with the information given

section_title: Uncertainties and errors in measurement and results

question_html: Identify the correct preparation of bromobenzene.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Benzene does not undergo addition reactions like other compounds that contain unsaturated C to C bonds, because of the system of six delocalised electrons. Therefore, it can only react by substitution.

question_html: Identify the type of reaction that takes place between CH3CH=CH2 and HCl.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Propene and HCl react in an electrophilic addition reaction, where the H atom is added to one carbon in the C=C bond and the Cl to the other, resulting in two possible products (1-chloropropane and 2-chloropropane).

question_html:
Identify the pair(s) of reactants that will react in the dark to form the product chloroethane.

I. ethene and hydrogen chloride

II. ethane and chlorine

III. ethene and chlorine

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Alkenes will react by addition reactions, whereas alkanes react by free-radical substitution, catalysed by UV light, so only reactions I and III will occur in the dark. Reaction III will result in the addition of both chlorine atoms to the two carbon atoms, forming dichloroethane, not chloroethane.

I. C2H4 + HCl → CH3CH2Cl (chloroethane)

II. C2H6 + Cl2 → no reaction without UV light

III. C2H4 + Cl2 → CH2Cl–CH2Cl (dichloroethane)

question_html:
Two resonance structures can be used to represent benzene.

If a C–C single bond has a bond length of 154 pm and a C=C double bond has a bond length of 134 pm, identify the correct statement regarding the C to C bonds in benzene.
(Note: 1 pm = 1 × 10–12 m.)

MCQ_set.answer_html: All C to C bond lengths in benzene are the same at 140 pm.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Physical and chemical evidence demonstrates that the length of all C to C bonds in benzene is equal and in between that of a C–C and a C=C bond. The six delocalised electrons are shared over all six carbon atoms. This makes each C to C bond identical in length as well as strength.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Three of the C to C bonds in benzene have a length of 154 pm and three of the bonds have a length of 134 pm.
Each C to C bond in benzene continually alternates in length between 134 pm and 154 pm.
The length of each C to C bond in benzene cannot be measured.

question_html: Which molecule is the least soluble in water?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: CH3CH2CH3 is propane which is a non-polar molecule (an alkane). Alkanes are insoluble in water because they cannot form hydrogen bonds with water molecules.

question_html: Which of the following is a structural isomer of butan-2-one?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
A structural isomer must have the same molecular formula, but a different arrangement of atoms in the molecule.

                Butan-2-one has the formula C4H8O.

                Butanol has the formula C4H10O.

                Butanal has the formula C4H8O.

                Butanoic acid has the formula C4H8O2.

                Propanone has the formula C3H6O.

Therefore, the structural isomer is butanal.

question_html: An electrolytic cell containing molten aluminium bromide is operated. Identify the correct statement below.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Al forms at the cathode and Br2 at the anode in a ratio of 2 mol:3 mol.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
In an electrolytic cell, the cation moves to the cathode and the anion to the anode, therefore Al3+ ions move to the cathode and Br– ions move to the anode.

The number of moles of product formed depends on the number of electrons gained or lost by each half-reaction.

                anode: 2Br–(l) → Br2(g) + 2e–

                cathode: Al3+(l) + 3e– → Al(l)

To balance the equations, you must multiply the equations to cancel out the electrons.

                anode: 3 × (2Br–(l) → Br2(g) + 2e–)

                cathode: 2 × (Al3+(l) + 3e– → Al(l))

Therefore, the ratio of products is 2 mol Al: 3 mol Br2.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Al forms at the cathode and Br2 at the anode in a ratio of 3 mol:2 mol.
Al forms at the anode and Br2 at the cathode in a ratio of 3 mol:2 mol.
Al forms at the anode and Br2 at the cathode in a ratio of 2 mol:3 mol.

question_html: A zinc–copper voltaic cell was constructed, and the salt bridge was prepared using ammonium nitrate. Identify the correct statement below.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Ammonium ions flow toward the copper half-cell and nitrate ions flow toward the zinc half-cell.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
In a zinc–copper cell, the zinc half-cell is the anode and copper half-cell is the cathode. The reactions at each half-cell are:

                anode: Zn(s) → Zn2+(aq) + 2e–

                cathode: Cu2+(aq) + 2e– → Cu(s)

The purpose of the salt bridge is to maintain electrical neutrality at each half-cell to complete the circuit. When electrons flow through the wire, there will be a build-up of positive charge at the anode and a build-up of negative charge at the cathode. The ammonium ions, which are positively charged, will flow toward the cathode and the nitrate ions, which are negatively charged, will flow toward the anode.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Ammonium ions flow toward the zinc half-cell and nitrate ions flow toward the copper half-cell.
Zinc ions flow toward the copper half-cell and copper ions flow toward the zinc half-cell.
Ammonium and chloride ions flow toward the copper half-cell and electrons flow toward the zinc half-cell.

question_html: Using the diagram of the voltaic cell below, identify the correct statement.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The nickel electrode will decrease in mass and the concentration of Pb2+ ions will decrease.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
The nickel half-cell is the anode and the lead half-cell is the cathode. The reactions at each electrode are:

                anode: Ni(s) → Ni2+(aq) + 2e–

                cathode: Pb2+(aq) + 2e– → Pb(s)

MCQ_set.answer_html: The nickel electrode will increase in mass and the concentration of Pb2+ ions will increase.
The nickel electrode will decrease in mass and the concentration of Pb2+ ions will increase.
The nickel electrode will increase in mass and the concentration of Pb2+ ions will decrease.

question_html:
When oxalic acid (ethanedioic acid), H2C2O4, is titrated with potassium permanganate (manganate(VII)), KMnO4, in acidic solution, the purple permanganate solution is decolourised. 

Calculate the concentration of a 10.0 cm3 sample of oxalic acid if 5.00 cm3 of 0.100 mol dm–3 KMnO4 solution is required for the titration.

     5C2O42–(aq) + 2MnO4–(aq) + 16H+(aq) → 10CO2(g) + 2Mn2+(aq) + 8H2O(l)

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
First, calculate the amount in moles of KMnO4 that was required to reach the end point.

                mol MnO4– = concentration × volume
                mol MnO4– = 0.10 mol dm–3 × 0.00500 dm3
                mol MnO4– = 0.000500 mol

Next, apply the mole ratio of 2:5.

\(\qquad\qquad\rm{0.000500\,mol\,MnO_4{^–} × \dfrac{5}{2}\,=\,0.00125\,mol\,C_2O_4{^{2–}}}\)

Finally, calculate the concentration.

\(\qquad\qquad\begin{align}\text{concentration} &= \dfrac{\text{amount}}{\text{volume}}\\ \text{concentration} &= \dfrac{\rm{0.00125\,mol\,C_2O_4{^{2–}}}}{\rm{0.0100\,dm^3}}\\ \text{concentration} &= 0.125\text{ mol dm}^{–3}\end{align}\)

question_html:
Propan-2-ol, CH3CH(OH)CH3, can be oxidised by permanganate (manganate(VII)) ions to form propan-2-one, CH3COCH3, according to the unbalanced reaction equation below.

                CH3CH(OH)CH3 + MnO4– → CH3COCH3 + Mn2+

Identify the correctly balanced equation for the redox reaction that takes place in an acidic solution.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Balancing a redox reaction in acidic conditions involves first separating the half-equations and balancing all atoms and ions except H and O.

\(\qquad\qquad\begin{align}\rm{CH_3CH(OH)CH_3(aq) + MnO_4{^–}(aq)} &→ \rm{CH_3COCH_3(aq) + Mn^{2+}(aq)}\\ \rm{CH_3CH(OH)CH_3(aq)} &→ \rm{CH_3COCH_3(aq)}\\ \rm{MnO_4{^–}(aq)} &→ \rm{Mn_2+(aq)}\end{align}\)

Next, balance O atoms by adding water molecules.

\(\qquad\qquad\begin{align}\rm{CH_3CH(OH)CH_3(aq)} &→ \rm{CH_3COCH_3(aq)}\\ \rm{MnO_4{^–}(aq)} &→ \rm{Mn^{2+}(aq) + 4H_2O(l)}\end{align}\)

Then balance H atoms by adding H+ ions.

\(\qquad\qquad\begin{align}\rm{CH_3CH(OH)CH_3(aq)} &→ \rm{CH_3COCH_3(aq) + 2H^+(aq)}\\ \rm{MnO_4{^–}(aq) + 8H^+(aq)} &→ \rm{Mn^{2+}(aq) + 4H_2O(l)}\end{align}\)

Balance the charges by adding electrons.

\(\qquad\qquad\begin{align}\rm{CH_3CH(OH)CH_3(aq)} &→ \rm{CH_3COCH_3(aq) + 2H^+(aq)+ 2e^–}\\ \rm{MnO_4{^–}(aq) + 8H^+(aq) + 5e^–} &→ \rm{Mn^{2+}(aq) + 4H_2O(l)}\end{align}\)

Lastly, balance the half-equations to cancel out the electrons. The first half-equation will be multiplied by 5 and the second by 2, in order to make the number of electrons in each half-equation 10.

\(\qquad\qquad\begin{align}\rm{5 × (CH_3CH(OH)CH_3(aq)} &→ \rm{CH_3COCH_3(aq) + 2H^+(aq)+ 2e^–)}\\ \rm{2 × (MnO_4{^–}(aq) + 8H^+(aq) + 5e^–} &→ \rm{Mn^{2+}(aq) + 4H_2O(l))}\end{align}\)

\(\qquad\qquad\begin{align}\rm{5CH_3CH(OH)CH_3(aq)} &→ \rm{5CH_3COCH_3(aq) + 10H^+(aq)+ 10e^–}\\ \rm{2MnO_4{^–}(aq) + 16H^+(aq) + 10e^–} &→ \rm{2Mn^{2+}(aq) + 8H_2O(l)}\end{align}\)

Add the two half-equations together and cancel out any terms that appear on both sides of the reaction arrow.

\(\qquad\qquad\rm{5CH_3CH(OH)CH_3(aq) + 2MnO_4{^–}(aq) + 16H^+(aq) + 10e^–} → \\\qquad\quad\,\,\,\,\rm{5CH_3COCH_3(aq) + 10H^+(aq)+ 10e^– + 2Mn^{2+}(aq) + 8H_2O(l)}\)

\(\qquad\qquad\rm{5CH_3CH(OH)CH_3(aq) + 2MnO_4{^–}(aq) + 6H^+(aq) }→\\ \qquad\quad\,\,\,\,\rm{5CH_3COCH_3(aq) + 2Mn^{2+}(aq) + 8H_2O(l)}\)

question_html:
Breathalyser machines test for the presence of ethanol, CH3CH2OH, on the breath using an oxidation–reduction reaction that takes place in acidic conditions. Identify the correctly balanced redox equation for the change below. 

                CH3CH2OH(aq) + Cr2O72–(aq) → CH3COOH(aq) + Cr3+(aq)

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Balancing a redox reaction in acidic conditions involves first separating the half-equations and balancing all atoms and ions except those of hydrogen and oxygen.

\(\qquad\qquad\begin{align}\rm{CH_3CH_2OH(aq) + Cr_2O{_7}^{2-}(aq)} &→ \rm{CH_3COOH(aq) + Cr^{3+}(aq)}\\ \rm{CH_3CH_2OH(aq)} &→ \rm{CH3COOH(aq)}\\ \rm{Cr_2O{_7}^{2-}(aq)} &→ \rm{2Cr^{3+}(aq)}\end{align}\)

Next, balance O atoms by adding water molecules.

\(\qquad\qquad\begin{align}\rm{CH_3CH_2OH(aq) + H_2O(l) }&→ \rm{CH_3COOH(aq)}\\ \rm{Cr_2O{_7}^{2-}(aq) }&→\rm{ 2Cr^{3+}(aq) + 7H_2O(l)}\end{align}\)

Then balance H atoms by adding H+ ions.

\(\qquad\qquad\begin{align}\rm{CH_3CH_2OH(aq) + H_2O(l) }&→ \rm{CH_3COOH(aq) + 4 H^+(aq)}\\ \rm{Cr_2O{_7}^{2-}(aq) + 14H^+(aq) }&→ \rm{2Cr^{3+}(aq) + 7H_2O(l)}\end{align}\)

Finally, balance the charges by adding electrons.

\(\qquad\qquad\begin{align}\rm{CH_3CH_2OH(aq) + H_2O(l) }&→ \rm{CH_3COOH(aq) + 4H^+(aq) + 4e^-}\\ \rm{Cr_2O{_7}^{2-}(aq) + 14H^+(aq) + 6e^-}&→ \rm{2Cr^{3+}(aq) + 7H_2O(l)}\end{align}\)

Lastly, balance the half-equations to cancel out the electrons. The first half-equation will be multiplied by 3 and the second by 2, in order to make the number of electrons in each half-equation 12.

\(\qquad\qquad\begin{align}\rm{3 × (CH_3CH2OH(aq) + H_2O(l) }&→ \rm{CH_3COOH(aq) + 4H^+(aq) + 4e^-)}\\ \rm{2 × (Cr_2O{_7}^{2-}(aq) + 14H^+(aq) + 6e– }&→ \rm{2Cr^{3+}(aq) + 7H_2O(l))}\end{align}\)

\(\qquad\qquad\begin{align}\rm{3CH_3CH_2OH(aq) + 3H_2O(l) }&→ \rm{3CH_3COOH(aq) + 12H^+(aq) + 12e^-}\\ \rm{2Cr_2O{_7}^{2-}(aq) + 28H^+(aq) + 12e^- }&→ \rm{4Cr^{3+}(aq) + 14H_2O(l)}\end{align}\)

Add the two half-equations together and cancel out any terms that appear on both sides of the reaction arrow.

\(\qquad\qquad\rm{3CH_3CH_2OH(aq) + 3H_2O(l) + 2Cr_2O{_7}^{2-}(aq) + 28H^+(aq) + 12e^- }→\\ \qquad\quad\,\,\,\,\rm{3CH_3COOH(aq) + 12H^+(aq) + 12e^- + 4Cr^{3+}(aq) + 14H_2O(l)}\)
