\(\qquad\qquad\rm{3CH_3CH_2OH(aq) + 2Cr_2O{_7}^{2-}(aq) + 16H^+(aq) →}\\ \qquad\qquad\rm{3CH_3COOH(aq) + 4Cr^{3+}(aq) + 11H_2O(l)}\)

question_html:
Four metals – W, X, Y and Z – are each treated with the ions of the other three to see whether displacement reactions took place. Y2+ did not react with any of the metals. X2+ reacted with Y, but not with Z. W reacted with X2+. 

Deduce the activity series of these four metals, most reactive first.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Y must be higher than all other metals, since Y2+ was not displaced by any of the metals.

                Y, ___, ___, ___

X is higher than Z, since Z was not able to displace X2+.

                Y, X, Z

W is higher than X, since it was able to displace X2+.

                Y, W, X, Z

question_html: Identify the reaction that does not involve oxidation–reduction.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: All the reactions involve electron transfer except for the double displacement (precipitation) reaction.

question_html:
The Haber process is used to produce ammonia from nitrogen and hydrogen via the following equilibrium reaction:

                N2(g) + 3H2(g) ⇌ 2NH3(g)    ΔH = –92 kJ mol–1

Which of the following changes would cause the reaction to proceed from left to right in order to reestablish equilibrium?

MCQ_set.answer_html: adding hydrogen to the system, keeping temperature and volume constant
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Adding hydrogen (a reactant) to the system disrupts the equilibrium. In order to reestablish equilibrium, the rate of consumption of the reactants increases, favouring the forward reaction (left to right) in order to reach equilibrium again.

MCQ_set.answer_html: increasing the volume of the reaction vessel, keeping temperature constant
removing nitrogen gas from the system, keeping temperature and pressure constant
increasing the temperature, keeping the pressure and volume constant

question_html:
If Q > Kc for a reaction at a certain point in time, which of the following statements are true?

I. The reaction will proceed to the left

II. The reaction is not at equilibrium 

III. There is a higher concentration of reactants than there would be at equilibrium

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Since the reaction quotient, Q, is greater than the equilibrium constant, Kc, there is a higher concentration of products than there would be at equilibrium.

Until equilibrium is reached, the reverse reaction will be faster than the forward reaction so the net effect is that the reaction proceeds to the left, favouring the formation of reactants. The rate of the forward reaction increases as the concentration of reactants increases, and the rate of the reverse reaction decreases as the concentration of products decreases, until the rates are equal and equilibrium is established.

question_html:
The equilibrium reaction of N2O4 (colourless gas) and NO2 (brown gas) is shown below:

\(\qquad\qquad\begin{array}{ccc}\rm{N_2O_4(g)} &⇌& \rm{2NO_2(g)}\\                                    \text{ (colourless gas)}&&\text{(brown)}\end{array}\)

At room temperature, a sealed glass tube of the equilibrium mixture appears to be a dark brown. When this sealed tube is placed into an ice bath, the gas within the tube starts to change colour and, when equilibrium is reestablished, it is light yellow.

What information does this change provide about the equilibrium mixture in the ice bath?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Forward reaction is endothermic; Kc decreases when mixture is placed in the ice.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
The fact that the tube contents become lighter in colour in a cold environment indicates that the reaction has shifted to the left to favour the production of N2O4, which is colourless.

Lowering the temperature will shift the equilibrium in favour of the exothermic reaction. The change indicates that the reverse reaction is exothermic and therefore the forward reaction is endothermic.

Since the reverse reaction is now favoured, there will be a greater concentration of reactants present at equilibrium, lowering the value of the equilibrium constant Kc.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Forward reaction is exothermic; Kc decreases when mixture is placed in the ice.
Forward reaction is endothermic; Kc increases when mixture is placed in the ice.
Forward reaction is exothermic; Kc increases when mixture is placed in the ice.

question_html: Nitrogen and oxygen combine to form dinitrogen monoxide in an equilibrium reaction. Identify which of the following would represent the expression for the equilibrium constant, Kc.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
The first step is to write out a chemical equation for the reaction.

2N2(g) + O2(g) ⇌ 2N2O(g)

Then write the equilibrium constant expression placing the concentration of products in the numerator and the concentration of the reactants in the denominator. The concentrations should be raised to the power of their coefficients.

\({{K}_{c}}=\dfrac{{{[{{N}_{2}}O]}^{2}}}{{{[{{N}_{2}}]}^{2}}\left[ {{O}_{2}} \right]}\)

question_html:
The following equilibrium reaction has an equilibrium constant Kc1.

                A + 2B ⇌ C + 2D

Identify which of the following would represent the equilibrium constant Kc2, for the following equilibrium reaction at the same temperature.

                ½C + D ⇌ ½A + B

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
The expression for the equilibrium constant Kc1 would be:

\(\qquad\qquad{{K}_{c1}}=\dfrac{\left[ C \right]{{[D]}^{2}}}{\left[ A \right]{{[B]}^{2}}}\)

The expression for the equilibrium constant Kc2 would be:

\(\qquad\qquad{{K}_{c2}}=\dfrac{{{[A]}^{\frac{1}{2}}}\left[ B \right]}{{{[C]}^{\frac{1}{2}}}\left[ D \right]}\)

We can relate Kc2 to Kc1 by:

\(\qquad\qquad{{K}_{c2}}=\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{{{K}_{c1}}}}\)

\(\qquad\qquad{{K}_{c2}}=\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{\dfrac{\left[ C \right]{{[D]}^{2}}}{\left[ A \right]{{[B]}^{2}}}}}\)

\(\qquad\qquad{{K}_{c2}}=\dfrac{{{[A]}^{\frac{1}{2}}}\left[ B \right]}{{{[C]}^{\frac{1}{2}}}\left[ D \right]}\)

question_html: Which of the following is correct for the graph below?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Position of the equilibrium lies to the right and Kc > 1
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: From the graph it is apparent that at equilibrium (where the graphical region is flat), there is a significantly larger concentration of products than reactants. This means that the equilibrium position is in favour of the products (the equilibrium lies to the right) and so Kc is larger than 1 (since the concentration of products is greater than that of reactants, making the ratio of product to reactant concentration larger than 1).

MCQ_set.answer_html: Position of the equilibrium lies to the right and Kc < 1
Position of the equilibrium lies to the left and Kc > 1
Position of the equilibrium lies to the left and Kc < 1

question_html:
Nitrogen and hydrogen gas were placed in a sealed container at 300°C and allowed to reach equilibrium. The equilibrium constant was found to be Kc = 4.34 × 10–3. At 400°C the equilibrium constant becomes Kc =1.64 × 10-4.

                N2(g) + 3H2(g) ⇌ 2NH3(g)

Which of the following statements about this equilibrium mixture is correct?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Temperature is the only change in condition that has an influence on the value of Kc. Increasing temperature causes the equilibrium to shift to favour the endothermic reaction. The equilibrium constant here is smaller at the higher temperature. A smaller Kc means fewer products and more reactants, indicating that the equilibrium has shifted in the reverse direction. This implies that the reverse reaction is endothermic and the forward reaction is exothermic.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The rate of the forward reaction is greater than the rate of the reverse reaction.

question_html:
Which of the following correctly describes the reaction shown by the reaction profile shown below?

I. Reaction has a two step-mechanism.

II. Step two in the reaction is the rate-determining step.

III. B is a reaction intermediate.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
In this reaction profile there are two distinct peaks. This indicates that the reaction proceeds via two separate steps. It can be seen that step 1 has a higher activation energy than step 2. This means that step 1 is the rate-determining step, not step 2.

Reaction intermediates are low-energy species that are formed and then consumed to form products in the following step.

question_html: Using the following graphical data, calculate the value of the Arrhenius constant.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
The equation of this plot is:

\(\qquad\qquad\text{ln}\left(k\right)=\dfrac{-{{E}_{a}}}{R}\left( \dfrac{1}{T} \right)+\text{ln}\left(A\right)\)

The Arrhenius constant, A, can be found from the y-intercept of this graph. The y-intercept is approximately 23.1.

23.1 = ln(A)

A = e23.1

A = 1.08 × 1010

question_html: State the correct match of the following concentration against time graphs with orders of reaction.

MCQ_set.answer_html: a: zero order, b: first order, c: second order
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
The gradient of the tangent line at any point on a concentration against time plot represents the instantaneous rate of reaction.

In a, the gradient (i.e. rate) is constant, indicating that this is a zero-order reaction.

In b, the gradient decreases over time.

In c, the gradient again decreases over time, but the decrease is more rapid than in b. This indicates that c is a higher-order reaction than b, so b is first order and c is a second-order reaction.

MCQ_set.answer_html: a: first order, b: second order, c: third order
a: zero order, b: second order, c: first order
a: first order, b: third order, c: second order

question_html:
The overall reaction:

                4HI(g) + O2(g) → 2I2(g) + 2H2O(g)

is hypothesised to proceed via the following mechanism:

Step 1: HI + O2 → HIO2

Step 2: HI + HIO2 → H2O + I2O

Step 3: I2O + HI → I2 + HIO

Step 4: HIO + HI → I2  + H2O

Using the following experimental data, deduce which step is the rate-determining step in the proposed reaction mechanism.

Experiment Initial [HI] / mol dm–3 Initial [O2] / mol dm–3 Initial rate / mol dm–3 s–1
1 \(1.00 × 10^{-2}\) \(1.00 × 10^{-2}\) \(4.20 × 10^{-3}\)
2 \(1.00 × 10^{-2}\) \(2.00 × 10^{-2}\) \(8.40 × 10^{-3}\)
3 \(2.00 × 10^{-2}\) \(2.00 × 10^{-2}\) \(1.68 × 10^{-2}\)

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Comparison of experiments 1 and 2 shows that when [HI] is constant and [O2] increases by a factor of 2, the initial rate increases by a factor of 2. Therefore the rate of reaction is first-order with respect to O2.

Comparison of experiments 2 and 3 shows that when [O2] is constant and [HI] increases by a factor of 2, the initial rate increases by a factor of 2. Therefore the rate of reaction is first-order with respect to HI.

The only rate-determining step that is consistent with a second order overall is step 1.

If step 2 were the rate-determining step, we would expect a rate of reaction second-order with respect to HI and first-order with respect to O2.

If step 3 were the rate-determining step we would expect a rate of reaction third-order with respect to HI and first-order with respect to O2.

If step 4 were the rate-determining step we would expect a rate of reaction fourth-order with respect to HI and first-order with respect to O2.

question_html: Which of the following statements is correct for an endothermic reaction?

MCQ_set.answer_html: The activation energy of the forward reaction is equal to the sum of the activation energy for the reverse reaction and the enthalpy change for the forward reaction.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
As can be seen from the energy profile for an endothermic reaction, the activation energy for the forward reaction is the energy needed to transition from reactants to the highest point on the energy profile curve. For the reverse reaction, the activation energy is the energy needed to transition from the products to the highest point on the energy profile curve.

On this profile, it can be seen that:

\(\qquad\qquad{{E}_{\text{a}}}_{( \text{fwd})}={{E}_{\text{a}}}_{( \text{rvs})}+ \Delta H\)

MCQ_set.answer_html: The activation energy of the forward reaction is equal to the enthalpy change for the reverse reaction.
The activation energy of the forward reaction is equal to the difference of the activation energy for the reverse reaction and the enthalpy change for the forward reaction.
The activation energy for the forward and reverse reactions is equal.

section_title: Collision theory and rates of reaction

question_html: Which of the following letters represents the activation energy for an endothermic reaction in the presence of a catalyst?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
A catalyst provides an alternative reaction pathway that has a lower activation energy than the uncatalysed pathway.

Since activation energy is defined as the minimum amount of energy that colliding reactant particles must have in order for a reaction to occur, the minimum energy should be the difference between the enthalpy of the reactants and the maximum of the “hump” for the catalysed process (the red line).

The blue line represents the reaction pathway for the uncatalysed reaction and line D represents the activation energy for this reaction. A represents the activation energy for the catalysed reverse reaction and B is the activation energy for the uncatalysed reverse reaction.

section_title: Collision theory and rates of reaction

question_html: Deduce the average rate of reaction, over the first 60 seconds, in mol dm–3 s–1, given the graphical data of the concentration of reactant over time.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
In order to calculate the average rate of change, the gradient of the secant between the two points in time needs to be calculated. From a secant line connecting t = 0 s and t = 60 s, two points that fall along the tangent line are (0, 1.0) and (60, 0.3).

Calculating the gradient:

\(\qquad\qquad\begin{align}\text{Gradient}&=\dfrac{{{y}_{2}}-{{y}_{1}}}{{{x}_{2}}-{{x}_{1}}}\\ \text{Gradient}&=\dfrac{1.0-0.3}{0-60}\\ \text{Gradient}&=-0.01167\,\text{ mol dm}^{-3}{{\text{ s}}^{-1}}\end{align}\)

Since the reactant concentration is decreasing the rate can be interpreted as a positive value (concentration of reactant decreases by 0.012 mol dm–3 each second on average between 0 and 60 seconds).

section_title: Collision theory and rates of reaction

question_html: Deduce the initial rate of reaction, at t = 0 s, in mol dm–3 s–1, given the graphical data of the concentration of reactant over time.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
In order to calculate the instantaneous rate of reaction, the gradient of the tangent line at that particular instant in time needs to be calculated. For the initial rate of reaction, draw a tangent line at t = 0 s and extend the line outwards; the two points that fall along the tangent line are (0, 1.0) and (10, 0.8)

Calculating the gradient:

\(\qquad\qquad\begin{align}\text{Gradient}&=\dfrac{{{y}_{2}}-{{y}_{1}}}{{{x}_{2}}-{{x}_{1}}}\\ \text{Gradient}&=\dfrac{1.0-0.8}{0-10}\\ \text{Gradient}&=-0.020\,\text{mol dm}^{-3}{{\text{ s}}^{-1}}\end{align}\)

Since the reactant concentration is decreasing the rate can be interpreted as a positive value (concentration of reactant decreases by 0.020 mol dm–3 each second as the initial, instantaneous rate).

section_title: Collision theory and rates of reaction

question_html:
Which of the following methods is appropriate to measure the rate of reaction for the reaction of sodium thiosulfate with hydrochloric acid?

                Na2S2O3(aq) + 2HCl(aq) → 2NaCl(aq) + SO2(g) + H2O(l) + S(s)

I. time taken for a precipitate to form that obscures a black cross

II. change in mass of reaction vessel over time

III. change in pH over time

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
I. Since a precipitate is being formed, a mark drawn on a piece of paper below the reaction vessel will no longer be visible once a certain quantity of S(s) is produced. This method can be used to determine the reaction rate.

II. Since a gas is being formed, if the reaction vessel is left open to the atmosphere, the mass of the vessel will decrease over time. This method can be used to determine the reaction rate.

III. Since HCl, a strong acid, is one of the starting reagents, as it reacts, the pH will increase with time. This method can be used to determine the reaction rate.

section_title: Collision theory and rates of reaction

question_html: For which of the following reactions could a conductivity meter be used in order to measure the rate of the reaction experimentally?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Since aqueous ionic compounds involve the dissociation of ions into their solvent, water, the ions will move around as individual ions. This means that all of the aqueous substances (AgNO3, NaCl and NaNO3) will have a high conductivity, whereas the precipitate (AgCl) will have low conductivity. As AgCl is produced, the conductivity of the solution should decrease over time.

Since all the other reactions involve covalent compounds, no change in conductivity will be observed.

section_title: Collision theory and rates of reaction

question_html:
Nitrogen dioxide can be formed via the following reaction:

                N2(g) +2O2(g) →2NO2(g)

What is the rate of decrease of the nitrogen gas if the concentration of nitrogen dioxide changes from 0.35 mol dm–3 to 0.84 mol dm–3 in 3 minutes?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
The first step is to find the rate of production of nitrogen dioxide from the information provided.

Since rate of reaction in terms of the product is:

\(\qquad\qquad\begin{align}\text{Rate }\left( \text{N}{{\text{O}}_{2}} \right)&=\dfrac{\text{Increase in product concentration}}{\text{time}}\\ \text{Rate }\left(\text{N}{{\text{O}}_{2}} \right)&=\dfrac{0.84\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ }-\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ }0.35}{3\times 60}\\ \text{Rate }\left( \text{N}{{\text{O}}_{2}} \right)&=0.0027222\,\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ mol }\,\!\!~\!\!\text{ d}{{\text{m}}^{-3}}\,{{\text{s}}^{-1}}~\end{align}\)

Note the conversion of 3 minutes into seconds by multiplying by 60 in the denominator.

This represents the rate of formation of nitrogen dioxide. In order to determine the rate of consumption of nitrogen the coefficients in the reaction equation must be considered.

Since every mole of N2 forms 2 moles of NO2, the rate of consumption of nitrogen is half the rate of production of nitrogen dioxide.

\(\qquad\qquad\begin{align}\text{Rate}\left( {{\text{N}}_{2}} \right)&=\dfrac{1}{2}\times \text{Rate}\left( \text{N}{{\text{O}}_{2}} \right)\\ \text{Rate}\left( {{\text{N}}_{2}} \right)&=0.0013611\,\text{mol dm}^{-3}\,\text{s}^{-1} \end{align} \)

section_title: Collision theory and rates of reaction

question_html: Identify which of the following units would not be appropriate for expressing the rate of a reaction.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Rate is a measure of the 'speed' of a reaction. It represents the change in the amount of reactant or product per unit time.

cm3, mol dm–3, g and kPa are all variables that could provide information about the change in amount of reactant or product in different intervals of time. However only units of 1/time, usually s–1, are appropriate to include as units for rate (per unit time), s would not be appropriate.

section_title: Collision theory and rates of reaction

question_html: Which of the following graphical representations best represents the distribution of kinetic energy among particles in any system with and without a catalyst added?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Catalysts provide an alternative pathway for a reaction with a lower activation energy. The addition of a catalyst will not influence the kinetic energy of particles within a system, so the correct graph should have one only curve representing the distribution of energies among those particles.

The minimum energy needed for a reaction to occur will be lower with the addition of a catalyst than with no catalyst. This means that, when a catalyst is present, there will be a greater proportion of reactant molecules with enough kinetic energy to overcome the activation energy.

section_title: Collision theory and rates of reaction

question_html:
Which of the following pairs of Maxwell–Boltzmann distribution curves best represents the distribution of kinetic energy for particles at two different temperatures?

Note: dashed line = higher temperature, solid line = lower temperature.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Since temperature represents the average kinetic energy of particles in a system, a system at a higher temperature will have, on average, more particles with a higher kinetic energy. This means that the broken curve (hot) should lie more to the right than the solid curve (cool).

In terms of area underneath the curve, the area of both curves should be the same as the number of particles is not changing. Since the curve always starts at the origin, this means that the curve flattens at higher temperatures.

section_title: Collision theory and rates of reaction

question_html: Maxwell-Boltzmann distribution curves provide information about the distribution of kinetic energy among particles in a system. Which of the following graphical representations best represents the distribution of kinetic energy among particles in any system?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
The particles within any system will have varying kinetic energies. The kinetic energies will span from close to zero up to high kinetic energies. Most will be somewhere in the middle; fewer particles will be in the low and high ranges of kinetic energy.

Consider a cup of water at room temperature. Water molecules are able to evaporate from that cup even though the temperature is below the boiling point. This means there is a proportion of molecules with high enough activation energy to overcome the hydrogen bonding between them and adjacent molecules, and escape the cup of water into the atmosphere.

Conversely, in a pot of boiling water not all molecules instantly evaporate. Rather, some molecules have a lower kinetic energy that is not enough to overcome the activation energy needed to break the hydrogen bonds between adjacent molecules and escape.

section_title: Collision theory and rates of reaction

question_html: Identify the hardest material of those below on the basis of their structure and bonding.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Sodium chloride is an ionic compound, which is a hard but brittle material.

Iron and sodium are both pure metals, whereas steel is an alloy of iron and carbon. Sodium is an incredibly soft metal that can be cut easily with a knife. Iron metal is harder than sodium; however, steel will be harder than iron. This is because alloys are always harder than their base metals owing to the introduction of different-sized ions within the lattice structure, making it much more difficult for layers to slide past one another. This reduces the malleability of the material, increasing the hardness.

question_html: Which of the following explains why alloys are less malleable than their base metals?

MCQ_set.answer_html: difficult for layers to slide past one another
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
The introduction of atoms of another metal or non-metal into the lattice structure of the base metal makes it less malleable, because the different-sized ions within the lattice structure make it more difficult for layers to slide past one another.

This does also make the material harder to bend. However this is not an explanation for the reduced malleability.

MCQ_set.answer_html: stronger attraction between ions and delocalised electrons

question_html:
Identify which of the following substances conduct electricity in the solid state.

I. sodium chloride

II. sodium

III. graphite

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
To deduce the electrical conductivity of each material it is important to first consider the bonding present within each.

Sodium chloride is an ionic compound. Ionic compounds are not conductive in the solid state as their ions are fixed in their positions within the lattice. Ionic compounds are, however, conductive in aqueous or molten states.

Sodium is a metal. Metals are conductive in both solid and liquid states because of their delocalised electrons.

Graphite is a network covalent solid. The structure of graphite has delocalised electrons in individual layers. These delocalised electrons lead to conductivity of the solid material. Note that not all network covalent solid materials are conductive, only those that have delocalised electrons within their structure.

question_html:
Which of the following correctly identifies the general trends in melting point down Group 1 and Group 17?

Group 1 Group 17
Trend in melting point down group Bonds / forces broken during melting Trend in melting point down group Bonds / forces broken during melting
A increases metallic increases covalent
B increases ionic decreases covalent
C decreases metallic increases London dispersion
D decreases ionic decreases London dispersion

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
To explain the melting point trend in each group, the type of bonding must be analysed.

Group 1 elements have metallic bonding. When metals melt, the metallic bonds between the lattice of positive ions and the delocalised electrons are starting to break. The larger the metal ions are within the metallic lattice, the weaker the attraction to the delocalised electrons. This means that the larger the metal ion size, the weaker the metallic bond and therefore the lower the melting point. Therefore, travelling down Group 1 the melting point will decrease.

Group 17 contains small covalent molecules. When small covalent molecules are melting, the intermolecular forces acting between the molecules will start to be overcome. Travelling down Group 17, the molecule size increases. As the mass of a molecule increases, its polarisability increases, increasing the strength of the London dispersion forces between molecules. This means that the greater the size of the molecule, the stronger the London dispersion forces are between them and therefore the higher the melting point will be. Therefore, travelling down Group 17 the melting point will increase.

question_html:
An alloy could be created from which of the following combinations:

I. metal + different metal

II. non-metal + different non-metal

III. metal + non-metal

IV. metal + same metal

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Alloys are defined as homogeneous mixtures of metals with other metals or non-metals (so only I and III). Many alloys involve the combination of two metals; however, carbon is often added. For example steel involves iron with carbon included throughout its structure.

question_html: The structure of a soap (surfactant) molecule is given below. Looking at the structure, deduce what solvent(s) the molecule will be soluble in.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Soap (surfactant) molecules have a polar region (known as a hydrophilic head) and a non-polar region (known as a hydrophobic tail). Since water is a polar molecule, the polar region of soap can interact with it, making the soap soluble in water. Since oil is a non-polar substance, the non-polar region of soap can interact with it, making the soap soluble in oil.

question_html: Identify the hydrogen halide with the highest boiling point.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: HF has hydrogen bonding and London dispersion forces between molecules. The other hydrogen halides have only dipole–dipole and London dispersion forces between molecules. Hydrogen bonding is a much stronger intermolecular force to overcome, meaning more energy will be needed to separate molecules. This causes the boiling point of HF to be much higher than those of the other hydrogen halides.

question_html: When graphite is used as a writing material, individual layers of graphite transfer from the pencil to the page. What interaction has to be overcome in order for this transfer to occur?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The individual layers in graphite are held together by weak intermolecular forces. Since the substance is non-polar and does not contain any hydrogen atoms, the intermolecular forces holding these individual layers together are London dispersion forces.

question_html:
In which of the following structures are the carbon–carbon bonds all the same length? 

A
B
C
D

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
The diagram style used above is the skeletal formula for each molecule. What can be seen from each diagram is that A has a triple bond, B and C have two double bonds and D has three double bonds.

The special thing about benzene, the molecule in D, is the presence of alternating single and double bonds. Since they are located in this cyclic structure, the electrons in the double bonds are not confined to one location and are delocalised throughout the structure. Another way of looking at this is to see the ring as two different resonance structures. This delocalisation provides extra stability to the molecule and causes all of the carbon–carbon bond lengths to be the same, somewhere intermediate between the length of a single and double bond.

question_html:
Which combination of conductivity of solid and bond angle is correct for the graphite allotrope of carbon?

Conductivity of solid Bond angle Type of intermolecular force between layers
A Poor \(120°\) Dipole–dipole
B Good \(120°\) London dispersion
C Good \(109.5°\) Dipole–dipole
D Poor \(109.5°\) London dispersion

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The structure of graphite has layers in which each carbon atom is covalently bonded to three other carbon atoms arranged in a trigonal planar arrangement (120°). These form sheets (layers) of carbon atoms. Since carbon atoms can form four bonds, each carbon atom contributes another electron into a delocalised layer. This makes graphite a good conductor, particularly along the layers.

question_html:
Which of the following could represent the identity of X, Y and Z?

X Y Z
Melting point high low high
Electrical conductivity of solid low low high

MCQ_set.answer_html: X is SiO2, Y is CO2 and Z is Al
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Since the options are between SiO2, CO2 and Al we need to compare the properties between them. Both SiO2 and CO2 have covalent bonding between atoms whereas Al is a metallic substance.

Metallic substances have high melting points in addition to high electrical conductivities as solids. Therefore substance Z has to be Al.

SiO2 is a covalent substance that forms a giant lattice structure, so it has a high melting point. Since there are no delocalised electrons in this structure, the solid has low conductivity.

CO2 is a covalent substance that forms small molecules held together by intermolecular forces in the solid material. Therefore it has a low melting point (relative to lattice structures). Since there are no delocalised electrons or ions, the solid has low conductivity.

MCQ_set.answer_html: X is CO2, Y is Al and Z is SiO2
X is CO2, Y is SiO2 and Z is Al
X is SiO2, Y is Al and Z is CO2

question_html:
Which of the following combinations of bond angle and molecular polarity is correct?

Molecule Bond angle Molecular geometry Molecular polarity
I. NH3 \(120°\) trigonal planar polar
II. CHCl3 \(109.5°\) tetrahedral polar
III. BF3 \(120°\) trigonal planar non-polar

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
In order to determine both the bond angle and molecular polarity, it is important to draw the Lewis structure to deduce the number of electron domains around the central atom and then apply VSEPR theory.

NH3 has three bonding electron domains and one non-bonding electron domain (lone pair). This means the electron domains have a tetrahedral arrangement around the N atom. However, lone pairs are not used to describe the shape of the molecule, so the molecule would be trigonal pyramidal. Because the lone pair repels the other electron pairs slightly more strongly than a bonding pair, the bond angles are slightly less than the 109.5° bond angle in a tetrahedral molecule, at approximately 107°.

Since there is a lone pair on the central atom the molecule is polar.

CHCl3 has four bonding electron domains and no non-bonding electron domains. This makes the arrangement of the electron domains and shape of the molecule tetrahedral, with a bond angle of 109.5°. Since the C–Cl bond is polar and the dipoles will not cancel out (because the presence of one C–H bond makes the molecule asymmetrical) the molecule will be polar.

BF3 has three bonding electron domains and no non-bonding electron domains. This makes the arrangement of the electron domains and the shape of the molecule trigonal planar with a bond angle of 120°. The B–F bond is polar, but the dipoles from the polar bond will all cancel out, making the overall molecule non-polar.

question_html: Which statement best describes the structure and bonding in SiO2?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Electrostatic attraction between shared pairs of electrons and positively charged nuclei forming a giant covalent network structure
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
The bonding between silicon atoms and oxygen atoms in SiO2 is covalent. When silicon atoms bond with oxygen atoms they share electrons to form bonds. The definition of covalent bonding is the electrostatic attraction between shared pairs of electrons and positively charged nuclei.

The structure of SiO2 is a network covalent structure in which each silicon atom is covalently bonded to four oxygen atoms in a tetrahedral arrangement, and each oxygen atom is covalently bonded to two silicon atoms in a bent arrangement.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Electrostatic attraction between shared pairs of electrons and positively charged nuclei held together by dipole–dipole forces
Electrostatic attraction between Si4+ and O2– ions forming a 3D lattice
Electrostatic attraction between positive cations arrange in a 3D lattice and the surrounding delocalised electrons

question_html:
Arrange the following diatomic molecules in order of increasing bond length:

F2, N2, Cl2, O2

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Multiple bonds are shorter than single bonds. To decide whether a molecule has a single, double or triple bond, the easiest method is to draw out the Lewis structures. This will show that nitrogen has a triple bond, oxygen has a double bond and both fluorine and chlorine have single bonds.

Since there are two species with a single bond, it makes sense to compare them directly. These two elements are in the same group. Atomic size increases down a group (due to the increasing number of electron energy levels), so chlorine is a larger atom than fluorine, and two chlorine atoms bonded together will be further apart than two fluorine atoms (F2 < Cl2).

Since multiple bonds consist of more shared electrons, there is a stronger electrostatic attraction between the shared electrons and the nuclei. This means the bond length decreases with increasing number of covalent bonds between two atoms (N2 < O2 < F2).

Putting it together: N2 < O2 < F2 < Cl2.

question_html:
The formula for ammonium phosphate is (NH4)3PO4.

What would be the charge n on a metal ion, Mn+, if the formula of the metal phosphate is MPO4?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
It is important to be familiar with the formulas and charges of polyatomic ions.

Since the ammonium ion is NH4+ and the phosphate ion is PO43–, three ammonium ions are required to balance the charge of every one phosphate ion, hence the formula (NH4)3PO4.

The formula MPO4 is given, so for every one Mn+ ion there is one PO43– ion. This indicates that the metal M has a charge of 3+ to balance out the 3– charge from the phosphate.

question_html:
Which of the following explains why ionic compounds are solids under standard conditions?

I. strong electrostatic attraction between oppositely charged ions

II. ions arranged in a 3D lattice structure

III. delocalised electrons stabilising the structure

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
The strong electrostatic attraction between oppositely charged ions arranged in a 3D lattice is responsible for the high melting points of ionic compounds.

Ionic compounds do not have delocalised electrons in the structure.

question_html: Identify the correct species responsible for electrical conductivity in a sample of molten sodium chloride.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
In a molten, or liquid, sample of sodium chloride, the electrostatic attraction holding the oppositely charged ions fixed in the solid lattice would be overcome. The ions become mobile. Charged species that can move throughout a material give rise to conductivity.

Note that in an ionic compound, the electron transfer has already occurred and delocalised electrons are not present in sodium chloride.

MCQ_set.answer_html: electrons transferring from the metal to the non-metal

question_html: A student performed a serial dilution involving a 1.00 mol dm–3 solution of NaCl. To do this, the student took 10 cm3 of that solution, added it to a 100 cm3 volumetric flask and diluted with water to create dilution #1. The student then took 10 cm3 of dilution #1, added it to a 100 cm3 volumetric flask and diluted with water to create dilution #2. The student repeated this process 3 more times to get dilution #5. Each time the solution is made up to 100 cm3 in the flask. Calculate the concentration of dilution #5 in g cm–3.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
To solve this problem, find the amount in moles taken from the original sample and then calculate the concentration of the diluted solution for each dilution.

Dilution #1

\(\qquad\qquad\begin{align}C&=\dfrac{\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ }\left( 1.00\,\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ mol }\,\!\!~\!\!\text{ d}{{\text{m}}^{-3}} \right)\left( 0.010\,\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ d}{{\text{m}}^{3}} \right)}{\left( 0.100\,\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ d}{{\text{m}}^{3}} \right)}\\ C&=0.100\,\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ mol }\,\!\!~\!\!\text{ d}{{\text{m}}^{-3}}\end{align}\)

After the first dilution it is apparent the concentration is decreased by a factor of 10.

Dilution #2

\(\qquad\qquad C=0.0100\,\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ mol }\,\!\!~\!\!\text{ d}{{\text{m}}^{-3}}\)

Dilution #3

\(\qquad\qquad C=0.0010\,\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ mol }\,\!\!~\!\!\text{ d}{{\text{m}}^{-3}}\)

Dilution #4

\(\qquad\qquad C=0.00010\,\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ mol }\,\!\!~\!\!\text{ d}{{\text{m}}^{-3}}\)

Dilution #5

\(\qquad\qquad C=0.000010\,\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ mol }\,\!\!~\!\!\text{ d}{{\text{m}}^{-3}}\)

Therefore the concentration of dilution #5 is 1.00 × 10–5 mol dm–3.

In order to convert to g cm 3, the mass of NaCl in the amount of solute can be calculated.

\(\qquad\qquad\begin{align}n&=\left( 1.00~\times {{10}^{-5}}\,\text{mol }\,\!\!~\!\!\text{ d}{{\text{m}}^{-3}} \right)\left( 0.100\text{ }\,\!\!~\!\!\text{ d}{{\text{m}}^{3}} \right)\\ n&=1.00\times {{10}^{-6}}\,\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ mol}\end{align}\)

The mass of NaCl can be calculated

\(\qquad\qquad\begin{align}m&=n{{M}_{r}}\\ m&=\left( 1.00\times {{10}^{-6}}\,\text{ }\!\!\!\!\text{ mol} \right)\left( 58.44\,\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ g }\,\!\!~\!\!\text{ mo}{{\text{l}}^{-1}} \right)\\ m&=5.844\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ }\times {{10}^{-5}}\,\text{g}\end{align}\)

The volume in cm3 can be found

\(\qquad\qquad\begin{align}V&=0.100\,\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ d}{{\text{m}}^{3}}\\ V&=100\,\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ c}{{\text{m}}^{3}}\end{align}\)

Concentration in g cm–3 would be:

\(\qquad\qquad\begin{align}C&=\dfrac{m}{V}\\ C&=\dfrac{5.844\times {{10}^{-5}}\,\text{g}}{100\,\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ c}{{\text{m}}^{3}}}\\ C&=5.84\times {{10}^{-7}}\,\text{g }\,\!\!~\!\!\text{ c}{{\text{m}}^{-3}}\end{align}\)

question_html: Which of the following best describes what the notation [CuSO4] means?

MCQ_set.answer_html: The molar concentration of the copper(II) sulfate solution
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The square bracket notation is used to denote the molar concentration of a solution in units of mol dm–3.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The mass of the copper(II) sulfate solute
The volume of the copper(II) sulfate solution
The percentage of the copper(II) sulfate solute

question_html:
In reality, gases deviate from ideal behaviour because of which of the following?

I. Gas particles have a finite volume

II. Gases are not all monatomic

III. Attractive forces exist between gas particles

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
II is a correct statement: gas particles are not necessarily monatomic; however, this does not explain why real gases deviate from ideal behaviour.

In the ideal gas model, it is assumed that the gas particles themselves do not occupy any volume. This assumption works well for systems under low pressures, but at high pressures the volume occupied by gas particles can no longer be considered negligible relative to the total volume.

In the ideal gas model, it is assumed that the gas particles do not interact with one another. At low temperatures, particles become more closely spaced, and forces of attraction become more noticeable. This will have an influence on the volume of the gas that is not accounted for by the ideal gas model.

question_html:
1.50 g of aluminium reacted with 35.0 cm3 of 1.00 mol dm–3 copper(II) chloride solution, producing 1.98 g of solid copper. Calculate the percentage yield for this reaction.

2Al (s) + 3CuCl2 (aq) → 2AlCl3 (aq) + 3Cu (s)

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Since the quantities of both reactants have been provided, the first step will involve determining the limiting reactant in order to calculate the theoretical yield of the solid product (copper).

\(\qquad\qquad\begin{align}n\left( \text{Al} \right)&=~\dfrac{m}{{{M}}}\\ n\left( \text{Al} \right)&=\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ }\dfrac{1.50\,\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ g}}{26.98\,\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ g }\,\!\!~\!\!\text{ mo}{{\text{l}}^{-1}}}\\ n\left( \text{Al} \right)&=0.0556\,\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ mol}\\ n\left( \text{CuC}{{\text{l}}_{2}} \right)&=CV\\ n\left( \text{CuC}{{\text{l}}_{2}} \right)&=\left( 1.00\,\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ mol }\,\!\!~\!\!\text{ d}{{\text{m}}^{-3}} \right)\left( 0.0350\text{ d}{{\text{m}}^{3}} \right)\\ n\left( \text{CuC}{{\text{l}}_{2}} \right)&=0.0350\text{ mol}\end{align}\)

Looking at the coefficients, for every 2 moles of aluminium that react, 3 moles of copper(II) chloride react. This means 3/2 moles more of copper(II) chloride are required than aluminium. Dividing the quantities just calculated by 2 and 3 respectively shows that copper(II) chloride is the limiting reactant and aluminium the excess reactant.

To calculate the theoretical yield we can compare the coefficients of copper(II) chloride to copper, the solid of interest. Since they have the same coefficient, theoretically, the amount in moles will be equivalent.

\(\qquad\qquad n\left( \text{Cu} \right)=\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ }0.0350\,\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ mol}\)

A mass is required for a theoretical yield in order to compare it with the actual yield obtained experimentally.

\(\qquad\qquad\begin{align}m\left( \text{Cu} \right)&=~n{{M}}\\ m\left( \text{Cu} \right)&=\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ }\left( 0.0350\,\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ mol} \right)\left( 63.55\,\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ g }\,\!\!~\!\!\text{ mo}{{\text{l}}^{-1}} \right)\\          m\left( \text{Cu} \right)&=2.22\,\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ g}\end{align}\)

To calculate the percentage yield, a comparison between the actual yield and theoretical yield is required.

\(\qquad\qquad\begin{align}\text{Percentage yield}&=\dfrac{\text{Actual yield}}{\text{Theoretical yield}}\times 100\%\\ \text{Percent  yield}&=\dfrac{1.98}{2.22\,\text{ g}}\times 100\%\\ \text{Percent yield}&=89\%\end{align}\)

question_html:
1.00 g of magnesium ribbon reacted with 25.0 cm3 of 1.00 mol dm–3 hydrochloric acid. Determine the volume, in cm3, of a balloon filled with the hydrogen gas produced at SATP (25°C and 100 kPa).

                Mg(s) + 2HCl(aq) → MgCl2(aq) + H2(g)

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Since quantities of both reactants are provided, it is important first to determine the limiting reactant.

\(\qquad\qquad\begin{align}n\left( \text{Mg} \right)&=\dfrac{m}{{{M}_{r}}}\\ n\left( \text{Mg} \right)&=\dfrac{1.00\,\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ g}}{24.31\,\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ g }\,\!\!~\!\!\text{ mo}{{\text{l}}^{-1}}}\\ n\left( \text{Mg} \right)&=0.0411\,\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ mol}\\ n\left( \text{HCl} \right)\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ }&=\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ }CV\\ n\left( \text{HCl} \right)\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ }&=\left( 1.00\,\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ mol }\,\!\!~\!\!\text{ d}{{\text{m}}^{-3}} \right)\left( 0.025\,\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ d}{{\text{m}}^{3}} \right)\\ n\left( \text{HCl} \right)\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ }&=0.025\,\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ mol}\end{align}\)

It is apparent that there are fewer moles of hydrochloric acid, and that two moles of hydrochloric acid are needed to react with one of magnesium. This means that hydrochloric acid is the limiting reactant and magnesium is the excess reactant.

Now comparing the amount of hydrochloric acid reacting and the amount of hydrogen gas produced, we see there is a 2:1 ratio, so for a given number of moles of hydrochloric acid reacting half that number of moles of hydrogen is produced.

\(\qquad\qquad\begin{align}n\left( {{\text{H}}_{2}} \right)&=\dfrac{n\left( \text{HCl} \right)}{2}\\ n\left( {{\text{H}}_{2}} \right)\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ }&=\dfrac{0.025\,\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ mol}}{2}\\ n\left( {{\text{H}}_{2}} \right)\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ }&=0.0125\,\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ mol}\end{align}\)

Since a gas is formed and the volume is the variable to find, the ideal gas law should be used. It is important to remember that units of Pa must be used for pressure, yielding units of m3 for volume.

\(\qquad\qquad\begin{align}V&=\dfrac{nRT}{P}\\ V&=\dfrac{(\text{0.0125 mol})\,\text{ }\!\!\!\!\text{ }( 8.31\,\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ J }\,\!\!~\!\!\text{ mo}{{\text{l}}^{-1}}\text{ }\,\!\!~\!\!\text{ }{{\text{K}}^{-1}} )( 298\,\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ K})}{100\times {{10}^{3}}\,\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ Pa}}\\ V&=3.10\,\times {{10}^{-4}}{{\text{ m}}^{3}}\\ V&=0.310\,\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ d}{{\text{m}}^{3}}\\ V&=310\,\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ c}{{\text{m}}^{3}}\end{align}\)

question_html:
A student found a 500 cm3 sample of vinegar. Knowing that vinegar is a solution of ethanoic acid (CH3COOH) and water, this student decided to take a 25.0 cm3 sample, dilute it with 25.0 cm3 of water and then react it with sodium hydroxide. The dilute sample required 37.0 cm3 of 0.850 mol dm–3 sodium hydroxide solution to react entirely with it via the following reaction:

                CH3COOH(aq) + NaOH(aq) → NaCH3COO(aq) + H2O(l)

Calculate the concentration of ethanoic acid in the original 500 cm3 sample of vinegar.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
The first step is to find the amount in moles of sodium hydroxide that reacted with the ethanoic acid.

\(\qquad\qquad \begin{align}n\left( \text{NaOH} \right)&=CV\\ n\left( \text{NaOH} \right)&=\left( 0.850\,\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ mol }\,\!\!~\!\!\text{ d}{{\text{m}}^{-3}} \right)\left( 0.0370\,\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ d}{{\text{m}}^{3}} \right)\\ n\left( \text{NaOH} \right)&=0.03145\,\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ mol}\end{align} \)

Since sodium hydroxide and ethanoic acid react in a 1:1 ratio, the amount in moles of ethanoic acid is equivalent to the amount in moles of sodium hydroxide.

\(\qquad\qquad\begin{align}n\left( \text{C}{{\text{H}}_{3}}\text{COOH} \right)&=n\left( \text{NaOH} \right)\\ n\left( \text{C}{{\text{H}}_{3}}\text{COOH} \right)&=0.03145\,\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ mol}\end{align}\)

Note that more than 3 significant figures were used in the intermediate calculations. It is a good idea to leave the full value in your GDC to use for the following steps in your calculations.

There are two ways to approach the next step. Since we are looking for the concentration of the undiluted vinegar sample we could simply use the volume of the vinegar initially sampled, as the entire sample was titrated, although it was diluted.

\(\qquad\qquad\begin{align}C\left( \text{C}{{\text{H}}_{3}}\text{COOH} \right)&=\dfrac{n}{V}\\ C\left( \text{C}{{\text{H}}_{3}}\text{COOH} \right)&=\dfrac{0.03145\,\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ mol}}{0.0250\,\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ d}{{\text{m}}^{3}}}\\ C\left( \text{C}{{\text{H}}_{3}}\text{COOH} \right)&=1.258\,\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ mol }\,\!\!~\!\!\text{ d}{{\text{m}}^{-3}}\end{align}\)

Alternatively, we could find the concentration of the reacted sample (volume 50 cm3) and recognise that this sample was twice as dilute as the original, meaning that the undiluted sample would be twice as concentrated.

\(\qquad\qquad\begin{align}C{{(\text{C}{{\text{H}}_{3}}\text{COOH})}_{\text{dilute}}}&=\dfrac{n}{V}\\ C{{(\text{C}{{\text{H}}_{3}}\text{COOH})}_{\text{dilute}}}&=\dfrac{0.03145\,\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ mol}}{0.0500\,\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ d}{{\text{m}}^{3}}}\\ C{{(\text{C}{{\text{H}}_{3}}\text{COOH})}_{\text{dilute}}}&=0.629\,\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ mol }\!\!~\!\!\text{ d}{{\text{m}}^{-3}}\\ C{{(\text{C}{{\text{H}}_{3}}\text{COOH})}_{\text{undiluted}}}&=2\times C{{(\text{C}{{\text{H}}_{3}}\text{COOH})}_{\text{dilute}}}\\ C{{(\text{C}{{\text{H}}_{3}}\text{COOH})}_{\text{undiluted}}}&=2\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ }\left( 0.629\,\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ mol }\!\!~\!\!\text{ d}{{\text{m}}^{-3}} \right)\\ C{{(\text{C}{{\text{H}}_{3}}\text{COOH})}_{\text{undiluted}}}&=1.258\,\text{ }\!\!~\!\!\text{ mol }\!\!~\!\!\text{ d}{{\text{m}}^{-3}}\end{align}\)

question_html:
A student conducted a titration to determine the concentration of a 50.0 cm3 sample of HCl using 0.10 mol dm–3 NaOH as the titrant. The student conducted four trials of the titration using phenolphthalein as an indicator. Below are the results. Calculate the average volume of NaOH solution used for this titration.

Trial 1 (rough) Trial 2 Trial 3 Trial 4
Initial volume of NaOH /cm3 0.37 2.84 1.39 1.62
Final volume of NaOH /cm3 26.75 28.82 27.33 27.65
Qualitative observations Change from colourless to dark pink Change from colourless to faint pink Change from colourless to faint pink Change from colourless to faint pink

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
The first step here is to calculate the volumes of NaOH solution added for each trial, followed by taking an average.

Trial 1 Trial 2 Trial 3 Trial 4
Volume of NaOH added (cm3) 26.38 25.98 25.94 26.03

The next thing to note is that in a titration the first trial is usually the least accurate trial (sometimes known as the 'rough trial'). This is because the endpoint volume is not yet suspected, so it is difficult to titrate slowly near the endpoint. In this case, the first trial had a dark pink solution at the endpoint, indicating over-titration of the acid. Generally, the results from the first trial are therefore discarded. This would mean we average the volume of NaOH added for trials 2, 3 and 4, resulting in an average volume of 25.98 cm3.

question_html: The term relative atomic mass is best defined as which of the following?

MCQ_set.answer_html: The weighted average mass of naturally occurring isotopes of an element compared with 1/12 the mass of an atom of carbon-12
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
The term relative atomic mass tells us that the atomic mass is relative to some standard. The isotope of carbon with a mass number of 12 is chosen as the reference standard for the relative scale of atomic masses.

Since carbon-12 has 6 protons and 6 neutrons, it has 12 atomic mass units. In order to compare with other elements, one atomic mass unit must be established. This is where the part of the description “compared with 1/12 the mass of an atom of carbon-12” comes from.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The weighted average mass of naturally occurring isotopes of an element
The average number of neutrons and protons within the element
The weighted average mass of naturally occurring isotopes of an element compared with the mass of an atom of carbon-12

question_html:
A student mixed 20.0 cm3 of water with 20.0 cm3 of ethanol and found the resultant volume to be 38.7 cm3. Calculate the density of the resultant mixture.

(Note: Density of water is 1.00 g cm–3 and density of ethanol is 0.789 g cm–3.)

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Note that the resultant volume is smaller than the sum of the total. This decrease is due to the forces of attraction between the two solutions upon mixing (intermolecular forces). Since the total volume is known and

\(\qquad\qquad d=\dfrac{m}{V}\),

the total mass of the substance needs to be found. Mass must be conserved, so the total mass of the mixture will be the same as the sum of the masses of the individual substances.

For water, since the density is 1.00 g cm–3 and the volume used is 20.0 cm–3:

\(\qquad\qquad\begin{align}m &= dV\\ m &= 1.00\text{ g cm}^{–3} × 20.0\text{ cm}^{3}\\ m &= 20.0\text{ g}\end{align}\)

For ethanol, since the density is 0.789 g cm–3 and the volume is 20.0 cm–3:

\(\qquad\qquad\begin{align}m &= dV\\ m &= 0.789\text{ g cm}^{–3} × 20.0\text{ cm}^{3}\\ m &= 15.78\text{ g}\end{align}\)

To calculate the density of the solution:

\(\qquad\qquad \begin{align}d&=\dfrac{m}{V}\\ d&=\dfrac{\left( 20.0\text{ g}~+\text 15.78\text{ g} \right)}{38.7\text{ cm}^{3}}\\ d&=0.925\text{ g cm}^{-3}\end{align} \)

question_html: Which of the following is not a name associated with a change of state?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Condensation is the change in state from a gas to a liquid. Sublimation is the change in state from a solid to a gas. Deposition is the change in state from a gas to a solid. In chemistry, precipitation is the creation of a solid from a reaction in solution. This is an example of a chemical change rather than a physical change. The term can be confusing, as in meteorology, the term precipitation refers to the condensation of water vapour (rain).

question_html: Which of the following molecules contains a coordinate covalent bond?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Water, ammonia, and carbon dioxide all have 'regular' covalent bonds between their atoms in which each atom donates one electron to the bond. Ozone has a coordinate covalent bond between two of the oxygen atoms. This can be seen by drawing out the Lewis structure for ozone. Note that once formed, coordinate covalent bonds are identical to 'regular' covalent bonds.

question_html: Which of the following is the correct molecular geometry of the molecule xenon tetrafluoride (XeF4) ?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The four bonding domains are arranged around the xenon atom in a square planar arrangement with a bond angle of 90o. The two non-bonding domains are arranged at 180o to each other above and below the xenon atom. This arrangement minimises the repulsion between the non-bonding domains.

question_html: Apart from having a cyclic structure, which other feature causes molecules to have cis and trans forms?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: These features prevent rotation around the carbon-carbon axis which means that one form of the molecule cannot simply rotate into the other form.

question_html: 0.200 mol of calcium fluoride, CaF2, is added to 50.0 cm3 of distilled water which is then made up to a total volume of 250 cm3. Determine the concentration of the solution, in mol dm–3.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Using the equation C = n/V (in dm3):

C = 0.200 / (250/1000) = 0.800 mol dm–3

Note that the volume must be converted to dm3 by dividing cm3 by 1000.

question_html: Which of the two graphs below represent a reaction at equilibrium?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The graph on the left shows that, at equilibrium, the concentrations of reactants and products are constant (not equal) and the graph on the right shows that the rate of the forward reaction is equal to the rate of the reverse reaction. Both of these are features of a reaction at equilibrium.

question_html: Markovnikov’s rule is used to predict the products for which type of reaction?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Markovnikov’s rule is used to predict the products of an electrophilic addition reaction. This rule states that the electrophilic portion of the molecule will add to the carbon atom involved in the double bond that already has the most hydrogen atoms bonded to it. This arises from the fact that the carbocation intermediate involved in the addition will be more stable.

question_html: Red cabbage (Brassica oleracea capitata rubra) can be used as a natural pH indicator: its pigments change colour in response to varying pH levels. Using section 17 and section 35 of your IB data booklet to help you, determine which of the following wavelengths of light would be most strongly absorbed by red cabbage indicator mixed with aqueous carbonic acid.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct because red cabbage contains anthocyanin molecules, which tend to be red in acidic solution. The complementary colour of light is therefore most strongly absorbed, which is green (491nm to 575nm).

question_html: Carbon monoxide is poisonous. Which of the following best describes why?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Carbon monoxide binds at the same site in hemoglobin as the oxygen and shifts the oxygen dissociation curve to the left
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Carbon monoxide binds to hemoglobin at the same site as the oxygen, forming carboxyhemoglobin. It is therefore acting as a competitive inhibitor, reducing oxygen released, and will have shifted the dissociation curve to the left.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Carbon monoxide binds at the same site in hemoglobin as the oxygen and shifts the oxygen dissociation curve to the right
Carbon monoxide binds at a different site in hemoglobin to the oxygen and shifts the oxygen dissociation curve to the left
Carbon monoxide binds at a different site in hemoglobin to the oxygen and shifts the oxygen dissociation curve to the right

question_html: Which of the following would be the polymer formed from the reaction of 1,3-propanediol with pentanedioic acid?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
1,3-propanediol: HOCH2CH2CH2OH

Pentanedioic acid: HOOCCH2CH2CH2COOH

n HOCH2CH2CH2OH + n HOOCCH2CH2CH2COOH → (-OCH2CH2CH2OOCCH2CH2CH2CO-)n + (2n-1)H2O

question_html:
Which of the following is correct?

I. Addition polymers use an alkene monomer.

II. Condensation polymers require monomers each with one functional group.

III. Condensation polymerisation has less than 100% atom economy.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Addition polymers involve an alkene monomer where the double bond breaks in order to polymerise. This results in a polymer material where all of the starting materials are in the desired polymer. This means that addition polymers have a 100% atom economy. 

Condensation polymers require monomers with two functional groups. For example, an ester can form when the hydroxyl group on an alcohol reacts with the carboxyl group on a carboxylic acid. A polyester forms when two hydroxyl groups (one on either end of the monomer) react with two carboxyl groups on a carboxylic acid. Without having two functional groups, a polymer would not form, only a simple ester. 

During the formation of a polyester from a dialcohol and dicarboxylic acid water is also produced as a product. This means that some of the atoms in the starting materials are not ending up in the desired polymer product. This would result in an atom economy of less than 100% for condensation polymer formation.

question_html:
Determine the density of silicon in a simple cubic structure. 

Note: For silicon r=114 pm and Mr = 28.09

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
In a simple cubic structure, the length of the unit cell is twice the radius length. Therefore the volume of the unit cell is V = (2r)3.

A unit cell contains only one full atom, therefore the mass of one atom is m = Mr / NA

Thus density of silicon = Mr /(NA(2r)3)

Density = (28.09)/[(6.02×1023)(2×114×10-12)3]

Density = 3.94 × 106 g m-3

Density = 3.94 g cm-3

question_html: Which of the following would be the correct identification of the unit cell from the following crystal lattice?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Looking at the lattice, the first thing we need to do is identify the unit cell. The unit cell is the smallest repeating unit within the lattice. The smallest repeating unit of this structure would be with 8 of the dark grey atoms in the corner of a cubic structure, with one light grey atom in the centre. Having 8 corner atoms and 1 centre atom will form a body-centred cubic (BCC) structure.

question_html:
Which of the following explains superconducting behaviour under the Bardeen-Cooper-Schrieffer (BCS) theory?

I. Above a critical temperature, electrons form Cooper pairs.

II. Electron movement distorts the crystal lattice.

III. Cooper pairs move freely throughout the superconducting lattice.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: At temperatures below the critical temperature, the cations interact with a moving electron, which in turn interacts with another electron. As an electron passes through the lattice, the positive cations are attracted to the electron, distorting the lattice as the cations are drawn to it. This distortion will leave a localised positive region in the lattice that will attract a neighbouring electron. The two electrons move throughout the material in unison. This pair of electrons is called a Cooper pair, as this pair is able to move more freely throughout a metallic lattice than a single electron.

question_html: Which of the following is the ability of a superconductor to create a mirror image magnetic field of an external field, thus expelling it?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The Meissner effect is the ability of a superconductor to create a mirror image magnetic field of an external field, thus expelling it. When a superconductor is cooled below its critical temperature, the superconductor acts as a perfect diamagnet, creating a temporary magnetic field in order to directly oppose an applied magnetic field. While this effect can cause levitation, it is not known as the levitation theorem, therefore @4 would be incorrect. Options @2 and @3 are involved in the theory to explain how zero resistance is reached when the material is below a critical temperature for superconducting metals. BCS theory explains zero resistance, not levitation.

question_html:
Which of the following is correct for a metal with a simple cubic lattice structure?

I. Number of atoms within each unit cell is 8

II. Coordination number of each atom is 6

III. All atoms are located on the corners of the cubic unit cell

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
In a simple cubic structure, the atoms are located on the corners of the unit cell like the image below shows.

Coordination numbers are the number of nearest neighbours of an atom or ion. What is important is that we consider multiple unit cells aligned side-by-side in order to determine the coordination numbers of atoms. In this case, if we pick a corner atom, we can see that 7 more unit cells could be attached to that each of the unit cells shares the corner atom. Looking at multiple unit cells side-by-side we can see that the coordination number is 6. This is illustrated below.

In order to count the number of atoms in a unit cell, we must consider whether the atom in the unit cell is a corner, face, edge or body atom. In a simple cubic structure, there are only corner atoms, and each corner atom contributes 1/8 of an atom to the unit cell itself. This means that there are 8 corner atoms each contributing 1/8 for a total of 1 atom per unit cell.

question_html:
Which of the following are concerns about materials made from PVC?

I. Hormone-disrupting chlorinated dioxins can be released during combustion of PVC.

II. Volatile plasticisers which can disrupt the endocrine system can escape from PVC when heated.

III. Contributors to acid deposition can be released during combustion of PVC.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: When PVC has combusted both dioxins and polychlorinated biphenyls can be released into the atmosphere. These dioxins are toxic and can disrupt the secretion and function of many hormones. When PVC materials are heated, the plasticisers within the material can evaporate from the plastic and into the atmosphere. The more volatile, low molecular weight, phthalates are known endocrine disruptors. When PVC is combusted, hydrochloric acid (HCl) is also produced as a product. This HCl produced is a contributor to acid deposition in the atmosphere. Therefore all three statements are valid concerns with regards to PVC plastic.

question_html: Which of the following is not involved the arc discharge of a hydrocarbon solvent in the production of carbon nanotubes?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Carbon nanotubes form on the surface of the anode
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: In this method, two metal electrodes are placed into a hydrocarbon solvent in close proximity to one another. A plasma arc forms between the two electrodes that can conduct electricity. The applied voltage causes the oxidation and decomposition of the hydrocarbon at the surface of the anode. Reduction of the hydrocarbon solvent into carbon occurs at the surface of the cathode. Carbon self-assembles into soot, single-walled carbon nanotubes, multi-walled carbon nanotubes and fullerenes at the surface of the cathode. This method uses inert electrodes to avoid replacing electrodes on a regular basis.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Inert electrodes are placed into a hydrocarbon solvent

question_html:
Which of the following explain why carbon nanotubes are strong and good conductors of electricity?

I. Delocalised electrons 

II. Single chain of covalent bonds

III. Tetrahedral arrangement of carbon atoms

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Carbon nanotubes can be thought of as a rolled-up sheet of graphene. In graphene, carbon atoms are arranged in a trigonal planar arrangement where electrons (pi electrons) are delocalised along the sheet. In carbon nanotubes, this arrangement and the delocalisation of electrons are maintained. The delocalisation of electrons is what makes carbon nanotubes good conductors of electricity. The cylindrical nature of carbon nanotubes is made up from a single chain of covalent bonds. This single chain is difficult to break and results in a very strong material. This would make only options I and II correct.

question_html: Which of the following is not a method that can be used to modify the properties of polymers?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Option @1 is incorrect because although increased branching does result in different polymer properties, it would not be a method used to modify the properties, i.e. it would be the result as opposed to the method. Option @2 is a method used to make polystyrene light and useful as a packing material. Option @3 is often used to make plastics made from PVC more flexible. Option @4 can result in polymers with varying properties. For example, during the synthesis of polyethene, if the addition polymerisation proceeds via the free radical mechanism, then a very branched polymer is formed, creating a low-density plastic material (LDPE). If the addition polymerisation proceeds in the presence of a Ziegler-Natta catalyst, then a polymer with minimal branching is formed, creating a high-density plastic material (HDPE).

question_html: Which of the following is a concern of using genetically modified organisms (GMO)?

MCQ_set.answer_html: The ability of a GM food to trigger an allergy in humans.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Genes used in GM technology might be taken from a food that causes allergies in certain people.

question_html:
Which of the following is correct with respect to inductively coupled plasma methods?

ICP-MS ICP-OES
A

Emitted photons from the excited electrons returning to the ground state are detected.

 Ions are deflected in the presence of a magnetic field.
B Good sensitivity. Extremely sensitive.
C Good for quantifying samples with unknown elements. Good for quantifying samples where elements are known.
D A spectrometer is used to analyse the wavelength and intensity of light emitted. A spectrometer is used to analyse the mass-to-charge ratio of ions.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: As a sample interacts with the ICP argon plasma, the elements are atomised, ionised and electrons from the sample are excited. ICP-MS analyses the mass-to-charge ratios of different species whereas ICP-OES analyses the emitted photons from excited state electrons returning to the ground state. ICP-MS utilises a mass spectrometer which deflects ions in the presence of a magnetic field. ICP-OES analyses the intensity of emitted light for a specific wavelength. ICP-MS is much better at quantifying samples with unknown samples with extreme sensitivity since the mass-to-charge ratio is analysed. ICP-OES is a good technique when the element of interest is already identified in a sample. A calibration curve can be created in order to quantify the concentrations of species in a sample. Using a calibration curve does have a lower sensitivity in comparison to using ICP-MS.

question_html: Inductively coupled plasma (ICP) spectroscopy utilises an argon plasma. Which of the following best describes the production of this plasma?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Argon atoms passing through a Tesla coil are ionised by strong electromagnetic fields.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
In order to produce the argon plasma, a sample of argon gas is passed through a Tesla coil. The Tesla coil uses a high current and a radio frequency to generate a high-energy spark. This spark has a high enough energy to ionise the argon sample. The Ar+ ions and electrons produced interact with the magnetic field caused by the applied radiofrequency, causing the electrons in the sample to flow rotationally. The result is a high-temperature plasma of about 7000 K that is capable of atomising and ionising samples.

Options @2 and @3 are incorrect because argon atoms, not ions, pass through the Tesla coil before being atomised and ionised. Option @4 is incorrect because a Tesla coil, not a furnace, is used to produce a spark to atomise and ionise argon atoms.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Argon ions passing through a Tesla coil are atomised by strong electromagnetic fields.
Argon ions are passed through a Tesla coil to generate strong currents.
Argon atoms are heated to 7000 K in a furnace.

question_html: Which reaction produces trans-fatty acids during food processing?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct. The hydrogenation of vegetable oils is a process that occurs to make an unsaturated oil into a saturated fat by adding hydrogen gas to a polyunsaturated fatty acid. This is often done to turn a liquid oil into a solid so it can be, for example, spread.

question_html: When a sugar cyclises, it converts to a ring structure that introduces an additional chiral carbon, as compared to its straight chain form. Two different enantiomers of these cyclic sugars exist, referred to as α or β. The only difference between these enantiomers is in the direction that -H and -OH groups point on which carbon?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct. The difference between α and β sugars lies with the orientation of the -OH group on carbon 1. For example, D-glucose can exist in two forms α-D-glucose and β-D-glucose. They differ only in the direction that -H and -OH groups point on carbon 1.

question_html: Which type of linkages does cellulose contain?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct because cellulose is a polymer of β-glucose monomers joined by β1,4-glycosidic linkages. The straight chain component of starch, amylose, is a polymer of α-glucose monomers joined by α1,4-glycosidic linkages. The branched portion of starch, amylopectin, and glycogen are both polymers of α-glucose joined by α1,4 and α1,6 linkages. Peptide linkages occur in proteins.

question_html: Retinal (or retinaldehyde) plays an essential role in our vision. It is derived by oxidising a compound called retinol in our diet, which can be found in green vegetables and fruit. What is retinol more commonly called?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct: retinol is often called vitamin A and this is why sufficient amounts of vitamin A are needed for vision. A lack of vitamin A can cause a condition called night blindness.

question_html: Unsaturated fatty acids can exist as stereoisomers due to the presence of a C=C double bond. Which of the isomers, cis or trans, is likely to have the highest melting point and why?

MCQ_set.answer_html: trans because they have straighter chains and therefore stronger intermolecular forces
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct. trans-isomers have straighter chains and therefore have stronger intermolecular forces between the chains. cis-isomers tend to have a 'kink' in the chain which means that the chains cannot pack so closely together. This results in weaker intermolecular forces between the chains and a lower melting point.

MCQ_set.answer_html: cis because they have straighter chains and therefore stronger intermolecular forces
cis because they have cross-links between the chains
trans because they have cross-links between the chains

question_html: Amino acid tablets are becoming increasingly popular with athletes and body builders as they are a convenient way to add a large amount of amino acids into the diet. However, they are not as good a source as naturally occurring proteins because they are produced synthetically and therefore contain a racemic mixture of the amino acids. What proportion of the tablet is likely to be the L-isomers and therefore be useful to the human body?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct because a racemic mixture contains a 50:50 mixture of the D and L isomers.

question_html: D-phenylalanine is an enantiomer of the amino acid phenylalanine. Will D-phenylalanine be a (+) or (-) isomer?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct. The only way to know if an isomer is a (+) or (-) enantiomer is to see which way it rotates plane-polarised light i.e. by experimentation.

question_html: Alanine is an amino acid with the formula NH2-CH(CH3)-COOH. This means it can exist as which isomers?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct because alanine has a chiral carbon and can therefore exist as two optical isomers, D and L. @2 is incorrect because alanine does not have a C=C and/or is not cyclic and therefore cannot exist in cis and trans forms. @3 is incorrect because alanine is not IUPAC nomenclature and the numbers 1 and 2 here are meaningless. @4 is incorrect because alanine only contains 2 carbon atoms and therefore cannot exist as branched isomers.

question_html:
Limonene is a hydrocarbon which exists as two optical isomers (enantiomers). In which of the following ways would the two enantiomers D-limonene and L-limonene differ?

I. Taste

II. Smell

III. Melting point

IV. Rotation of plane polarised light

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct because isomers have different smells and tastes as they have different shapes and fit into the receptors in our noses and on our tongues differently. For example, D-limonene smells of oranges and L-limonene has a lemon-like aroma. They can also be distinguished due to the fact that they rotate plane-polarised light in opposite directions. However, enantiomers have identical physical properties, such as melting point.

question_html:
The balance between oxygen and carbon dioxide in the atmosphere is an important one. Which of the following can lead to an increase in the proportion of carbon dioxide present in the air? 

I. Increased amount of photosynthesis occurring due to higher numbers of crops being grown.

II. Increased amount of respiration due to human population increase.

III. Increased combustion of fossil fuels.

IV. Increased usage of nuclear energy.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct. More humans will respire more and burn more fossil fuels and both of these processes will produce more carbon dioxide (and also use up more oxygen). @2, @3 and @4 are incorrect because photsynthesis uses up carbon dioxide and produces oxygen and nuclear energy does not emit air pollution of any kind.

question_html: Thin layer chromatography (TLC) is carried out on a mixture of various carotene molecules. Which of the following would be suitable to use as the mobile phase?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct as carotenes are non-polar and therefore a non-polar solvent should be used.

question_html: Thin layer chromatography is performed upon a biological pigment. Heptane is used as the solvent and moves 16.5 cm up the plate. The pigment travels 95 mm. What is the retention factor (Rf) of this pigment?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
@1 is correct. Both distances must be converted into the same units and then Rf = distance moved by solute (the pigment) / distance moved by the solvent (heptane) = 95/165 = 0.58.

@2 is incorrect as the units have not been converted; 95/16.5 = 5.8.

@3 is incorrect as the solvent distance has been divided by the solute distance; 165/95 = 1.7.

@4 is incorrect as it has been converted into a percentage; (95/165)×100 = 58.

question_html: What is the best description of why pigments are coloured?

MCQ_set.answer_html: They strongly absorb in the visible region of the electromagnetic spectrum
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct. The colour of pigments is due to highly conjugated systems with delocalised electrons, which have intense absorption bands in the visible region.

MCQ_set.answer_html: They actively reflect in the visible region of the electromagnetic spectrum
They weakly absorb wavelengths in the 400 to 700nm range of the electromagnetic spectrum
They absorb both IR and UV light

question_html: Depending on the conditions metal A can exist in various crystal structures. In which crystal structure variation would the density be the highest?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Face-centred cubic has the highest number of atoms per unit cell (4). This would give it the largest density in comparison to the others. @2 has 2 atoms per unit cell, @3 has 1 atom per unit cell and @4 is not a crystal structure variation.

question_html: Which of the following best describes resistance in a metal?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Collisions between electrons and vibrating positive ions of the lattice.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Resistance is the opposition a material has against the flow of electric charges. Conductivity and resistance are inversely proportional to one another. In a metal, resistance is from the collisions between delocalised electrons and metal cations. As an electron collides with a vibrating metal cation, it loses kinetic energy, reducing the ability of electric charges to be able to flow.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Electrons vibrate in the metal, opposing the motion of cations.
Electrons absorb energy and are put into an excited state while travelling through the material.
Electrons moving through the lattice induce a magnetic field opposing the motion of electrons.

question_html: X-rays are used to find information about crystal lattices that have crystal planes separated by distance d. If the x-ray hits the surface of the crystal at angle θ, what must the extra path length of the x-rays travelled be for constructive interference to occur?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The difference in path length travelled by x-rays must be an integer multiple of wavelength in order for constructive interference to occur. Bragg's equation relates the lattice spacing d to the angles at which constructive interference is observed.
