question_html: The substances that make up our material world can usually be placed into four distinct classes. Which of the following is not one of those classes?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The four distinct classes of materials are 1) metals, 2) polymers, 3) ceramics and 4) composites. Although gases are readily required in the production of various materials, the class of gases themselves would not be considered a distinct class of materials.

question_html: Which of the following best describes permeability?

MCQ_set.answer_html: The ability of a porous material to pass certain species through it.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Permeability is a property of porous materials to pass smaller atoms, ions and molecules through the pores. Passing species through a material is often referred to as permeating. Option @2 would describe elasticity and option @4 would describe conductivity. If a material is malleable, this would not influence the permeability of the material, therefore @3 is incorrect.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The ability of a material to stretch and compress.
The ability of a material to be malleable.
The ability of a material to allow electrons to move freely within the structure.

question_html:
Which of the following represents the percent covalent character of alumina?

(The electronegativities of aluminium and oxygen are 1.6 and 3.4 respectively)

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Alumina is Al2O3. The difference in electronegativities is 3.4 - 1.6 = 1.8.

% Ionic character = (1.8/3.2) × 100%

% Ionic character = 56.25%

% Covalent character = 100.00% - 56.25%

% Covalent character = 43.75%

question_html: What is the percent ionic character of lithium chloride? (Electronegativities of lithium and chlorine are 1.0 and 3.2 respectively)

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Difference in electronegativity = 2.2

% ionic character = (2.2/3.2) × 100%

% ionic character = 68.8%

question_html: Cytochromes can act as oxidising agents. Which of the following options best describes how they do this?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Their iron(III) ions gain one electron to become iron(II)
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct. Cytochromes contain heme groups in which the iron ion interconverts between iron(II) and iron(III) during redox reactions. When acting as an oxidising agent, the iron(III) would become reduced to iron(II).

MCQ_set.answer_html: Their iron(II) ions are reduced to iron atoms
Their iron(II) ions are oxidised to iron(III)

question_html: Refer to the structures of anthocyanins shown in section 35 of your data booklet to help you to answer this question. Suggest which of the following is commonly added to blueberries whilst cooking in order to preserve their characteristic blue colour?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Baking soda (bicarbonate of soda or sodium hydrogen carbonate) is often used so @1 is correct. It is basic and so shifts the equilibrium towards the blue quinoidal base. @2 is a strong base and so would be corrosive. @3 is neutral and @4 is acidic so they would be ineffective.

question_html:
Sodium nitrite is often added to red meat to convert the myoglobin to nitrosomyoglobin, which gives the meat an appealing red colour. Which other conditions may affect the colour of red meat?

I. Standing in air

II. Cooking

III. Marinading in an acidic sauce

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Red meat contains a pigment called myoglobin. Myoglobin is a protein, which is sensitive to changes in heat and pH. It also binds to oxygen. All of these factors will lead to a change in the configuration of the protein and therefore potentially change its colour, so @1 is correct.

question_html: Which of the following is the best explanation for why chlorophyll is necessary for photosynthesis to occur?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Chlorophyll harvests the light energy needed for the endothermic reaction to occur.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct because photosynthesis is an endothermic process, which therefore requires an input of energy to occur.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Chlorophyll releases the light energy needed for the endothermic reaction to occur.
Chlorophyll uses light energy from the sun to create the bonds in the glucose molecules produced.
Chlorophyll absorbs the energy needed to enable the catabolic process to occur.

question_html:
The overall reaction for the Haber-Weiss process is shown below.

·O2- (aq) + H2O2 (aq) → ·OH (aq) + OH- (aq) + O2 (g)

This reaction is an example of:

I. Disproportionation

II. Termination

III. Forming DNA-damaging products

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The Haber-Weiss process is the process of forming harmful hydroxyl free radicals in the body that can be catalysed from toxic heavy metals in the body. These hydroxyl free radicals are capable of damaging DNA, proteins and lipids within the body. Since it involves free radicals we can also analyse the type of reaction from a free radical perspective. Since a free radical is involved in both reactants and products, this would be an example of a propagation reaction, not a termination reaction. This is an example of a disproportionation reaction, since if we compare the oxidation state of oxygen in hydrogen peroxide (-1) the oxidation state decreases to form oxygen gas (0) and increases to form hydroxide (-2). Since both reduction and oxidation are occurring, this would be an example of a disproportionation reaction.

question_html: Which of the following expressions would represent the concentration of free silver ions present from dissociation of silver sulfate?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Ag2SO4 (s) ⇌ 2Ag+ (aq) + SO42- (aq)

Assuming that there are no excess sulfate ions, for every 2 Ag+ ions produced, 1 SO42- ion will be produced. This means that the concentration of sulfate can be represented as:

\([SO_4^{2-}] = {[Ag^{+}] \over 2}\)

Therefore the solubility product for Ksp

\(K_{sp}=[Ag^{+}]^2[SO_4^{2-}]\)

becomes

\(K_{sp}={[Ag^{+}]^3 \over 2}\)

Rearranging for silver

\([Ag^{+}]=(2K_{sp})^{1/3}\)

question_html: What is the concentration (in mol dm-3) of zinc ions (Zn2+) present when zinc ions are precipitated using sodium hydroxide that is added with 0.5 mol in excess in a 1 dm3 container?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Zn(OH)2 (s) ⇌ Zn2+ (aq) + 2OH- (aq)

\(K_{sp}=[Zn^{2+}][OH^{-}]^2\)

Where Ksp = 3.0 × 10-17

\([Zn^{2+}]={K_{sp} \over [OH^{-}]^2}\)

\([Zn^{2+}]={3.0 \times 10^{-17} \over (0.5)^2}\)

[Zn2+] = 1.2 × 10-16 mol dm-3

question_html:
The 'insoluble' salt nickel(II) carbonate actually exists in the following equilibrium with its dissociated ions:

NiCO3 (s) ⇌ Ni2+ (aq) + CO32- (aq)

Which of the following methods could be used to reduce the quantity of nickel ions dissociated in water?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: In order to reduce the quantity of nickel ions, we would want to shift the equilibrium to the left to utilise Le Châtelier's Principle. In order to shift the equilibrium left, we would want to add more products to the overall reaction mixture. By adding carbonate ions to the equilibrium mixture, the equilibrium can be shifted left and reduce the quantity of nickel ions in solution. This would leave options @1 and @3. Looking at either a solubility table or Section 32 of the Chemistry data booklet, we can see that CdCO3 is a precipitate formed when cadmium is in the presence of carbonate. Therefore @3 would not be a good choice as there would not be free carbonate ions available to react with the nickel ions in solution.

question_html: Which of the following methods would be used to remove heavy metal ions from the body?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: If the heavy metal ions have made their way into the body, it would be extremely difficult to perform techniques such as electrolysis, adsorption or precipitation. The most likely method would be to ingest a chelating agent, such as EDTA, that would be capable of binding to the heavy metal ion, forming a complex and then excreting the complex, say through the urine. This is currently a method employed, referred to as chelation therapy.

section_title: Toxicity and removal of heavy metal ions

question_html:
Which of the following complexes would be the most stable?

Note: NH3 is ammonia, ed is ethanedioate, en is ethane-1,2-diamine, and EDTA is ethylenediaminetetraacetate

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The greater the number of bonds that a ligand can make with a transition metal complex, the greater the stability of the complex ion formed. In [Cu(EDTA)]2- there are six coordinate bonds made with the copper(II) ion, increasing the stability from [Cu(en)3]2+ and [Cu(ed)3]2+, where there are three ligands bonding each with two coordinate bonds, and [Cu(NH3)6]2+, where there are six ligands bonding each with only one coordinate bond to the copper ion.

section_title: Toxicity and removal of heavy metal ions

question_html: Identify which of the following molecules cannot act as a chelate to a transition metal centre.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A chelate is a ligand that is capable of forming two or more coordinate bonds with a transition metal centre. Ammonia only has one lone pair and therefore is only able to form one coordinate bond with a transition metal. Options @3 and @4 are both bidentate ligands, capable of forming two coordinate bonds with a transition metal centre. @2 is a hexadentate ligand, capable of forming six coordinate bonds with a transition metal centre.

section_title: Toxicity and removal of heavy metal ions

question_html:
The ethanedioate ion, shown below, is capable of acting as which of the following:

I. Chelate

II. Bronsted-Lowry base

III. Ligand

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Since ethanedioate (structure located in section 16 of Chemistry data booklet) has two lone pairs, it is capable of acting as a chelate, forming multiple coordinate bonds with a transition metal ion centre. A chelate is where a ligand forms two or more coordinate bonds, so this would imply that it is also a ligand. A Bronsted-Lowry base is capable of accepting a proton. Since the ethandioate anion has two negative oxygen ends, each end is capable of accepting a proton in order to form ethanedioic acid. Therefore all three suggestions would be correct for the ethanedioate ion.

section_title: Toxicity and removal of heavy metal ions

question_html: Which of the following ways is not a way for adsorption of a metal ion to a solid support to occur?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Chelation involves ligands forming coordinate bonds with a metal ion centre. For this to occur efficiently, the ligand molecule should be free in solution in order to maximise probability of collision with the metal ion. This would not be very efficient if chelation was to occur at the surface of a solid support. Options @2, @3 and @4 are all processes that can occur at the surface of a solid support (surface, zeolite, carbon nanotubes, resin, etc.).

section_title: Toxicity and removal of heavy metal ions

question_html:
Which of the following are reasons why transition metals are toxic?

I. Transition metals can disturb the normal oxidation/reduction balance in cells through various mechanisms.

II. Transition metals can catalyse reactions that produce harmful hydroxyl free radicals.

III. Transition metal can disturb the interactions of proteins and enzymes with essential nutrients.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The presence of transition metals in the body is toxic, even at small doses. Since transition metals have various oxidation states, they can gain and lose electrons readily. This disturbs the normal oxidation/reduction processes in cells and act as a catalyst in the formation of hydroxyl free radicals in the Haber-Weiss process. The presence of transition metals in the body interrupts the interaction between proteins and enzymes with essential nutrients. For example, sulfur-containing amino acids will preferentially bond to mercury. This prevents the amino acids from interacting with the essential nutrient selenium.

section_title: Toxicity and removal of heavy metal ions

question_html: Identify the method for removal of lead ions in water using sodium hydroxide.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: In this question, we are told that sodium hydroxide is added to water. Looking at section 32 of the Chemistry data booklet, we can see that lead ions form an 'insoluble' precipitate in the presence of hydroxide ions. The Ksp value for lead hydroxide is very low, indicating that it is fairly insoluble. Therefore precipitation would be the most appropriate choice of removal.

section_title: Toxicity and removal of heavy metal ions

question_html: Which of the following salts would not form a precipitate?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Either using a solubility table or relating to the heavy metal precipitates listed in section 32 of the Chemistry data booklet, we can see that PbSO4, NiCO3, and Cd(OH)2 are all listed as insoluble or heavy metal precipitates. This would leave AgNO3 as the last possible option that will not form a precipitate. In general, nitrates form soluble solutions, even when combined with heavy metal ions that typically form precipitates.

section_title: Toxicity and removal of heavy metal ions

question_html: A DNA strand with the sequence AACGTAACG is transcribed. What is the sequence of the mRNA molecule synthesised?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: During transcription, one strand of the DNA, the template strand (or non-coding strand), is used as a template for RNA synthesis. The mRNA produced pairs A to U, G to C, C to G and T to A.

question_html: Which nitrogenous bases does an mRNA molecule contain?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct because RNA contains four different bases. Three of these are the same as in DNA: adenine, guanine, and cytosine. Unlike DNA, RNA contains uracil instead of thymine.

section_title: The structures of DNA and RNA

question_html: The amino acid sequence of a polypeptide chain represents which structure of the protein?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The primary structure of a protein refers to the linear sequence of amino acids joined by peptide (covalent) bonds in the polypeptide chain.

question_html: What is the process of copying a gene's DNA sequence into a sequence of RNA called?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: During transcription a segment of DNA is copied into mRNA.

question_html: Which molecule contains the genetic code?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The genetic code by which DNA stores the genetic information consists of 'codons' of three nucleotides. It is then transcribed into mRNA.

question_html: What is the origin of the negative charge of DNA?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct because phosphate groups, which are negatively charged, give DNA molecules a negative charge.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The carboxylic acid group of the nucleic acid.
The nitrogen atoms of the nitrogenous base.

section_title: The structures of DNA and RNA

question_html: GMO foods are becoming increasingly common around the world. Which of the following is an incorrect statement with regard to foods derived from genetically modified organisms?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: GMO foods can be modified with regard to their flavour but this is subjective. Many people think 'organic' foods grown unmodified and also free from artificial additives taste better.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The introduction of modified genes into the environment has the potential to adversely effect ecosystems.
GMO crops can grow in more harsh conditions.

question_html: Nucleotides react in a condensation reaction to form polynucleotides. For example, in DNA, the hydroxyl group from the pentose sugar from one nucleotide reacts with the hydroxyl group from the phosphate of another nucleotide. The phosphate group ends up being joined to two sugars. Which carbon atoms on the sugar molecules are attached to the phosphate group?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: In the backbone of DNA, the 3’ carbon of one nucleotide is linked to the 5’ carbon of another so @1 is correct.

question_html: What is the difference between RNA and DNA?

MCQ_set.answer_html: DNA contains a monosaccharide with the formula C5H10O4 and RNA contains a monosaccharide with the formula C5H10O5.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
@1 is correct because ribose has one more oxygen atom than deoxyribose.

@2 is incorrect because RNA is single-stranded and DNA is double-stranded.

@3 is incorrect because both RNA and DNA contain phosphodiester bonds.

@4 is incorrect because both RNA and DNA contain guanine bases.

MCQ_set.answer_html: DNA is single-stranded whereas RNA is double-stranded.
RNA contains phosphodiester bonds but DNA does not.
DNA contains guanine bases and RNA does not.

question_html: DNA is a polymer made from nucleotides. These nucleotides are joined together by which type of bond?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The hydroxyl group from the pentose sugar from one nucleotide reacts with the hydroxyl group from the phosphate of another nucleotide by a condensation reaction. The result is a phosphodiester bond so @1 is correct.

question_html:
Hydrochloric acid (Mr = 36.5) reacts with calcium carbonate (Mr = 100) to make calcium chloride (Mr = 75.5), water (Mr = 18) and carbon dioxide (Mr = 44), according to the following equation:

CaCO3 + 2HCl → CaCl2 + H2O + CO2

At STP, 5 g of calcium carbonate reacts and produces 330 cm3 of carbon dioxide. What is the % yield of carbon dioxide in this reaction?

Molar volume of a gas at STP = 22.7 dm3 = 22700 cm3

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
5/100 = 0.05 moles of CaCO3. CO2 is produced in a 1:1 ratio, so 0.05 moles of CO2 are produced.

0.05 * 22700 = 1135 cm3 of CO2, which is the theoretical yield.

% yield = (actual yield / theoretical yield) × 100

(330 / 1135) * 100 = 29.1% yield, so @1 is correct.

question_html:
The thermal decomposition of copper carbonate (Mr = 123.5) is shown in this equation:

CuCO3(s) → CuO(s) + CO2(g).

The desired product is copper oxide (Mr = 79.5) and the waste product is carbon dioxide (Mr = 44).

What is the atom economy for this reaction?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The atom economy is (79.5 / 123.5) * 100 = 64% to 2 significant figures and so @1 is the correct answer.

question_html: Paper is a thin material produced by pressing together moist fibres derived from wood or grasses, and drying them into flexible sheets. Which enzyme would be most useful in breaking down the waste from a paper mill (a factory where paper is produced)?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Paper is made from plant sources and therefore its main component is cellulose. The hydrolysis of cellulose into glucose is catalysed by the enzyme called cellulase.

question_html:
The following is an example of an aquatic food chain:

phytoplankton → zooplankton → smelt fish → lake trout → herring gull

Which of the organisms is likely to be most affected by toxins within the water?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is the most likely answer. This is because, in many cases, animals near the top of the food chain are most affected because of a process called biomagnification.

question_html:
Enzymes can play an essential role in 'green chemistry' because of which of the following?

I. They are proteins themselves and therefore do not pollute the environment.

II. They reduce the temperature at which processes need to be carried out and so less energy is used.

III. They can be used to break down pollutants, such as oil spills or plastics.

IV. They have a specific active site and therefore can be used to only act upon target chemicals.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct. Enzymes are important tools in green chemistry as they act as catalysts which accelerate chemical reactions without using harsh conditions and chemicals. They are also reusable, natural and specific.

question_html:
In host-guest chemistry, the interaction between the ‘host’ and the ‘guest’ is like the interaction between an enzyme and the substrate. Chemical bonding is critical in maintaining the 3D structure of the large molecules (supramolecules) involved. Which of the following types of interaction happen between the 'host' and the 'guest'?

I. Ionic bonds

II. Van der Waals forces

III. Hydrophobic interactions

IV. Covalent bonds

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct because supramolecular complexes are formed between two or more molecules or ions that are held together by non-covalent bonds. These can interact via ionic bonds, van der Waals forces, hydrophobic interactions or hydrogen bonds.

question_html: An increasing number of biodegradable plastics are being manufactured as a way to reduce waste build-up in the environment. Which of the following would not be classified as a bioplastic?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @2, @3 and @4 are all bioplastics as they are produced from renewable plant materials, namely the castor oil plant and sugars from e.g. corn or sugar cane. @1 is the most common form of synthetic polymer and is a mixture of polymers of ethene, originally derived from crude oil. This is therefore not a bioplastic.

question_html: PTFE (polytetrafluoroethene) is an addition polymer used for many things, such as non-stick coatings on frying pans. It can cause a problem by persisting in the environment for thousands of years. What is the main reason for this?

MCQ_set.answer_html: The high bond enthalpy of the carbon to fluorine bond.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct. The C-F bond is one of the strongest in organic chemistry (with an average bond energy around 480 kJ/mol). This is significantly stronger than the bonds of carbon with other halogens (an average bond energy of e.g. C-Cl bond is around 320 kJ/mol) and is one of the reasons why fluoroorganic compounds have high thermal and chemical stability.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The C=C double bonds in the polymer are very strong.
Many covalent bonds will need to be broken in order to melt it.

question_html: Heavy metals can accumulate in organisms, resulting in biomagnification. They often cause problems by binding irreversibly to the allosteric site (a site away from the active site) of an enzyme, thus reducing its effectiveness. In this case, the heavy metals are acting as ....................

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct because non-competitive inhibitors bind to the enzyme, but not to the active site. Instead, they bind to another site in the enzyme called the allosteric site. Non-competitive inhibitors do not compete with the substrate directly and some do not alter the active site very much, meaning that the substrate can sometimes still bind, but not as efficiently.

question_html: DDT (dichloro-diphenyl-trichloroethane) was developed as one of the first modern synthetic insecticides. It was initially used with great effect to combat malaria, typhus and the other insect-borne human diseases. However, problems later arose as it accumulated up the food chain, leading to top predators having very high concentrations of it in their systems. Which of the following physical properties of DDT is most likely to have allowed it to become biomagnified in this way?

MCQ_set.answer_html: It is a non-polar molecule which is soluble in fats.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct. Since DDT is lipid-soluble, it tends to concentrate in the body fat of animals.

MCQ_set.answer_html: It is a non-polar molecule which is soluble in water.
It is a polar molecule which is soluble in water.
It is a polar molecule which is soluble in fats.

question_html: What is the class of compounds that Kevlar® belongs to?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Kevlar® contains the amide functional group, containing adjacent N-H and C=O bonds. The presence of these bonds gives rise to the strength, allowing for strong hydrogen bonding between polymer chains. The presence of the amide functional group makes this type of compound a polyamide.

question_html: Which of the following reasons does not explain why a bullet-proof vest made of Kevlar® should be kept away from concentrated sulfuric acid?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Sulfuric acid protonates the nitrogen atoms enhancing the strength of the hydrogen bonds.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: While sulfuric acid does protonate the nitrogen and oxygen atoms within the amide linkage of the polyamide Kelvar®, this protonation breaks apart the hydrogen bonding between polymer chains and promotes the dissolution of the polymer within the acid. Sulfuric acid is also capable of breaking down the amide linkage.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Sulfuric acid breaks apart the intermolecular forces between polymer chains.

question_html: Which of the following is a monomer for the following condensation polymer?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Looking at the polymer and each side of the ester linkage, we can see that the left-hand side would be from the dicarboxylic acid and would contain the phenyl ring. This would be from benzene-1,4-dicarboxylic acid (or terephthalic acid) and not ethanoic or diethanoic acid. The right-hand side would involve the dialcohol, involving two carbon atoms, which implies 1,2-ethanediol would be the correct choice.

question_html: Which of the following is an unlikely product during condensation polymerisation?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Condensation reactions involve the loss of a small molecule. Typically water, ammonia and hydrochloric acid are the small molecule products that are formed. Propanoic acid is a large molecule and one that would be very unlikely to be produced when a polymer reaction is formed from the joining of two monomer molecules.

question_html: Which of the following is a polyester?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is the only option containing the ester linkage. @2 contains an ether linkage within the polymer chain, @3 and @4 are examples of polyamides.

question_html: Why does Kevlar® have a lower density than steel?

MCQ_set.answer_html: The C, H, N and O atoms have a lower relative atomic mass than Fe.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Since the C, H, N and O atoms have a smaller molar mass than iron, this will cause the structure to have a lower density. Iron is a metal with a close-packed lattice structure, which will mean a large number of atoms occupy a volume of space, leading to a higher volume. This is why @2 is incorrect. While often metals tend to be more dense than covalent substances, this is not always the case. For example, lithium metal will float on top of water due to its low molar mass and relatively low density. Therefore @3 is incorrect. Since polymers are typically used to make plastic sheets and fibres, they generally occupy a smaller volume of space than metals. Therefore @4 is incorrect.

MCQ_set.answer_html: C, H, N and O atoms have close-packed structures whereas Fe does not.
Metals are always more dense than covalent substances.
Polymers occupy a greater volume of space than metals.

question_html:
Which of the following is a correct combination for the following crystal structures?

Simple cubic Face-centred cubic Body-centred cubic
A 1 atom in unit cell 2 atoms in unit cell 4 atoms in unit cell
B 8 corner atoms 8 corner atoms and 1 body atom 8 corner atoms and 6 face atoms
C 9 atoms contribute to unit cell 14 atoms contribute to unit cell 8 atoms contribute to unit cell.
D Unit cell length is twice the length of the radius Unit cell length is \(\sqrt{8}\) of the radius Unit cell length is \(\frac{4}{\sqrt{3}}\)radius

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Simple cubic has 1 atom in the unit cell, FCC has 4 atoms and BCC has 2 atoms. FCC has 8 corner atoms and 6 face atoms whereas BCC has 8 corner atoms and 1 body atom. Simple cubic has 8 atoms that contribute to the unit cell, FCC has 14 atoms that contribute to the unit cell and BCC has 9 atoms that contribute to the unit cell.

question_html:
Which of the following combinations is correct for Type 1 and Type 2 superconductors?

Type 1 superconductor Type 2 superconductor
A Gradual drop off in resistance at a critical temperature Sharp drop off in resistance at a critical temperature
B High critical temperatures Low critical temperatures
C Typically metals and metalloids Typically metal oxides, metal alloys and perovskites
D Magnetic field slowly decays above a critical applied magnetic field No opposing magnetic field higher than a critical applied magnetic field

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Type 1 superconductors show a sharp drop in their resistance at a critical temperature and their opposing magnetic field above a critical applied magnetic field. Type 2 superconductors show a gradual drop in their resistance at a critical temperature and their opposing magnetic field above a critical applied magnetic field. This would make A and D incorrect. B is incorrect because Type 1 superconductors tend to have very low critical temperatures (liquid helium temperatures) whereas Type 2 superconductors tend to have relatively higher critical temperatures (liquid nitrogen temperatures).

question_html: Which of the following is not a property of superconducting materials?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Superconductors act as a perfect diamagnet as they generate a magnetic field in opposition to an applied magnetic field. A paramagnet is attracted to an applied magnetic field, while a diamagnet is repelled by one. Superconductors expell magnetic field lines within the material (Meissner effect) and have zero resistance below their critical temperature.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Expels magnetic field lines within the material

question_html: Which of the following is a characteristic symptom of a lack of vitamin D (rickets)?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct because when sufficient vitamin D is not present, calcium cannot be absorbed and so bones remain soft and flexible and weight-bearing bones can bend.

question_html: Lack of which vitamin causes night blindness (nyctalopia)?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct because vitamin A is needed by the retina of the eye in the form of retinal, which combines with the protein opsin to form rhodopsin, a light-absorbing molecule.

question_html: Which of the following is caused by a deficiency of vitamin B3?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct. A deficiency in niacin (vitamin B3) results in a condition known as pellagra. Symptoms include diarrhoea, dermatitis and memory loss.

question_html: Which of the following is caused by a lack of Vitamin D?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: When sufficient vitamin D is not present, calcium cannot be absorbed and children can develop a condition where the bones remain soft and flexible and weight-bearing bones can bend. This is called rickets and so @1 is correct.

question_html: Vitamin K is commonly found in plant oils such as corn oil and soya bean oil. What does this indicates about vitamin K?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct because, if vitamin K is fat-soluble, it is very likely to be non-polar.

question_html: Which of the following is the best source of vitamin D?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct. Egg yolks are an excellent source of vitamins A, B, D and E.

question_html: Which of the following is an essential role of vitamin C?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct because vitamin C acts to quench potentially harmful free radicals in our bodies.

question_html: Vitamin A only has one hydroxyl (OH) group and has a long chain of conjugated carbon atoms. What is the best way to describe vitamin A?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct because vitamin A has very low solubility in water, due to its non-polar nature. Therefore, vitamin A is considered to be a "fat soluble" vitamin.

question_html: You may wish to refer to the colour wheel on section 17 of your IB data booklet to help you to answer this question. Vitamin A absorbs light mostly in the region of 450nm (blue light). What colour is Vitamin A (β carotene)?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct. Vitamin A gives carrots their orange colour.

question_html: Health problems may arise from insufficient consumption of one or more vitamins. For example, lack of vitamin C can lead to weakness, bleeding gums and a low immunity to disease. Which of the following is not a sensible way to counteract a Vitamin C deficiency?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct because human skin can synthesise vitamin D in the presence of sunlight but not vitamin C.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Increased dietary intake of citrus fruits such as oranges.
Eating cereals fortified with vitamins and minerals.

question_html: Which of the following cannot be digested by humans?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct because humans do not have the enzyme cellulase, which breaks down cellulose.

question_html: Monosaccharides are joined together to make disaccharides by what kind of linkage?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct because disaccharides are formed when a dehydration/condensation reaction occurs between two monosaccharides. An oxygen remains between the monomers – this is called a glycosidic linkage (or ether bond).

question_html: Galactose is a hexose sugar. Which of the following statements is not correct about galactose?

MCQ_set.answer_html: It will give a negative result with Benedict's reagent
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: All monosaccharides are reducing sugars and therefore will give a positive result (red) with Benedict's solution.

question_html: What colour does iodine solution become in the presence of starch?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct. Iodine solution turns a blue-black colour in the presence of starch.

question_html: Benedict's reagent is used as a test for reducing sugars and contains aqueous Cu2+ ions. What is the colour of Benedict's reagent?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct because Benedict's reagent is made of anhydrous sodium carbonate, sodium citrate and copper(II) sulphate pentahydrate, the latter of which has a characteristic blue colour.

question_html: Which of the following does not have the formula C6H12O6?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct because sucrose is a disaccharide and its formula is C12H22O11.

question_html: Which functional group would a monosaccharide NOT contain?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct because monosaccharides contain either an aldehyde group (-CHO) or a ketone group (C=O) and several hydroxyl (-OH) groups.

question_html: Which of the following is NOT a health issue associated with over-consumption of simple carbohydrates?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct because anaemia is caused by a lack of iron in the diet.

question_html: Which of the following is a good source of carbohydrate in the diet?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct because rice contains starch, a polymer of α glucose and glucose (C6H12O6) is a carbohydrate.

question_html: Which of the following is NOT a carbohydrate?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The correct answer is @1 because carbohydrates have multiple OH groups and a C=O group. Ethanol is just a primary alcohol.

question_html: Refer to Table 34 in your IB data booklet to help you to answer this question. Which of the following is a monounsaturated fatty acid?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct. Oleic acid has only one C=C double bond – its formula is CH3(CH2)7CH=CH(CH2)7COOH.

question_html: Oxidative rancidity is typically caused by the reaction of oxygen with which functional group?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct. Oxygen is usually added to a C=C double bond.

question_html: Which of the following is not a potential negative effect of using anabolic steroids?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is a positive effect of using anabolic steroids. They are used to increase muscle growth either for medical purposes (such as quicker recovery from an operation) or sporting purposes (such as increased athletic performance). There are, however, many negative potential side effects from over-use, such as @2, @3 and @4.

question_html: Which of the following is not an example of a steroid?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is not an example of a steroid. It is a group of phospholipids.

question_html: The hydrolysis of a phospholipid would never produce which of the following?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct because if a phospholipid is completely broken down into its constituents it would produce glycerol, two fatty acid molecules and a phosphate ion.

question_html: Which of the following is the best explanation for why fats have a higher melting point than oils?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Fats are saturated and straight-chain and therefore they have more van der Waals forces between molecules.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct because saturated fatty acid chains are roughly linear, so there is more surface area between triglycerides, increasing the strength of the intermolecular forces, which take more energy to overcome. @2 is incorrect as oils are unsaturated. @3 and @4 are incorrect as the covalent bonds are not broken when melting occurs.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Oils are saturated and straight-chain and therefore they have more van der Waals forces between molecules.
Fats are saturated and therefore they contain more covalent bonds which need to be broken in order to melt.
Oils are unsaturated and double bonds are stronger than single bonds and so more energy is needed to overcome them.

question_html: Linoleic acid contains 2 C=C double bonds. Its molecular formula is C18H32O2 and so its Mr is 280. What is its iodine number?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Answer @1 is correct because (127 × 2 × 2 × 100)/280 = 181. As linoleic acid contains two double bonds, two iodine molecules will react by addition. The iodine number refers to 100g of fat reacting and so 100/280 (the Mr of linoleic acid) is the number of moles of fat reacting. 127 × 2 is the Mr of iodine (I2) and there are two of them reacting so × 2.

question_html: What is the functional group present in all fatty acids?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The correct answer is @1 because although some fatty acids contain C=C double bonds, all fatty acids contain a carboxylic acid group.

question_html: Which structural feature do fats and oils have in common?

MCQ_set.answer_html: They both have ester linkages between the fatty acids and glycerol.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Fats and oils are triglycerides. These are formed from the condensation reaction between 3 fatty acid molecules (carboxylic acids) and a glycerol molecule (alcohol).

MCQ_set.answer_html: They both have peptide linkages between amino acids.
They both have phosphodiester bonds between the fatty acids and glycerol.

question_html: Which of the following is NOT a direct negative health impact of eating too much fat?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct because fats do not play a direct role in bone formation. It is a lack of calcium or Vitamin D in the diet which may lead to reduced bone density.

question_html:
Which of the following statement(s) correctly describes the formation of crude oil and natural gas?

I. Crude oil and natural gas were formed from the remains of marine plants and animals. 

II. Crude oil and natural gas were formed by the reduction of biological compounds that contained carbon, hydrogen, nitrogen, sulfur and oxygen.

III. Crude oil and natural gas were formed by the decay of prehistoric land-based plants.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Oil and natural gas were formed from ocean-dwelling plants and animals. When these organisms died, they sank to the bottom and became buried under layers of sediment. As the layers of sediment increased, the heat and pressure also increased, which, combined with anaerobic conditions, produced oil and natural gas. The reduction of biological compounds that contained carbon, hydrogen, nitrogen, sulfur and oxygen led to the formation of coal, oil and natural gas.

question_html:
Which of the following statement(s) correctly describes the formation of coal?

I. Coal was formed from the remains of marine organisms. 

II. Coal was formed by the reduction of biological compounds that contained carbon, hydrogen, nitrogen, sulfur and oxygen.

III. Coal was formed by the anaerobic decay of plant material under conditions of high temperature and pressure.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Coal, was formed from the remains of prehistoric plants that grew in vast swamps. When the plants died, they became buried under layers of mud and sand. Over millions of years, heat and pressure, combined with the anaerobic conditions, converted the decaying plant material into coal.The reduction of biological compounds that contained carbon, hydrogen, nitrogen, sulfur and oxygen led to the formation of coal, oil and natural gas.

question_html:
Which of the following statement(s) are disadvantages of burning coal in a power station?

I. The combustion of coal that contains sulfur contributes to the formation of acid deposition

II. Coal has a high energy density that results in a large amount of energy released per unit mass

III. The combustion of coal produces carbon dioxide, a potent greenhouse gas

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The combustion of coal produces carbon dioxide gas, and if the coal contains sulfur, sulfur dioxide can also be produced. Carbon dioxide is a potent greenhouse gas and sulfur dioxide reacts with water in the atmosphere to produce sulfuric acid.

section_title: Advantages and disadvantages of fossil fuels

question_html:
Which of the following statement(s) explains why kerosene has a higher boiling point than refinery gas?

I. The intermolecular forces found between the molecules in kerosene are dipole-dipole attractions, whereas in refinery gas there are only weaker London dispersion forces between the molecules. 

II. Kerosene has a higher molar mass than refinery gas, which results in stronger London dispersion forces between the molecules and therefore a higher boiling point. 

III. Molecules of kerosene have hydrogen bonding between them, which results in a higher boiling point than refinery gas.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The fractions of crude oil are non-polar hydrocarbons, therefore the only intermolecular forces between the molecules are relatively weak London dispersion forces. As the molar mass of a hydrocarbon increases, the strength of the London dispersion forces between molecules also increases, which results in a higher boiling point.

question_html:
The cracking of a saturated straight-chain hydrocarbon, C7H16, could yield which of the following products?

I. C3H8 and C4H10

II. C4H10 and C3H6

III. C5H12 and C2H4

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Cracking breaks up longer-chain hydrocarbons to form shorter-chain hydrocarbons. The products are usually a mixture of saturated and unsaturated hydrocarbons. Choices II and III both include a saturated and an unsaturated hydrocarbon. The number and type of atoms must be the same in the reactants and products.

question_html:
Which of the following activities could reduce a person's carbon footprint? 

I. Walking to the supermarket instead of driving a car

II. Turning off electronic devices when not in use

III. Buying locally grown produce

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: All 3 activities could help reduce a person's carbon footprint by reducing the amount of CO2 being produced.

question_html:
Which of the following occurs during the process of nuclear fission?

I. Lighter nuclei combine to form heavier nuclei 

II. The binding energy per nucleon increases 

III. The products are more stable than the reactants

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: In a nuclear fission reaction, heavier nuclei spilt to form smaller, more stable nuclei. The binding energy per nucleon increases.

question_html:
Which of the following occurs during the process of nuclear fusion?

I. Lighter nuclei combine to form heavier nuclei 

II. The binding energy per nucleon increases 

III. The products are less stable than the reactants

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: In a nuclear fusion reaction, lighter nuclei combine to form heavier, more stable nuclei. The binding energy per nucleon increases.

question_html:
Which of the following is/are classified as low-level radioactive waste? 

I. Plastic gloves used in the x-ray department of a hospital

II. Spent nuclear fuel rods

III. Paper towels used in a nuclear research facility

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Spent nuclear fuel rods are high-level nuclear waste.

question_html:
Which of the following are features of high-level nuclear waste? 

I. Low activity 

II. High activity 

III. Long half-life

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: High-level waste is classified as having a long half-life and high activity.

question_html:
Which of the following statement(s) is/are correct about fast breeder reactors?

I. Fast breeder reactors convert non-fissile U-235 into fissile Pu-249.

II. Fast breeder reactors produce more fissile material than they consume.

III. Fast breeder reactors produce plutonium that can easily be converted to weapons grade plutonium.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: I is incorrect as U-235 is a fissile isotope, meaning that it is able to sustain a nuclear chain reaction. Fast breeder reactors convert non-fissile U-238 into fissile isotopes such as Pu-249.

question_html:
Which of the following statement(s) correctly describes the reactions that take place in photosynthesis?

I. Carbon dioxide is oxidised to form glucose 

II. Water is oxidised to form oxygen

III. Light energy is converted to chemical energy

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: During photosynthesis, carbon dioxide is reduced to form glucose and water is oxidised to form oxygen gas. Light energy from the sun is converted into chemical energy that is stored in the glucose.

question_html:
Which of the following statement(s) correctly describes the enthalpy change (ΔH) in photosynthesis?

I. The ΔH is negative

II. The products have higher enthalpy than the reactants

III. The ΔH is positive

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: During photosynthesis, sunlight is absorbed which means that it is an endothermic reaction. Endothermic reactions have a positive ΔH and the products have higher enthalpy than the reactants.

question_html:
Vegetable oils are too viscous to use in an unmodified diesel engine. Which of the following statement(s) correctly explains the reason for this?

I. Vegetable oils are composed of triglycerides that have high molar masses

II. The London dispersion forces that exist between triglyceride molecules give them their high viscosity

III.  Triglyceride molecules have strong hydrogen bonding between the molecules

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Vegetable oils are composed of triglycerides which are non-polar molecules. They have high molar masses with London dispersion forces between the molecules. This gives them their high viscosity.

question_html: Amino acids and proteins serve an important function in our bodies by acting as buffers. What is the pH of a buffer solution containing 0.100 mol dm-3 ethanoic acid and 0.100 mol dm-3 sodium ethanoate? (The Ka for ethanoic acid is 1.74 × 10-5 mol dm-3).

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
@1 is the correct answer. The pH of a buffer solution can be calculated using the following equation: 

pH = pKa + log([A-]/[HA]). In this instance pH = -log(1.74 × 10-5) + log(0.1/0.1) = 4.76.

section_title: Buffering capacity of amino acids and proteins

question_html: What name is given to a species which has separate positive and negatively charged groups?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct. A zwitterion contains separate positive and negatively charged groups. Amino acids can exist as zwitterions.

question_html: Which of the following will be true upon the addition of a non-competitive inhibitor?

MCQ_set.answer_html: The Vmax will decrease but the Km will remain the same.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct because the presence of a non-competitive inhibitor lowers Vmax, but it does not change Km. There is the same level of affinity between the enzyme and the substrate, as there is no direct competition for binding between the inhibitor and the substrate. However, the number of active enzymes has been reduced and therefore the overall maximum rate of reaction which can be achieved is lower.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The Vmax will increase but the Km will remain the same.
The Vmax will decrease and the Km will increase.
Both the Vmax and the Km will decrease.

question_html: Which of the following will be true upon the addition of a competitive inhibitor?

MCQ_set.answer_html: The Vmax will stay the same but the Km will be higher.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct because the presence of a competitive inhibitor does not change Vmax, but it does increase Km. This is due to the fact that a larger concentration of substrate is required in order to have the same enzyme activity level.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The Vmax will be higher but the Km will stay the same.
The Vmax will be lower and the Km will be higher.
The Vmax and the Km will be lower.

question_html: What does a very low value for Km indicate?

MCQ_set.answer_html: The enzyme has a very high affinity for the substrate.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct because if there is a very strong affinity between the enzyme and the substrate, a lower concentration of substrate is required to achieve Vmax.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The enzyme has a very low affinity for the substrate.
The enzyme requires a high concentration of substrate to reach Vmax.
The Vmax must also be very low.

question_html:
An enzyme called alcohol dehydrogenase is used to catalyse the following reaction:

CH3CH2OH + NAD → CH3CHO + NADH + H+

Which would be the most sensible way to monitor the rate of this enzyme-catalysed reaction?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is the correct answer because the conductivity would increase as increasing amounts of hydrogen ions are produced. @2 is incorrect because there would be no colour change. @3 is incorrect because no gas is produced. @4 is incorrect because there would be no change in mass.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Using a colorimeter to measure colour change.
Using a gas syringe for a fixed period of time.
Using a mass balance to measure changes in mass.

question_html: What is the origin of the enzymes used to make yoghurt?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct. Yoghurt is produced by the bacterial fermentation of milk.

question_html: The following molecule can be produced from the combustion of PVC. What type of byproduct is this?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: PCB stands for polychlorinated biphenyl. The molecule represented in the image above would be an example of this. @3 involves two oxygen atoms on a heterocyclic ring, usually in the 1 and 4 positions, which is not present in this structure. Phthalates are used as plasticisers in PVC and not generally a byproduct in combustion.

question_html: Which of the following best explains why plastics require more processing than other materials?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Separation of the plastic is required before heating.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Since plastics look similar to one other but are made from different polymers, they must be separated. This adds increased effort for processing plastics at a recycling plant. Metals and glass are heavier, have a higher melting point and shatter more easily than plastic, therefore @2, @3 and @4 would be incorrect.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Plastics have a higher melting point than other recycled materials.
Plastics are heavier than other recycleable materials.
Plastics shatter easily in comparison to other recycled materials.

question_html: All of the following are concerns of PVC plastic materials, except:

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: While PVC does contain C-Cl bonds, it is much more likely for the polymer to form HCl, PCBs and dioxins upon degradation and combustion than Cl2 (g).

MCQ_set.answer_html: Polychlorinated biphenyls released in the presence of heat
Dioxins released in the presence of heat

question_html: Identify which of the following is not an environmental concern for the combustion of polymers.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Water is produced in the combustion reaction of polymers. The majority of this water is released as water vapours and trapped in the atmosphere as a greenhouse gas. Any water condensed in the ocean would have negligible influence on the ocean levels.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Carbon dioxide released as a greenhouse gas

question_html: Plastics are synthesised using starting materials obtained from fossil fuels. Which of the following provides the best reason for why this is a concern?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Since fossil fuels are used to produce the starting materials needed in polymer synthesis, use of these fuels would diminish the supply of non-renewable resources.

question_html: Identify which of the following is not a property of a plastic polymer.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Can easily be broken down by bacteria
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Polymers are extremely difficult to decompose and break down. Bacteria have difficulty breaking polymer chains down. This is why the accumulation of plastics in landfills poses a challenge. Since polymers are largely made of carbon and hydrogen, plastics can be combusted; however, often incomplete combustion and the production of toxic byproducts can occur. This is why @3 is incorrect. Since polymers have strong covalent bonds, plastic materials have a long shelf-life and are relatively strong materials. This is why @2 and @4 are incorrect.

question_html: Use table 33 on page 31 of your IB data booklet to help you to answer this question. Which of the following amino acids is polar?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct because aspartic acid has a highly polar, acidic side group (-CH2COOH). The other choices have non-polar alkyl side chains.

question_html: Use table 33 on page 31 of your IB data booklet to help you answer this question. Which of the following amino acids has the lowest pH at its isoelectric point?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct because, as its name implies, aspartic acid has an acidic side chain (-CH2COOH) and therefore its isoelectric pH is 2.8.

question_html: Use Table 33 on page 31 of your IB data booklet to help you to answer this question. Which amino acid's R group is a methyl (-CH3)?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct because alanine's side chain is a methyl group. @2 is incorrect because cysteine's side chain is -CH2SH, @3 is incorrect because glycine's side chain is -H and @4 is incorrect because aspartic acid's side chain is -CH2COOH.

question_html:
Which of the following molecules contain a conjugated system?

I.

II. 

III.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: All 3 molecules have conjugated systems consisting of alternating single and double bonds.

question_html: Which of the following is an advantage of dye-sensitised solar cells?

MCQ_set.answer_html: They use low-cost materials and are simple to manufacture.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Compared to silicon based photovoltaic cells, DSSCs use low-cost materials and are simple to manufacture.

MCQ_set.answer_html: They are more efficient than silicon-based photovoltaic cells.

question_html: The dye in a dye-sensitised solar cell contains a conjugated system. Which of the following statements correctly describes a conjugated system?

MCQ_set.answer_html: A region of overlapping p orbitals that allow for the delocalisation of pi (π) electrons.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A conjugated system has a region of overlapping p orbitals that allow for the delocalisation of π electrons. Delocalised π electrons are electrons that are free to move within the conjugated system.

MCQ_set.answer_html: A series of overlapping s orbitals that allow for the delocalisation of pi (π) electrons.
A series of overlapping d orbitals that allow for the delocalisation of pi (π) electrons.
A series of overlapping f orbitals that allow for the delocalisation of pi (π) electrons.

question_html: This addition of which of the following elements will lead to an increase in the number of free electrons in a semiconductor such as silicon?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: n-type doping involves the addition of small amounts of group 15 elements such as phosphorus and arsenic (known as dopants). These elements, with their 5 valence electrons, create extra electrons in the silicon lattice, increasing its electrical conductivity.

question_html: Which of the following is the correct bond angle in a lattice of silicon atoms?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The silicon atoms have a similar structure to that of diamond with a tetrahedral arrangement and a bond angle of 109.5o.

question_html: Why are amino acids more specifically known as 2-amino acids?

MCQ_set.answer_html: The variable R group and the amino group are attached to the second carbon.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct because the carbon 1 is the carboxyl group and carbon 2 has the R group attached.

MCQ_set.answer_html: There are 2 amino groups on the molecule.
Carbon 2 forms part of the carboxyl group.
The second carbon always has a methyl group attached to it.

question_html: Approximately how much of the human body is composed of protein?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct. Proteins are used to form structural components of an organism, such as hair, skin, muscle tissue and finger- and toenails. Other molecules such as enzymes and hormones are also made of protein.

question_html: Which energy conversion takes place in a photovoltaic cell?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A photovoltaic cell converts light energy from the Sun to electrical energy.

question_html:
Which of the following reasons are a public concern about nanotechnology?

I. Ability of nanomaterials to interact with cellular processes.

II. Nanotechnology is still experimental and its products will only be seen in the future.

III. Unknown long-term effects of nanomaterials in the body, environment and atmosphere.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
I. Ability of nanomaterials to interact with cellular processes. TRUE Matter on the nanoscale, such as nanoparticles, is small enough to pass through cellular membranes. This would cause the nanoparticles to interact with various cellular processes.

II. Nanotechnology is still experimental and its products will only be seen in the future. FALSE Nanotechnology has been incorporated into a number of products to date. Modern electronic devices utilise nanotechnology to make circuits, connections and displays in the miniaturisation of electronics. Antimicrobial silver nanoparticles are used for clothing, surfaces in hospitals, cleaning agents, wound dressings, etc. Nanotechnology has found its way into a large variety of goods and products found worldwide.

III. Unknown long-term effects of nanomaterials in the body, environment and atmosphere. TRUE Since nanotechnology is a relatively new area of study, long-term effects of nanomaterials have yet to be studied. This provides a concern as a substance that has no immediate toxic effects over the short term in the environment may show toxic effects after degradation over the years.

question_html: Which of the following gases cannot be used during the production of carbon nanotubes using chemical vapour deposition?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Oxygen will readily react with the carbon-containing gas phase reagent to form carbon dioxide. This will prevent the carbon-containing gas phase reagent from forming carbon nanotubes and instead form carbon dioxide. An inert gas must be used during chemical vapour deposition. @3 and @4 are examples of inert gases.

question_html: Which of the following chemical reactions describes the formation of carbon nanotubes using the high pressure carbon monoxide process?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: In the high pressure carbon monoxide process, carbon monoxide undergoes oxidation and reduction to form carbon dioxide and carbon nanotubes respectively. @2 is incorrect because carbon monoxide is not utilised at all. @3 is not a balanced chemical reaction and @4 does not produce the favourable carbon dioxide product.

question_html: Which of the following methods would be the best choice for production of single-walled carbon nanotubes?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: In the high pressure carbon monoxide process, single-walled carbon nanotubes are formed on the iron nanoparticle catalyst surface. Since the nanoparticles have a small diameter, single-walled carbon nanotubes are favoured. In @2 and @3, carbon nanotubes assemble on the surface of one of the electrodes. A combination of carbon products are formed including single-walled and multi-walled carbon nanotubes. @4 forms carbon nanotubes on a substrate surface in the high temperature region. A combination of single and multi-walled carbon nanotubes are formed.

question_html: What conditions are utilised in the high pressure carbon monoxide method for production of carbon nanotubes?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Iron pentacarbonyl catalyst, high temperature, high pressure
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: In the HIPCO method for carbon nanotube production, iron pentacarbonyl is utilised as it breaks down to form iron nanoparticles and carbon monoxide. High pressure is needed to flow solid clusters of iron pentacarbonyl with the carbon monoxide. High temperatures are needed to decompose the cabron monoxide to form carbon dioxide and carbon nanotubes.

question_html: Which of the following would have the greatest surface area to volume ratio?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A nanoparticle has been reduced to the nanoscale in all 3 dimensions. This makes a very high percentage of the atoms making up the nanoparticle surface atoms. @2 has been reduced to the nanoscale in two of the three dimensions, @3 has been reduced in one of the three dimensions and @4 has not been reduced to the nanoscale in any form. @1 > @2 > @3 > @4 are ordered in decreasing order of surface area to volume ratio.

question_html: Which of the following is not a physical technique for the manipulation of matter at the nanoscale?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Alkanethiol self-assembled monolayer on a gold surface.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: In the formation of an alkanethiol self-assembled monolayer, the sulfur atom forms a chemical bond with gold atoms on the surface. The London dispersion forces between alkyl chains cause the alkyl chains to align with one another. Since chemical interactions are occurring this would be an example of a chemical method for matter manipulation. @2, @3 and @4 are all physical techniques that utilise an instrument to scan a sample and pull, move, shape and sculpt matter.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Creating the nanoscale IBM image using scanning tunnelling microscopy.
Using an atomic force microscope to pull on a polymer chain.
Using lithography to form a computer chip.

question_html: Which of the following would be considered a top-down approach for the formation of nanomaterials?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Lithography involves starting with the bulk material and removing matter until the desired material is formed. It is a top-down approach because it starts with the large macroscale material and manipulates the matter down to the nanoscale. @2, @3 and @4 are all methods that involve chemical reactions where atoms and molecules react with one another in order to form a material. These are examples of bottom-up methods for the formation of nanomaterials, because they start with small atoms/molecules which build onto one another, forming nanomaterials that are larger in size than the individual molecules.

question_html:
Which of the following can be caused by exposure to gamma radiation?

I. Cancer

II. Fetal abnormalities 

III. DNA mutations

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Gamma radiation is an example of ionising radiation. Exposure to gamma radiation can lead to all three of the above.

question_html: Ionising radiation can lead to the formation of free radicals in the human body. Which feature of free radicals makes them highly reactive?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Free radicals are highly reactive species due to the presence of unpaired electrons. In the human body, they can lead to DNA mutations and cancer.

question_html: Which rate expression is correct for the radioactive decay of an isotope, X?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Radioactive decay is a first-order process, therefore the rate expression can be written as rate = k [X].

question_html: Which of the following contains only types of ionising radiation?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Ionising radiation is radiation that has sufficient energy to remove electrons from an atom or molecule. Examples of ionising radiation include gamma radiation, x-rays, and alpha (α) and beta minus (β-) particles. Types of electromagnetic such as microwaves and infra-red do not have enough energy to ionise atoms or molecules.

question_html: Which property is used to separate the two isotopes of uranium, 235U and 238U?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The two isotopes have slightly different masses, therefore it is this property that is used to separate them in gaseous diffusion and centrifugation.

question_html: Which of the following correctly describes the mass defect?

MCQ_set.answer_html: The difference between the mass of a nucleus and the sum of the masses of the individual nucleons that make up the nucleus
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The mass of an atomic nucleus is slightly less than the mass of the nucleons that make up the nucleus. This is known as the mass defect.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The energy required to a split a nucleus into its component nucleons
The difference between the mass of an atom and the sum of the masses of the individual sub-atomic particles that make up the atom
The energy released when a nucleus splits into its component nucleons

question_html: Which of the following is a disadvantage of hydrogen fuel cells?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Fuel cell vehicles are more expensive than conventional motor vehicles
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Due to the higher cost of fuel cell technology, fuel cell cars are more expensive than cars with internal combustion engines.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Fuel cells are less efficient than petrol and diesel engines
Fuel cells produce more carbon dioxide than gasoline engines
The increased use of fuel cell vehicles would increase a country's dependence on imported crude oil

question_html:
Which of the following statement(s) is/are correct about microbial fuel cells?

I. Ethanoate ions are reduced at the cathode 

II. Biodegradable substrates in wastewater can be used as a fuel source 

III. Carbon dioxide is produced at the negative electrode

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A microbial fuel cell has bacteria that live in the anode under anaerobic conditions. They are able to oxidise organic waste at the anode to produce carbon dioxide.

question_html:
Which of the following statement(s) are correct about primary cells, secondary cells and fuel cells?

I. Primary cells are used once and then discarded

II. Fuel cells require a constant source of fuel

III. Certain types of secondary cells contain toxic metals such as lead

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: All three statements are correct.

question_html: Which of the following correctly describes a concentration cell?

MCQ_set.answer_html: A concentration cell has the same electrodes in each half-cell but the concentration of the electrolyte in each half-cell is different.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A concentration cell is composed of two half-cells that have the same electrodes and electrolyte, but the concentration of the electrolyte in each half-cell is different.

MCQ_set.answer_html: A concentration cell has different electrodes in each half-cell and the concentration of the electrolyte in each half-cell is also different.
A concentration cell has the same electrodes in each half-cell and the concentration of the electrolyte in each half-cell is also the same.
A concentration cell has different electrodes in each half-cell but the concentration of the electrolyte in each half-cell is the same.

question_html: Which of the following reactions takes place at the anode of a direct methanol fuel cell?

MCQ_set.answer_html: The oxidation of a mixture of methanol and water to form carbon dioxide
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: At the anode of a direct methanol fuel cell, the fuel, a mixture of methanol and water, is oxidised to form carbon dioxide.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The oxidation of oxygen gas to form water
The reduction of a mixture of methanol and water to form carbon dioxide
The reduction of oxygen gas to form water

question_html: Which of the following is a disadvantage of a lead-acid battery?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Lead-acid batteries have low energy densities, as the use of lead, which is a dense metal, makes the battery heavy.

MCQ_set.answer_html: They have high energy densities and low discharge rates.
They are expensive when compared to other types of batteries
They charge quickly and have a high number of charge/discharge cycles

question_html:
Which of the following statement(s) are correct about the energy density of fossil fuels?

I. Natural gas has a lower energy density than coal.

II. Gasoline (petrol) has a higher energy density than natural gas.

III. Solid and liquid fuels tend to have lower energy densities than gaseous fuels.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Natural gas has a lower energy density than coal and petrol. This is because gases have lower densities than solid and liquid fuels such as coal and crude oil based fuels. For this reason, gases used as fuels are usually compressed or liquefied to increase the energy density of the fuel.

question_html: Which of the following reactions takes place at the cathode of a nickel-cadmium battery when it is being discharged?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: When being discharged, nickel oxide hydroxide, NiO(OH), is reduced at the cathode.

question_html: Which of the following reactions takes place at the cathode of a lead-acid battery when it is being discharged?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: When being discharged, lead(IV) oxide (PbO2) is reduced at the cathode to form lead(II) sulfate (PbSO4) and water.

question_html: Propanone and ethanoic acid are compounds commonly used in organic chemistry. Which statement correctly describes the relationship between the boiling points and vapour pressures of these two pure compounds?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Propanone exerts a greater vapour pressure and has a lower boiling point than ethanoic acid.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Ethanoic acid has hydrogen bonds between its molecules which are stronger intermolecular forces than the dipole-dipole forces that exist between molecules of propanone. At a temperature below its boiling point, these stronger intermolecular forces keep most molecules of ethanoic acid in the liquid phase. Only a few of the molecules evaporate, resulting in a lower vapour pressure. The boiling point of ethanoic acid is higher due to the stronger intermolecular forces.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Ethanoic acid exerts a greater vapour pressure and has a higher boiling point than propanone.
Propanone exerts a greater vapour pressure and has a higher boiling point than ethanoic acid.
Ethanoic acid exerts a greater vapour pressure and has a lower boiling point than propanone.

question_html:
Breathalysers are used to detect the blood alcohol content (BAC) from a breath sample. One of the types of breathalysers uses redox reactions and fuel cell technology. Which reactions take place in breathalysers that use fuel cell technology?

I. CH3CH2OH(g) + H2O(l) → CH3COOH(l) + 4H+(aq) + 4e−

II. ​Cr2O72- (aq) + 14H+ (aq) + 6e- → 2Cr3+(aq) + 7H2O (l)  

III. O2(g) + 4H+(aq) + 4e− → 2H2O(l)

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Breathalysers based on the fuel cell technology do not use dichromate ions in the redox reaction.

question_html: A mixture of three organic solvents undergoes fractional distillation. The three solvents are ethanol, toluene and hexane with boiling points of 78°C, 111°C and 69°C respectively. What is the correct order in which the distilled liquids will be collected in the receiving flasks?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Hexane, with the lowest boiling point of 69°C, will start boiling first. Next ethanol (b.p. 78°C) and finally toluene (b.p. 111°C).

MCQ_set.answer_html: All three solvents will distil at the same time.

question_html: Which one of the methods listed below is not a purification method?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Mass spectroscopy is the only technique which is not a purification method. It is used to determine the mass of the entire molecule as well as its fragments.

question_html: Ionic compounds are usually more soluble in water due to the formation of what type of intermolecular forces?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Ion-dipole forces are created between polar water molecules and cations and anions. The hydrogen atoms in the water molecule have a slightly positive charge and attract negative anions. The oxygen atoms, on the other hand, are slightly negative and are attracted to the positive cations.

question_html: Which piece of equipment is indispensable during liquid-liquid extraction?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A separatory funnel is used to separate components of a mixture of two immiscible solvent phases of different densities.

question_html: In the synthesis of a non-polar compound X, liquid-liquid extraction will be used. Which is the best solvent to use for compound X extraction?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: According to the rule 'like dissolve like', non-polar compound X will best dissolve in a non-polar solvent, hexane.

question_html: Which is not a common side-effect of radiotherapy?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Radiation used in radiotherapy can damage healthy cells and tissues near the treatment area, so, if applied near the reproductive organs, may cause reduced fertility.

question_html:
Which statements regarding targeted alpha therapy (TAT) are correct?

I. TAT requires radiation with a neutron beam from an outside source.

II.The 'targeting' is achieved by attaching alpha-emitting particles to antibodies which bind specifically to cancer cells that contain a particular antigen on their cell surface. 

III. The antibodies target one particular type of cell anywhere in the body and so TAT has the potential to treat cancers that have spread throughout the body.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Targeted Alpha Therapy (TAT) is a treatment in which a radioisotope emitting α-particles is specifically directed at the biological target.

question_html:
Which statements regarding boron neutron capture therapy (BNCT) are correct?

I. 10B atoms, present in the cancer cells, are irradiated with an electron beam from an outside source. 
II. 10B atoms capture neutrons, forming 11B atoms, which decay rapidly and consequently release alpha particles and gamma radiation.
III. BNCT is a promising form of radiotherapy for the treatment of head and neck cancers.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: BNCT involves injecting tumors with the non-radioactive boron-10 isotope which is then radiated with neutrons, not electrons, that interact with the boron-10 to produce boron-11, releasing alpha particles that kill the tumor.

question_html: Which is a correct definition of the term half-life?

MCQ_set.answer_html: It is the time it takes for half the number of atoms to decay.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Half-life is the time needed for 50% of the radioactive nuclei in any sample to undergo radioactive decay. After two half-lives, there will only be 25% of the original sample left; after three half-lives 12.5% of the original sample, etc.

MCQ_set.answer_html: It is half of the time needed for an original quantity of atoms to reduce to half of its initial value.
It is the time needed for an original quantity of atoms to double its initial value.
It is half of the time needed for an original quantity of atoms to double its initial value.

question_html:
Order the following particles from the lowest (most negative) to the highest (most positive) charge: 

I. Neutron
II. Positron
III. Alpha particle
IV. Beta particle

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The most negative particle is a beta particle (-1), followed by a neutron (0), then a positron (+1) and finally an alpha particle (+2).

question_html:
What is the correct order of increasing relative mass (from the lightest to the heaviest) of the following particles?

I. Proton
II. Alpha particle
III. Beta particle

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The lightest is a beta particle with a relative mass of 0, followed by the proton with a relative mass of 1. The heaviest is an alpha particle – relative mass of 4.

question_html:
Which equations correctly represent β decays?

I. \(^{42}_{19} \space K \rightarrow \space ^{42}_{20} \space Ca \space + \space ^{0}_{-1} \space β\)

II. \(^{82}_{35} \space Br \rightarrow \space ^{82}_{36} \space Kr \space + \space ^{0}_{-1} \space β\)

III. \(^{99}_{43} \space Tc \rightarrow \space ^{99}_{44} \space Ru \space + \space ^{0}_{-1} \space β\)

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: During beta decay, the mass number does not change and the atomic number increases by one due to the process in which a neutron turns into a proton.

question_html: What is a beta (β) particle?

MCQ_set.answer_html: A high speed electron or positron produced when one of the neutrons in the nucleus transforms into a proton.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A beta particle is a high-speed electron or positron emitted in the radioactive decay of an atomic nucleus when one of the neutrons transforms into a proton.

question_html: What is an alpha (α) particle?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: An alpha particle is a 2+ ion of He, containing only 2 protons and 2 neutrons.

MCQ_set.answer_html: A high-speed electron produced when one of the neutrons in the nucleus transforms into a proton.

question_html:
Which statements are correct regarding side effects of Taxol?

I. Treatment with Taxol has no side-effects.
II. Taxol also targets non-cancer cells that undergo rapid cell division.
III. Taxol frequently causes low blood counts, mouth sores, nausea, diarrhoea, and/or hair loss.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Taxol, just like other chemotherapy drugs, targets rapidly splitting cells. This is the reason why patients exhibit several severe side-effects during their treatment.

section_title: Taxol - a chiral auxiliary case study (AHL)

question_html:
Which statements correctly describe the method of action of Taxol?

I. Taxol works by interfering with the process of cell division.
II. Taxol promotes the growth of cancer cells.
III. Taxol binds to microtubules in the cytoplasm, preventing them from breaking down during cell division.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Taxol inhibits the growth of cancer cells.

section_title: Taxol - a chiral auxiliary case study (AHL)

question_html:
Which statements correctly summarise the possible semi-synthetic ways of producing Taxol?

I. Taxol is made by fermentation using animal cell cultures.
