II. A precursor of Taxol, 10-deacetylbaccatin, is extracted from the leaves of the European yew tree and converted into Taxol through several synthetic steps. 
III. Taxol precursor can be also synthesised by E. coli or yeast under specific conditions.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Taxol is made by fermentation using plant cell cultures, not animal.

section_title: Taxol - a chiral auxiliary case study (AHL)

question_html: The structure of a molecule of Taxol is shown below. What are the two circled functional groups, A and B?

MCQ_set.answer_html:
Group A Group B
hydroxyl ester
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The two circled functional groups are: A – hydroxyl (alcohol) and B – ester.

MCQ_set.answer_html:
Group A Group B
ester carbonyl

Group A Group B
hydroxyl carboxyl

Group A Group B
ester hydroxyl

section_title: Taxol - a chiral auxiliary case study (AHL)

question_html: What is the angle of rotation of plane-polarised light of a racemic mixture?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A racemic mixture is not optically active and therefore it does not rotate the plane-polarised light passing through it.

section_title: Taxol - a chiral auxiliary case study (AHL)

question_html:
Which statements correctly explain the importance of using specific enantiomers in medicine?

I. Both enantiomers are able to bind effectively to a receptor protein because of a correct orientation of the functional groups.

II. The other enantiomer may not be able to bind as strongly to the receptor protein because the groups are in the wrong orientation to form bonds.

III. One enantiomer may produce a therapeutic effect by binding to its target receptor protein, whereas the other may produce a toxic effect by binding somewhere else.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Only one enantiomer is able to bind effectively to a receptor protein because of a correct orientation of the functional groups.

section_title: Taxol - a chiral auxiliary case study (AHL)

question_html:
Below are the stages of the process of using a chiral auxiliary to produce a specific enantiomer during drug synthesis, in a random order. Which is the correct order?

I. Adding a chiral auxiliary to a non-chiral substrate.
II. Removal of the auxiliary.
III. Reaction resulting in synthesis of a single enantiomer.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Chiral auxiliaries are inserted during the synthesis phase to promote the production of the correct enantiomer. The chiral auxiliary is removed at a later step in the drug synthesis after the specific chiral centre in the drug is made.

section_title: Taxol - a chiral auxiliary case study (AHL)

question_html:
Which statements regarding chiral compounds are correct?

I. Chiral compounds contain asymmetric carbon atom(s) with 4 different groups attached.
II. Chiral compounds are usually not optically active.
III. Large organic molecules often have one or more chiral centers.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Chiral compounds are optically active.

section_title: Taxol - a chiral auxiliary case study (AHL)

question_html: Shikimic acid is a precursor to which antiviral medicine?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Shikimic acid, extracted from the star anise, is used as a base material for the production of Oseltamivir. Since the demand for the production of this antiviral medicine increased significantly, shikimic acid is being produced by E. coli bacteria under controlled conditions.

question_html: One of the key concepts of green chemistry is atom economy. What is understood by the term 'atom economy'?

MCQ_set.answer_html: In the synthesis of a compound, all materials used in the production should be incorporated into the final product, rather than having leftover materials or by-products.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The 'atom economy' is a measure of the effectiveness of chemical processes in terms of converting reactants into products. The higher the atom economy (closer to 100), the greener the process.  Atom economy = (molar mass of desired product / molar mass of all reactants) × 100.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The ratio of the mass of the product to the combined masses of the reactants, solvents and catalysts should be as small as possible.
Solvents and catalysts used in the process increase atom efficiency.
Such synthetic methods should be designed as to minimise the incorporation of all materials used in the process into the final product.

question_html:
Which combination correctly gives an example of low-level nuclear waste and an appropriate method for its disposal?

Material Disposal method
I. Spent uranium fuel. Incineration to reduce its volume.
II. Empty syringes used to administer cobalt-60 medicine. Spending 10-20 years in spent fuel pools (wet storage).
III. Protective clothing used at the hospital during radiation treatment. Steel cylinders (dry storage) until sufficient decay has happened so that the waste can be disposed of as ordinary waste.
IV. Materials from nuclear reactors. Burying underground, near the surface.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Protective clothing used at the hospital during radiation treatment is an example of low-level nuclear waste, due to its limited radioactivity. It should be stored in dry storage until sufficient decay has happened, so that it can be disposed of as regular waste.

question_html:
Which combination correctly gives an example of high-level nuclear waste and an appropriate method of its disposal?

Material Disposal method
I. Spent uranium fuel. Spending 10-20 years in spent fuel pools (wet storage).
II. Fission products generated in the reactor core. Burying underground, near the surface.
III. Liquid waste containing fission products. Pouring the wastes down the drain for further treatment at a local water treatment facility.
IV. Gloves from the hospitals administering radiation therapy. Steel cylinders (dry storage) until sufficient decay has happened so that the waste can be disposed of as ordinary waste.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Spent uranium fuel is an example of high-level nuclear waste, which due to its high radioactivity should be kept for decades in wet storage.

question_html:
Which statements correctly explain the reason why antibiotic waste (from improper drug disposal and animal waste) is a problem?  

I. Antibiotic waste causes antibiotic resistance, by adapting bacteria to produce penicillinase.

II. The existence of antibiotic waste in water or soil can destroy the 'good' bacteria and allow for          the development of 'bad' bacteria.

III. Antibiotic waste may potentially cause the formation of a supervirus.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Antibiotics have no effect on viruses, therefore antibiotic waste will not cause the formation of a supervirus.

question_html: Substances ingested or injected into a patient, used in medical imaging techniques for diagnostic purposes are called ___________.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Radioactive isotopes are chemical elements which undergo radioactive decay and release ionising radiation which is used in medical imaging techniques.

question_html:
What are the potential effects of nonpolar organic solvents such as hexane or benzene on living organisms?

I. Hexane is a neurotoxicant and exposure can cause numbness in the feet and hands and later weakness or numbness throughout the arms and legs.
II. It has been determined that benzene causes cancer in humans and animals.
III. Benzene and hexane can both be handled in the laboratory without any safety precautions.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Both hexane and benzene have very serious potential health hazards and therefore correct handling and disposal methods of these organic solvents should be applied.

question_html: Some solvent waste can be recycled using a separation technique which is based on the difference in boiling points of the solvents present in the mixture. This technique is called:

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Fractional distillation is the process of separating the mixture into its fractions by their boiling points. The mixture is heated to a temperature at which one of the fractions of the mixture will evaporate. Once all that fraction has distilled, the temperature is increased, so the next fraction can distil.

question_html:
Ethanol is a solvent commonly used in synthesis reactions. What are the proper ways of disposing of leftover ethanol?

I. Incineration of the solvent for a combustion reaction.
II. Diluting to a low concentration and disposal as waste water.
III. Mixing with all other organic and inorganic solvent wastes and pouring them down the drain for further treatment at a local water treatment facility.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Organic and inorganic solvents should not be mixed and poured down the drain – they should be separated and specialised methods of disposal should be applied, depending on the type of solvent.

question_html:
One of the few different ways that antiviral medicines work is by interfering with the replication of the virus. This is done by:

I. Interfering with the host's ability to generate the protein capsule for the virus.
II. Inhibiting the activity of enzymes within the host cell that are necessary for the formation of new viruses.
III. Incorporating active metabolites into the growing DNA strands of the viruses, stopping the replication process.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: All of the options given are correct.

question_html:
One of the few different ways that antiviral medicines work is by blocking the virus from entering the cell. This is done by:

I. Mimicking the virus to bind to the cell receptors.
II. Interfering with the host's ability to generate the protein capsule for the virus.
III. Interfering with the host cell’s selectively permeable membranes, not allowing the entry of viral genetic material.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Generating the protein capsule for the virus is a stage of replication of the virus and not how the virus enters the cell.

question_html:
Viruses are very difficult to combat because they undergo constant mutations. Which are the types of possible virus mutations?

I. antigenic drift
II. antigenic transfer
III. antigenic shift

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The two types of virus mutation are antigenic drift and antigenic shift. Antigenic drift produces small changes to the virus strain; antigenic shift, on the other hand, combines two or more different strains of virus to produce a new one.

question_html: Zanamivir and Oseltamivir work by inhibiting an enzyme called neuraminidase responsible for:

MCQ_set.answer_html: cutting through the host's cell membrane allowing the replicated virus to leave.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Zanamivir and Oseltamivir inactivate neuraminidase, so the virus is not able to leave or detach itself from the host cell.

MCQ_set.answer_html: stopping the DNA from entering the nucleus.
binding with receptors on the cell surface.

question_html: The structures of Oseltamivir and Zanamivir are available in the data booklet on page 39. Which functional group, present in oseltamivir and not present in zanamivir, is used to turn it into an active metabolite?

MCQ_set.answer_html: ester group which needs to be hydrolysed
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The ester group in the structure of oseltamivir needs to be converted into a carboxyl group, through a hydrolysis reaction.

MCQ_set.answer_html: aromatic ring which needs to be opened
alkyl group which needs to be substituted

question_html:
How does human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) affect the organism?

I. HIV attacks and kills CD4 lymphocyte cells.
II. HIV weakens the body’s immune system.
III. HIV uses CD4 lymphocyte cells to reproduce the virus.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: All above answers are correct.

question_html:
How can HIV be transmitted?

I. Through sharing of infected bodily fluids such as vaginal fluids or semen.
II. By receiving blood transfusion with infected blood.
III. Through a hand shake.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: HIV is spread only through infected bodily fluids which come in contact with a mucous membrane or damaged tissue or are directly injected into the bloodstream. HIV is not transmitted by air, water, saliva, sweat, or sharing toilets or drinks.

question_html:
What is the correct order of the stages in the reproduction cycle of a bacterium?

I. Cell separates.
II. Cell wall and plasma wall begin to divide.
III. Cell elongates and DNA is replicated.
IV. Cell wall forms around the DNA.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A bacterium rapidly divides by binary fission, using the host organism's nutrients, but does not attack the cells directly, like viruses do.

question_html:
What is the correct order of the stages in the reproduction cycle of a virus?

I. Virus injects its DNA or RNA into the cell.
II. Virus attaches itself to a cell.
III. The host cell bursts, releasing newly made viruses.
IV. Virus takes over the cellular machinery in order to replicate the nucleic acid.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: First viruses identify and attach themselves to a specific cell and inject their genetic material. The host cell is then hijacked by the virus to use its cellular machinery to make more viruses. Finally, the host cell bursts, releasing the newly produced viruses, and dies itself.

question_html:
Which statements regarding the difference between bacteria and viruses are true?

I. Neither Bacteria, nor viruses are living organisms. 
II. Both bacteria and viruses can live outside of living organisms but viruses cannot perform any biological functions without the host cells. 
III. Bacteria contain both DNA and RNA, while viruses contain either DNA or RNA.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Bacteria are certainly considered to be living, which means the first statement is false. Viruses invade the host cells and take over the cells to reproduce using either RNA or DNA. On the other hand, bacteria are living cells, with cellular structure and can reproduce outside host cells by cell division.

question_html: Omeprazole and esomeprazole prevent the release of acid into the stomach. They do it by:

MCQ_set.answer_html: irreversibly blocking the enzyme system called the gastric proton pump.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Omeprazole is a proton pump inhibitor and works by preventing the release of acid from the parietal cells into the stomach.

MCQ_set.answer_html: binding to a receptor protein - histamine H2-receptor.
inhibiting the process of making and releasing prostaglandin.

question_html: A compound such as ranitidine (Zantac) inhibits the production of acid in the stomach acid. It does it by:

MCQ_set.answer_html: Binding to a receptor protein - histamine H2-receptor.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Ranitidine inhibits the production of the acid by binding to a receptor protein (histamine H2-receptor)

MCQ_set.answer_html: Inhibiting the process of making and releasing prostaglandin.
Irreversibly blocking the enzyme system called the gastric proton pump.

question_html: What is the sum of all coefficients in the correctly balanced equation between sodium carbonate and hydrochloric acid?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: 1Na2CO3 + 2HCl → 2NaCl + 1H2O + 1CO2, sum of coefficients: 1+2+2+1+1 = 7

question_html: A buffer is a solution which resists a change in pH upon addition of a small amount of an acid or a base. Which pair of compounds of equal concentrations and volumes mixed together would produce a buffer solution?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Buffer solutions must contain two conjugated species (differing by one H+ ion, in this case CH3COOH / CH3COO-).

question_html: Hydrochloric acid is a component of gastric juice. What is the pH of a 0.0100 mol dm-3 HCl(aq) solution?
Which equation is not a neutralisation reaction?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: This reaction is only a double displacement, not neutralisation (acid-base reaction). ZnS(s) is not a base and water is not one of the products.

question_html: Which is a correctly balanced equation for the reaction between magnesium hydroxide and hydrochloric acid?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Answer contains correct formulae of the compounds Mg(OH)2, HCl, MgCl2 and H2O, and is correctly balanced.

question_html: Which compounds are used in antacids?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: KOH and NaOH are strong bases, and are not used in antacids

question_html:
Dyspepsia is a condition of overproduction of stomach acid. Medical treatment of this illness includes prescribing:

I. aspirin
II. H2-receptor antagonists
III. proton pump inhibitors

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Only methods II and III: H2-receptor antagonists, or proton pump inhibitors which stop the production of stomach acid, are valid ways of treating dyspepsia.

question_html:
Morphine can be converted into codeine and diamorphine via two types of reactions. Choose the correct combination of reaction types needed to convert:

morphine into codeine morphine into diamorphine
I methylation elimination
II esterification methylation
III methylation esterification
IV addiction esterification

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Codeine is sometimes referred to as methylmorphine since one hydroxyl functional group is replaced with a methyl alkyl group via a methylation reaction. Diamorphine is made synthetically by reacting morphine with ethanol in an esterification reaction.

question_html:
What are the potential side-effects of opiates?

I. fever
II. addiction
III. development of tolerance

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Fever is not one of the side-effects of opiates.

question_html:
Dopamine is released when endorphins and opiates bind with endorphin receptors. What is the role of dopamine?

I. It functions as a neurotransmitter.
II. It functions as an antipyretic.
III. It helps regulate movement and emotional response.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Dopamine is an amine acting as a neurotransmitter which helps to regulate the brain's pleasure and reward centers.

question_html: What is the difference between the analgesic function of aspirin and opiates?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Aspirin inhibits the production of prostaglandins and opiates bind to opiate/endorphin receptors in the brain.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Aspirin is a mild analgesic, inhibiting the production of prostaglandins at the site of injury. Opiates are strong analgesics, intercepting pain signals in the brain.

MCQ_set.answer_html: They both work the same by inhibiting the production of prostaglandins.
Opiates inhibit the production of prostaglandins and aspirin binds to receptors in the brain.
They both work the same by binding to the receptors in the brain.

question_html:
Why is codeine less effective as a painkiller than morphine?

I. Codeine’s ability to bind to receptors is much lower than in morphine.
II. Codeine must first be metabolised in the liver back into morphine.
III. The structures of codeine and morphine are very similar.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The structure of codeine and morphine are very similar but this does not make codeine less effective.

question_html: Diamorphine is a stronger opiate than morphine due to its a higher ability to cross the blood-brain barrier. Why is diamophine able to do this more effectively than morphine?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Because it has the least polar side groups attached to the non-polar core.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The core of the diamorphine molecule is non-polar and the ester groups have relatively low polarity.

MCQ_set.answer_html: It can cross the blood-brain barrier just as easily as the other opiates.
Because it has the most polar side groups attached to the non-polar core.
Because it has the most polar side groups attached to the polar core.

question_html: Which functional group in the structure of opiates ensures the highest solubility in water?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Hydroxyl groups attached to the backbone of opiates make the molecule much more polar than with the other side-groups. Additionally, hydrogen bonds are formed with molecules of water, ensuring the highest solubility in water.

question_html: What two functional groups are present in the core (backbone) of the three opiates?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Morphine, codeine and diamorphine contain tertiary amine and aromatic (benzene) ring in their structure.

question_html: How do the opiates work as analgesics?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Opiates bind to endorphin/opioid receptors and interrupt the delivery of the pain signal.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Opiates, upon reaching the brain, activate the endorphin/opiate receptors that are found in the brain and produce an effect that mimics the effect of endorphins.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Opiates inhibit the production of the prostaglandins formed at the site of the injury.
Opiates prevent the cross-linking of the polymers in the cell walls.
Opiates produce active metabolites which react with neurotransmitters.

question_html: What is the difference between the terms opiate and opioid?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Opiates are analgesics derived from natural poppy opium and opioids are synthetically obtained compounds which mimic the behavior of the naturally occurring opiates.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Opiates are the compounds found naturally in the opium poppy or derived from it. Opioids are synthetically obtained substances which act on opioid receptors to produce morphine-like effects.

MCQ_set.answer_html: There is no difference and the two terms can be used interchangeably.
Opioids are analgesics derived from natural poppy opium and opiates are synthetically obtained compounds which mimic the behaviour of the naturally occurring opioids.
Opiates are strong analgesics intercepting pain signals in the brain, opioids are weak analgesics inhibiting the production of prostaglandins.

question_html:
Aspirin can be chemically modified into a salt in order to: 

I. increase its aqueous solubility 
II. increase its bioavailability
III. turn it into a strong analgesic

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Converting aspirin into salt makes it more soluble in water. The bioavailability of soluble aspirin is almost the same as the insoluble form because the ionic salt reacts with stomach acid to produce (insoluble) aspirin.

question_html: Alcohol shouldn’t be drunk while taking aspirin because it might cause haemorrhage in the stomach. This effect is called:

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Synergistic effect means that each drug has a higher medicinal effect when taken in combination than they would when taken separately.

question_html: How are large quantities of penicillin prepared by pharmaceutical companies?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Populations of fungi are fermented in large steel tanks under controlled conditions in a sterile environment.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Production of large population of fungi in a Petri dish is not appropriate, therefore they are fermented in large, stainless steel tanks under stress conditions in a sterile environment.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Populations of fungi are grown in Petri dishes.
By designing specific molecules to interfere with only chosen target receptors.
By extracting molecules from leaves and flowers of different plants.

question_html: Certain bacteria produce enzymes such as penicillinase or beta-lactamase. These enzymes render penicillin inactive by:

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Certain strains of bacteria developed methods of rendering penicillin inactive by 
producing an enzyme known as penicillinase, which breaks the beta-lactam ring of the penicillin and stops it from working.

MCQ_set.answer_html: replacing side groups R in the structure of penicillin

question_html: How does penicillin work?

MCQ_set.answer_html: By permanently binding to the transpeptidase enzyme and not allowing cross-linking to take place during the binary fission process.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Penicillin binds irreversibly to the enzyme (transpeptidase) involved in the cross-linking of the polymer making up the bacteria cell wall. This results in weakening of the wall and causes the bacterial cell to burst as an effect of high osmotic pressure from surrounding water.

MCQ_set.answer_html: By inhibiting the sensory neural pathways of pain.
By interfering with the histamine receptor and blocking its action.

question_html: The purpose of introducing different R groups into the structure of penicillin is to differentiate physical properties of the molecule and therefore its bioavailability. How will the introduction of a non-polar group such as a phenyl group in Penicillin G affect its bioavailability and its administration method?

MCQ_set.answer_html: It will make the molecule less soluble in water and therefore will require delivery by intravenous injection.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The benzene ring in Penicilin G is nonpolar, so it must be injected to have an effect, as it is not water-soluble enough to be absorbed by oral ingestion.

MCQ_set.answer_html: It will make the molecule more soluble in water and allow for easy oral delivery.
It will make the molecule less soluble in water and allow for easy oral delivery.
It will make the molecule more soluble in water and therefore will require delivery by intravenous injection.

question_html:
Pure salicylic acid has a melting point of 158.6°C and pure aspirin melts at 135°C. Four students synthesised aspirin in the laboratory. To determine its purity, they tested the melting point of their samples. The following results were obtained:

Melting point / °C
Sample A 128-130
Sample B 134-135
Sample C 132-136
Sample D 157-158

Which sample was the purest?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The sample with the melting point closest to 135°C and the smallest range of temperatures corresponds to the purest sample. The more impuries are present in the sample, the lower and more spread the melting point temperatures are. Sample D is most likely unreacted salicylic acid.

question_html: Synthesized aspirin should be further purified using one these laboratory techniques:

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Recrystallisation is a common laboratory technique used to improve the purity of the solid product. It is done by dissolving both the synthesized compound and impurities in an appropriate solvent. After lowering the temperature, the compound crystallizes, leaving dissolved impurities behind.

question_html: Aspirin, being a mild analgesic, inhibits the production of what substance responsible for pain sensation and swelling?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Aspirin works by stopping cyclooxygenase, the enzyme that produces prostaglandins.

question_html: Which signal will not be present in the IR spectrum of aspirin?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Aspirin structure does not contain C ≡ C bonds, therefore this peak is not observed in the IR spectrum.

question_html: What are the two functional groups present in the molecule of aspirin?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Aspirin contains a carboxyl group –COOH as well as an ester group –O(C=O)CH3

question_html: What is defined as a desired effect of a drug on a patient’s body, affecting the physiological state of the body, altering mood or changing the perception of sensory information?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A therapeutic effect is a positive, desirable and beneficial effect of a medical treatment of any kind, on patient’s body.

question_html: During the process of developing new drugs, three phases of clinical trials on humans take place. Which of those phases requires the largest number of volunteers?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Phase 3 confirms the effectiveness of the drug on the larger group of volunteers and compares its activity with existing drug treatments or placebos.

MCQ_set.answer_html: All phases require the same number of volunteers.

question_html: What is the difference between the terms LD50 and TD50?

MCQ_set.answer_html: LD50 refers to the dose needed to kill 50% of animal test subjects, and TD50 refers to the dose needed to cause a toxic effect in 50% of human test subjects.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: For ethical reasons LD50 value for humans is not determined. Only TD50 (toxic – unacceptable adverse effect – ​dose) value is found for humans.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Both terms mean the same and can be used interchangeably.
LD50 refers to the dose needed to kill 50% of human test subjects, and TD50 refers to the dose needed to cause a toxic effect in 50% of human test subjects.
LD50 refers to the dose needed to kill 50% of animal test subjects, and TD50 refers to the dose needed to cause a therapeutic effect in 50% of animal test subjects.

question_html:
How are the lead compounds of medicines found?

I. by isolation from natural sources
II. by chemical synthesis
III. by searching through existing ‘banks’ of compounds already synthesised

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: All three methods listed can be used to identify the active ingredient (lead compound) of the medicine.

question_html: What is a correct definition of the term: placebo effect?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Patients given inert substance and experiencing positive effects of the medicine.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Placebo effect is a phenomenon of experiencing positive or negative effects of the medicine without actually taking it. It is usually related to the pure belief of the patient.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Patients given active ingredient and experiencing no effect of the medicine.
Patients given inert substance, experiencing no effects of the drugs.
Patients given active ingredient and experiencing positive effects of the medicine.

question_html: Which is not a type of injection?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The three types of injections are: subcutaneous, intramuscular and intravenous.

question_html: Therapeutic index and therapeutic window are two factors taken into consideration during the process of developing a new drug. These two factors are determined through both animal and human studies. Which definition correctly describes the term therapeutic window in humans?

MCQ_set.answer_html: It is the dosage range between the minimum amount needed to cause a therapeutic effect and the level which produces toxic effects.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Therapeutic window is a dosage range which causes therapeutic effect without causing any significant negative effect in patients. It is a range between minimum effective concentration and the minimum toxic concentration.

MCQ_set.answer_html: It is the dosage range between the minimum amount needed to therapeutic effect and the maximum level which produces no effect.
It is the dosage range between the maximum amount needed to cause a toxic effect and the level which produces lethal effect.
It is the dosage range between the maximum amount needed to cause a lethal effect and the level which produces therapeutic effect.

question_html:
On a molecular level, drugs interact with the 

I. functional groups of haemoglobin molecules
II. receptors in cell cytoplasm 
III. receptors in cell membranes

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Drugs act by binding to a receptor in the body. This receptor is either an enzyme (inhibited by the medicine) or a protein found in cell membranes or in the cytoplasm of the cell.

question_html: What should be the most effective way of administering a medicine if it comes in the form of a gas, volatile liquid or dry powder?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The medicines in this form should be administered via pulmonary route because the lungs have a large surface area, so the absorption of the drug into the bloodstream is very quick.

question_html: What is the fraction of the administered amount of the medicine that reaches the target site?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Bioavailability is the fraction of an administered dose of the medicine that reaches the target site.

question_html:
Primary and secondary cells are both used in portable electronic devices. Which of the following statement(s) are correct about these types of cells?

I. Secondary cells can be recharged

II. Primary cells are disposed of after they are no longer able to produce an electric current. 

III. The reverse reaction in a secondary cell has a negative value for its ΔG

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The reverse reaction in a secondary cell is non-spontaneous (positive ΔG).

question_html: In a voltaic cell, which one of the following statements correctly describes the reactions that occur at the anode and cathode?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Metal atoms are oxidised at the anode and metal ions are reduced at the cathode.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: In a voltaic cell, oxidation occurs at the anode and reduction occurs at the cathode (An Ox and Red Cat).

MCQ_set.answer_html: Metal ions are oxidised at the anode and metal atoms are reduced at the cathode.
Metal atoms gain electrons at the cathode and metal ions lose electrons at the anode.
Metal ions gain electrons at the anode and metal atoms lose electrons at the cathode.

question_html: Ocean acidification caused by increased concentrations of greenhouse gases is harmful to coral because corals are mainly composed of which of the following substances?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Corals are mainly composed of calcium carbonate (CaCO3), which reacts with hydrogen ions in the water, which can lead to the destruction of coral reefs.

question_html: Which of the following acids are produced when carbon dioxide dissolves in ocean water?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: H2CO3 is carbonic acid, formed when carbon dioxide dissolves in water.

question_html: Which of the following does not reduce carbon dioxide emissions?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Increased use of fuels derived from crude oil, such as gasoline
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The increased combustion of fossil fuels would actually increase the amount of carbon dioxide emitted into the atmosphere.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Increased use of renewable energy sources such as solar and wind
Increased use of hydrogen fuel cell vehicles
Increased use of biofuels such as bioethanol

question_html: Which of the following cause global dimming?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Oxides of sulfur, ash and soot in the atmosphere
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Particulate matter such as the oxides of sulfur, ash and soot in the atmosphere absorb incoming solar radiation, leading to global dimming.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Increased concentrations of hydrogen ions in the oceans

question_html: Which of the following is a greenhouse gas produced by the combustion of fossil fuels?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Carbon dioxide (CO2) is a greenhouse gas that is produced by the combustion of fossil fuels such as coal, natural gas and fuels derived from crude oil.

question_html: Which of the following has the longest wavelength and lowest frequency?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Infra-red (IR) radiation has the longest wavelength and lowest frequency. The relationship between wavelength and frequency is inverse; high frequency = short wavelength and low frequency = long wavelength.

question_html: Which of the following gases is IR active?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: H2O is IR active, meaning that it absorbs IR radiation and is classified as a greenhouse gas.

question_html:
Which of the following molecular vibrations in CO2 result in a change in the dipole moment of the molecule?

I. Asymmetrical stretching 

II. Bending

III. Symmetrical stretching 

A. I only

B. II only

C. I, II and III

D. I and II only

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Bending and asymmetrical stretching produce a change in the dipole moment of the CO2 molecule allowing it to absorb IR (infra-red) radiation.

question_html: Which of the following are the correct conditions for the fermentation of glucose?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The conditions of a fermentation reaction are a temperature of 37oC in anaerobic conditions. In addition a catalyst (zymase) present in yeast is used.

question_html: Which of the following functional groups are present in a molecule of biodiesel?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A molecule of biodiesel has an ester group bonded to a long hydrocarbon chain and a methyl group.

question_html: Which wavelengths of light are absorbed by the chlorophyll molecule that result in its green colour?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Chlorophyll is a biological pigment that absorbs wavelengths of visible light. The wavelengths of light that correspond to red and blue light are absorbed and wavelengths of light that correspond to green light are reflected, making chlorophyll appear green.

question_html: Which of the following could be used as the catalyst in a transesterification reaction?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The catalyst in a transesterification reaction can be either a strong acid or a strong base. KOH is the only strong base in the list of examples given.

question_html: Which of the following is the correct, balanced equation for the fermentation of glucose to produce ethanol?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The products of the fermentation of glucose are ethanol and carbon dioxide. The balanced equation must have the same number and type of atoms in the reactants and the products.

question_html: Which of the following can be used as reactants in a transesterification reaction to produce biodiesel?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Biodiesel is produced in the reaction of a triglyceride (such as vegetable oil) and either methanol or ethanol with a strong acid or strong base as a catalyst.

question_html: Which feature do both beta-carotene and chlorophyll have that enables them to absorb wavelengths of visible light?

MCQ_set.answer_html: A conjugated system of alternating single and double bonds
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Molecules with conjugated systems of a certain size absorb wavelengths of visible light. These conjugated systems are composed of alternating single and double bonds.

question_html:
U-235 is a fissile isotope that undergoes nuclear fission in a nuclear power station. The equation for the fission of U-235 is shown below with one isotope missing. 

23592U + 10n → _______ + 9236Kr + 310n

Which isotope of barium (Ba) is missing from the equation?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The sum of the mass numbers and atomic numbers of the reactants and products must be the same.

question_html: Which of the following is the most suitable method of disposal for high-level nuclear waste?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Vitrification and storage in a geologically stable location.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: High-level waste, with its high activity and long half-life, is made into a glass-like substance and stored in a geologically stable location.

question_html:
The equation for a nuclear reaction is shown below:

21H + 21H → 32He + 10n

Which of the following is correct about this nuclear reaction?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: In a fusion reaction, the binding energy per nucleon increases, resulting in a more stable product.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Smaller nuclei combine to form a less stable nucleus.
Larger nuclei split to form smaller, more stable nuclei.

question_html: Absorption spectra are produced as electrons transition to higher energy levels by absorbing wavelengths or frequencies of visible light. Which of the following correctly explains the relationship between the wavelength or frequency of light absorbed and the energy?

MCQ_set.answer_html: As the energy increases, the frequency of light absorbed increases.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: As the energy of visible light increases, the wavelength decreases and the frequency increases.

MCQ_set.answer_html: As the energy increases, the frequency of light absorbed decreases.
As the energy increases, the wavelength of light absorbed increases.
As the energy decreases, the wavelength of light absorbed decreases.

question_html:
Both producers and consumers rely on the reciprocal processes of respiration and photosynthesis to keep the balance of oxygen and carbon dioxide in the atmosphere. Which of the following can affect the amount of carbon dioxide present in the atmosphere?

I. Population growth of humans 

II. Deforestation

III. Combustion of fossil fuels

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct. Increasing population levels mean an increase in the amount of respiration occurring and therefore an increase in CO2 levels. Deforestation will lead to a decrease in the number of trees photosynthesising and therefore lead to an increase in CO2 levels. Combustion of fossil fuels can generate large amounts of carbon dioxide as a product and therefore also increase CO2 levels.

question_html: Which of the following hydrocarbons could have been produced in an aromatisation reaction?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Aromatisation is a chemical reaction that converts straight-chain hydrocarbons into aromatic hydrocarbons. Methylbenzene (C6H5CH3) is an aromatic hydrocarbon that has a higher octane number than a straight-chain hydrocarbon.

question_html: Coal can be converted into syngas in the process of coal gasification. Which two gases make up syngas?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Syngas is a mixture of carbon monoxide and hydrogen gas.

question_html: Which of the following is not an example of a condensation polymer?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct because glucose is a small molecule (a monomer) and all of the other answers are examples of condensation polymers (long chain molecules made up from many monomer units).

question_html: Photosynthesis is an endothermic process. Where does the energy for photosynthesis come from?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct. Producers, like plants and algae, are capable of obtaining light energy from the sun and converting that form of energy into stored chemical potential energy in a molecule of glucose, a type of carbohydrate, during the process of photosynthesis.

question_html:
Which factors can affect metabolic processes?

I. pH

II. Temperature

III. Enzymes

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct because metabolic processes can be affected by pH, temperature and the presence of enzymes used to catalyse them.

question_html: Which of the following is an anabolic process?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct because when compounds are synthesised, the process is called anabolism. @2, @3 and @4 are all incorrect as they are catabolic processes.

question_html: Which of the following is an example of a condensation reaction?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct because condensation reactions involve the combination of at least two small molecules and water forms as a byproduct. Esterification reactions involve joining an alcohol and a carboxylic acid molecule together to form an ester and water. @2 and @3 are incorrect as water is not formed. @4 is incorrect as, although water is formed in respiration, two small molecules are not joined together (i.e. it is catabolic not anabolic).

question_html: Which biochemical molecules contain the genetic information for an organism?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is the correct answer because nucleic acids are biopolymers that allow organisms to transfer genetic information from one generation to the next.

question_html: Which of the following occurs when a straight-chain hydrocarbon undergoes an isomerisation reaction?

MCQ_set.answer_html: The straight-chain hydrocarbon is converted to a branched hydrocarbon and the octane number increases
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: In an isomerisation reaction, straight-chain hydrocarbons are converted into branched-chain hydrocarbons. Branched-chain hydrocarbons have higher octane numbers than straight-chain hydrocarbons, therefore, the octane number increases.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The straight-chain hydrocarbon is converted to an aromatic hydrocarbon and the octane number increases
The straight-chain hydrocarbon is converted to an aromatic hydrocarbon and the octane number decreases
The straight-chain hydrocarbon is converted to a branched hydrocarbon and the octane number decreases

question_html: Which of the following is an advantage of the combustion of natural gas for use as a fuel?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Natural gas has a higher specific energy than coal and oil
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: When compared to other fossil fuels, natural gas has a higher specific energy, which means it contains more energy per unit mass.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Natural gas has a lower energy density than oil and coal
Natural gas is unevenly distributed throughout the world
Natural gas produces carbon dioxide, a potent greenhouse gas, when burned

section_title: Advantages and disadvantages of fossil fuels

question_html: In an energy transfer, the quality of energy is degraded. Which of the following is a form of low-quality energy?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Steam released from the cooling towers of a coal-fired power station.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The steam released into the environment is a form of low-quality energy, meaning it is less able to do useful work.

question_html: Which of the following energy sources make up the largest percentage of the world's energy use?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The world is still heavily reliant on fossil fuels such as coal, oil and natural gas. Currently about 80% of the world's energy use is provided by fossil fuels.

question_html: Which of the following best describes renewable energy sources?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Unlike non-renewable energy sources, which are finite, renewable energy sources such as solar, wind and geothermal are naturally replenished, meaning that they will not run out in the average human lifespan.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Renewable energy sources include coal, oil and natural gas.
Renewable energy sources contribute to a larger percentage of the world's energy needs than non-renewable energy sources.

question_html: Which of the following renewable energy sources converts light energy from the Sun into electrical energy?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Solar energy converts light energy from the Sun into electrical energy.

question_html: Which of the following is the correct equation to calculate percentage efficiency?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The percentage efficiency is calculated by the dividing the useful output energy by the total input energy and then multiplying by 100. It must be multiplied by 100 in order to get a percentage.

question_html: Which of the following fuels has the highest specific energy?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Uranium-235 has a very high specific energy, which means that it produces a large amount of energy per unit mass.

question_html: Lead is poisonous. This is because it can inhibit the activity of a number of enzymes essential for the synthesis of hemoglobin. It does this by:

MCQ_set.answer_html: binding to a site on the enzyme away from the active site irreversibly.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct because heavy metals bind to a site other than the active site on enzymes and thereby bring about a conformational change which makes the enzyme inactive.

MCQ_set.answer_html: binding to the active site of the enzymes irreversibly.
binding to the active site of the enzymes reversibly.
binding to a site on the enzyme away from the active site reversibly.

question_html: According to the Beer-Lambert Law, the absorbance of a solution containing a protein-dye complex will be proportional to the

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct because absorbance is a measure of log10I0/I. Therefore, it will be directly proportional to the concentration.

question_html:
The Vmax of an enzyme-catalysed reaction can be altered by:

I. Changing pH

II. Changing temperature

III. Adding a competitive inhibitor

IV. Adding a non-competitive inhibitor

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct because the rate of an enzyme-catalysed reaction can be altered by changing pH and temperature. Additionally, for non-competitive inhibitors, the Vmax is lowered, but for competitive inhibitors, the Vmax stays the same.

question_html: Enzymes are often referred to as 'biological catalysts'. A catalyst speeds up a reaction by:

MCQ_set.answer_html: Providing an alternative pathway for the reaction.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct because a catalyst increases the rate of a reaction by providing an alternative pathway which has a lower activation energy.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Increasing the average kinetic energy of the particles.
Increasing the surface area of the reactants.

question_html: Biopolymers, such as proteins, are synthesised by condensation reactions. What is a condensation reaction?

MCQ_set.answer_html: A reaction whereby two molecules are joined together and water is also produced.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct because the two key characteristics of condensation reactions are that they (a) join molecules together and (b) produce water as a byproduct.

MCQ_set.answer_html: A reaction whereby water catalyses the joining of two molecules.
A reaction whereby a molecule is split apart and water is also produced.

question_html: A natural gas-fired power station has an efficiency of 60%. Which of the following explains how the quality of the energy is degraded in the power station?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: At each stage in the power station, the quality of the energy is degraded as heat is lost to the surroundings.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Natural gas has a low specific energy.
Natural gas has a low energy density.

question_html:
Which of the following is correct about the intermolecular forces between polymers in the following materials?

Option Weaker intermolecular forces Stronger intermolecular forces
A Isotactic polypropene Atactic polypropene
B Flexible polyvinyl chloride Rigid polyvinyl chloride
C High-density polyethene (HDPE) Low-density polyethene (LDPE)
D Unexpanded polystyrene Expanded polystyrene

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: When additives are added to polymer materials, the additives add spacing between polymer chains and weaken the intermolecular forces between polymer chains. Flexible PVC is where plasticisers have been added, weakening the intermolecular forces between polymer chains. This is why @1 is correct. Expanded polystyrene is where volatile hydrocarbons have been added, causing bubbles to form, increasing the spacing between polymer chains. Therefore expanded polystyrene would have weaker intermolecular forces than unexpanded, so @4 would be incorrect. HDPE has little to no branching and would allow the polymers to be in close proximity to one another, in comparison with LDPE, therefore HDPE would have stronger intermolecular forces between polymers. Isotactic polypropene is very ordered, with methyl groups oriented on the same side of the polymer backbone, and would allow polymer chains to pack closely. Therefore isotactic polypropene would have stronger intermolecular forces between polymer chains than atactic polypropene. This is why @3 and @2 would be incorrect.

question_html: Calculate the atom economy for the production of methanol from the nucleophilic substitution reaction of bromomethane with sodium hydroxide.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
CH3Br + NaOH → CH3OH + NaBr

Atom economy = (32.05)/(40.00+94.94) × 100%

Atom economy = 23.75%

question_html: Which of the following best explains what occurs when an elastic band breaks?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The covalent bonds in the elastomer cross-link break at the elastic band breaking point. This does not allow the elastomer to coil around this region. Since it is not reversible it cannot be due to intermolecular forces, therefore @2 and @3 are incorrect. Since the material is still elastic in the unbroken regions there is still a material with covalent bonds, therefore @4 would be incorrect.

question_html:
Which of the following is correct?

Option Thermoplastic Thermoset
A Maintain shape when heated Soften when heated
B Cannot be melted or remoulded Can be melted and remoulded
C Has intermolecular forces between polymer chains Has cross-links between polymer chains
D Requires curing of the prepolymer Does not require curing of prepolymer

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A thermoplastic is a material made up of polymer chains with intermolecular forces between polymer chains. This causes the material to soften when heated, makes it capable of melting and remoulding, and does not require any curing. A thermoset polymer has covalent cross-links between polymer chains. This causes the material to remain firm when heated, does not allow it to be melted and remoulded and requires curing of the prepolymer in order to form the covalent cross-links.

question_html: Which of the following additives could be used to form expanded polystyrene?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: In order to form expanded polystyrene, a volatile substance is required. The volatile substance evaporates and forms gas bubbles as the polymer forms around the gas bubbles. This produces a very lightweight foam. Options @2, @3 and @4 are not volatile substances.

question_html: Identify which of the following materials would be unlikely to be made of expanded polystyrene.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Plastic cutlery would be unlikely to be made from expanded polystyrene. Since the material is very lightweight and has a high-impact absorption, it would be very difficult to apply force to the cutlery to puncture and attach to many food items. Expanded polystyrene's high impact absorption make it an ideal material for @3 and @4. Expanded polystyrene's high insulating properties make it an ideal material for @2 and @4.

question_html: Which of the following is not an addition polymer?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Polyester is not an addition polymer. Recall that esters are formed through a condensation reaction with alcohols and carboxylic acids, where water is produced as another product. Similarly, polyesters are formed through condensation reactions with dialcohols and dicarboxylic acids, where water is produced as another product. @2, @3 and @4 are all addition polymers, as they are all alkenes that can undergo addition polymerisation through the breaking of the pi bond in the double bond.

question_html: Identify which of the following provides the best reason for why phthalate plasticiser molecules are added to polyvinyl chloride polymers.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Molecules prevent PVC polymer chains from packing too closely, increasing its flexibility.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: As phthalate molecules are added as plasticisers to PVC, they interact with the polar C-Cl bonds. This interaction causes the phthalate molecules to take up space between polymer chains. This prevents neighbouring PVC molecules from approaching too closely. Since there is space between the polymer chains, the resultatnt material is much more flexible.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Molecules allow the PVC polymer chains to pack closely, increasing its flexibility.
Molecules prevent PVC polymer chains from packing too closely, decreasing its flexibility.
Molecules allow the PVC polymer chains to pack closely, decreasing its flexibility.

question_html:
Which of the following increases the flexibility of polypropene plastic?

I. Atactic stereoisomer

II. Substituents randomly placed along polymer backbone

III. Increased intermolecular attractions

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A plastic material becomes more flexible the weaker the intermolecular forces are between polymer chains. In comparison with the different stereoisomers of polypropene, the atactic polymer has weaker intermolecular attractions between polymer chains since the methyl group substituent is randomly placed along the polymer backbone. This prevents polymer chains from packing too closely.

question_html: When plane polarised light propagates through the first polarisation filter in an LCD, what is the angle of rotation required for all of the light to pass through the second polarisation filter?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: As unpolarised light encounters the first polarisation filter, the light that propagates through is travelling in only one plane. With 0°, 180° or 360° rotation, light will not be able to pass through the second polarisation filter, since it is held at 90° from the first filter, therefore @3 and @2 are incorrect. Light rotated by 45° may let some photons of light propagate through the second filter, but light rotated by 90° should be able to fully pass through the second polarisation filter. Therefore @1 would be a much more suitable choice than @4.

question_html: Which of the following does not occur within a subpixel of an LCD screen?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Light can propagate through the second filter only if there is an applied voltage across the electrodes.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: In a subpixel, unpolarised light passes through the filter and becomes plane polarised. When there is no voltage across the electrodes, the liquid crystals sandwiched in between, which are twisted, will rotate the plane polarised light by 90°. This will allow the light to pass through the second polarisation filter, which is rotated by 90°. Light will be able to pass through and appear bright when there is no voltage applied. Applying a voltage causes the liquid crystals to untwist and align with the generated electric field. @2, @3 and @4 all do occur within the subpixel of an LCD screen. When there is a voltage applied, the plane polarised light is unable to rotate and thus will not pass through the second polarisation filter. The subpixel will appear dark when a voltage is applied. Therefore @1 does not occur within a subpixel of an LCD screen.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Unpolarised light is plane polarised when passing through the first filter.
Plane polarised light is rotated in the presence of twisted nematic liquid crystals.
Applying a voltage across the electrodes disrupts the twisting of the nematic liquid crystal between the two polarisation filters.

question_html: What does unpolarised light do when it encounters a polarisation filter?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Light travelling in the plane parallel to the polymers making up the filter will pass through.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: When unpolarised light (light oscillating in all directions) passes through a polarisation filter, only light travelling in one direction will propagate through, therefore @3 and @4 are incorrect. @2 is incorrect because the polymer molecules used to make up the polarisation filter interact with the incoming polarised light to pass light through that is oscillating parallel to the polymer alignment.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Light travelling in the plane perpendicular to the polymers making up the filter will pass through.
All light will be absorbed and dissipated.
Light travelling in all planes will pass through.

question_html: Which of the following molecules would be the most likely to make up a thermotropic liquid crystal material?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Some of the conditions for a thermotropic liquid-crystal molecule is that it is rigid (usually from a biphenyl backbone), elongated and polar. @2 and @3 are both incorrect since they are both non-polar molecules and would not be likely to exhibit a liquid crystal phase. @4 would be unlikely because the number of methyl groups surrounding it would cause the molecule in that region to be bulkier and more 'spherical' rather than rod-like. Comparing @1 and @4, @1 would be a more suitable candidate because it has a more elongated, rod structure.

question_html:
Which of the following is characteristic of molecules that exhibit a nematic liquid crystal phase?

I. Organised, ordered distribution

II. Rod-shaped

III. On average align in the same direction

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A nematic liquid crystal phase is characterised by rod-shaped molecules which are randomly distributed but on average align in the same direction. Molecules that are distributed in an organised, ordered fashion would be characteristic of a crystalline solid rather than a nematic liquid crystal.

question_html: Which of the following could exhibit a lyotropic liquid-crystal phase?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: As this molecule contains a polar head group (sodium sulfate region) and a non-polar hydrophobic tail (dodecyl alkyl chain), molecules can interact with one another, self-assembling to form ordered structures such as micelles. Lyotropic liquid crystals are solutions that show the liquid crystal state over a range of concentrations. This is why @3 and @4 would be incorrect, even though @3 would be an example of a thermotropic liquid crystal. @2 would be incorrect because this is an ionic substance that would dissociate into its individual ions when dissolved in water. Ions will not self-assemble into ordered structures as there are no non-polar regions.

question_html: Which of the following is the best description of a lyotropic liquid-crystal micelle occuring at low aqueous concentrations?

MCQ_set.answer_html: A sphere where non-polar hydrophobic tails face inwards and hydrophilic polar head groups face outwards.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A micelle (illustrated below) is made up of surfactant molecules. These molecules are elongated molecules that contain a polar and non-polar region. The polar region will attract surrounding water molecules, making that part of the molecule 'water-loving' or hydrophilic. The non-polar region will repel surrounding water molecules, making that part of the molecule 'water-repelling' or hydrophobic. This is why @3 and @4 are incorrect because they do not correctly attribute hydrophilic/hydrophobic to polar/non-polar. @2 is incorrect because it says that the non-polar regions would be facing outwards. This would imply that the non-polar regions would be self-assembling in order to interact with the water solvent molecules.

MCQ_set.answer_html: A sphere where hydrophilic polar head groups face inwards and non-polar hydrophobic tails face outwards.
A sphere where non-polar hydrophilic tails face inwards and hydrophobic polar head groups face outwards.
A sphere where hydrophobic polar head groups face inwards and non-polar hydrophilic tails face outwards.

question_html: Which of the following is not a factor to consider when choosing a heterogeneous catalyst?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Since reactant molecules will interact with metal atoms at the surface of the heterogeneous catalyst, malleability will not affect the number of surface atoms. Since the number of surface atoms will remain constant, the malleability will not affect the rate of reaction. When choosing a catalyst, the efficiency of the catalyst reacting and regenerating itself is an important consideration. Purity is an important consideration as the purity of the catalyst can influence the overall reaction. In industry, minimising cost is always an important consideration.

question_html: Which of the following does not explain why transition metals are typically used for heterogeneous and homogeneous catalysis?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: If transition metals had high reactivities, it would make it difficult for products to form, since the catalyst would react in preference. @2 is incorrect because the partially filled d-orbitals allow ligands to form coordinate covalent bonds as is typically done in homogeneous catalysis. @3 and @4 are incorrect because both of these reasons allow catalysts both to react but also regenerate themselves as the catalyst can undergo oxidation followed by reduction to its original species.

question_html: Which of the following best describes a reaction intermediate?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Stable, low-energy species that can be physically isolated.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Activated complexes (or transition states) are high-energy species that cannot be isolated. Reaction intermediates are low-energy species that can be physically isolated. These are products that form in one step of a reaction and then act as products in a later step of a reaction. In general, stability coincides with lower energy. This is why @2 and @3 would be incorrect. High-energy species are too unstable to isolate, so @4 is incorrect.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Unstable, low-energy species that can be physically isolated.
Stable, high-energy species that can be physically isolated.
Unstable, high-energy species that can be physically isolated.

question_html: What type of catalyst is used in a catalytic converter?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: In a catalytic converter, Rh, Pd and Pt nanoparticles line a honeycomb ceramic material inside of an exhaust. Options @3 and @4 are incorrect because they do not include nanoparticles. The catalyst must be a heterogeneous catalyst for ease of separation from the reactants and products, therefore @2 and @4 are incorrect.

question_html: Which of the following would not be a benefit of using a heterogeneous nanoparticle metal catalyst in comparison to the bulk metal?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: In general, heterogeneous catalysts are easy to separate from reactants and products because they are in a different phase from reactants and products. However, when using a nanoparticle catalyst, the particle size is in the nanometre range, making it much more difficult to separate. Nanoparticles will be able to pass easily through filter paper. Other methods must be employed in order to separate out nanoparticle catalysts. Choices @2, @3 and @4 are all things that typically benefit from using metal nanoparticle catalysts in comparison to the bulk metal.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Greater number of surface sites for reactant molecules to interact with

question_html: Which of the following would not describe a zeolite material?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
A zeolite material is an aluminosilicate containing a porous structure. The porous structure has more surface atoms than the bulk structure. This increased porosity increases the surface area to volume ratio. This would make a zeolite have a very high surface area compared to its bulk structure.

The porous structure allows a zeolite to act as a molecular sieve, a size-selective catalyst and an absorbent material, which is why choices @2, @3 and @4 are incorrect.

question_html:
Which of the following should be considered when choosing a catalyst:

I. Purity of catalyst

II. Separating catalyst

III. Efficiency of catalyst

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Purity, separation and efficiency of the catalyst are all important considerations when choosing a catalyst. Purity is important because the presence of impurities could react differently with starting materials, producing undesired products. Separation is important in order to remove the desired product from the catalyst and reuse the catalyst. Efficiency is important in order to be aware of the rate at which the catalyst can regenerate (homogeneous) or have surface sites available for incoming reactants (heterogeneous).

question_html: Which of the following does not occur in an ICP spectrometer?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: In order to produce the plasma, a sample of argon gas is passed through the spark of a Tesla coil, where argon atoms lose electrons, which flow through the magnetic field rotationally. @3 is one of the first stages in the ICP spectrometer. When a sample is introduced, the plasma provides enough energy to atomise the sample and promote electrons from lower energy levels into higher energy levels. @2 and @4 are stages of a sample interacting with an ICP spectrometer. In general, the argon atoms are losing electrons, not gaining them, in order to create a plasma.

question_html: Which of the following is used as a detection method for inductively coupled plasma spectroscopy?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The two methods of detection used for ICP spectroscopy, in general, are optical emission spectroscopy (OES) and mass spectrometry (MS). @2 and @3 are techniques used to analyse molecules and compounds and would not benefit from the atomisation of ICP. @4 is an imaging technique and not typically used for detection of trace metals.

question_html: A sample of water thought to be contaminated with lead was analysed using ICP-OES. The detection of emission at 220 nm confirmed the presence of lead ions. A calibration curve of known concentration of lead ions using ICP-OES was made with a linear trendline equation of I = 9.8C + 0.06, where I is the relative intensity and C represents the concentration of the solution in mg dm-3. The contaminated water sample was found to have a relative intensity of 0.77 analysed at 220 nm. Calculate the concentration of Pb2+ ions that are present in the contaminated water sample.
Identify the element that is diamagnetic.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The electron configuration for @1 is [Ar]4s23d10. All electrons are paired and therefore will exhibit diamagnetic behaviour. @2 is [Ar]4s23d3, @3 is [Ar]4s23d8 and @4 is [Ar]4s13d10, which are all paramagnetic due to having unpaired electrons.

question_html: Which of the following types of magnetism would weakly repel a magnetic field?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Diamagnetism is where a temporary field is created from moving electrons, which oppose an applied magnetic field. This is a weak effect caused by electrons that are paired in their respective orbitals. Options @2, @3 and @4 are all types of magnetism that are attracted to an applied magnetic field.

question_html: Which of the following is not a property of most alloys in comparison to their base metal?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Alloying a metal does not necessarily change the colour of the resultant material. By alloying, the sizes of cations in the lattice vary. This causes the larger cations in the lattice to resist motion of layers sliding past one another. This makes the material stronger and harder. This is why options @4 and @3 would be incorrect. The irregular arrangement of the lattice tends to weaken the metallic bond, lowering the melting point. This is why option @2 would be incorrect.

question_html: Which of the following best describes the makeup of an alloy?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Base metal combined with an added element.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: An alloy is a homogeneous mixture of metals with other metals or non-metals. This indicates that the base of an alloy is a metal. Only option @1 satisfies this definition. Option @2 includes an element as its base but does not specify metal, and @2 and @3 state that the base is an ionic compound, which does not make up an alloy.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Base element combined with an added metal.
Base ionic compound combined with an added metal.
Base ionic compound combined with an added element.

question_html: What mass of aluminium can be produced from the electrolysis of alumina using the Hall-Heroult process at 150 kA for 1 day?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
n(e-) = It/F

n(e-) = (150 000)(86 400)/(96 500)

n(e-) = 1.343 × 105 mol e- (this is not a mass, therefore @3 would be incorrect)

Since Al3+ + 3e- → Al there are three electrons required to reduce every one Al3+ ion. Therefore there will be a third as many moles of Al produced as the number of moles of electrons. (Option @4 would be the mass produced if the electrons and metal had a one-to-one molar ratio, but in this example that is not the case).

n(Al) = 4.477 × 104 mol Aluminium (this is not a mass, therefore @2 would be incorrect)

m(Al) = nMr

m(Al) = (4.477 × 104)(26.98)

m(Al) = 1.208 × 106 g

question_html: Which of the following best describes Faraday's constant F?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Relationship between charge and the number of moles of electrons.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Since Faraday's constant is 96 500 C mol-1, purely by looking at the units we can see it is a relationship between the charge in coulombs (C) per mole of electrons (mol-1). Option @2 is incorrect as it would lead to units of C s-1, @3 is incorrect as it would lead to units of A s-1 and @4 is incorrect as it would lead to units of A mol-1.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Relationship between charge and time of electrolysis.
Relationship between current and time of electrolysis.
Relationship between current and the number of moles of electrons.

question_html: Identify a factor that has no effect on the mass of metal produced at the cathode during electrolysis.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: At the cathode, the type of electrode would not change the quantity of metal produced. Since metal ions are reduced in solution, the electrode mass increases over time and the material comprising the electrode would not have an effect (provided that the electrode is conductive). Options @2, @3 and @4 all will influence the mass of the metal produced at the cathode.

question_html: Identify the consequence of using graphite as electrodes at high temperatures.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Graphite electrodes react with oxygen and must be replaced regularly.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: While it is true that graphite does not conduct electricity well across the graphene layers, it is still a conductive material useful for electrolysis. This would make @2 incorrect. When carbon oxidises it forms CO2, therefore an oxide coating would not occur on a graphite electrode (@3 incorrect). @4 is incorrect because graphite's melting point is approximately 5500°C.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Graphite electrodes don't conduct electricity very well across their graphene layers.
Graphite electrodes create an oxide coating, preventing conductivity.

question_html: When extracting aluminium from bauxite, why must the alumina be dissolved in cryolite?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Alumina has an extremely high melting point, so dissolving in cryolite allows electrolysis at a much lower temperature.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Alumina has a melting point of ~2000°C, therefore @3 is incorrect. @2 is incorrect because cryolite is just a solvent, therefore excitation of ions should not occur. While bauxite is fairly impure, these impurities must be removed before electrolysis occurs. Since purification occurs before dissolving in cryolite @4 would be incorrect.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Alumina cannot be melted and therefore must be dissolved in order to perform electrolysis.
Alumina is impure, and dissolving in cryolite helps remove the impurities.

question_html: Which of the following is not a main step that industry uses to obtain aluminium metal?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: In general, distillation is a method used to separate out substances with different boiling points. This is often used for a mixture of organic substances. To extract aluminium from its bauxite ore, the ore must first be @2, then @3 since alumina has a very high melting point, followed by @4 to reduce Al3+ to molten aluminium.

question_html: Which of the following explains why a blast furnace has a variation in temperature along its vertical height? (the tallest point having the lowest temperature)

MCQ_set.answer_html: In order for molten iron with the highest melting point to form at the bottom.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: For a blast furnace, the iron ore, limestone and coke are added to the top in the lowest temperature region (this is why @4 is incorrect). The hot air that is inserted in the bottom rushes to the top and reacts with coke (carbon) to produce CO2 which further produces CO. This is why @2 is incorrect since the oxygen reacts fairly high up in the blast furnace. Silicon and calcium oxides make up the composition of most of the impurities (known as slag) which are solids that collect near the bottom of the blast furnace (this is why @3 is incorrect).

MCQ_set.answer_html: In order for oxygen to react near the bottom.
In order for impurities to evaporate near the top.
In order to insert the iron ore into the bottom.

question_html: Which of the following is not a method of extraction of a metal from its ore?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Cooling will reduce the kinetic energy of particles making up the ore, making it more difficult to extract specific elements from it. Cooling will not allow the extraction of a metal from its ore. The three main methods to extract metals from their ores are @2, @3 and @4.

question_html: Which of the following would serve as the best definition for an ore?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Naturally occuring minerals or rocks that contain desired elements that can be economically extracted.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Ores are naturally occurring minerals or rocks that are mined from the Earth for purposes of extraction. @2 is an oar using for rowing, not ore. @3 is correct in that minerals or rocks contain elements; however, this definition is not specific enough. @4 is incorrect because ores are not synthesised in a laboratory.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Lab-synthesised minerals or rocks that contain desired elements that can be economically extracted.

question_html: Deduce which method would be most appropriate for extraction of cobalt metal from its ore.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Since carbon is higher up on the activity series than cobalt, reacting a cobalt mineral with coke will cause reduction of the mineral to elemental cobalt and oxidation of carbon to produce carbon dioxide. While @2 and @3 may be possible, they would not be the most suitable methods due to the positioning of cobalt in the activity series. Since gold is very low on the activity series, @4 would not be a suitable reducing agent as it is not interested in oxidising.

question_html: How can mercury be extracted from the cinnabar ore containing mercury(II) sulfide?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Since mercury has a low melting and boiling point it can be extracted by heating. By heating the ore, mercury escapes the ore as a vapour which can be collected and condensed to be harvested as a liquid. Options @2 and @3 would not cause mercury to be extracted from the ore. Option @4 would not occur because gold is more likely to be reduced than mercury and thus would not promote the reduction of mercury from mercury(II) sulfide.

question_html: Which of the following is not a composite material?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Steel is considered an alloy. While it is composed of two different elements (at least), they are both in the same phase. The composites are @2 (cement – matrix, rebar/gravel – reinforcement), @3 (polymer plastic – matrix, graphite fibres – reinforcement) and @4 (plastic – matrix, glass – reinforcement) as each are made up of a matrix and reinforcement in two different phases.

question_html: Which property is not characteristic of ceramic materials?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Ceramics are composed of either giant ionic or giant covalent structures. Of the two, ionic structures are the only ones capable of conducting electricity; however, ionic compounds cannot conduct electricity in the solid state as ions are fixed in their respective positions. In general, metals are the only material conductive in the solid state. Option @2 is incorrect because ceramics often have gaps in their structures allowing small molecules to permeate through. Option @3 is incorrect since ceramic materials shatter fairly easily if dropped. Option @4 is incorrect as ceramic materials are often treated at high temperatures (consider a kiln used in pottery).

question_html: What property allows gold to be formed into jewellery?
