MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Malleability is a property of metals where layers can slide past one another in the lattice with relative ease. If the layers are able to slide past each other relatively easy, it allows a jeweller to mould the material into the desired shapes and sizes required for jewellery. Option @2 considers the movement of electrons within the lattice, which would not help the forming of gold. Gold is not particularly elastic or permeable to fluids, eliminating the possibility of @3 and @4.

question_html: What type of chemical bonding does not always result in a lattice structure?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Small molecules contain only covalent bonds. Molecules in the liquid and solid state are held together by intermolecular forces. It is important to note that covalent bonding can form lattice structures but these are known as network covalent solids. Option @2 is not correct because ionic compounds are made up of cations and anions electrostatically attracted to each other in three dimensions to form a lattice. Option @3 is incorrect because metallic bonding is a lattice of positive ions surrounded by delocalised valence electrons, and @4 is incorrect because hydrogen bonding is an intermolecular force and not a type of bonding.

question_html: Identify which of the following alloys has the most covalent character.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
SnSb

If we calculate the difference in electronegativity and the average electronegativity between each of the binary compounds we can see that SnSb has the largest average electronegativity and smallest difference in electronegativity. Option @2 has the most ionic character, option @4 has the most metallic character and option @3 is right on the covalent-metallic boundary.

question_html:
Acid rain can damage buildings, historic monuments, and statues, especially those made of limestone or marble (calcium carbonate). Complete the equation below for the reaction between sulfuric acid and calcium carbonate:

CaCO3 (s) + H2SO4 (aq) →

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
The full balanced equation is:

CaCO3 (s) + H2SO4 (aq) →  CaSO4 (aq) + CO2 (g) + H2O (l)

Note that the state symbol used here for calcium sulfate is (aq). It should be noted that some sources use solid (s) because of the low solubility of calcium sulfate in water.

question_html: Which of the methods listed below is not one by which sulfur dioxide emissions from power stations can be reduced?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Acidic water is reacted with a base to reduce the acidity of the water
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: This method is used to reduce the acidity of acidic lake or river water - it is not used to reduce the sulfur dioxide emissions from a power station.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The sulfur present in coal or oil is removed before combustion
Fluidised bed combustion is a method by which the amount of sulfur oxides resulting from combustion is lowered
Flue gas desulfurisation removes sulfur dioxide from the exhaust gases before they leave the power station flue

question_html:
Limestone and marble are forms of calcium carbonate. Many historical buildings are made from these materials, so they can be eroded by acid rain. What is the product of the reaction involving nitric acid?

CaCO3 (aq) + 2HNO3 (aq) →

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
The complete and balanced reaction is: 

CaCO3 (s) + 2HNO3 (aq) → Ca(NO3)2 (aq) + H2O (l) + CO2 (g)

question_html:
Nitric acid and nitrous acid are major components of acid deposition. Complete the product(s) of the balanced equation for the reaction of nitrogen dioxide with oxygen and water: 

NO2 (g) + O2 (g) + H2O (l) → ?

Note that the above equation is not balanced.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
This reaction is one of the contributory reactions of acid deposition – in this case producing nitric acid. The complete balanced equation is:

4NO2 (g) + O2 (g) + 2H2O (l) → 4HNO3 (aq)

question_html: Which of the following compounds formed in a vehicle engine contributes to the formation of acid rain?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Nitrogen monoxide (NO) is produced at high temperatures in vehicle engines and contributes to the formation of acid rain.

question_html: Which acidic gas is produced when fossil fuels that naturally contain sulfur are burned in power stations?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Sulfur (in coal or fuel oil) is oxidised during the combustion process in the power station and forms sulfur dioxide.

S (s) + O2 (g) → SO2 (g)

question_html: Which of the following compounds, when oxidised in the atmosphere and dissolved in rainwater, produces an acidic product that contributes to acid rain?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
In air, NO is oxidised to nitrogen dioxide (NO2), which in turn reacts with water to produce nitric acid (HNO3) as follows: 

2NO• (g) + O2 (g) → 2NO2 •(g)

2NO2 • (g) + H2O (l) → HNO3 (aq) + HNO2 (aq)

CO is a poisonous gas produced during incomplete combustion of fossil fuels. CH4 and CO2 are greenhouse gases that contribute to the enhanced greenhouse effect. CO2, when dissolved in rainwater, is also responsible for the natural acidity of rain water, but this is not considered to be acid rain.

question_html: Which of the following gases is not a by-product of burning fossil fuels?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Sulfur dioxide (SO2) and nitrogen oxides (NO, NO2) are by-products from burning fossil fuels in power stations and vehicle engines.

question_html: Which of the compounds listed below produces a salt and water only when reacted with dilute sulfuric acid?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Ammonia is a base and reacts to form ammonium sulfate with sulfuric acid. Zinc carbonate will react to produce carbon dioxide, salt and water. Zinc will react to form a salt and hydrogen gas. Magnesium oxide will produce a salt and water only upon reaction with sulfuric acid.

question_html: An unknown substance is reacted with dilute acid and produces a flammable gas and a salt solution. What is the possible identity of the substance?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Dilute acids react to give hydrogen gas and a solution of a salt when a moderately reactive metal such as magnesium, iron or zinc is added. Metal oxides do not produce a gas when reacted with acids; a carbonate would produce carbon dioxide as a product.

question_html: A certain mineral rock containing a metal carbonate was tested with dilute sulfuric acid and produced a salt solution, water and bubbles of a colourless gas which turned limewater milky. Which of the following gases was produced?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The identity of the mineral is a metal carbonate. Dilute acids react to give carbon dioxide gas when a metal carbonate or metal hydrogen carbonate is added. The salt solution is a sulfate.

question_html: Which of the following species is the conjugate base of the H2PO4–  ion?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: When the dihydrogen phosphate (H2PO4– ) ion acts as an acid it will form the hydrogen phosphate (HPO42– ) ion by loss of a proton. The hydrogen phosphate (HPO42– ) ion is its conjugate base.

question_html: Which among the molecular/ionic species below is amphiprotic?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The hydrogen sulfite ion (HSO3– ) is the conjugate base of sulfurous acid (H2SO3, sulfuric(IV) acid). It is also the conjugate acid of the sulfite ion (SO32– ). It is an amphiprotic ionic species because it is able to both donate a proton and accept a proton.

question_html:
Equal amounts of sulfuric acid (H2SO4) and nitric acid (HNO3) are mixed in a beaker. The following reaction occurs: 

HNO3 (aq) + H2SO4 (aq) ⇌  H2NO3+ (aq) + HSO4–  (aq)

Which statement is true about the reaction?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: H2SO4 is a stronger acid than HNO3, therefore, it donates a proton to the HNO3 which acts as a Bronsted-Lowry base by accepting a proton.

question_html: Which of the following statements concerning amphoteric and amphiprotic molecules or ions is incorrect?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The term amphoteric is used to describe any substance which can act as both an acid and a base. The term amphiprotic specifically relates to the acceptance or donation of H+ ions (which is Bronsted-Lowry acid-base theory). Amphoteric species are a broader group than amphiprotic species; so zinc oxide, for example, is amphoteric, but not amphiprotic.

question_html: Which of the following molecules or ions is not amphiprotic?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The sulfate ion (SO42– ) can act as a base by accepting a proton but cannot act as an acid as it does not have a proton to donate. All the other options are both able to accept or donate a proton.

question_html: Carbonic acid (H2CO3) is a weak acid formed when carbon dioxide dissolves in water. What ions could be present in a carbonic acid solution?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Ions such as H+, HCO3–  and CO32–  could be present in the carbonic acid solution; formed from the loss of a proton from HCO3–  ions and H2CO3 molecules respectively. Note that H+ (aq) can also be represented as H3O+ (aq) in solution.

question_html: Which of the following ionic species can behave as both a Brønsted–Lowry base and as a Brønsted–Lowry acid?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
HSO4–  is amphiprotic - it can act as an acid or a base as follows:

As an acid by donating a proton: HSO4–  + OH–  ⇌ SO42–  + H2O  

As a base by accepting a proton: HSO4–  + H3O+ ⇌ H2SO4 + H2O

question_html: What combination of reactants could be used to make a cobalt chloride solution and hydrogen gas?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A piece of cobalt dissolved in HCl(aq) produces a solution of cobalt chloride and an effervescence of hydrogen (H2).

question_html: Which two reactants would react to produce potassium nitrate, KNO3?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Reaction of nitric acid and potassium hydroxide solutions will form water and potassium nitrate as follows:

HNO3 (aq) + KOH (aq) → KNO3 (aq) + H2O (l)

question_html: What products are formed when a metal carbonate reacts with an acid?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: When a metal carbonate reacts with an acid, a salt, water and carbon dioxide are formed.

MCQ_set.answer_html: A salt and carbon dioxide gas only

question_html:
Which of the following statements are correct about acids and bases?

I. A 1.0 mol dm-3 solution of NaOH has a pH of 10

II. Hydrochloric acid solution is acidic because its [H3O+] > [OH–]

III. A 1.0 mol dm-3 of H2SO4 has a pH of 3

IV. Ammonia solution is basic because its [OH–] > [H3O+]

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A 1.0 mol dm-3 solution of NaOH has a pH of 14 as it is a strong base. The definition of an acidic solution is [H3O+] > [OH–] and basic is [OH–] > [H3O+]. A 1.0 mol dm-3 of H2SO4 has a pH of 0 as it is a strong acid.

question_html: Ammonia (NH3) is an important compound used in many commercial cleaning products. Which of the following statements is true regarding its reaction with hydrochloric acid, HCl (aq)?

MCQ_set.answer_html: It accepts a proton from the HCl (aq)
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Ammonia acts as a Bronsted-Lowry base (a proton acceptor) in this reaction because it accepts a proton (H+ ion) from the HCl (aq) to become the ammonium ion (NH4+). 

NH3 (aq) + HCl (aq) → NH4Cl (aq)

Note that NH4Cl in solution fully dissociates to form the NH4+ and Cl- ions.

MCQ_set.answer_html: It donates a proton to the HCl (aq)

question_html: Calcium hydroxide, Ca(OH)2, is added to a lake to neutralise the effects of acid rain. The pH value of the lake water rises from 4 to 7. What is the change in concentration of ions [H+(aq)] in the lake water?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: An increase in pH represents a decrease in [H+(aq)], each unit increase representing a decrease by a factor of 10. A pH rise of 3 units indicates a 1000-fold decrease in [H+(aq)].

question_html: Methanoic acid, HCOOH, is a stronger acid than propanoic acid, CH3CH2COOH. Which one of the following statements about these acids is correct?

MCQ_set.answer_html: The pH of a solution of 1.0 mol dm-3 propanoic acid is higher than the pH of a solution of 1.0 mol dm-3 methanoic acid
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Weaker acids have higher pH values than stronger acids of the same concentration. This is because weaker acids are less dissociated in solution whereas stronger acids are more dissociated. For equal concentrations, stronger acids have a higher concentration of hydrogen ions in solution than weaker acids, which results in a lower pH value.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Propanoic acid is more dissociated in water than methanoic acid
Magnesium will react with methanoic acid but not with propanoic acid
A 1.0 mol dm-3 solution of methanoic acid will turn blue litmus red, but a 1.0 mol dm-3 solution of propanoic acid will turn red litmus blue

section_title: Strong and weak acids and bases

question_html: A dilute aqueous solution of benzenecarboxylic acid (an organic acid) is a poor conductor of electricity. Which of the following statements accounts for this observation?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Benzenecarboxylic acid is only partially dissociated in water
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Benzenecarboxylic acid is a weak acid which is partially dissociated in solution and the low concentration of ions in solution accounts for its low conductivity.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Benzenecarboxylic acid solution has a high concentration of ions
Benzenecarboxylic acid is completely dissociated in water

section_title: Strong and weak acids and bases

question_html: Which one of the following best describes a strong acid?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
A strong acid is almost completely dissociated in water. Using HA as a strong acid, this can be represented as:

 HA (aq) → H+ (aq) + A– (aq)

Note the use of the one way arrow (→) to show complete dissociation.

MCQ_set.answer_html: A strong acid has a high concentration
A strong acid does not dissociate in solution
A strong acid partially dissociates in solution

section_title: Strong and weak acids and bases

question_html: Which of the following has the fastest rate of reaction with a reactive metal such as magnesium (assume all solutions are 1.00 mol dm-3)?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: H2SO4, sulfuric acid, is a strong acid and dissociates completely in solution. Compared to weak acids of equal concentration, strong acids have faster rates of reactions with reactive metals than weak acids because of the higher concentration of H+ ions in solution. All other choices are weak acids which react more slowly with reactive metals such as magnesium.

section_title: Strong and weak acids and bases

question_html: Which is the correct description for an aqueous solution with a pH of 9.5 at 298 K?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Alkaline solutions have pH values of greater than 7 at 298 K.

question_html: A decrease in the pH of an aqueous solution corresponds to which of the following?

MCQ_set.answer_html: An increase in the [H+] and a decrease in the [OH–]
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The pH scale is an inverse scale so a decrease in pH correlates to an increase in the [H+] and a decrease in the [OH–].

MCQ_set.answer_html: A decrease in the [H+] and an increase in the [OH–]
A decrease in both the [H+] and the [OH–]

question_html: Which of the following aqueous solutions of concentration 1.00 mol dm-3 would have the highest pH value?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Sodium hydroxide is a strong alkali and will have the highest pH value. Ammonia is a weak base and ethanoic acid and sulfuric acid are weak and strong acids respectively.

question_html:
Four flasks labelled A, B, C and D contain equal volumes of hydrochloric acid at different concentrations. When equal volumes of 1.00 mol dm-3 sodium hydroxide are added to each flask the pH values below are produced.

flask A B C D
pH 2 6 8 12

Which flask contains the acid with the highest concentration?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The most concentrated acid has the highest amount (concentration) of hydrogen ions​, therefore, it has the smallest change in pH of the four solutions when the sodium hydroxide is added.

question_html: What is the pH of pure water at 298 K?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Pure water is essentially molecular but contains low but equal concentrations of hydrogen and hydroxide ions (10-7 mol dm-3 in each case). This gives it a pH value of 7.

question_html: When the following 1.0 mol dm-3 solutions are listed in order of increasing pH (lowest first), what is the correct order?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The order is strong acid < weak acid < weak base < strong base. For equal concentrations, strong acids have the lowest pH, followed by weak acids, weak bases and strong bases (with the highest pH).

question_html: The pH of solution X is 1 and that of Y is 2. Which statement is correct about the hydrogen ion concentrations in the two solutions?

MCQ_set.answer_html: [H+(aq)] in X is ten times that in Y
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A change in pH of one unit corresponds to a change of ×10 in the concentration of hydrogen ions. Remember that [H+(aq)] is increasing down the pH scale.

MCQ_set.answer_html: [H+(aq)] in X is half of that in Y
[H+(aq)] in X is twice that in Y
[H+(aq)] in X is one tenth of that in Y

question_html: Which equation correctly describes phosphoric(V) acid, H3PO4 (aq), behaving as a monoprotic acid in aqueous solution?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A monoprotic acid releases one hydrogen ion per molecule in water. The number of acidic hydrogens in the acid molecule decreases by one producing a negatively charged ion.

question_html: Which of the following would exactly neutralise 100 cm3 of a 1.00 mol dm-3 solution of sulfuric acid?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Sulfuric acid reacts with barium hydroxide according to the following equation:

H2SO4 (aq) + Ba(OH)2 (aq) → BaSO4 (aq) + 2H2O (l) 

Amount (in mol) of sulfuric acid = 1.00 × (100/1000) = 0.100 mol

From the balanced equation 0.100 mol of sulfuric acid reacts with 0.100 mol of barium hydroxide.

question_html: Which one of the following equations represents the reaction between aqueous calcium hydroxide and dilute hydrochloric acid?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Metal hydroxides react with acids to form a salt and water. The formulas need to be correct, and the equation balanced.

question_html: Which of the following equations does not show a Brønsted-Lowry acid−base reaction?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: This equation shows an acid-base reaction based on the Lewis definition of acids and bases. There is no proton transfer which would be characteristic of a reaction between Brønsted-Lowry acids and bases, and is present in the other reactions.

question_html: Which of the following is not a conjugate acid-base pair?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A conjugate acid-base pair differ by a proton (H+). In the case of NaH/Na+ it is an H– ion (a hydride ion) that has been lost, therefore, it is not a conjugate acid-base pair.

question_html: What is the conjugate acid of the HPO42–  ion?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The conjugate acid will have an added H+ ion. The conjugate acid of HPO42–  is H2PO4– .

question_html:
In the reaction below, which species represent a conjugate acid-base pair?

CH2ClCOOH (aq) + H2O (l) → CH2ClCOO–  (aq) + H3O+ (aq)

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A conjugate acid–base pair differ by a proton (H+).

question_html: Hydrogen chloride (HCl) dissolved in water reacts with magnesium. Hydrogen chloride dissolved in ethanol does not react with magnesium. Which statement accounts for this observation?

MCQ_set.answer_html: The water molecules accept protons from the HCl
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
When hydrogen chloride gas dissolves in water, it donates a proton to a water molecule forming hydronium ions, H3O+ :

HCl (g) + H2O (l) → H3O+ (aq) + Cl- (aq)

In this reaction water is acting as a Bronsted-Lowry base. Note that water can also act as a Bronsted-Lowry acid by donating a proton - it is amphiprotic.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Magnesium is very soluble in ethanol but insoluble in water
Hydrogen chloride does not form ions in water

question_html: Ammonia molecules in aqueous solution can be considered as:

MCQ_set.answer_html: both a Brønsted–Lowry base and a Lewis base
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The ammonia molecule has an available lone pair of electrons and is able to accept a hydrogen ion and form the ammonium ion (via coordinate {dative) bond formation).

section_title: Lewis theory of acids and bases

question_html: Complete the following statement. According to the Lewis theory, a base:

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A Lewis base is any molecule or ion that can form a new coordinate (dative) covalent bond, by donating a pair of electrons.

section_title: Lewis theory of acids and bases

question_html: Which of the following species is not amphiprotic?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
The ammonium ion can only act as a Bronsted-Lowry acid by donating a proton: 

NH4+ (aq) + H2O (l) → NH3 (aq) + H3O+ (aq)

It cannot act as a Bronsted-Lowry base by gaining a proton so it is not amphiprotic.

question_html: Which of the following compounds containing hydrogen acts as an acid in aqueous solution?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Hydrogen chloride reacts with water to form a solution of hydrochloric acid, which dissociates completely according to the following equation:

HCl (g) + H2O (l) → H3O+ (aq) + Cl- (aq)

question_html: In which one of the following reactions does the nitric acid act as a Brønsted-Lowry base?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: In this reaction, the sulfuric acid donates a proton to the nitric acid. The sulfuric acid is acting as a Brønsted-Lowry acid and the nitric acid as a Brønsted-Lowry base.

question_html: Which species can behave as a Brønsted–Lowry base and as a Brønsted–Lowry acid?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: HSO4–  is amphiprotic - it can act as a Brønsted–Lowry acid and as a Brønsted–Lowry base.

question_html: Phenylamine (aniline, C6H5NH2) can be produced from benzene in a two-step synthesis.The first step in this conversion is the production of nitrobenzene (C6H5NO2) from benzene using a nitrating mixture. What are the necessary reactants (reagents) for this first step?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The synthesis of nitrobenzene proceeds when benzene is refluxed with a mixture of concentrated nitric acid and concentrated sulfuric acid. This nitrating mixture produces the NO2+ ion which acts as an electrophile, substituting into the benzene ring. The nitrobenzene is subsequently reduced to phenylamine.

question_html:
Synthesis of a carboxylic acid product (compound X below) can be achieved using a sequence of steps starting from cyclopentane.

The possible first reaction in this synthetic pathway would be:

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Alkanes are unreactive compounds and the only reaction that they take part in, other than combustion, is halogenation: using Br2 with UV light, for instance. The formation of a halogenoalkane can be a useful first step in a synthetic route.

question_html: Octanoic acid (caprylic acid) is a carboxylic acid that is found in coconuts and breast milk. If octanoic acid is fully reduced using lithium aluminium hydride (LiAlH4), what is the expected product?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Complete reduction of a carboxylic acid yields first an aldehyde, and then a primary alcohol.

question_html: Hydrogenation of unsaturated fats produces saturated fats which are the major constituents of dairy products. Which of the following reagents is used in the hydrogenation process?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Hydrogenation involves the addition of hydrogen across a carbon to carbon double bond. The reaction converts unsaturated molecules to saturated molecules. Metals such as nickel, platinum and palladium are used as catalysts for the addition of hydrogen to alkenes and alkynes and across carbon-carbon double bonds in unsaturated fats.

question_html: Butanal is an aldehyde with a distinct fruity odour. It is reacted with sodium borohydride, NaBH4, followed by the addition of acid. Which of the choices is the product of this reaction?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Sodium borohydride (NaBH4) is a reducing agent. The reaction is the reduction of an aldehyde to a primary alcohol, so butanal is reduced to butan-1-ol.

question_html:
Which statement(s) is/are correct for the emission line spectrum of the hydrogen atom?

I. The lines converge at lower energies

II. Electron transitions to n = 1 are responsible for lines in the UV region

III. Lines are produced when electrons transition from higher to lower energy levels

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The first statement is incorrect as the lines in a spectrum converge at higher energies. The other two statements are correct; when electrons transition to the n = 1 energy level, they release energy that corresponds to the UV region and the lines are produced when electrons transition from higher to lower energy levels.

question_html: An emission line spectrum consists of a series of coloured lines that converge at high frequencies. These emission spectra provide evidence for which of the following?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Electrons transition from higher to lower energy levels with the higher energy levels being closer together
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The lines in an emission spectrum are produced by electrons transitioning from higher to lower energy levels; the energy levels converge at high energy / high frequency / short wavelength.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Electrons transition from lower to higher energy levels with the lower energy levels being closer together
Electrons transition from higher to lower energy levels with the lower energy levels being closer together
Electrons transition from lower to higher energy levels with the higher energy levels being closer together

question_html: Which statement is correct for the emission spectrum of the hydrogen atom?

MCQ_set.answer_html: The lines corresponding to the greatest emission of energy are in the ultraviolet region
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Electrons falling back to energy level 1 in an atom give out the greatest amount of energy and produce lines in the ultraviolet region as this type of radiation has the highest frequency.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The lines are produced when electrons transition from lower to higher energy levels
The lines in the visible region involve electron transitions into the energy level closest to the nucleus

question_html:
Successive ionisation energies for an unknown element are given in the table below.

First ionisation energy/kJ mol-1 Second ionisation energy/kJ mol-1 Third ionisation energy/kJ mol-1 Fourth ionisation energy/kJ mol-1
590 1145 4912 6491

Identify the unknown element.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: There are two electrons that are relatively easy to remove; then a significant jump in the energy required to remove any further electrons. This suggests the element is in group 2 which corresponds with Ca.

question_html: The first four ionisation energies of a particular element are 738, 1450, 7730 and 10550 kJ mol-1 respectively. Deduce the group number of the element.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: There are two electrons that are relatively easy to remove; then a significant jump in the energy required to remove any further electrons. This suggests the element is in group 2.

question_html:
The graph below represents the energy needed to remove nine electrons successively (one at a time) from an atom of an element. Not all of the electrons in the atom have been removed.

Which element could this be?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: There are four electrons that are relatively easy to remove; then a significant increase in the energy required to remove further electrons. This suggests the element is in group 14, which corresponds with Si. It cannot be carbon, (which also has four valence electrons) as it only has 6 electrons in its atom.

question_html: Between which ionisation energies of boron will there be the greatest difference in energy?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Boron is in group 13 of the periodic table so the atom has three valence electrons. The first three electrons will be relatively easy to remove and then there will be a large increase in the energy required to remove the fourth electron as it is in an energy level closer to the nucleus.

question_html:
Values for the first ionisation energies (IE) for five successive elements in the Periodic Table are given below (the letters are not their actual symbols). Based on these values, which statement is correct?

Element   K L M N O P
IE (kJ mol-1) 1060 1000 1260 1520 418 ?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Element N is most likely a noble gas (group 18), and a non-metal, as it has the highest value. Element O with the lowest value is likely to be in group 1.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The outermost electron in element K is in a higher energy level than that in element L
Element P has a lower first ionisation than element O

question_html: Which of the following electron configurations gives rise to the largest increase between the second and third ionisation energies?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: This electron configuration will give rise to the largest increase between 2nd and 3rd ionisation energies as the 3rd electron is removed from the second energy level, which is closer to the nucleus. In the other examples, the third electron is being removed from the same main energy level (n=2).

question_html: In which of the following series are the atoms arranged in order of increasing first ionisation energy?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Ionisation energy increases across a period and decreases down a group. Elements in the far right of the periodic table will have higher ionisation energies.

question_html:
The first three ionisation energies for two elements, X and Y, are given below.

Element

First ionisation energy/kJ mol−1

 Second ionisation energy/kJ mol−1 Third ionisation energy/kJ mol−1
X 520 7300 11800
Y 1086 2350 4620

Which pair of elements could represent X and Y?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct; X is in group 1 and Y is in group 13 or 14. @1 is the only option that fits with this. Group 1 elements such as lithium have low first ionisation energies and then a large jump to the second ionisation energy. Carbon is in group 14 and would show a large increase after the 4th electron is removed.

question_html: Which of the following elements has the largest first ionisation energy?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Ionisation energies decrease down a group and generally increase across a period. Across a period, nuclear charge increases and atomic radius decreases. Both of these factors result in an increase in ionisation energy across a period (left to right).

question_html: Which of the following atoms has the lowest first ionisation energy?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Ionisation energies decrease down a group and generally increase across a period. The valence electron in sodium is experiencing the lowest effective nuclear charge.

question_html: Deduce which of the following elements has the lowest first ionisation energy value.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Ionisation energies decrease down a group and generally increase across a period. Of these elements, K has the largest atomic radius and the lowest first ionisation energy value.

section_title: Effective nuclear charge and ionisation energy

question_html: Which of the following increases across a period (from left to right) in the periodic table?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: First ionisation energy and electronegativity increase across a period with increasing nuclear charge and decreasing atomic radius.

question_html: Deduce which of the following species has the largest ionic radius.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct; Al3+ has the electron configuration 1s2 2s2 2p6 (with 13 protons), Mg2+ has the electron configuration 1s2 2s2 2p6 (with 12 protons), F− has the electron configuration 1s2 2s2 2p6 (with 9 protons) and S2− has the electron configuration 1s2 2s2 2p6 3s2 3p6 (with 16 protons). The electrons in the sulfide ion experience the weakest attraction from the nucleus as there are 16 protons 'pulling' on 18 electrons which results in a larger ionic radius.

question_html: Deduce which property changes along with increasing ionisation energy across a period (from left to right) in the periodic table.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Ionisation energies generally increase across a period. This results in a decrease in metallic character, that is, a decrease in the tendency to lose electrons and form cations (positive ions).

question_html: Which of the following species has the largest radius?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct; Na+ has the electron configuration 1s2 2s2 2p6 (with 11 protons), N3− has the electron configuration 1s2 2s2 2p6 (with 7 protons), F− has the electron configuration 1s2 2s2 2p6 (with 9 protons) and Ne has the electron configuration 1s2 2s2 2p6 (with 10 protons). The electrons in the nitride ion experience the weakest attraction from the nucleus as there are 7 protons 'pulling' on 10 electrons which results in a larger ionic radius.

question_html: Deduce which of the following species has the smallest radius.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Na has the electron configuration 1s2 2s2 2p6 3s1 (with 11 protons), Na+ has the electron configuration 1s2 2s2 2p6 (with 11 protons), Mg2+ has the electron configuration 1s2 2s2 2p6 (with 12 protons) and Al3+ has the electron configuration 1s2 2s2 2p6 (with 13 protons). The electrons in the aluminium ion experience a stronger attraction from the nucleus as there are 13 protons 'pulling' on 10 electrons. This results in a stronger attraction between the nucleus and the valence electrons and a smaller ionic radius.

question_html: Deduce which set of ions is arranged in order of decreasing ionic radius (from largest to smallest).

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Answer @1 is correct; in @1 the electron configurations of the ions are all 1s2 2s2 2p6, that is, they are isoelectronic. However, the atomic (proton) numbers are 8, 9 and 11 respectively. The sodium ion has 11 protons 'pulling' on 10 electrons which results in a stronger attraction between the nucleus and the valence electrons and the smallest ionic radius. The oxide ion has 8 protons 'pulling' on 10 electrons which results in a weaker attraction between the nucleus and the valence electrons and the largest ionic radius.

question_html: Deduce the total number of p orbitals containing one or more electrons in an atom of germanium, Ge (Z = 32).

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A germanium atom has the following configuration: 1s2 2s2 2p6 3s2 3p6 3d10 4s2 4p2. It has three 2p orbitals, three 3p orbitals and two half-filled 4p orbitals. One of the 4p orbitals will be totally unoccupied. This gives a total of 8 occupied p orbitals.

question_html: A transition metal ion, X3+, has the electronic configuration [Ar] 3d4. Determine the atomic number of element X.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: An atom of X has the electron configuration [Ar] 3d54s2. The atom loses 3 electrons to form a 3+ ion. Transition metal ions ionise via the loss of 4s and then 3d electrons, so the total number of electrons in the atom is 25 (the ion has 22). In a neutral atom, the number of protons is equal to the number of electrons, therefore the atomic number of the element is 25 (manganese, Mn).

question_html: Determine the number of unpaired electrons in the chromium(III) ion, Cr3+.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The chromium(III) ion has the electron configuration [Ar] 3d3. This is derived from a chromium atom which has the electron configuration [Ar] 3d54s1.  The one 4s electron is lost first followed by two 3d electrons. The remaining three electrons will be unpaired in three of the 3d orbitals.

question_html: Which of the following increases by one from left to right in the Periodic Table for each element in period 3?

MCQ_set.answer_html: The number of electrons in the valence shell of the atom
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: For sodium to argon (the elements in period 3), the atomic number increases by one each time you move from one element to the next. This is accompanied by the addition of an extra electron in the valence shell of the atom.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The number of electrons in the innermost energy level
The number of occupied electron energy levels

question_html: Elements in the first row d-block of the periodic table (with the exception of copper and chromium) contain different numbers of electrons in which sub-level(s)?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The elements in the first row d-block of the periodic table (with the exception of copper and chromium) have electron configurations ending with 3dx 4s2 (or 4s2 3dx). Across the period electrons are added to the 3d sub-level (3d1 to 3d10).

question_html: Determine which of the following atoms or ions has the electron configuration [Ar] 3d8.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The electron configurations of these species are as follows: Ni2+ [Ar]3d8 ; Mn [Ar]3d54s2 (or [Ar] 4s23d5); Cu2+ [Ar]3d9 ; Cr3+ [Ar]3d3.

question_html: Deduce the maximum number of electrons that can occupy the 5d sub-level.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: All d sub-levels contain 5 orbitals which can each hold a maximum of 2 electrons each (5 × 2 = 10 electrons).

question_html: How many unpaired electrons would the cobalt atom (element number 27) be expected to have in its ground state electron configuration?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
The cobalt atom has the following electron configuration:

1s2 2s2 2p6 3s2 3p6 3d7 4s2

The 3d sub-shell has two paired electrons and three unpaired electrons in the five d orbitals.

question_html: Identify which electron configuration for the following atoms is incorrect.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The electron configuration for a manganese atom is [Ar] 4s2 3d5

question_html: Deduce the electron configuration of the Fe3+ ion in its ground state.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
The electron configuration of the iron(III) ion (Fe3+) is:

1s2 2s2 2p6 3s2 3p6 3d5

The 4s electrons are lost from a transition metal atom before the 3d electrons.

question_html: Deduce the electron configuration of the cobalt(II) ion (Co2+ ).

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
The electron configuration of the cobalt(II) ion is:

1s2 2s2 2p6 3s2 3p6 3d7 or [Ar] 3d7

The two 4s electrons are lost from a transition metal atom before the 3d electrons.

question_html: Determine the total number of electrons in the d orbitals of an atom of tin, Sn (Z = 50).

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
An atom of tin has the electron configuration:

1s2 2s2 2p6 3s2 3p6 3d10 4s2 4p6 4d10 5s2 5p2

There are a total of 20 electrons in the 3d and 4d sub-levels.

question_html: Which of the following pairs of elements have similar chemical properties?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: These two elements are both in the same group (group 1). Elements in the same group have similar chemical properties.

question_html: An atom of chlorine has the electron configuration [Ne] 3s2 3p5. Determine how many atomic orbitals in this atom are occupied by at least one electron.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The full electron configuration of chlorine is 1s2 2s2 2p6 3s2 3p5. The atomic orbitals are occupied as follows: 1s sub-level: 1 occupied s orbital; 2s sub-level: 1 occupied s orbital; 2p sub-level: 3 occupied p orbitals; 3s sub-level: 1 occupied s orbital; 3p sub-level: 3 occupied p orbitals (two filled and one half-filled). This gives a total of nine occupied atomic orbitals: 1s (1) 2s (1) 2p (3) 3s (1) 3p (3), 1+1+3+1+3 = 9.

question_html: Deduce the number of unpaired electrons in the Fe2+ ion.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The Fe2+ ion has the electron configuration [Ar] 3d6, therefore, there are four unpaired electrons in the 3d sub-level.

question_html: Determine the electron configuration for an atom with atomic number (Z) = 22.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Titanium has an atomic number of 22. Its electron configuration is 1s2 2s2 2p6 3s2 3p6 4s2 3d2. This electron configuration can also be written as 1s2 2s2 2p6 3s2 3p6 3d2 4s2.

question_html:
Deduce which of the following ground-state electron configurations contain unpaired electrons.

I. [He] 2s2 2p2                           

II. [He] 2s2 2p3

III. [He] 2s2 2p4

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: I has two unpaired 2p electrons; II has three unpaired 2p electrons and III has two unpaired 2p electrons.

question_html:
The diagram below shows five main energy levels in the hydrogen atom (n = 1 to n = 5).

Deduce how many electron transitions would emit electromagnetic radiation in the visible region of the electromagnetic spectrum.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Lines in the visible region of the electromagnetic spectrum are produced by electron transitions in which electrons transition from higher energy levels to the second main energy level; so the possible lines result from 5 → 2, 4 → 2 and 3 → 2.

question_html: Emission and absorption line spectra both provide evidence for which of the following:

MCQ_set.answer_html: the existence of energy levels within the atom
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The lines in both emission and absorption line spectra are produced by electron transitions between the energy levels in the atom.

question_html: Which of the following elements has atoms with only two half-filled atomic orbitals in the ground state?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct; a carbon atom has the following electron configuration 1s2 2s2 2p2. The p sub-level has two unpaired electrons, each in a different 2p orbital, in accordance with Hund’s rule.

question_html: The diagram below shows a set of experimental data points, x, determined when one experimental measurement was repeated four times. The centre of the diagram represents the literature value. Which of the following statements is correct about these measurements?

MCQ_set.answer_html: The measurements involve low accuracy and high precision
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct; the results are closely grouped together so they have high precision, but they are far from the literature value and so have low accuracy.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The measurements involve high accuracy and high precision
The measurements involve high accuracy and low precision
The measurements involve low accuracy and low precision

question_html: How many peaks would be observed in the 1H NMR spectrum of benzene (C6H6)?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct; all six protons are in identical chemical environments so there is just one peak or line in the 1H NMR spectrum.

question_html:
How many different chemical environments that contain hydrogen atoms (protons) are there in the 1H NMR spectrum of the following compound?

(CH3)2CHCH2CH3

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @3 is correct; there are four different chemical environments that contain protons. The protons in the two methyl groups on the left are equivalent and are one chemical environment. The protons in the -CH- group, the protons in the -CH2- group and the protons in the -CH3 on the right are all in different chemical environments, which makes a total of four different chemical environments that contain protons.

question_html: Which of the following sketch graphs shows the values of y decreasing exponentially with increasing values of x?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @4 is correct; for such a graph the decreasing values of y should form a curve of diminishing values, not a straight line or curve of increasing values.

question_html:
The equation for a straight line graph is often written as

                                                                y = mx + c

The sketch below shows how a line graph is extrapolated (the dotted extension to the y axis) to find the value of which term in this equation?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @3 is correct; the line is extrapolated to find the intercept on the y-axis which is the valie of c in the equation.This is a particular value of y, not a general value of y which would be found by interpolation from a known value of x.

question_html:
The following data were obtained in a thermochemistry experiment:

Initial temperature / oC 18.7 ± 0.5
Maximum temperature / oC 37.6 ± 0.5

How should the temperature change for the reaction be recorded?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @2 is correct; The temperature change is the maximum temperature minus the initial temperature (37.6 oC – 18.7 oC). The value is quoted to one decimal place, that is to the same precision as the original measurement. The uncertainty quoted should be the sum of the uncertainties of the experimental readings.

question_html:
A student carried out a series of experiments to determine how the rate of the reaction X → Y varies with the concentration of X.The following table shows a selection of results, all of which fell on the same straight line.

experiment [X] / mol dm-3 rate of reaction / mol dm-3 s-1
1 0.1 0.2
2 0.3 0.6
3 0.6 1.2

What is the gradient (slope) of the graph plotted (= the rate constant for the reaction)?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @2 is correct; remember that the independent variable (concentration in this case) is plotted on the x-axis, and that the gradient of the line is Δy / Δx. Note too that the units must be divided in the same way (or remember that for a first order reaction the units of k are time-1).

question_html: In the Maxwell-Boltzmann distribution of kinetic energies in a sample of gas at a particular temperature, the area under the curve represents which of the following?

MCQ_set.answer_html: the total energies of all the particles in the sample
the total number of particles in the sample
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @2 is correct; remember that the area under such a curve represents the total number of particles sampled in the distribution.

question_html: A student obtained the following experimental value from an experiment; volume = 0.003650 m3. The number of significant figures and decimal places in this value are:

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct; remember that the zeros that precede the integers do not count as significant figures, but those quoted after the integers do.

question_html: Which of the following would reduce the random error in an experiment to measure the enthalpy of neutralisation when 50 cm3 of 0.50 mol dm-3 NaOH (aq) reacts with 50 cm3 of 0.50 mol dm-3 HCl (aq)?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @2 is correct; in general random errors can be reduced by doing repeat trials and taking an average.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Carry out the reaction in an insulated cup
Use a 50 cm3 measuring cylinder for adding the acid rather than a burette

question_html:
Analytical techniques provided the following information about the identity of compound X.

  • IHD = 0
  • the molecular ion peak occurs at m/z = 58
  • there are two peaks in the 1H NMR spectrum

Which of the following could be the structure of compound X?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct; this is the only molecule that fits all the analytical information. CH3CH2CH2CH3 (butane) has an IHD of 0, the mass of the molecular ion, CH3CH2CH2CH3+, is 58 and it will produce two peak in a 1H NMR as there are two different chemical environments that contain protons (CH3 and CH2).

question_html:
Which of the following compounds exhibits three peaks in its 1H NMR spectrum?

I. CH3CH2OCH3

II. (CH3)3CCl

III. CH3CH2COOH

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @3 is correct; compounds I and III have three different hydrogen environments that contain protons, and three peaks. Compound II has just one hydrogen environment that contains protons.

question_html: Which of the following m/z values is for the peak of the molecular ion in the mass spectrum of CH3COOC2H5?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @2 is correct; The molar mass of CH3COOC2H5 is 88, therefore, the molecular ion CH3COOC2H5+ would have a peak at this m/z value.

question_html: Which of the following compounds, when analysed in a mass spectrometer, will give a molecular ion peak with a m/z which is an odd number?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
@3 is correct; this CH3CH2NH2 contains two C atoms (Ar = 12), seven H atoms (Ar = 1) and one N atom (Ar = 14), By adding up the atomic masses of these atoms we will obtain the molecular mass (Mr) for the compound:

Mr = (2 × 12) + (7 × 1) + (1 × 14) =  45

We can therefore conclude that Mr for CH3CH2NH2 is an odd number.

question_html: Propanal, CH3CH2CHO (Mr = 58), is fragmented in a mass spectrometer. What is the m/z of the molecular ion, M+, in the mass spectrum?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @4 is correct; the molecular ion, CH3CH2CHO+, is simply the molecule which has lost one electron, therefore, it will have an m/z of 58.

question_html:
Consider the gaseous equilibrium between N2O4 and NO2

                           N2O4(g) ⇌ 2NO2(g)        Kc = 5.0 x 10-3

If in an equilibrium mixture of these two gases the [N2O4(g)] =

5.0 x 10-1 mol dm-3. What is the equilibrium concentration of NO2 in mol dm-3?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
@3 is correct; Kc = [NO2]2 / [N2O4]

Therefore Kc = 5.0 x 10-3 = [NO2]2 / 5.0 x 10-1

[NO2]2 = ( 5.0 x 10-3) ( 5.0 x 10-1) = 25 x 10-4

[NO2] = 5.0 x 10-2 mol dm-3

question_html:
The equilibrium constant expression, Kc, for a reaction is:

\(K_c = \dfrac{\mathrm{[B][C]}}{\mathrm{[A]^2}}\)

At a certain temperature the equilibrium values of [A], [B] and [C] are all 0.200 mol dm-3. What will happen to the value of Kc if these concentrations are doubled at constant temperature?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @2 is correct; the only change in conditions which changes the value of Kc for a reaction is a change in temperature.

MCQ_set.answer_html: the value of Kc increases by a factor of 4

question_html:
Which change increases the concentration of ammonium ions in the reaction below?

NH3 (g) + H2O (l) ⇌ NH4+ (aq) + OH– (aq)      ΔH > 0

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @3 is correct; adding an acid (H+) will remove OH– ions from the equilibrium mixture; the equilibrium will shift to the right to replace the H+ ions, resulting in an increased concentration of ammonium ions. The other changes all shift the equilibrium position to the left.

question_html: Which of the following gases cannot lead to acid deposition?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @2 is correct; CO is produced in vehicle exhaust but it does not contribute to acid rain.

question_html: In a voltaic cell, oxidation occurs at which of the following?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @3 is correct; oxidation is the loss of electrons (OILRIG); this takes place at the half-cell of the most reactive metal which becomes the anode. It is worth remembering that the anode of any type of cell is defined as the electrode at which oxidation takes place. In a voltaic cell, the anode is negatively charged and the cathode is positively charged.

question_html: A voltaic cell is made up of iron and magnesium half-cells. Magnesium is a more reactive metal than iron. Which of the following statements is correct when the cell produces electricity?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Electrons are lost from the magnesium atoms to form Mg2+ ions
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct; magnesium is the more reactive metal and therefore forms ions more readily than iron. The electrons flow from the magnesium to the iron, the concentration of Fe2+ ions decreases, and negative ions flow from the salt bridge to the magnesium half cell to balance the Mg2+ ions formed.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Electrons flow from the iron half cell to the magnesium half cell
The concentration of Fe2+ ions in solution increases
Negative ions flow through the salt bridge from the magnesium half cell to the iron half cell

question_html: The following substances are dissolved in water to form 1.00 mol dm-3 solutions. When these solutions are listed in order of increasing pH, which is the correct order?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @4 is correct; remember that strong acids have the lowest pH, and strong alkalis the highest. Carbonic acid is a weak acid, and ammonia is a weak base. Note that the concentration of each is the same to make it a fair comparison.

section_title: Strength of conjugate acids and bases

question_html:
Consider a weak acid HA dissolved in water giving rise to the following equilibrium:

HA(aq) + H2O(l) ⇌ H3O+(aq) + A-(aq)

Which of the following statement(s) is/are correct?

I.  A– (aq) is a much stronger base than H2O (l)

II. the concentration of H3O+ is much greater than that of HA

III. HA only dissociates to a very small extent in water

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @3 is correct; a weak acid only dissociates to a very small extent in water (III is correct); this indicates that A- is a much stronger base than H2O as the equilibrium position lies to the left.

section_title: Strength of conjugate acids and bases

question_html: Which of the following pH indicators has a colour change from pink in an alkaline solution to colourless in an acidic solution?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @3 is correct; phenolphthalein changes from pink in an alkaline solution to colourless in an acidic solution.

question_html:
5.00 dm3 of ethane reacts with 5.00 dm3 of oxygen according to the reaction below. Calculate the volume of carbon dioxide that is produced in the reaction.

                   2C2H6 (g) + 7O2 (g) → 4CO2 (g) + 6H2O (g)

All gas volumes are measured under the same conditions of temperature and pressure.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct; You need to first work out which is the limiting reactant. Divide the volume of the reactant by the coefficient in the equation and the smaller value is the limiting reagent (remember that in reactions involving gases, we can use volume ratios as molar ratios). In this case it is the oxygen. The equation tells us that 7 moles (or volumes) of oxygen produces 4 moles (or volumes) of carbon dioxide. Therefore, 5.00 dm3 of oxygen will give 5.00 dm3 × \(4 \over 7\) =  \(20 \over 7\)dm3 = 2.86 dm3 of CO2

section_title: Avogadro's law and molar volume of a gas

question_html:
Determine the mass (in g) of one molecule of methanal (HCHO). 

M C = 12.01 g mol-1

M O = 16.00 g mol-1

M H = 1.01 g mol-1

Avogadro constant, L = 6.02 × 1023

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
@3 is correct: The mass of one mole of methanal is its molar mass (30.03 g mol-1). One mole of methanal consists of 6.02 × 1023 methanal molecules. To find the mass of one methanal molecule, divide the molar mass by the Avogadro constant:

30.03 / 6.02 × 1023 = 4.99 × 10-23 g

section_title: The mole and the Avogadro constant

question_html: If aluminium is soft and malleable while raw tungsten is hard and brittle, which of the following statements is correct?

MCQ_set.answer_html: When you squeeze or press aluminium, it will bend easily
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Malleable means that the metal will bend easily and thus not break when pressed into a shape. Brittle means that though a lot of force may be required, the metal will eventually shatter as it is not particularly easy to bend.

MCQ_set.answer_html: When you squeeze tungsten weakly, it will shatter
When you squeeze aluminium strongly it will shatter
When you squeeze tungsten strongly, it will bend

question_html: What is the difference between malleability and ductility?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Malleability means the metal can be reshaped and bent under pressure. Ductility means they can be drawn out into a wire.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: You should make sure that you know these two terms and understand the difference between them. They both refer to key properties that make metals so useful and result from the nature of the metallic bond.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Ductility means the metal can be reshaped and bent under pressure. Malleability means they can be drawn out into a wire.
Malleability means the metal can be reshaped or bent under pressure and ductility means that metals can be polished to a shine.
Malleability means metals are can be polished to a shine and ductility means the metal can be reshaped or bent under pressure.

question_html: Which of the following explains why metals are able to conduct electricity?

MCQ_set.answer_html: They contain free-moving electrons which are able to move in an electrical field
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: In order to conduct electricity, the substance must possess electrons or ions that are free to move around. In a metal it is the delocalised electrons that move in one direction when a potential difference is applied. The cations in a metal are held in a lattice and cannot move. Conductivity due to movement of ions is a phenomenon that takes place in electrolytes (ionic compounds in a molten state or solution in water).

MCQ_set.answer_html: They contain free-moving ions which are able to move in an electrical field
They contain free-moving cations which are able to move in an electrical field
They contain free-moving anions which are able to move in an electrical field

question_html: How does the presence of impurities affect the malleability of a metal?

MCQ_set.answer_html: They make the metal less malleable because the layers cannot slide over each other as easily
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Impurities are often different sizes to the cations within the metal structure so they disrupt the layers and prevent them from easily sliding over each other; the property that allows the metal to be malleable. Thus the presence of the impurity tends to make the metal less malleable (for example, pig iron is quite brittle as it has quite high carbon content).

MCQ_set.answer_html: They make the metal more malleable because the layers cannot slide over each other as easily
They make the metal more malleable because the layers can slide over each other more easily
They make the metal less malleable because the layers can slide over each other more easily

question_html: Which of the following fuels is not obtained from the fractional distillation of the homogeneous mixture that is crude oil (petroleum)?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @3 is correct; be careful of a question that asks a negative. Ethanol can be used as a fuel as it burns very exothermically. However it is not a component of petroleum, which is a mixture of hydrocarbons.

question_html:
Which of the following changes of state are endothermic processes (absorb heat)?

I. Condensation
II. Sublimation
​III. Melting

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct; sublimation and melting are endothermic processes; energy is required to overcome the intermolecular forces between the particles in a solid. Condensation is exothermic; when a gas becomes a liquid, energy is released.

question_html: Which of the following species cannot act as a Lewis acid?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @2 is correct; this molecule has a full set of eight valence electrons around the central N atom (a full octet) and cannot, therefore, accept a lone pair. All the other species are electron deficient and can accept a lone pair of electrons (such as the Al in AlCl3 and the B in BF3).

section_title: Lewis theory of acids and bases

question_html:
What is the correct order of reaction types in the following synthetic route?

Step I. C3H7Br → C3H7OH

Step II. C3H7OH → C2H5COOH

Step III. C2H5COOH → C2H5COOC2H5

Step I   Step II Step III
A  nucleophilic substitution oxidation  nucleophilic substitution
B  nucleophilic substitution oxidation esterification
C addition  nucleophilic substitution esterification
D oxidation  nucleophilic substitution esterification

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @2 is correct; Step 1 is a nucleophilic substitution reaction; step 2 shows the oxidation of an alcohol to a carboxylic acid; and step 3 shows an esterification reaction.

question_html: Which of the following combinations of compounds can be used to prepare the ester CH3COOCH3?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @4 is correct; the compound is an ester which is formed from an alcohol and a carboxylic acid. Here the alcohol has just one C atom, as does methanol. The carboxylic acid has two C atoms, as does ethanoic acid.

question_html: Which compound is produced when a ketone is reduced by sodium borohydride, NaBH4?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @4 is correct; ketones produce secondary alcohols on reduction; the reverse of the fact that ketones are produced by the oxidation of secondary alcohols.

question_html: Which of the following is the intermediate formed during the reduction of nitrobenzene to phenylamine by tin and concentrated hydrochloric acid?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct; the phenylammonium ion is the intermediate formed in the reduction of nitrobenzene.

question_html: Which of the following alcohols cannot be oxidised by an acidified solution of potassium dichromate(VI)?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @2 is correct; this alcohol is a tertiary alcohol and is not oxidised by acidic potassium dichromate(VI) solution. Primary and secondary alcohols can be oxidised to either aldehydes, carboxylic acids or ketones. The structure of (CH3)3COH is shown below. Note that the carbon atom bonded to the hydroxyl group (OH) is bonded to three other carbon atoms, making it a tertiary alcohol.

question_html: Which two reactants could be used to form the compound with the structure shown below?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @4 is correct; the molecule contains an ester linkage and is synthesised by an esterification or condensation reaction. In this case the parent alcohol is ethanol (on the right hand side of the molecule) and the acid is butanoic acid (remember to count the carbon atom of the ester link as part of the parent acid).

question_html: Halogenoalkanes typically react by which of the following types of reaction mechanism?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @2 is correct; halogenoalkanes have an electron-deficient carbon atom (δ+) and therefore are attacked by nucleophiles in substitution reactions.

question_html:
Which of the following properties of benzene is due to the fact that its structure involves delocalised π-electrons?

I. benzene undergoes electrophilic addition reactions
II. benzene undergoes electrophilic substitution reactions
III. benzene has intermediate carbon to carbon bonds between a single and a double bond

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @2 is correct; the benzene structure is a regular hexagon with all carbon to carbon bonds in the benzene ring being the same length and the same strength. The molecule undergoes electrophilic substitution reactions because this mechanism restores the stability of the delocalised ring structure.

question_html:
The reaction between (CH3)3CBr and aqueous NaOH results in bromine being replaced by a hydroxyl group. What type of reaction mechanism is favoured and what species is an important feature of that mechanism?

Mechanism Key feature
A SN2 an intermediate
B SN2 a transition state
C SN1 an intermediate
D SN1 a transition state

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @3 is correct; the halogenoalkane is tertiary and so the mechanism involved is SN1, which proceeds via a carbocation intermediate.

question_html: Which of the following molecular or ionic species is not amphiprotic?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct; this ion (sometimes referred to as the hydronium or oxonium ion) is very acidic and does not act as a base. All the other species are amphiprotic as they are able to either accept a proton and donate a proton.

question_html: Which of the reactions listed below is an example of a Lewis acid–base reaction, but is not a Brønsted–Lowry acid–base reaction?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @2 is correct; in this case there is a transfer of ligands, with Cl−  ions replacing the water molecules around the central cobalt ion, but there is no transfer of H+ ions. In fact the H+ ions are spectator ions in the aqueous solution.

section_title: Lewis theory of acids and bases

question_html: Which of the following is a correct statement about a Lewis base?

MCQ_set.answer_html: It is an electron pair acceptor and can act as a nucleophile
It is an electron pair donor and can act as a nucleophile
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @2 is correct; essentially this question is based on knowing certain key definitions, that of a Lewis base and then the difference between a nucleophile and an electrophile. A Lewis base is an electron pair donor, which means that @1 and @4 are incorrect. Such a base is a nucleophile donating a lone pair of electrons to an electron-deficient centre in the target molecule, hence @2 is correct.

MCQ_set.answer_html: It is an electron pair donor and can act as an electrophile
It is an electron pair acceptor and can act as an electrophile

section_title: Lewis theory of acids and bases

question_html: Which of the following molecular species can act as an acid according to the Lewis theory, but not according to the Brønsted–Lowry theory?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @3 is correct; a Lewis acid is electron deficient and is therefore able to accept a lone pair of electrons. BCl3 is electron deficient as there are only six electrons around the central B atom. BCl3 cannot act as a Brønsted–Lowry acid as it does not have a proton (H+) to donate. The remaining molecules can act as Brønsted–Lowry acids by donating protons.

section_title: Lewis theory of acids and bases

question_html: Which of the following regions of the electromagnetic spectrum corresponds to the energy of molecular vibrations?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @3 is correct; the energy involved in the bending and vibration about the bonds of a molecule falls in the infrared region of the electromagnetic spectrum.

question_html: Which one of the following techniques may be used to identify the crystalline components of paints based on analysis of their crystal structure?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct; the analytical technique which probes crystal structure is X-ray crystallography – the diffraction pattern produced being dependent on how the atoms are arranged in a lattice.

question_html: Which of the following molecules gives more than a single peak in its 1H NMR spectrum?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @4 is correct: the phenol molecule contains protons in two different chemical environments, one where they are attached to the ring structure, the other being the hydrogen of the –OH group.

question_html: What structural information about an organic molecule is provided by infrared spectroscopy?

MCQ_set.answer_html: The number of carbon atoms in the molecule
The functional groups present in the molecule
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @2 is correct; infrared spectroscopy shows peaks that correspond to the bending and stretching of different bonds and hence it provides information on the functional groups present in a molecule.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The number of hydrogen atoms in each molecule

question_html:
Which of the following correctly describes the 1H NMR spectrum of tetramethylsilane (TMS)?

Number of protons Number of different chemical environments in which protons are located
i. 12 4
ii. 9 4
iii. 12 1
iv. 9 1

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @3 is correct; there are four methyl groups in the molecule and 12 protons; however, they are all in the same chemical environment, which is why the molecule gives a single peak on a 1H NMR spectrum.

question_html:
Consider the following standard electrode potentials:

Mg2+ (aq) + 2e– ⇌ Mg (s)    E⦵ = –2.37 V

2H+ (aq) + 2e– ⇌ H2 (g)     E⦵ = 0.00 V

Which of the following is the correct spontaneous reaction between hydrochloric acid and magnesium metal, and the correct value for the E⦵cell?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Magnesium has the more negative E⦵ value and will therefore be the oxidation reaction.

E⦵cell = E⦵red – E⦵ox = (0.00) – (–2.37) = +2.37 V

The positive sign tells us the reaction is spontaneous.

question_html: The electrolysis of aqueous copper(II) sulfate using copper electrodes is the basis of refining impure copper in industry. Which of the following statements is correct for this example of electrolysis?

MCQ_set.answer_html: the anode gains in mass due to deposition of copper atoms.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @2 is correct; during electrolysis metal ions always move to the cathode to be discharged; pure copper is deposited on the cathode. The anode actually loses mass as copper dissolves from the electrode and the solution remains the same colour (as copper ions enter the solution at the anode and are deposited at the cathode).

MCQ_set.answer_html: oxygen gas is produced at the cathode.
the blue colour of the copper(II) sulfate solution becomes lighter.

question_html: Which of the following are used to make a standard hydrogen electrode (SHE)?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @2 is correct; the SHE uses a platinum (Pt) electrode in contact with hydrogen gas (H2) at a pressure of 100 kPa and 1 mol dm-3 H+ ions.

question_html: Which of the following statements about the electrolysis of concentrated sodium chloride solution using graphite electrodes is incorrect?

MCQ_set.answer_html: sodium metal is deposited at the cathode
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is the only option that is an incorrect statement. Sodium ions are never discharged during the electrolysis of aqueous solutions of sodium as they are too strong a reducing agent; water is reduced instead to form hydrogen gas. All the other statements are correct. Be careful of questions asking for a statement that is incorrect.

MCQ_set.answer_html: a greenish-yellow gas is produced at the anode

question_html:
The following sequence of diagrams represents the reaction mixture as time passes for a gas phase reaction in which reactant A is converted to product B.

Which of the following statements is correct?

MCQ_set.answer_html: At t = 10 minutes, the system has reached a state of equilibrium
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct: comparing the proportions of A and B in the mixtures after t = 10 minutes and t = 3 days shows that there is no change, therefore, the system is at equilibrium when t = 10 minutes.

MCQ_set.answer_html: At t = 3 days, the rate of the forward reaction is greater than the rate of the reverse reaction
At t = 5 seconds, the reaction has reached completion
At t = 3 days, the rate of the forward reaction is less than the rate of the reverse reaction

question_html:
Which combination of standard change of Gibbs free energy (ΔG⦵) and equilibrium constant (K) is most typical for a reaction that goes to completion?

ΔG⦵ (kJ mol-1) K
i. positive   low
ii. negative  high
iii. positive high
iv. negative low

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @2 is correct: A reaction that goes to completion will have a high value for the Kc and a negative value of ΔG⦵. The high value for the Kc occurs because the equilibrium mixture will have a high concentration of products. When calculating the ΔG using the equation ΔG = –RT ln K, this will give a negative value for the ΔG.

question_html:
Which set of conditions gives rise to the greatest equilibrium yield of methanal, H2CO(g), in the following reaction?

CO (g) + H2 (g) ⇌ H2CO (g)   ΔH = –1.80 kJ mol-1

Pressure Temperature
i. low high
ii. low low
iii. high high
iv. high low

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @4 is correct; applying Le Chatelier's principle, the products side of the equation involves fewer moles of gas and so will be favoured by increased pressure; the forward reaction is exothermic and so will be favoured by decreasing the temperature.

question_html:
Iron(III) ions, Fe3+, react with thiocyanate ions, SCN–, in a reversible reaction shown by the equation below. The [FeSCN]2+ ion has a red colour in solution.

Which of the following changes made to the reaction at equilibrium will cause the solution to be a deeper red colour?

Fe3+ (aq) + SCN– (aq) ⇌ [FeSCN]2+ (aq)   ΔH⦵ = positive

I. Increasing the temperature
II. Adding FeCl3 solution
III. Adding a catalyst

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct: a catalyst does not affect the position of an equilibrium, therefore, III is incorrect; both the other options are correct. Increasing the temperature favours the endothermic process, which is the forward reaction. Adding more Fe3+ ions (from the addition of FeCl3) will shift the equilibrium position to the right.

question_html:
Which of the following statements are correct?

I. the rate constant, k, for a reaction increases with increasing temperature
II. increasing the temperature decreases the activation energy of a reaction
III. the term A in the Arrhenius equation relates to the energy requirements of the collisions between reactants

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct; increasing the temperature increases the rate constant for a reaction, however, the activation energy is not affected by changes in temperature. The factor A is the Arrhenius constant and relates to the collision orientation of reactant particles.

question_html: What happens to the rate constant (k) and activation energy of a reaction (Ea) when the temperature is increased?

MCQ_set.answer_html: k increases and Ea is unaffected
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct; the activation energy is unaffected by a change in temperature. The rate constant, k, increases with an increase in temperature.

MCQ_set.answer_html: k decreases and Ea is unaffected
Ea increases and k is unaffected
Ea decreases and k is unaffected

question_html: A reaction involves two reactants, compounds A and B. Which one of the following changes would result in an increase in the value of the rate constant, k?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct; a change in temperature is the only factor that affects the rate constant of a particular reaction. An increase in temperature increases the value of the rate constant k.

question_html:
A compound shows an 1H NMR spectrum with three major peaks and the integrated trace shown below:

Chemical shift / ppm Integrated trace (ratio)
1.0 3
2.0 3
2.3 2

Which of the following compounds does the spectrum relate to?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct; according to the spectrum, there are 3 three different chemical environments in which hydrogen atoms are located; this and the second option (CH3CH2CHO) are the only ones where this is the case; the others show only two different environments. The integrated trace ratio shows hydrogen atoms in the ratio of  2:3:3 which correspond to the hydrogen atoms in the CH3, CH2 and CH3 groups in the molecule. This is not the case for CH3CH2CHO.

question_html: For an ideal gas, the volume V, pressure P, temperature T, and amount (in mol), n, are related by the ideal gas equation: PV = nRT. If the relationship between pressure and volume of a fixed amount of gas at constant temperature is investigated experimentally, which one of the following plots would produce a linear graph?

MCQ_set.answer_html: No possible plot can produce a straight line

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @3 is correct; if PV is a constant then P and V must be inversely proportional to each other, so a graph of P versus 1/V would be a straight line.

question_html:
The graph below shows how the mass of copper deposited during electrolysis varies with time.

Which of the following is the dependent variable?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @2 is correct; the mass of copper deposited increases with time (the independent variable); the current flowing is the other variable which could affect the mass deposited, and it is kept constant.

question_html: How many significant figures are there in the mass 5.010 × 10–3 g?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @3 is correct: remember that zeros to the right of the decimal point are significant, so the final zero is included. Therefore, there are four significant figures in the mass 5.010 × 10-3 g

question_html: Which of the techniques listed below involves the absorption of radiation by bonds between atoms?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct; this type of spectroscopy depends on the absorption in the infrared as the bonds in a molecule bend or stretch (with a resulting change in the dipole of the molecule).

question_html:
In comparing the random uncertainties and systematic errors involved in an investigation, the following properties of errors may be considered:

I.    it is possible to eliminate the error 
II.   it is not possible to remove the error entirely
III.  the sign and size of the error is constant
IV.  the error is of varying sign and size
V.   averaging repeated measurements will reduce the error
VI.  the error cannot be reduced by averaging repeated measurements.

Which of the above properties apply to random errors (or uncertainties)?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct; random errors cannot be removed entirely, their size and sign is variable, but they can be reduced by averaging many repeated measurements.

question_html:
The results of an experiment on the variation of the rate of reaction with changing reactant concentration produced the following graph. Which combination of data in the table below correctly states the value and units of the gradient of the straight line obtained?

value units
i (0.050 − 0.010) / ( 3.0 × 10−3 − 0.6 × 10−3) s−1
ii (3.0 × 10−3 − 0.6 x10−3) / ( 0.050 − 0.010) s
iii (3.0 ×10−3 − 0.6 × 10−3) / (0.050 − 0.010) s−1
iv (0.050 − 0.010) / (3.0 × 10−3 − 0.6 × 10−3) s

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @3 is correct; the units of the gradient are mol dm−3 s−1 / mol dm–3 = s−1. The value of the gradient is given by Δy / Δx. Therefore, (3.0 × 10−3 − 0.6 ×10−3) / (0.050 − 0.010) is correct.

question_html: Which of the following is the correct index of hydrogen deficiency (IHD) for testosterone, with the molecular formula C19H28O2?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
@3 is correct; the oxygen does not contribute to the IHD, so we can use the formula for CxHy , which is:

IHD = (2 × 19 + 2 − y) / 2 = (38 + 2 − 28) / 2 = 12 / 2 = 6

question_html:
What type of chemical reaction is represented by the following equation involving bromomethane?

CH3Br (aq) + OH– (aq) → CH3OH (l) + Br– (aq)

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @3 is correct; this is a (nucleophilic) substitution reaction as the OH group replaces the Br. This is the preferred type of reaction for halogenoalkanes. The hydroxide ion is behaving as a nucleophile.

question_html:
Which of the following reactions does benzene readily undergo?

I. Addition
II. Combustion
III. Substitution

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct: benzene, as all other hydrocarbons, burns to form carbon dioxide and water. It does not readily undergo addition reactions, instead it undergoes (electrophilic) substitution reactions such as chlorination and nitration.

question_html: Which of these statements about the reaction between methane and chlorine is correct?

MCQ_set.answer_html: It involves heterolytic bond fission and Cl– ions
It involves heterolytic bond fission and Cl• radicals
It involves homolytic bond fission and Cl• radicals
