MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @3 is correct; ultraviolet radiation brings about the homolytic fission of chlorine molecules, and this produces chlorine free radicals, Cl•. Note that the reaction occurs in the presence of ultraviolet (UV) light.

MCQ_set.answer_html: It involves homolytic bond fission and Cl– ions

question_html: A hydrocarbon, X, decolourises aqueous bromine, Br2 (aq). Which one of the following molecular formulas could be X?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @3 is correct; C3H6 is an unsaturated hydrocarbon that contains a carbon to carbon double bond. The test for unsaturation is to react the compound in question with bromine water. The bromine water is decolourised by the unsaturated hydrocarbon, in this case propene. The colour change is brown to colourless. The remaining choices are all alkanes which are saturated hydrocarbons.

question_html: Which of these compounds could form an addition polymer? Hint - try drawing out the full structural formulas of the compounds to help you.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct; to form an addition polymer the molecule must be unsaturated (contain a C=C). This option (propene) is the only one that is unsaturated. The other molecules are saturated (have C-C bonds). Drawing out the full structural formula of the molecule will help you answer this question.

question_html: What is the role of UV radiation during the reaction between chlorine and methane?

MCQ_set.answer_html: To break the bond between the chlorine atoms in the chlorine molecule
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct; the energy from UV radiation breaks the bond in the chlorine molecules (homolytic bond fission) to produce chlorine free radicals. These are uncharged but have an unpaired electron.

MCQ_set.answer_html: To dissociate the chlorine molecules into ions
To increase the temperature of the mixture
To break C−H bonds in the methane molecules

question_html:
Which of the following have positive entropy changes, ΔS?

I. NaCl (s) →  NaCl (aq)
II. Na2CO3 (s) + 2HCl (aq) → CO2 (g) + 2NaCl (aq) + H2O (l)
III. AgNO3 (aq) + NaCl (aq) → AgCl (s) + NaNO3 (aq)

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct; both of the first two options will result in increased entropy. In I, aqueous ionic compounds have higher entropy than solids, in II, there is an increase in the number of moles of gas. In III, there will be a decrease in entropy as a solid is produced.

question_html:
What can be concluded from the fact that the following reaction is spontaneous only at temperatures above 1100 K?

C (s) + CO2 (g) → 2CO (g)

MCQ_set.answer_html: ΔH is negative and ΔS is positive
ΔH is positive and ΔS is positive
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @2 is correct: for a reaction to be spontaneous ΔG must be negative. Inspection of the equation indicates that ΔS is positive as the products are all in the gas phase. If the reaction is only spontaneous at a high temperature, then ΔH must be more positive (endothermic) than  ΔS, resulting in a positive value of ΔG at lower temperatures. However, if the temperature is sufficiently high then the factor -TΔS becomes sufficiently large to overcome the positive ΔH and make ΔG negative, and the reaction is spontaneous.

MCQ_set.answer_html: ΔH is negative and ΔS is negative
ΔH is positive and ΔS is negative

question_html:
Which combination of ionic radii and ionic charges will produce the most endothermic lattice enthalpy (ΔHlat)?

Radius of positive ion / nm Radius of negative ion / nm Charge on positive ion Charge on negative ion
i. 0.100 0.185 2+ 2–
ii. 0.102 0.180 1+ 1–
iii. 0.149 0.180 1+ 1–
iv. 0.100 0.140 2+ 2–

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @4 is correct; the value of the lattice enthalpy for an ionic compound depends on the ionic radius and the charge on the ions. Choice iv has the smallest ionic radii and the highest charge, therefore, it has the most endothermic lattice enthalpy.

question_html:
Which of the following statements explains why the value of the lattice enthalpy of lithium fluoride is less than that of strontium fluoride?

I. The ionic radius of a lithium ion is less than that of a strontium ion.
II. The ionic charge of a lithium ion is less than that of a strontium ion.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @3 is correct; The strontium ion has a charge of 2+ whereas a lithium ion is only 1+. The lithium ion has a smaller ionic radius than the strontium ion, however, the higher ionic charge of Sr2+ results in a higher lattice enthalpy.

question_html: Which of these equations is the correct equation to represent the lattice enthalpy of magnesium oxide?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @2 is correct: the lattice enthalpy is the enthalpy change when one mole of solid ionic compound is broken down into its constituent gaseous ions. This equation represents that process.

question_html:
Which processes take place at the negative electrode in a voltaic cell and an electrolytic cell?

Voltaic cell Electrolytic cell
i. oxidation reduction
ii. reduction oxidation
iii. oxidation oxidation
iv. reduction reduction

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct; in a voltaic cell the negative electrode is the anode, which is where oxidation takes place. In an electrolytic cell, the negative electrode is the cathode, which is where reduction takes place.

question_html: Which statement is correct for the electrolysis of molten lead(II) bromide?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Lead ions move toward the positive electrode
Both lead and bromide ions move toward the electrodes
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @2 is correct; in an electrolytic cell the positive and negative ions in the electrolyte move to the opposite electrodes; metal ions (cations) to the cathode, non-metal ions (anions) to the anode. The gas, bromine vapour, is produced at the positive electrode.

MCQ_set.answer_html: A gas is produced at the negative electrode

question_html:
Which of these half-equations could take place at the positive electrode (cathode) of a voltaic cell?

I. Zn2+ (aq) + 2e– → Zn (s)
II. Cu2+ (aq) + 2e– → Cu (s)
III. Mg (s) → Mg2+ (aq) + 2e–

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @4 is correct; in a voltaic cell reduction takes place at the cathode (positive electrode) – electrons are gained. Electrons are gained in both I and II; but III is an oxidation reaction, as electrons are being lost as magnesium ions are formed from magnesium atoms.

question_html:
What are the products at each electrode when molten sodium chloride, NaCl, is electrolysed?

Anode Cathode
i. hydrogen sodium
ii. chlorine sodium
iii. chlorine hydrogen
iv. sodium chlorine

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: (ii) is correct; in the electrolysis of a molten salt, the metal ions are always reduced at the cathode and the halide ions are always oxidised at the anode. Note that this is the electrolysis of molten sodium chloride so there is no water present and there is no possibility of hydrogen being produced.

question_html:
The overall reaction in the voltaic cell below is:

Ni (s) + Pb2+ (aq) → Ni2+ (aq) + Pb (s)

Which of the following statements is correct for the nickel half-cell?

MCQ_set.answer_html: The nickel half-cell is the negative electrode and is reduced
The nickel half-cell is the positive electrode and is reduced
The nickel half-cell is the negative electrode and is oxidised
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @3 is correct; nickel is more reactive than lead (it is higher in the activity series). This means that the nickel half-cell is oxidised and the electrode is the negative electrode. In voltaic cells oxidation always takes place at the anode which is the negative electrode.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The nickel half-cell is the positive electrode and is oxidised

question_html:
Magnesium is a more reactive metal than copper and the two undergo a redox reaction when reacted together:

Mg (s) + Cu2+ (aq) → Mg2+ (aq) + Cu (s)

Which of the following species is the strongest oxidising agent?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @4 is correct. The strongest oxidising agent is the species that most readily accepts electrons as it is itself reduced during the reaction. In this reaction the Mg atoms are oxidised to Mg2+ ions, while Cu2+ ions are reduced to Cu atoms.

question_html: Which of the following is a natural source of nitrogen oxides (NOx) that are responsible for the formation of acid deposition?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @2 is correct; lightning storms are a natural phenomenon and the energy generated causes nitrogen and oxygen in the air to react. This takes place independently of human activity. Pollution is a result of events/activities that are not caused by natural phenomena.

question_html: Calcium oxide is added to a lake to neutralise the effects of acid deposition. The pH value of the lake water is increased from 4 to 6. What is the change in concentration of [H+(aq)] in the lake water?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @2 is correct; the pH scale is logarithmic, with each unit change being a factor of 10. The lower the pH number the higher the concentration of hydrogen ions. So an increase in pH of 2 means that the concentration of hydrogen ions has fallen by a factor of 100.

section_title: Effects and reduction of acid deposition

question_html: In which of the following reactions does nitric acid act as a Brønsted-Lowry base?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @4 is correct; in this reaction sulfuric acid is a stronger acid than nitric acid and so, when the two concentrated acids are mixed, it is the nitric acid that acts as a base and accepts a proton. In all the other options nitric acid is acting as an acid and donating a proton (with the nitrate ion being formed).

section_title: Strength of conjugate acids and bases

question_html: Which of the lists below contains only strong bases?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @3 is correct; strong bases are completely dissociated into ions in solution and comprise the hydroxides of the metals in groups 1 and 2. Ammonia and amines are only weak bases.

section_title: Strength of conjugate acids and bases

question_html: Which of the following acids has the lowest electrical conductivity (assume all solutions are 1.00 mol dm-3)?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @2 is correct; carbonic acid (H2CO3) is only partially dissociated into ions and so is a weak acid; all the other alternatives are strong acids. Weak acids have lower electrical conductivity than strong acids (of equal concentration) as they have lower concentrations of mobile ions in solution.

question_html: Propanoic acid, CH3CH2COOH, is a weaker acid than methanoic acid, HCOOH. Which one of the statements below about these two acids is correct?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Magnesium will react with methanoic acid but not with propanoic acid.
The pH of a solution of 1.00 mol dm−3 propanoic acid is higher than that of 1.00 mol dm–3 methanoic acid.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @2 is correct; both these acids are weak acids containing the carboxylic acid group, but methanoic acid is the stronger of the two. So for two solutions of the same concentration, methanoic acid will have the lower pH as the solution will contain a higher concentration of hydrogen ions.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Propanoic acid is more dissociated in water than methanoic acid.
A 1.00 mol dm−3 solution of methanoic acid will turn blue litmus red, but a 1.00 mol dm−3 solution of propanoic acid will turn red litmus blue.

question_html: A dilute aqueous solution of methanoic acid has a slow rate of reaction with magnesium. Which of the following statements correctly accounts for this observation?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Methanoic acid solution has a high concentration of ions

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @2 is correct; methanoic acid is a weak acid which only partially dissociate into ions. As there is a low concentration of hydrogen ions in solution, the rate of reaction with magnesium is slow.

question_html:
Which of the following is/are formed when a dilute acid reacts with a metal oxide?

I. Hydrogen gas
II. A metal salt
III. Water

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @4 is correct; the metal oxide here is acting as a base, and the general reaction of a base and an acid is to give a salt and water only.

question_html:
The ionisation of sulfuric acid can be represented by the following two equations:

H2SO4 (l) + H2O (l) → H3O+ (aq) + HSO4– (aq)

HSO4– (aq) + H2O (l) → H3O+ (aq) + SO42– (aq)

Which species is the conjugate base of HSO4– (aq)?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @3 is correct; to be a conjugate base the species must be in the same equation, have a lone pair of electrons with which to accept a proton, and differ from the acid by a proton, H+.

question_html: Among the few compounds of gold, KAu(CN)2 is used for electroplating gold onto other metals. A current of 2.00 A is applied to the electrolytic cell for 20.0 minutes, generating a total charge of 2400 C. One mole of electrons carries approximately 96500 C. How many grams of gold will be electroplated?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Based upon the formula KAu(CN)2, gold is in the +1 oxidation state; therefore, one mole of electrons will be required to form one mole of gold metal:

Au+(aq)  +  e-  ⇌  Au(s)

\(\dfrac {2400 C}{96500 C mol^{-1}}=0.02487  mol\)

\((0.02487 mol)(196.97 g mol^{-1})=4.90 g\)

The other three answers correspond to greater moles of electrons required for the reduction.

question_html: Predict the products - and at which electrode they occur - for the electrolytic cell shown below. The electrolyte is dilute sodium chloride and the electrodes are inert (graphite).

MCQ_set.answer_html: H2 at the cathode and O2 at the anode
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Possible reduction reactions at the cathode:

2H2O (l) + 2e− ⇌  H2 (g) + 2OH− (aq)   E⦵ = − 0.83 V

Na+ (aq)  +  e−  ⇌  Na (s)    E⦵ = − 2.71 V

Na+ ions are a weak oxidising agent and will not be discharged in an aqueous solution, therefore, hydrogen gas will be discharged instead.  

Possible oxidation reactions at the anode:

2Cl−(aq) ⇌ ½Cl2(g)  +  e−   E⦵ = −1.36 V

2H2O (l) ⇌ O2 (g) + 4H+ (aq) + 4e−   E⦵ = −1.23 V

At low sodium chloride concentrations (dilute NaCl), oxygen is discharged at the anode. At high sodium chloride concentrations (concentrated NaCl), chlorine will be discharged rather than oxygen. 

Pay careful attention to state symbols, as the product of molten versus aqueous sodium chloride electrolysis are quite different.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Na at the cathode and Cl2 at the anode

question_html:
Using the standard electrode potentials below, write the spontaneous redox reaction that occurs between chlorine gas and copper metal.

Cu2+(aq)  +  2e–  →  Cu (s),  E⦵ = +0.34 V

½Cl2 (g)  +  e–  →  Cl– (aq),  E⦵ = +1.36 V

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Cu2+(aq)  +  2e–  →  Cu(s),  E⦵ = +0.34 V

Cl2(g)  +  2e–  →  2Cl–(aq),  E⦵ = +1.36 V

E⦵cell = E⦵red  –  E⦵ox = +1.36 – (+0.34) = +1.02 V

question_html:
Consider the following standard electrode potentials:

Zn2+(aq)  +  2e–  ⇌  Zn(s), E⦵ = –0.76 V

2H+(aq)  +  2e–  ⇌  H2(g), E⦵ = 0.00 V

Write the balanced, spontaneous redox reaction between hydrochloric acid and zinc metal, thereby determining the E⦵cell.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Although the reduction of Zn2+ is highly non-spontaneous, relative to the standard hydrogen electrode, the oxidation of Zn is quite the opposite: E⦵ = +0.76 V.

question_html:
Consider the voltaic cell shown below and the accompanying data:

Cu2+(aq)  +  2e–  ⇌  Cu(s)   E⦵ = +0.34 V

Zn2+(aq)  +  2e–  ⇌  Zn(s)   E⦵ = –0.76 V

Identify each electrode, its half-equation and the cell potential, E⦵cell.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Cu2+(aq) + 2e– → Cu(s) has the more positive electrode potential, therefore, this is the cathode reaction and Zn(s) → Zn2+(aq) + 2e– has the more negative electrode potential, therefore, this is the anode reaction. 

EMF of the cell: E⦵cell = E⦵red − E⦵ox = + 0.34 – (– 0.76) = + 1.10 V

question_html: Which of the following statements about voltaic cells is correct?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Oxidation occurs at the negative electrode, which is called the anode
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: By convention, the electrode at which oxidation occurs is called the anode and the direction of electron movement is from the anode, which is negatively charged in a voltaic cell, to the cathode, which is positively charged in a voltaic cell.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Oxidation occurs at the positive electrode, which is called the anode
Oxidation occurs at the negative electrode, which is called the cathode
Oxidation occurs at the positive electrode, which is called the cathode

question_html: Which of the following can exist as optical isomers?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The carbon atom bonded to the hydroxyl group (OH) in 2-butanol has four different groups attached; therefore, this carbon is chiral and the molecule exists in two mirror-image forms. This is not the case for the other three examples.

question_html: Which of the following straight-chain alkanes has the highest boiling point?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: As the molar mass increases, the strength of the London dispersion forces between the molecules also increases, which results in an increase in boiling point. C8H18 has the highest molar mass, therefore, it has the highest boiling point.

question_html: Which of the following alkenes can occur as cis-trans isomers?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Each carbon comprising the carbon-carbon double bond must have two different groups attached, if cis-trans isomerism is to be possible.

question_html: Which pair of compounds are not part of the same homologous series?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: CH3NH2 and HCONH2 (methanamine and methanamide) are amines and amides respectively (not part of the same homologous series). The other pairs of molecules are part of the same homologous series.

question_html: What is the minimum number of steps required to produce ethyl ethanoate starting with only ethene?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
C2H4 → CH3CH2OH, reagents: H2O (g) and concentrated H2SO4  

CH3CH2OH → CH3COOH, reagent: acidified Cr2O72–, heat with reflux

CH3CH2OH  +  CH3COOH  ⇌  CH3COOCH2CH3, reagent: H+ catalyst

question_html: Which is the correct order of increasing rate of reaction for halogenoalkanes undergoing nucleophilic substitution?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Experimentally, SN1 reactions are generally found to be faster than SN2 reactions. This may be because the activation energy required to form the tertiary carbocation intermediate is less than the activation energy required to form the transition state of the SN2 reaction.

question_html: Which of the following is not considered a nucleophile?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: CH4 has no lone pairs of electrons, therefore does not act as a nucleophile in substitution nucleophilic reactions.

question_html: Which of the following reagents will convert an alkene to a ketone in two steps?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Step one is an addition reaction of H-OH across the carbon-carbon double bond to form a 2° alcohol. Step two oxidises the 2° alcohol to a ketone.

question_html: Which of the following is an example of a termination step in the free-radical substitution reaction of an alkane?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: In a termination step, two free-radicals combine to form a non-radical product, in this case chloromethane.

question_html: Which of the following are the correct products when octane (C8H18) undergoes incomplete combustion?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Incomplete combustion implies insufficient oxygen which results in the formation of either carbon monoxide (CO) or carbon (C). Both methane and hydrogen are highly flammable gases: they cannot be products of combustion.

question_html: Which of the following would be expected to have the lowest solubility in water?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Propanal is roughly 500 times more soluble in water than propane, due to dipole-dipole attractions between the carbon-oxygen double bond and the hydrogen-oxygen single bonds in water. Both 1-propanol and propanoic acid are capable of hydrogen bonding with water, making them both highly soluble in it. Propane, a non-polar molecule, has the lowest solubility in water.

question_html: Which of the following is a tertiary halogenoalkane?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: 2-bromo-2-methylpropane has three methyl groups attached to the carbon bonded to the bromine; therefore, it is a tertiary halogenoalkane. 1-bromo-2-methylpropane and 1-bromobutane are primary halogenoalkanes and 2-bromobutane is a secondary halogenoalkane.

question_html: Which of the following homologous series cannot have a molecular formula containing only two carbon atoms?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The following compounds all have two carbon atoms in their molecular formula: CH3CHO, ethanal, is an aldehyde; CH3COOH, ethanoic acid, is a carboxylic acid and HCOOCH3, methyl methanoate, is an ester. The simplest ketone is CH3COCH3, propanone, which has the molecular formula C3H6O. A ketone must have a carbon bonded on either side of the carbon atom bonded to oxygen (with at least 3 carbon atoms).

question_html:
Which of the following statements are correct for the complex ion [CuCl4]2–?

I. The oxidation number of Cu in the complex ion is +2
II. The coordination number of the complex ion is 4
III. Chloride ions are behaving as ligands

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @4 is correct; all three statements are correct: there are four ligands attached to the central copper ion of the complex, the ligands are four chloride ions, and they would have a total charge of 4-, therefore, the copper ion must have a charge of 2+ (oxidation state +2) as the overall charge on the complex is 2-.

question_html: Which of these species is the ligand in the complex K3[Fe(CN)6]?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct; the ligand is part of the complex ion and is attached to the metal ion at the centre of the complex. Fe3+ is the central metal ion of the complex, K+ is the other metal of the salt, and  [Fe(CN)6]3– is the formula of the whole complex ion.

question_html: Which of the following characteristics is an essential feature of a ligand?

MCQ_set.answer_html: The presence of two or more atoms
The presence of a non-bonding pair of electrons
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @4 is correct; a ligand must have a lone (non-bonding) pair of electrons in order to make the coordinate covalent bond to the central metal ion of the complex. A ligand can just contain one atom (e.g. Cl–); it does not have to be charged or have an odd number of electrons (water and ammonia molecules are common ligands).

question_html: Which one of the following molecules is not part of the alkene homologous series?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Alkenes are unsaturated hydrocarbons with carbon-carbon double bonds. C2H6 is an alkane, a saturated hydrocarbon with carbon-carbon single bonds only.

question_html:
What is the IUPAC name for the molecule with the following condensed structural formula? 

CH3CH2C(CH3)2CH(CH3)CH2CH3

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A branch cannot be assigned to the last carbon in a chain: it would be part of the longest carbon chain. 3,4,4-trimethylhexane is not the correct answer: by numbering from the opposite end of the butane chain the designations for the methyl groups become 3,3,4.

question_html: Which one of the following is an accepted IUPAC name for a compound with the molecular formula C6H14?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A methyl group cannot receive a number designation of "1"; this indicates that it is part of the longest carbon chain. 1,3-dimethylbutane should be named 2-methylpentane. The branches must always be given the lowest possible number designations: 3,3-dimethylbutane should be named 2,2-dimethylbutane. A methyl group cannot receive a number designation at the end of the longest carbon chain; it would be considered part of that chain. Therefore, 1,4-dimethylbutane should be named hexane.

question_html: Which of the following is not considered a structural isomer of C5H12?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Branches of the longest, continuous carbon chain are given the lowest number designations possible. A sketch of 3-methylbutane reveals that it is structurally identical to 2-methylbutane, therefore, the name 2-methylbutane should be used.

question_html: Which of the following is not true for a homologous series of alkanes?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Each member in the homologous series has the same general formula, CnH2n
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The alkane chain consists of CH2 units; however, bonding dictates that each end of the chain must terminate with a hydrogen atom. Therefore, the general formula for the homologous series of alkanes is C2H2n+2.  By contrast, C2H2n could represent a homologous series of alkenes.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The formula of each member in the homologous series differs from the others by the number of CH2 units present
Each member in the homologous series has similar chemical properties
The homologous series shows a gradual change in physical properties

question_html: Which of the following is not a monoprotic acid?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @2 is correct; this option has two hydrogens which can be replaced by a metal, whereas the other options only have one. They only have one hydrogen that can be released as an H+ ion; this acid has two. Be careful of acids such as HCOOH as only the hydrogen that is attached to the oxygen in the -COOH group can be released as H+.

section_title: Brønsted-Lowry theory of acids and bases

question_html: Which of the following equations represents the reaction between zinc powder and dilute sulfuric acid?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @3 is correct; a metal such as zinc reacts to displace the hydrogen from the acid to give a salt – the products are a salt and hydrogen gas. This equation is the only one showing the production of hydrogen gas (H2).

question_html:
Consider the following qualititative data for the reactions of halogens with silver halides in aqueous solution:

2AgX  +  Z2  →  2AgZ  +  X2   

where X and Z are halogens (Cl, Br or I)

Z = Cl Z = Br Z = I
AgCl no reaction no reaction no reaction
AgBr solution turns orange no reaction no reaction
AgI solution turns brown solution turns brown no reaction

Deduce the relative strength of the halogens as oxidising agents.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: According to the data table, Cl2 can oxidise bromide to bromine and iodide to iodine: aqueous bromine gives an orange solution and aqueous iodine give a brown solution.  Br2 can oxidise iodide to iodine.  I2 cannot oxidise any of the halides.  Therefore, chlorine must be the strongest oxidising agent and iodine the weakest.

question_html:
The following balanced redox reaction between acidified dichromate(VI) and ethanol is used to determine if motorists are driving under the influence of alcohol:

16H+ (aq)  +  2Cr2O72– (aq)  +  C2H5OH (l) →  4Cr3+ (aq) +  2CO2 (g) +  11H2O (l)

Identify the oxidising agent and reducing agent.

MCQ_set.answer_html: H+ is the oxidising agent and dichromate(VI) is the reducing agent.
H+ is the oxidising agent and ethanol is the reducing agent.
dichromate(VI) is the oxidising agent and ethanol is the reducing agent.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: chromium(VI) in dichromate is being reduced to chromium(III) ion; therefore, dichromate(VI) is the oxidising agent. Assigning oxidation numbers to organic compounds can be problematic; however, the total oxidation numbers for carbon in ethanol must be +4, whereas the total oxidation numbers for carbon dioxide must be +8: this is oxidation, so ethanol must be the reducing agent.

MCQ_set.answer_html: dichromate(VI) is the reducing agent and ethanol is the oxidising agent.

question_html:
Deduce the balanced redox equation, in aqueous solution, from the two unbalanced half equations below:

½S2O32–  (aq) +  2e–  →  S (s)

½S2O32– (aq) →  SO2 (g) +  2e–

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The convention for balancing oxygen is for including water: it is highly unlikely that oxide ions would exist in aqueous solution. Recall that charge must balance between reactants and products.

question_html:
The thermite reaction, shown below, is used to join railway lines.

2Al (s)  +  Fe2O3 (s)  →  Al2O3 (s) +  2Fe (s)

Which of the following are correct about the reaction?

I. The aluminium undergoes reduction 

II. Iron oxide is the oxidising agent

III. The oxidation state of the aluminium changes from 0 to +3

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: In the reaction the aluminium undergoes oxidation and the iron undergoes reduction. Iron oxide is the oxidising agent and aluminium is the reducing agent. The oxidation state of the aluminium changes from 0 to +3.

question_html:
Consider the following unbalanced redox equation:

S2O32- (aq)  +  H+ (aq)  →  S (s)  +  SO2 (g)

Which sulfur containing species in the products is the result of reduction and which is the result of oxidation?

MCQ_set.answer_html: The sulfur in S(s) is the product of reduction and the sulfur in SO2(g) the product of oxidation.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The oxidation state of the sulfur in thiosulfate, S2O32–, is +2. Note that there are two sulfur atoms in the thiosulfate ion. Consequently, one sulfur gains two electrons and is reduced to elemental sulfur, S, and the other loses two electrons and is oxidised to sulfur(IV), SO2. This is an example of a disproportionation reaction (where the same species is both reduced and oxidised).

MCQ_set.answer_html: The sulfur in S(s) is the product of oxidation and the sulfur in SO2 (g) the product of reduction.
The sulfur cannot be simultaneously oxidised and reduced.

question_html:
Consider the following unbalanced redox equation in acidic solution:

Cr3+ (aq)  +  H2O (l) + ClO3– (aq) → Cr2O72–  (aq) + ClO2 (l)  +  H+ (aq)

Determine the sum of all the stoichiometric coefficients in the balanced redox equation.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Cr3+ (aq)  +  H2O (l) + ClO3- (aq) → Cr2O72– (aq) + ClO2 (l)  +  H+ (aq)

First, balance the number of chromiums

2Cr3+  +  H2O  +  ClO3–  →  Cr2O72–  +  ClO2  +  H+

Chromium is oxidised from +3 to +6 and this happens to both chromium atoms: this is a six electron oxidation. Chlorine is reduced from +5 to +4: this is a one electron reduction; therefore, the chlorine compounds need a coefficient of six to balance the electron transfer.

2Cr3+  +  H2O  +  6ClO3–  →  Cr2O72–  +  6ClO2  +  H+

In order to balance the hydrogen, H+ must have a coefficient of two.

2Cr3+ (aq)  +  H2O (l) + 6ClO3– (aq) → Cr2O72– (aq) + 6ClO2 (l)  +  2H+ (aq)

Inspection reveals that each side of the equation has 2 chromium atoms, 2 hydrogen atoms, 6 chlorine atoms and 19 oxygen atoms. Furthermore, the net charge is the same on both sides: the redox equation is balanced.  A common error for this type of question is to forget the coefficients of one, which are implied for water and dichromate(VI).

question_html: Determine the oxidation state for chlorine in sodium hypochlorite, NaClO, more commonly known as bleach.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Sodium is typically assigned an oxidation state of +1 in its compounds and oxygen is typically assigned -2. The higher electronegativity of oxygen means that it is assigned a negative oxidation state and chlorine a positive oxidation state. 

(+1) + Cl + (-2) = 0

Cl + (-1) = 0

Cl = +1

question_html: Determine the oxidation state of chromium in the compound K2Cr2O7.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Oxygen is usually assigned an oxidation state of -2 in its compounds and potassium is assigned an oxidation state of +1 in its compounds.  

Therefore:

2(+1) + 2(Cr) + 7(-2) = 0

2(Cr) + (-12) = 0

2(Cr) = +12

Cr = +6 

The oxidation state of Cr in K2Cr2O7 is +6.

question_html: In which of the following compounds does bromine have a positive oxidation number?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Based upon the oxidation number rules, fluorine is assigned a -1 oxidation number in its compounds.  For this compound to have no net charge, bromine must have an oxidation number of +3.  You will find that elements often have unusual oxidation numbers when they form compounds with fluorine.

question_html:
Consider the following indicators:

Indicator pKa
methyl orange 3.7
bromothymol blue 7.0
phenol red 7.9
phenolphthalein 9.6

Which indicator would be best suited for a titration between a strong acid and a weak base?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: For a strong acid/weak base titration the equivalence point will occur at pH < 7.  The indicator should be chosen to change colour near the equivalence point. Typically, an indicator will change colours when pH ≈ pKa. Methyl orange is the only indicator with a pKa < 7.

question_html:
25.0 cm3 of 1.00 mol dm-3 CH3COOH is titrated with 1.00 mol dm-3 NaOH until a total of 50.0 cm3 of NaOH is added. 

Deduce the following:

a) the approximate pH of the acid solution. 

b) the approximate pH of the solution at the end of the titration. 

c) the pH at equivalence point.  

The pKa of ethanoic acid is 4.76.  Assume a temperature of 25.0 °C.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
a) CH3COOH is a weak acid; therefore, the initial [H+] is not equal to the concentration of the acid.

b) Once excess sodium hydroxide is added [OH–] ≈ 1 mol dm-3; therefore, pOH = 0 and pH = 14

c) At the equivalence point CH3COONa is the dominant solute; therefore, the pH > 7.

question_html: Which of the following compounds will produce an aqueous solution with a pH < 7?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: NH4Cl is the salt of a weak base and strong acid, so it will produce a solution with a pH <7. KNO3 and NaCl are salts of strong acids and strong bases; they give solutions with a pH ≈ 7. CH3COONa is a basic salt, giving a solution with a pH > 7.

question_html: Which of the following will form a basic buffer solution?

MCQ_set.answer_html: 25 cm3 of 1.0 mol dm-3 NH3 and 25 cm3 of 1.0 mol dm-3 HCl.
50 cm3 of 1.0 mol dm-3 NH3 and 25 cm3 of 1.0 mol dm-3 HCl.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: In order for maximum buffering capacity, the weak base and conjugate acid should be present in equal quantities. By adding twice as much NH3, half of the weak base will be neutralised by the strong acid, HCl, to give the conjugate acid, NH4+, in equal concentration to the remaining weak base.  In every other example, all the weak base is completely converted to conjugate acid by the strong acid.

MCQ_set.answer_html: 25 cm3 of 1.0 mol dm-3 NH3 and 50 cm3 of 1.0 mol dm-3 HCl.
50 cm3 of 1.0 mol dm-3 NH3 and 50 cm3 of 1.0 mol dm-3 HCl.

question_html: Which of the following will form an acidic buffer solution?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: In order for maximum buffering capacity, the weak acid and conjugate base should be present in equal quantities. By adding twice as much CH3COOH, half of the weak acid will be neutralised by the strong base, NaOH, to give the conjugate base, CH3COO-, in equal concentration to the remaining weak acid.  In every other example, all the weak acid is completely converted to conjugate base by the strong base.

question_html: Pure water, at 50 °C, has a pH of 6.63. What is the pOH for pure water at 50 °C?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
[H+] = 10-pH so [H+] = 10-6.63 = 2.34 × 10-7.

In pure water [H+] = [OH-] so [OH-] = 2.34 × 10-7.

pOH = -log [OH-] = -log (2.34 × 10-7) = 6.63

question_html: Which of the following hydrogen ion concentrations, [H+], corresponds to a pH of 8.5?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: [H+] = 10–pH = 10–8.5 = 3.16 × 10–9 mol dm-3

question_html: Which of the following is the weakest acid?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: This Ka value is the lowest of the four. This value reflects that undissociated reactants are far more favoured in the equilibrium than dissociated products. As this is the least dissociated acid, it must also be the weakest acid. The lower the Ka, the weaker the acid.

question_html: Which of the following is the weakest base?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: pKb = -log10Kb, so Kb = 10–9.13. This means that the weak base dissociation equilibrium lies far to the undissociated side, i.e. the reactant side. This base is almost 100,000 times less dissociated than (CH3)3N. A lower pKb value means a stronger base.

question_html: Which of the following is the strongest acid?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: pKa = -log10Ka, so Ka = 10–2.87, which is greater than 10–4.87 for CH3CH2COOH. A lower pKa means greater dissociation into ions, which means a stronger acid.

question_html: Which of the following represents the strongest acid?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The strength of an acid is determined by its extent of dissociation into ions, not its concentration. Although this is the least concentrated acid, it is the only strong acid among the four acids.

question_html: Which of the following Brønsted-Lowry acids has a conjugate base that cannot function further as a Brønsted-Lowry acid?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The conjugate base of HPO42–  is PO43– , which cannot function as an H+ donor, as it has no remaining protons to donate. All other examples give conjugate bases that can donate H+.

question_html: Which of the following is neither a Lewis acid nor a Brønsted-Lowry acid?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Ammonia is not an H+ donor, although it is an H+ acceptor, i.e. a Brønsted-Lowry base, and because it can donate an electron pair to H+, it is a Lewis base.

section_title: Lewis theory of acids and bases

question_html: Which of the following can function as an Brønsted-Lowry acid?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: H2O is the only example with hydrogen atoms. For a compound or element (e.g. H2) to behave as a Brønsted-Lowry acid it must at least possess one hydrogen. Recall that water can behave as both a Brønsted-Lowry acid and base, because it can accept or donate H+.

question_html: Which of the following is not a Lewis acid or Lewis base?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Both ammonia and the chloride ion possess lone pairs of electrons: they can be electron pair donors. BF3 has only six electrons around the central boron; therefore, it can accomodate and additional electron pair from a Lewis base. It is a Lewis acid. CH4 has a full outer electron shell and no lone pairs: it can function as neither a Lewis acid nor a Lewis base.

section_title: Lewis theory of acids and bases

question_html:
Consider the following reaction:

2NO2 (g) ⇌ N2O4 (g)

1.0 mol of nitrogen dioxide is placed in a 1.0 dm3 flask and allowed to reach equilibrium. The equilibrium concentration of dinitrogen tetroxide was found to be 0.40 mol dm-3. Determine the value of the Kc.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
2NO2        N2O4
Initial (mol dm-3) 1.0 0
Change (mol dm-3) –2(0.40) +0.40
Equilibrium (mol dm-3) 1.0 – 0.80 = 0.20 0.40

\(K_c=\dfrac {[N_2O_4]}{[NO_2]^2}=\dfrac {[0.40]}{[0.20]^2}=\dfrac {[0.40]}{[0.04]}=10\)

question_html: Which of the following changes made to the reaction at equilibrium will not result in a shift in the equilibrium position to the products side?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
There are an equal number of gaseous molecules in the reactants and products, therefore, an increase in pressure has no effect on the position of equilibrium and no change in the amounts of reactants and products. 

For this reaction:

N2 (g) + 3H2 (g) ⇌ 2NH3 (g)  

an increase in pressure will shift the position of equilibrium to the right.

For this reaction:

 2SO2 (g) + O2 (g) ⇌ 2SO3 (g)     ΔH = < 0 (negative)

a decrease in temperature will shift the position of equilibrium to the right.

For this reaction:

CO2 (g) + H2 (g) ⇌ CO (g) + H2O (g)     ΔH = > 0 (positive) 

an increase in temperature will shift the position of equilibrium to the right.

MCQ_set.answer_html:
CO2 (g) + H2 (g) ⇌ CO (g) + H2O (g)     ΔH = > 0 (positive) 

an increase in temperature

question_html:
Consider the following reversible reaction:

A + B ⇌ C + D       Kc > 1

Which of the following statements is false?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Addition of A and B will result in more successful collisions leading to products
Addition of A and B will result in a greater forward rate of reaction than the reverse rate of reaction
Addition of A and B will shift the position of equilibrium to the right
Addition of A and B will produce more C and D until the concentrations of reactants equal the concentration of products
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: If equilibrium is to be restored, and Kc > 1, then the concentrations of products must exceed reactants. Furthermore, equilibrium refers to equal rates, rather than equal concentrations. If the concentrations of products and reactants happen to be equal it is pure coincidence.

question_html:
Consider the following hypothetical, reversible reaction

A + 2B ⇌ C

0.25 mol A is mixed with 0.50 mol B and allowed to react. Once all visible change ceases, the reactants are barely detectable through analysis. Which of the following conclusions can be drawn regarding the value of the Kc for this reaction?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: When products (the numerator) are present in much larger quantities than reactants (the denominator), the value of the Kc must be much greater than one (Kc >> 1). Kc>1 means that the equilibrium position lies to the right and the reaction mixture will be mostly products, although some reactants will remain. Kc>>1 refers to a very large value for the equilibrium constant which means that the reaction goes to completion and the reaction mixture will contain almost all products, with little to no reactants.

question_html:
Consider the following equilibrium reaction:

2FeCl3 (aq) + SnCl2 (aq) ⇌ 2FeCl2 (aq) + SnCl4 (aq)

Which is the correct equilibrium constant expression for this reaction?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: In the equilibrium constant expression, each of the reactant and product concentrations are raised to the exponent corresponding to the coefficients from the balanced reaction equation. Product concentrations are always on the top and reactant concentrations are always on the bottom of the expression.

question_html: Which of the following is not necessarily true once dynamic equilibrium is achieved?

MCQ_set.answer_html: The concentration of reactants and products are equal
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: This answer is a common misconception regarding dynamic equilibrium. If the reactant and product concentrations are equal at dynamic equilibrium it is pure coincidental. At dynamic equilibrium, the concentration of products and reactants are constant; therefore, a plot of concentration versus time will give a horizontal line, which has a slope/gradient of zero.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The rate of the forward reaction is equal to the rate of the reverse reaction
The rate of change of the reactant concentrations is zero
The rate of change of the product concentrations is zero

question_html:
Consider the Arrhenius equation below:

\[k = Ae^{-\frac{E_a}{RT}}\]

The slope of a plot of ln k vs 1/T can be modeled by a straight line. The numerical value of the slope (the gradient) will give the value of which of the following?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Table 1 of the data booklet provides you with both the exponential and logarithmic forms of the Arrhenius equation.  This fact is often overlooked by students: the data booklet is a rich source of information for the IB chemistry papers 2 and 3 and you need to be familiar with it. The slope of an Arrhenius plot will be negative.

question_html: Which of the following statements regarding the mechanism of a reaction and its rate expression is false for a multi-step reaction?

MCQ_set.answer_html: A reaction mechanism is written as a series of elementary reactions, involving one or two reactants
The slowest elementary reaction determines the overall rate of reaction
All the reactants in the overall reaction equation appear in the rate expression
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The overall reaction equation represents the sum of all elementary reactions that occur. Only the slowest of these will appear in the rate expression. Note that although it is possible to have three reactant species in an elementary step, it is rare.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The slowest elementary reaction is called the rate-determining step

question_html: Which of the following shows the correct units for the rate constant of a second order (overall) reaction?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
The units of the rate constant render the units on both sides of the rate equation identical. For a second order rate equation:

rate = k[A]2  or

mol dm–3 s–1 = k (mol dm-3)2 = k mol2 dm–6

Therefore, k must have units of mol–1 dm3 s–1

mol dm–3 s–1 = (mol–1 dm3 s–1)(mol2 dm–6 ) = (mol–1 mol2)(dm-6 dm3)s–1

question_html: Which of the following cannot be determined from experimental kinetic data?

MCQ_set.answer_html: The order of reaction with respect to each reactant

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The "chicken and egg" paradox best explains this answer.  The rate equation, the order of reaction with respect to each reactant and the rate constant are all determined from experimental data.  The mechanism is a "best guess" that best fits the experimental data; therefore, the experimental data comes first and the mechanism is based upon it.  From a Theory of Knowledge perspective, a mechanism can never be proven correct by experimental data, only proven incorrect.

question_html:
The equation for the decomposition reaction of N2O5 is shown below:

2N2O5 (g) → 4NO2 (g) + O2 (g)

The rate equation is first-order overall. Which of the following rate equations is consistent with this reaction?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Recall that the rate equation is not derived from overall reaction equation. The overall reaction order is the sum of all the exponents in the rate equation; therefore, only this equation is consistent with first order overall.  Rate equations are determine from experimental data, not overall reaction equations.

question_html: Consider a reaction mixture consisting of 1 mol of gaseous iodine and 1 mol of hydrogen at 200 °C. The experiment is then repeated at 300 °C. Which of the following statements is consistent with comparisons between the Maxwell-Boltzmann distributions for this reaction mixture at these two temperatures?

MCQ_set.answer_html: The area under the curve is greater for the reaction at 300 °C
The area under the curve is smaller for the reaction at 200 °C
The peak of the curve flattens and the curve extends towards higher energies for the reaction at 300 °C
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Because the area under the curve represents the number of particles and because 2 mol of gas are used in each case, the area under the curve cannot change.  Maxwell-Boltzmann distributions are such that the peak of the curve becomes sharper and the curve retreats towards lower energies, as fewer particles have higher kinetic energies at lower temperatures. Therefore, the opposite is true as the temperature is raised, the peak of the curve flattens and the curve extends towards higher energies for the reaction at 300 °C.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The peak of the curve becomes sharper and the curve retreats towards lower energies for the reaction at 300 °C.

section_title: Collision theory and rates of reaction

question_html: Which of the following changes will not lead to an increase in the rate of reaction of a gas phase reaction occurring in a high pressure reaction vessel?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Decreasing the volume of the reaction vessel
Injecting more reactants into the existing reaction vessel
Increasing the volume of the reaction vessel
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
The following lead to an increase in the rate of reaction:

  • decreasing the volume of the reaction vessel will increase the pressure inside the vessel by increasing the rate of collisions between the gas particles and the sides of the vessel and, consequently, between the gas particles themselves
  • injecting more reactants into the existing reaction vessel will increase the concentration of the reactants
  • heating the reaction vessel - albeit highly dangerous - will speed up the reaction by increasing the average kinetic energy of the gas particles

Increasing the volume of the reaction vessel will decrease the pressure inside the vessel by decreasing the rate of collisions between the gas particles and the sides of the vessel and, consequently, between the gas particles themselves. This results in a slower rate of reaction.

section_title: Collision theory and rates of reaction

question_html: A single, large piece of calcium carbonate is reacted with excess 1.0 mol dm-3 hydrochloric acid and the rate of carbon dioxide production is monitored. The experiment is repeated with the same mass of calcium carbonate, but crushed into smaller pieces. Which of the following is incorrect with regards to the predicted results of the second reaction?

MCQ_set.answer_html: A larger surface of contact between the calcium carbonate and hydrochloric acid
An increase in the rate of carbon dioxide production
An increase in the frequency of successful collisions between the calcium carbonate and hydrochloric acid
A decrease in the rate of carbon dioxide production
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: If the calcium carbonate is crushed to produce smaller particles, this will create a larger surface of contact and an increase in the number of successful collisions (per unit time), which leads to an increase in the rate of carbon dioxide production, not a decrease.

section_title: Collision theory and rates of reaction

question_html: Which of the following is not a required condition for particles to react?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Particles must collide in the correct orientation, so that the reactive parts of each of the two particles make contact
Particles must collide with kinetic energy greater than or equal to the activation energy (E ≥ Ea) in order to react
Particles must collide with kinetic energy less than the activation energy (E < Ea) in order to react
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: If the energy of the collision is less that the activation energy, insufficient energy will be exchanged to break existing chemical bonds to form new chemical bonds.  Consider the cyclist trying to pass over a hill, as described in this section.

section_title: Collision theory and rates of reaction

question_html: A reaction involving a solid reactant in aqueous solution occurs in time t. Which of the following will not increase the rate of reaction when the same mass of solid is used?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Increasing the particle size will reduce the surface area per unit volume available and lead to fewer collisions per unit time and decrease the rate of reaction.

section_title: Factors that affect rates of reaction

question_html: The rate of a chemical reaction can be expressed as \(\dfrac{\Delta[R]}{\Delta t}\), where R is a reactant.  Which are the correct units for this expression?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: \(\dfrac{\Delta[R]}{\Delta t}\)=\(\dfrac{concentration}{time}\)=\(\dfrac{mol  dm^{-3}}{s}\)= \( {mol  dm^{-3}} s^{-1}\)

question_html: Which of the processes listed below is responsible for the colour of a transition metal complex?

MCQ_set.answer_html: The absorption of light when electrons transition between s orbitals and d orbitals.
The absorption of light when electrons transition between two sets of non-degenerate d orbitals.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @2 is correct; the colour of the complex ion is the complementary colour to the light which is absorbed by electrons as they transition between non-degenerate d orbitals.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The emission of light when electrons transition between s orbitals and d orbitals.
The emission of light when electrons transition between two sets of non-degenerate d orbitals.

question_html:
Consider the following reaction: N2 (g) + 3H2 (g) ⇌ 2NH3 (g)

Bond enthalpies (in kJ mol−1) involved in the reaction are represented by the following letters:

Bond  Letter
N≡N a
H−H b
N−H c

Which expression could be used to calculate the enthalpy change of reaction?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct; ΔH = Σ (bonds broken) – Σ (bonds made) = (N≡N + 3 H−H) − (6 × N−H).

question_html:
Consider the following bond enthalpies:

Bond  Bond enthalpy (kJ mol−1)
C=C 615
C−F 484
C−C 348
F−F 158

Which one of the following gives the enthalpy change (in kJ mol−1) for the addition reaction between fluorine and ethene (in the gaseous state)?

C2H4 (g) + F2 (g) → CH2FCH2F (g)

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
@3 is correct; ΔH = Σ (bonds broken) – Σ (bonds made) = [(615 + 158)] − [(1 × 348) + (2 × 484)]

Note that as there are four C-H bonds in both the reactants and products (4 × 414 = 1656 kJ); the values cancel out and are not included in the overall calculation.

question_html: The bond energy for the H−F bond is equal to the enthalpy change for which of the following processes?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @2 is correct; the H−F bond enthalpy is the amount of energy (in kJ) required to break one mole of a hydrogen fluoride covalent bond into gaseous hydrogen and fluorine atoms (under standard thermodynamic conditions).

question_html:
The bond energies for H2, I2 and HI are 432, 149 and 295 kJ mol−1 respectively. From this data, what is the enthalpy change (in kJ) for the following reaction?

H2 (g) + I2 (g) → 2HI (g)

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @4 is correct; ΔH = Σ (bonds broken) – Σ (bonds made) = [(432 + 149)] – [(295 × 2)] = −9 kJ

question_html: Which one of the following statements about bonding is correct?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Bond breaking is exothermic and bond making is endothermic
Bond breaking is endothermic and bond making is exothermic
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @3 is correct; to break a bond requires energy and when a bond is made, energy is released. Therefore, bond breaking is endothermic and bond making is exothermic.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Breaking bonds releases energy and making bonds absorbs energy

question_html: Which of the following processes is endothermic?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @2 is correct; bond breaking is always endothermic. Condensation is exothermic, as are neutralisation and combustion reactions.

question_html:
The following equation shows the formation of calcium oxide from calcium metal.

                                      2Ca(s) + O2(g) → 2CaO(s) ∆Ho = −1270 kJ

Which of the following statements is true?

MCQ_set.answer_html: 1270 kJ of energy are released for every mol of calcium reacted.
635 kJ of energy are absorbed for every mol of calcium oxide formed.
635 kJ of energy are released for every mol of oxygen gas reacted.
1270 kJ of energy are released for every 2 mol of calcium oxide formed.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @4 is correct; the value quoted is for the reaction presented, and for the formation of the compound from its element.

question_html:
The specific heat capacities of some metals (in J g−1 K−1) are given below.

Copper: 0.385
Magnesium: 1.020
Mercury: 0.138
Platinum: 0.130

If 100 kJ of heat is added to 10.0 g samples of each of the metals above, all at 25°C, determine which metal will have the smallest increase in temperature.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @3 is correct; q = mcΔT, therefore, q / mc = ΔT, hence if c is increased then ΔT will decrease. A higher heat capacity means more heat energy is required to raise the temperature of that metal. Magnesium has the highest specific heat capacity, therefore, it will have the smallest increase in temperature.

question_html:
A 1.00 g sample of octane (C8H18) is burned in a calorimeter containing 500.0 cm3 of water at an initial temperature of 20.0 oC. The maximum temperature of the water is 40.0 oC. Determine the enthalpy change (in kJ mol-1) for the reaction.

The heat capacity of water is 4.18 J g-1 oC−1. 

M (C8H18) = 114.23 g mol-1

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
@4 

Using q=mcΔT

q = 500.0 × 4.18 × (40.0 – 20.0)

q = 41800 J of heat released 

Divide by the amount (in mol) of octane:

ΔH = –41800 / (1.00 / 114.23)

ΔH = –4.77 × 106 J mol-1 

Convert to kJ by dividing by 1000: 

ΔH = –4.77 × 103 kJ mol-1 

Note the negative sign as the reaction is exothermic.

question_html:
Which of the following would result in the experimental value being different to the theoretical value in an experiment to measure the enthalpy change of combustion of methanol?

I. Incomplete combustion of the methanol

II. Heat loss to the surroundings 

III. Forgetting to zero the mass balance when recording the initial mass of the spirit burner

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @4 is correct; Incomplete combustion due to lack of oxygen and heat loss to the surroundings would result in the experimental value being lower than the theoretical value. Forgetting to zero the mass balance is a systematic error and will also result in the experimental value being different to the theoretical value.

question_html: Calculate the specific heat capacity of an alcohol (in J g−1 K−1) if 560.0 J of heat are required to raise the temperature of a 64.0 g sample of ethanol from 295.0 K to 310.0 K?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
@1 is correct; q = mcΔT, so c = q/mΔT  

c = 560 J / (64.0 g × 15.0 K) 

c = 0.583 J g−1 K−1.

question_html:
The diagram below shows the enthalpy level diagram for a reaction. What can be deduced about the relative stability of the reactants and products, and the sign of ∆H, from the diagram?

relative stability sign of ∆H
i. products more stable negative
ii. reactants more stable positive
iii. reactants more stable negative
iv. products more stable positive

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct; the vertical axis represents potential energy, energy or enthalpy. The reactants are high in energy and hence unstable; the products are lower in energy and hence more stable. The difference is released in the form of heat energy.

question_html:
Which of the following processes is/are endothermic?

I. H2O (s) → H2O (l)
II. CO2 (g) → CO2 (s)
III. Br2 (l) → Br2 (g)

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
@4 is correct; the melting (s) → (l) of ice is endothermic as energy needs to be supplied to overcome the hydrogen bonds between the water molecules holding the solid together.

Deposition (g) → (s) is exothermic – energy is released as the CO2 molecules change from the gaseous phase to the solid phase. 

Evaporation (l) → (g) is endothermic as energy is required to overcome the intermolecular forces between the bromine molecules.

question_html: Which of the following is correct for the dissolving of a salt in water in an insulated copper calorimeter (ΔH = positive)?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Heat is released to the surroundings and the temperature of the water decreases
Heat is released to the surroundings and the temperature of the water increases
Heat is absorbed from the surroundings and the temperature of the water increases
Heat is absorbed from the surroundings and the temperature of the water decreases
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @4 is correct; a positive enthalpy change means that heat flows from the surroundings to the system (endothermic). The surroundings is the water in the calorimeter and the heat absorbed by the system would make the temperature of the water decrease.

question_html: Which of the compounds H2O, H2S, H2Se and HCl has the highest boiling point?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct; water is hydrogen bonded. Hydrogen bonds are significantly stronger than the dispersion forces of attraction present in H2Se and H2S, and the dipole–dipole forces of attraction present in HCl.

question_html: The molar masses of C2H6, CH3OH and CH3F are similar. How do their boiling points compare when placed in order of increasing value?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @4 is correct; Ethane, C2H6, has the lowest boiling point owing to the presence of dispersion forces of attraction – the weakest of the three intermolecular forces. Fluoromethane, CH3F, has an intermediate boiling point owing to the presence of dipole–dipole forces. Methanol, CH3OH, has the highest boiling point owing to the presence of hydrogen bonding – the strongest of the three intermolecular forces.

question_html:
Three compounds X, Y, Z, have approximately the same molar mass.

X = C5H12
Y = CH3CH2CH2CH2OH
Z = CH3OCH2CH2CH3

When these compounds are arranged in order of increasing boiling point (with the lowest boiling point first), the correct order is:

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct; pentane, C5H12, will have the lowest boiling point. It is a non-polar substance and its molecules are associated in the liquid state via dispersion forces – the weakest of the three intermolecular forces. CH3OCH2CH2CH3 is associated in the liquid state via dipole–dipole forces. Propan-1-ol has the highest boiling point since it is capable of hydrogen bonding owing to the presence of a hydroxyl group, −OH.

question_html: Chlorine is found to have a lower boiling point than bromine. Differences in which of the following properties are responsible for this observation?

MCQ_set.answer_html: The difference in ionisation energies of bromine and chlorine
The average bond enthalpies between the atoms in the molecules
The number of electrons in the atoms
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @4 is correct; chlorine has the lower boiling point because it has the lower molar mass. A lower molecular mass means there are fewer electrons in the atom and it is more polarisable. Hence, the London dispersion forces of attraction between the molecules are weaker.

question_html: Which intermolecular forces exist between the CO2 molecules in dry ice, CO2 (s)?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct; carbon dioxide is a non-polar molecule due to its linear molecular geometry, so it does not possess a permanent dipole. Covalent bonds exist between the atoms in the molecule, however, these are not intermolecular forces, and a lack of O-H or N-H bonds means no hydrogen bonding will take place. This leaves us with London dispersion forces, which exist between all molecules regardless of polarity.

question_html: Which one of the following molecules has a trigonal pyramidal molecular geometry? Hint - draw out the Lewis structures to help you.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @2 is correct; the nitrogen atom in nitrogen trichloride is surrounded by three bonding pairs and one lone pair of electrons (see below). The molecular geometry is trigonal pyramidal.

question_html: Which one of the following molecules has a linear molecular geometry?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @4 is correct; carbon dioxide is a linear molecule. The central carbon atom is surrounded by two regions of high electron density (two double bonds).

question_html: The bond angle between the two carbon–fluorine bonds in CH3CH=CF2 is closest to which of the following? Hint - draw out the Lewis structure to help you.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @2 is correct; the molecule has a carbon–carbon double bond. This means that there will be three bonding domains around both the "CH' carbon and the "CF2" carbon. Therefore, the molecule must be trigonal planar and will have bond angles of 120° between the two C-F bonds.

question_html: Which of the following molecules has a trigonal planar molecular geometry?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @2 is correct; BH3 has three bonding domains around the boron atom with a trigonal planar arrangement and bond angles of 120o.

question_html: When the Lewis structure for HCOOCH3 (methyl methanoate) is drawn, how many bonding domains and how many non-bonding domains (lone pairs of electrons) are present?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct; each oxygen atom has two lone pairs (non-bonding domains), making a total of 4 lone pairs. There are seven bonding domains in the molecule: 4 × C−H; 2 × C−O, 1 × C=O. Remember than a C=O double bond counts as only one bonding domain. The Lewis structure of HCOOCH3 is show below.

question_html: Determine the formula of the ionic compound formed between strontium and nitrogen.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @4 is correct; strontium forms Sr2+ ions and nitrogen forms N3− ions. In every one formula unit of strontium nitride, there are 3 Sr2+ ions and two N3- ions. Therefore, the formula of strontium nitride is Sr3N2.

question_html: Which one of the following elements has the same group number and period number?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Beryllium is in group 2 and period 2, which corresponds to the electron configuration 1s2 2s2. It has two outer (valence) electrons in its second main energy level and two occupied main energy levels, therefore, it is in group 2 and period 2.

question_html: Identify which one of the following elements is located in period 2 and group 13 of the periodic table.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Boron has the electron configuration 1s2 2s2 2p1. It is in the second period as it has two occupied main energy levels and group 13 as it has 3 electrons in its outer (valence) shell.

question_html: Which is the best description of metallic bonding?

MCQ_set.answer_html: The electrostatic attraction between positive and negative ions
The electrostatic attraction between protons and electrons
The electrostatic attraction between a lattice of positive metal ions and delocalised electrons
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @3 is correct; @4 is a description of covalent bonding; @1 is a description of ionic bonding.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The electrostatic attraction between positive nuclei and shared electron pairs

question_html: In which of the following pairs does the second substance have the lower boiling point of the two?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @2 is correct; H2S has a higher molecular mass than H2O and hence more extensive dispersion forces. However, water is hydrogen bonded. Hydrogen bonds are significantly stronger than dispersion forces (for molecules of similar molecular mass). This more than outweighs the increase in dispersion forces from H2O to H2S.

question_html: Which of the following types of bond/force is not present in pure CH3CH2OCH2CH3 in the liquid state?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @4 is correct; all of the hydrogen atoms are attached to carbon atoms and are unable to engage in hydrogen bonding.

question_html: Which of the following compounds is the most soluble in water?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @2 is correct; ethane and propane are hydrocarbons and are unable to form hydrogen bonds with water. Propan-1-ol and hexan-1-ol are both alcohols and contain a hydroxyl group, −OH, capable of forming hydrogen bonds with water molecules. However, propan-1-ol is the more soluble since its hydrocarbon chain is smaller: three carbon atoms compared with six in hexan-1-ol. The longer hydrocarbon chain increases the hydrophobic ('water-hating') properties of the molecule, which decreases its solubility.

question_html:
In which of the following substances would hydrogen bonding be expected to occur?

I. C2H6
II. CH3CH2COOH
III. CH3OCH3

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct; hydrogen bonding would only be expected to occur in CH2CH3COOH since it contains a hydrogen bonded directly to oxygen. The −OH group is able to engage in hydrogen bonding. In the other two compounds the hydrogen is bonded to carbon atoms.

question_html: The following compounds all have a tetrahedral electron domain arrangement, but when CH4, NH3, H2O are arranged in order of decreasing bond angle, what is the correct order?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct; all three molecules are based upon a tetrahedral arrangement of four electron domains. However, lone pairs repel bonding pairs more than bonding pairs repel bonding pairs. The oxygen in H2O is surrounded by two lone pairs (maximum repulsion), the nitrogen atom in ammonia contains one lone pair, but the carbon in methane has no lone pairs (least repulsion). The bond angles are 109.5o (CH4), 107.8o (NH3) and 104.5o (H2O) (in decreasing order).

question_html: Which of the following molecules is the most polar?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @2 is correct; fluorine is non-polar as the two fluorine atoms have equal electronegativity values. Tetrafluoromethane is tetrahedral and even though it has 4 polar bonds, the bond polarities cancel out and the molecule is non-polar. Hydrogen iodide and hydrogen fluoride are both polar molecules owing to the presence of a polar bond and linear geometry. However, fluorine is the most electronegative element and the H-F bond is the most polar.

question_html: Which of the following molecules contains a multiple bond?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @3 is correct; tetrafluoroethene, C2F4, contains a carbon–carbon double bond.

section_title: Formation of single and multiple bonds

question_html:
In which of the following molecules are there one or more double covalent bond?

I O2
II CO2
III C2F4

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @4 is correct; The oxygen molecule (O=O) contains one double bond; the carbon dioxide molecule (O=C=O) contains two double bond and the tetrafluoroethene molecule contains one double bond.

section_title: Formation of single and multiple bonds

question_html: A group 1 element, X, bonds with a group 17 element, Y. Deduce the most likely formula and type of bonding in this compound.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @2 is correct; X, a group one element, will form a 1+ ion, X+, and Y, a group 17 element, will form a 1- ion, Y−. One formula unit will contain one X+ ion and one Y- ion, therefore, the formula is XY. The type of bonding is ionic as X is a metal and Y is a non-metal.

question_html: Determine which of the following compounds contains ionic bonds.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct; Magnesium is a metal; chlorine is a non-metal. Typically, a metal and a non-metal react to form an ionic compound

question_html: Barium is an element in group 2 of the periodic table. Which of the following statements about barium is incorrect?

MCQ_set.answer_html: It has a lower first ionisation energy than magnesium
It has two electrons in its valence shell
It has a smaller atomic radius than strontium
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @3 is correct; the atomic radius of barium is larger than that of strontium as it has an additional occupied main energy level which gives it a larger atomic radius, not smaller.

MCQ_set.answer_html: It has six occupied main energy levels

question_html: Which of the following occurs when chlorine water, Cl2 (aq), is added to an aqueous solution of potassium iodide, KI (aq)?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Chloride ions are displaced to produce chlorine gas
No reaction occurs because chlorine and iodine are equally reactive
No reaction occurs because chlorine is less reactive than iodine
Iodide ions are displaced to produce aqueous iodine molecules
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @4 is correct; chlorine displaces the iodide ions from solution according to the following equation: Cl2 (aq) + 2I− (aq) → 2Cl− (aq) + I2 (aq). Chlorine is more reactive than iodine (it is a more powerful oxidising agent than iodine), therefore, it can displace iodide ions in solution.

question_html:
Identify which of the following three statements regarding the periodic table is/are true:

I. The horizontal rows are called periods and the vertical columns are called groups
II. Electronegativity decreases down a group and across a period from left to right
III. Reactivity decreases down group 1 and group 17

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @4 is correct; electronegativity increases across a period from left to right. Reactivity decreases down group 17 (the halogens) only - it increases down group 1.

question_html: Determine which will produce an acidic solution when equal amounts of the following period 3 oxides are added to equal volumes of water.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
@4 is correct; when added to water, SO3 (sulfur trioxide) dissolves to form an acidic solution of sulfuric acid (H2SO4) according to the following equation:

SO3 (g) + H2O (l) → H2SO4 (aq) 

Aluminium oxide (Al2O3) is amphoteric - it can act as both an acid and a base, although it does not react with water. 

Both sodium oxide (Na2O) and magnesium oxide (MgO) react with water to produce basic solutions.

question_html:
Identify which of the following properties are typical of the non-metal elements in period 3 of the periodic table. 

I. They are poor conductors of both heat and electricity
II. They form negative ions by gaining one or more electrons
III. They have high melting points and boiling points

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct; most non-metals have low melting and boiling points because they are simple molecular substances, so III is incorrect. The other two statements are generally correct; non-metal elements are poor conductors of heat and electricity and form negative ions by gaining electrons to achieve a full outer shell.

question_html: Identify which of the following elements has the lowest first ionisation energy.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: First ionisation energies decrease down a group and increase across a period.

section_title: Effective nuclear charge and ionisation energy

question_html: Deduce which of the following series represents the correct size order (from smallest to largest atomic/ionic radius) for the various iodine species I, I− and I+.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @2 is correct; the removal of an electron from an iodine atom to form I+ results in an increase in the attraction between the nucleus and the valence electrons and the radius decreases. The addition of an electron to form I− increases the electron–electron repulsions and decreases the attraction between the nucleus and the valence electrons and the radius increases. Iodine (I) has equal number of protons and electrons.

question_html: Identify the general trend in first ionisation energies across the Periodic Table from left to right.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Ionisation energy remains constant across a period

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @2 is correct; Nuclear charge increases across a period and atomic radius decreases. These two factors mean that the amount of energy required to remove an electron (the ionisation energy) increases across a period. The are exceptions to this trend, however, but the general trend is that it increases.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Ionisation energy increases to a maximum and then decreases across a period

question_html: Determine which of the following trends will be observed down the same group in the Periodic Table.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct; each element of the same group has one more occupied energy level than the element above it which results in an increase in the atomic radius. The other statements are all the opposite of what actually occurs.

question_html: Deduce which property increases with increasing atomic number (down a group) for both the alkali metals and the halogens.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @4 is correct; atomic radii increases down any group due to the presence of additional occupied energy levels.

question_html: Identify which atom has the smallest atomic radius.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @3 is correct; atomic radii decrease across a period. Each subsequent electron enters the same main energy level, therefore, electron shielding remains more or less constant across a period but the nuclear charge increases. This results in a decrease in atomic radii across a period (from left to right).

question_html: Identify which is correct about the atomic radii of elements in the periodic table. Atomic radii decrease:

MCQ_set.answer_html: down a group from lower to higher atomic number
across a period from lower to higher atomic number
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @2 is correct; atomic radii decrease across a period due to the increase in nuclear charge. Each subsequent electron enters the same main energy level, therefore, the electron shielding remains more or less constant but the nuclear charge increases. This results in a decrease in atomic radii across a period (from left to right).

MCQ_set.answer_html: with an increase in the relative atomic mass of an element
with an increase in the electron shielding

question_html: In the periodic table, vertical groups of elements show similarities in their chemical properties. This can be best explained by the:

MCQ_set.answer_html: differences in the number of protons in the nucleus of the atoms
similarities in the results of emission spectrum analysis of gaseous samples of a group
similarities in the electronic structures of the atoms
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @3 is correct; each member of a group has the same number of valence electrons and hence form ions with the same charge or the same number of covalent bonds.

MCQ_set.answer_html: differences in the number of neutrons in the nucleus of the atoms

section_title: Atomic structure and the Periodic Table

question_html: Identify which of the following is a correct statement about the element with atomic number 20.

MCQ_set.answer_html: It is located in group 14 of the periodic table
It is located in group 2 of the periodic table
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @2 is correct; element 20 is calcium and is located in group 2 of the periodic table. It has the electron configuration 1s2 2s2 2p6 3s2 3p6 4s2.

MCQ_set.answer_html: It is located in group 17 of the periodic table

section_title: The structure of the periodic table

question_html: Which of the following, that can be found on the periodic table, gives the number of protons in the nucleus of an atom?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The atomic number (or proton number) of an element tells us the number of protons in the nucleus of an atom. It can be found on the periodic table in section 6 of the IB data booklet.

section_title: The structure of the periodic table

question_html: Identify the element that shows similar chemical behaviour to that of calcium.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @2 is correct; strontium and calcium are both in group 2 of the periodic table, therefore, they both show similar chemical behaviour.

section_title: The structure of the periodic table

question_html: Which of the following species possesses two unpaired electrons?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @3 is correct; @1 and @2 have no unpaired electrons, while Fe2+ has four unpaired electrons.

question_html: Deduce the electron configuration of the iron(III) ion, Fe3+.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @2 is correct; when elements in the first row of transition metals ionise, it is the 4s electrons that are lost first, so all the other alternatives are incorrect.

question_html: Which of the following statements is correct concerning atomic orbitals and energy levels in the electron configurations of the known elements?

MCQ_set.answer_html: The maximum number of electrons in a single d orbital is 10
The maximum number of electrons in the 4th main energy level is 18
Yttrium, Y, (Z = 39) is the first element in the Periodic Table with an electron in an f orbital
Within main energy levels 4 and 5, the sub-level with the highest energy is labelled f
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @4 is correct; in a main energy level the sub-levels increase in energy in the order s < p < d < f. All the other statements are incorrect.
