question_html: Spectra have been used to study the arrangements of electrons in atoms. An emission spectrum consists of a series of bright lines on a black background that converge at high frequencies. Such emission spectra provide evidence that electrons are moving from

MCQ_set.answer_html: lower to higher energy levels with the lower energy levels being closer together.
lower to higher energy levels with the higher energy levels being closer together.
higher to lower energy levels with the lower energy levels being closer together.
higher to lower energy levels with the higher energy levels being closer together.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @4 is correct; emission lines are produced when electrons fall back to lower energy levels. The energy levels in an atom converge at higher energies.

question_html: Which of the following statements is correct concerning the emission spectrum of the hydrogen atom?

MCQ_set.answer_html: The lines are produced when electrons move from lower to higher energy levels.
The lines in the visible region involve electron transitions into the energy level closest to the nucleus.
The line corresponding to the greatest emission of energy is in the ultraviolet region.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @4 is correct; the lines converge at high energies; lines are produced when electrons move from higher to lower energies.

question_html: Determine what information about the structure of a helium atom can be gained from its emission spectrum.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Most of the mass of the atom is in its nucleus
A helium atom contains two electrons and two protons
The electrons in the helium atom are located close to the nucleus

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @4 is correct; Emission spectra provide evidence that electrons exist in main energy levels within an atom and can only move between these.

question_html: Deduce which of the following is an incorrect statement about the hydrogen emission spectrum.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The frequency of each line depends on the difference in energy between the higher and lower energy levels
The spectrum consists of several series of lines
Electron transitions to the n = 2 energy level give rise to lines in the visible region
Electron transitions to the n = 3 energy level give rise to lines in the UV region.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @4 is the correct answer (meaning that it is an incorrect statement); Electron transitions to the level n = 3 give rise to lines in the IR region, not the UV region

question_html: A particular element consists of two isotopes: 72% of mass number 85 and 28% of mass number 87. What is the expected range of the relative atomic mass?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @3 is correct; Relative atomic mass is a weighted average. The more abundant isotope has a mass number of 85.

question_html: Naturally occurring chlorine consists of the isotopes chlorine-35 and chlorine-37. The relative atomic mass of chlorine is 35.50. Which one of the following statements is true?

MCQ_set.answer_html: The chlorine-35 and chlorine-37 atoms are present in equal amounts.
The ratio of chlorine-37 atoms to chlorine-35 atoms is 2:1.
The ratio of chlorine-37 to chlorine-35 atoms is 37/35.
There are three times as many as chlorine-35 atoms as chlorine-37 atoms.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @4 is correct; A cannot be correct or the atomic mass would be 36.00, there must be more chlorine-35 atoms than chlorine-37 to give the observed value.

question_html: Identify which of the following statements about the isotopes of an element is correct.

MCQ_set.answer_html: They have the same numbers of protons and neutrons in the nucleus.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @4 is correct: Isotopes are two or more atoms of the same element with different numbers of neutrons (and therefore different relative isotopic masses). They have the same numbers of protons and hence the same number of electrons.

question_html:
Identify which of the following statements is/are correct. Isotopes of uranium have the same:

I. number of protons
II. number of neutrons
III. mass number

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct; isotopes have the same number of protons but different numbers of neutrons, therefore they have different mass numbers.

question_html:
The atomic numbers and mass numbers for four different atoms are given in the table below. Identify which of these atoms are isotopes of each other.

Atomic number, Z Mass number, A
I 101 258
II 102 258
III 102 260
IV 103 259

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @3 is correct; isotopes of the same element have the same atomic number but different mass numbers (same number of protons but different number of neutrons).

question_html: Identify which one of the following atoms will have the same number of neutrons as an atom of 8838Sr.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @3 is correct; there are 50 neutrons in 8838Sr and 8737Rb

question_html: How many valence electrons (electrons in the outermost shell) are present in the element with the atomic number 14?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct; the element with atomic number 14 is silicon. It has the electron configuration 1s2 2s2 2p6 3s2 3p2. The valence electrons are those in the 3s and 3p sub-levels, giving a total of 4 (two in the 3s sub-level and two in the 3p sub-level).

question_html: The Bohr model of the atom accounts for the existence of which one of the following:

MCQ_set.answer_html: The ratios by mass of elements in compounds

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @3 is correct; According to the Bohr model of the atom, electrons can only exist in certain   energy levels with specific energies. The series of lines on the hydrogen emission spectrum correspond to the electron transitions from higher to lower energy levels. The electron transitions in the visible spectrum give rise to the four coloured lines seen on the hydrogen emission spectrum.

question_html:
Deduce the correct number of each of the following particles in the fluoride ion, 19F–.

protons neutrons electrons
i. 9 10 8
ii 9 10 9
iii. 9 10 10
iv. 9 19 10

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @3 is correct; The fluorine atom has 9 protons (atomic number 9) and 9 electrons. The fluoride ion has one extra electron, giving a total of 10 electrons. The number of neutrons is 10 (19 − 9).

question_html: An atom of an element has the abbreviated electron configuration [Ne] 3s2. Deduce the name of the element.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @2 is correct; This atom has 12 electrons - a neutral atom has the same number of protons as electrons, therefore, the atom has 12 protons which is magnesium (Mg).

question_html:
Identify which of the following species contain more electrons than neutrons.

I. 11H


II. 3517Cl−


III. 2311Na+

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
@1 is correct;

I. is an isotope of hydrogen; it has 1 electron and 0 neutrons.

II. is a chloride ion; it has 18 electrons and 18 neutrons.

III. is a sodium ion; it has 10 electrons and 12 neutrons.

question_html: 35.50 cm3 of NaOH solution is required for the complete neutralisation of a 25.00 cm3 sample of 0.200 mol dm−3 H2SO4. Calculate the concentration of the NaOH solution (in mol dm−3).

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
@3 is correct;

Amount (in mol) of H2SO4 = 0.200 × (25.00 / 1000) = 5.00 × 10−3 mol

2 mol of NaOH will react with 1 mol of H2SO4 according to the following equation:

2NaOH (aq) + H2SO4 (aq) → Na2SO4 (aq) + 2H2O (l)_

5.00 × 10-3 mol of H2SO4 will react with twice the amount of NaOH:

Amount (in mol) of NaOH = 5.00 × 10−3 mol × 2 = 0.0100 mol 

To find the concentration of the NaOH, divide the amount in mol by the volume (in dm3):

C = 0.0100 / (35.50 / 1000) = 0.282 mol dm−3 (to 3 significant figures)

question_html: Determine the concentration of nitrate ions in 0.500 cm3 of 0.600 mol dm–3 of Fe(NO3)3 solution.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
@4 is correct; 

Amount (in mol) of Fe(NO3)3 = 0.600 mol dm–3 × (0.500 cm3 / 1000) = 3.00 × 10-4 mol 

One mol of iron(III) nitrate contains 3 mol of nitrate ions, therefore, multiply the amount by 3:

3.00 × 10-4 mol × 3 = 9.00 × 10-4 mol NO3- ions

Concentration = amount in mol / volume in dm3 (C=n/V)

Concentration = 9.00 × 10-4 mol / (0.500 cm3 / 1000) = 1.80 mol dm−3

question_html: Calculate the volume of water that needs to be added to dilute 40.0 cm3 of 0.600 mol dm−3 HCl(aq) solution to a concentration of 0.100 mol dm–3.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
@2 is correct;

Using n = CV = 0.600 × (40.0 / 1000) = 0.0240 mol

Then V = n/C = 0.0240 / 0.100 = 0.240 dm3 = 240 cm3

Subtract initial volume: 240 - 40 = 200 cm3.

question_html: A sample of argon gas in a sealed container of fixed volume is heated from 300 K to 500 K. Identify which of the following quantities will not remain constant?

MCQ_set.answer_html: the average kinetic energy of the atoms
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @4 is correct;  The density remains constant since the mass and volume of gas also remain constant. The number of particles in the fixed volume remains the same. The average kinetic energy of the particles will increase as the absolute temperature is increased.

question_html: A 350 cm3 sample of helium gas is collected at 22.0°C and 99.3 kPa. Calculate the volume that this gas would occupy at STP (273 K and 100 kPa).

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
V2 = P1V1T2 / P2T1 = (350 cm3 × 99.3 kPa × 273 K) / (100 kPa × 295 K) = 322 cm3

P1 is the initial pressure of the gas (99.3 kPa)

V1 is the initial volume of the gas (350 cm3)

T2 is the final temperature of the gas (273 K)

P2 is the final volume of the gas (100 kPa)

T1 is the initial temperature of the gas (295 K)

V2 is the final volume of the gas (322 cm3)

Note that the STP values used are those for gas calculations: T = 273 K and P = 100 kPa. Note also that two of the options are expansions in volume which are impossible given the changes in temperature and pressure involved.

question_html: For an ideal gas, recall which variables are inversely proportional to each other, if all other factors remain constant.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct; P and V vary inversely at constant temperature. This relationship is referred to as Boyle’s law. In each of the other cases the parameters mentioned are directly proportional to each other.

question_html: Identify which of the following graphs shows how the average kinetic energy of the particles in a sample of an ideal gas varies with absolute temperature (in kelvin).

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The average kinetic energy of gas particles is directly proportional to the absolute temperature in kelvin.

question_html: 1000 cm3 of hydrogen gas (hydrogen molecules, H2) contains x number of molecules at room temperature and pressure. Determine the number of atoms in 500 cm3 of radon gas (radon atoms) at the same temperature and pressure (assume both gases behave ideally).

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @2 is correct; Avogadro’s Law states that equal volumes of gases at the same temperature and pressure contain equal numbers of particles. In this example, we have half the volume of gas, therefore, half the number of gas particles (x/2). The fact that hydrogen is diatomic does not affect our reasoning; it is the number of particles that we are focussed on.

question_html: At STP (273 K and 100 kPa), 1.15 dm3 of a gas has a mass of 3.96 g. Determine the molar mass of the gas.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
@1 is correct; use the equation PV = nRT to find n, the number of moles present.

n = PV/RT

n = (100000 × 1.15 × 10-3) / (8.31 × 273) = 0.0507 mol

From n and the mass (m) you can then fnd the molar mass (M).

M = m/n 

M = 3.96 / 0.0507 = 78.1 g mol-1

When using the ideal gas equation, be careful to use the correct units.

section_title: Avogadro's law and molar volume of a gas

question_html: A 27.0 g sample of an unknown hydrocarbon compound (containing carbon and hydrogen only) was burned in excess oxygen to form 88.0 g of CO2 and 27.0 g of H2O. Identify which of the following is a possible molecular formula for the hydrocarbon.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @3 is correct; Amount (in mol) of CO2 = 88.0 g / 44.01 g mol-1 = 2 mol. Hence amount (in mol) of carbon atoms = 2 mol; amount (in mol) of H2O = 27.0 g / 18.02 g mol-1 = 1.5 mol. Therefore, amount of hydrogen atoms = 3 mol; empirical formula is C2H3, possible molecular formulas include C4H6, C6H9, etc.

question_html:
Determine the mass (in grams) of silver chloride, AgCl, that would be precipitated if an excess of AgNO3 solution is added to 55.0 cm3 of 0.200 mol dm−3 KCl solution. The balanced equation for the reaction is:

KCl (aq) + AgNO3 (aq) → AgCl (s) + KNO3 (aq)

Mr AgCl = 143.32

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct; the limiting reagent is KCl. Amount (in mol) of KCl = 0.200 × (55.0/ 1000) = 0.0110 mol. Molar ratio of KCl to AgCl is 1:1, therefore, this will produce 0.0110 mol of AgCl. Convert from amount (in mol) to mass in grams: 0.0110 × 143.32 = 1.58 g AgCl.

question_html:
12 molecules of hydrogen gas, H2 (g), and 5 molecules of oxygen gas, O2 (g), were mixed together under conditions which allowed the reaction to go to completion, according to the following equation:

2H2 (g) + O2 (g) → 2H2O (g)

The following diagram represents the mixture of reactants.

Determine which diagram represents the reaction mixture when the reaction was complete.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @2 is correct; there will be 2 molecules of hydrogen in excess, ten molecules of water will be formed.

question_html:
Nitrogen(II) oxide, NO, is produced from the oxidation of ammonia, NH3, according to the following equation:                          

4NH3 (g) + 5O2 (g) → 4NO (g) + 6H2O (l)

 8.50 g of NH3 reacts with excess O2 to produce 15.0 g of NO. Calculate the percentage yield of NO.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Amount (in mol) of NH3 = 8.50 / 17.04 = 0.500 mol. 

Ratio of NH3 to NO is 4:4 or 1:1, therefore 0.500 mol of NH3 will produce 0.500 mol of NO

Theoretical yield : 0.500 mol NO = 0.500 × 30.01 = 15.0 g

Actual yield = 15.0 g

Percentage yield = (15.0 / 15.0) × 100  = 100%

question_html:
2.4 g of magnesium metal reacted vigorously when heated with excess iron(III) oxide, Fe2O3 according to the following equation:

3Mg (s) + Fe2O3 (s) → 2Fe (s) + 3MgO (s) 

Determine the mass of solid iron produced in the reaction.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
3Mg(s) + Fe2O3(s) → 2Fe(s) + 3MgO(s)

Amount (in mol) of magnesium = 2.4 / 24.31 = 0.10 mol 

Amount (in mol) of iron = 0.10 × (2/3) = 0.066 mol 

Mass of iron = 0.066 × 55.85 = 3.7 g

question_html:
16.0 grams of H2 react with 64.0 grams of O2 according to the following equation:

2H2 (g) + O2 (g) → 2H2O (l)

Determine which of the following species will be present in the reaction mixture at the end of the reaction. 

M H = 1.01 g mol-1

M O = 16.00 g mol-1

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
@3 is correct; Hydrogen is in excess, so there will be the product, water, and unreacted hydrogen present at the end of the reaction – no oxygen will remain as it was the limiting reagent.

How to determine the limiting reactant:

First, determine the amount in mol of each reactant by dividing the mass (in g) by the molar mass:

Amount in mol (H2) = 16.00 g / 2.00 = 8.00 mol

Amount in mol (O2) = 64.0 g / 32.00 = 2.00 mol

Next, find the limiting reactant by dividing the amount in mol of each reactant by its coefficient in the balanced equation. 

H2: 8.00 / 2 = 4

O2: 2.00 / 1 = 2 

Lowest number is limiting reactant, which is O2, therefore, H2 is the excess reactant.

question_html: Determine which of the following equations is not balanced correctly.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
@4 is correct; - it is not correctly balanced as there are different numbers of each type of atom on each side of the equation. The correct balanced equation is: 

2Fe2O3 (s) + 3C (s) → 4Fe (s) + 3CO2 (g)

question_html:
In a basic solution, hydrogen peroxide, H2O2, reacts with manganate(VII) ions, MnO4–, according to the following equation:

2MnO4–(aq) + 3H2O2(aq) → 2MnO2(s) + 3O2(g) + 2OH–(aq) + 2H2O(l)

Calculate the amount (in mol) of hydrogen peroxide needed to produce 8 moles of water.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @3 is correct; the molar ratio of H2O2 to H2O is 3:2. 12 moles of H2O2 will produce 8 moles of H2O (12 × 2/3 = 8).

question_html: Some metals can react directly with sulfur when heated. In one reaction, 32.0 g of sulfur (relative atomic mass of 32.0) combine completely with a metal, M (relative atomic mass of 40.0) to give a product with a mass of 52.0 g. Determine the empirical formula of the sulfide formed.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
@2 is correct;

Amount (in mol) of M = (52 − 32) / 40 = 0.50 mol; amount (in mol) of S  = 32 / 32 = 1.0 mol.

Divide each by the lowest to get the lowest whole number ratio:

M: 0.50 / 0.50 = 1

S: 1.0 / 0.50 = 2

Therefore, the empirical formula is MS2

question_html:
A compound has a relative molecular mass (Mr) of 56. Which of the following cannot be a possible empirical formula for this compound? 

(Ar values: H = 1, Cl = 35.5, C = 12, O = 16, Mg = 24, N = 14)

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct; all the other formulas add up to give a formula mass of 56, or to a value which can be multiplied by a whole number to give 56.

question_html: An unknown element M combines with oxygen to form the compound MO2. If 36.0g of element M combines exactly with 16.00 g of oxygen, what is the molar mass of M in g mol-1?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
@4 is correct; to form this oxide, M + O2 → MO2

Amount of oxygen molecules = 16.00 / 32.00 = 0.50 mol O2 molecules; from equation 0.50 mol M atoms combine with this amount of oxygen molecules.

Hence molar mass of M = 36.0 / 0.50 = 72.0 g mol−1.

@3: 6.258 × 10−3 mol Br2 molecules; 0.0125 mol Br atoms;
@4: 0.03125 mol O2 molecules; 0.0625 mol oxygen atoms

question_html: Which of the following samples has the greatest mass?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct; 28 g mol−1 × 2 mol = 56 g

question_html: Determine what 2Cl2 (g) represents when written in a balanced chemical equation.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @2 is correct; 2Cl2 (g) represents two moles of gaseous chlorine molecules. Chlorine forms a diatomic molecule with the formula Cl2.

question_html:
In the equilibrium represented by the equation below, which combination of species represents a conjugate acid–base pair?

                     CH2ClCOOH (aq) + H2O (l) ⇌ CH2ClCOO– (aq) + H3O+ (aq)

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @1 is correct; a conjugate acid-base pair differ from each other by a proton (H+), so @2, @3 and @4 are incorrect. Note that H2O and H3O+ are also a conjugate acid-base pair.

question_html: Which one of the following equations represents the reaction between dilute hydrochloric acid and calcium hydroxide?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @4 is correct as what we are looking at is a neutralisation reaction between an acid and a base. Neutralisation reactions produce water and a salt, which is made up of the conjugate base of the reagent acid and the conjugate acid of the reagent base. @2 and @3 are immediately seen to be incorrect as the formula of calcium hydroxide is incorrect; @1 is incorrect as one of the products is incorrect.

question_html: Which of the following compounds contains both ionic and covalent bonds?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @4 is correct; @1 is an ionic compound, while @2 and @3 are both covalent. @4 has covalent bonding between the atoms in the ammonium ion, which is bonded to the chloride ion via an ionic bond. The ammonium ion (NH4+)  is made of one nitrogen and four hydrogen atoms, which have covalent bonding. The ammonium ion has a 1+ charge and the chloride ion has a 1- charge. The ionic bond is the attraction between these oppositely charged ions.

question_html:
The diagram below shows one way of representing an atom, in this case an atom of element X.

Deduce the group of the Periodic Table that element X belongs to.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @4 is correct; there are six valence electrons which places the atom in group 16 of the periodic table - or, there are 16 electrons so the atomic number is 16, which is sulfur (in group 16).

section_title: Electron configurations and the periodic table

question_html: Deduce which of the following pairs of elements have the greatest difference in electronegativity.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: #1 is correct. Oxygen is the most electronegative element (apart from fluorine) and aluminium is a metal with a lower electronegativity value. This is the only combination involving a metal and a non-metal and so they have the greatest difference in electronegativity.

The correct answer is A., aluminum and oxygen.

All the other combinations of elements are adjacent within a group or within a period. Aluminum is in Group 3 and Period 3, whereas oxygen is in Group 6 and Period 2. By virtue of being more separated along the electronegativity trend, these two elements must have the greatest difference in electronegativity.

question_html: Deduce which of the following ions has the smallest ionic radius.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: On first inspection it might seem that fluoride, F-, is the correct answer, because it is furthest to the right in period 2. But the question refers to ions: the electron configurations of all four of these ions are identical, 1s2 2s2 2p6. The atomic numbers (Z) are 8, 9,11 and 12, respectively. Magnesium has the highest atomic number (Z = 12), therefore, the valence electrons 'feel' the strongest attraction from the nucleus, so it has the smallest ionic radius. The data supports this: the ionic radii of the ions are: 190, 181, 98, 65 pm for O2-, F-, Na+ and Mg2+, respectively.

question_html: Identify which of the following atoms has the largest atomic radius.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The atomic radius decreases as you move across a period in the periodic table. This results from the fact that the added electrons are going into the same main energy level so their is no great increase in the shielding of the valence electrons. However, the electrons do experience an increasing attraction from the more positive nucleus as atomic number increases and so are more strongly attracted to the nucleus.

The answer is C., potassium.

This question doesn't require data, only a clear understanding of atomic theory, electron arrangements and periodic trends.

Chlorine and argon both occur in Period 3, so they will have electron arrangements 2.8.7 and 2.8.8. Potassium and calcium are in Period 4, so they will have electron arrangements 2.8.8.1 and 2.8.8.2. Clearly, potassium and calcium must have larger radii than chlorine and argon. By virtue of postssium having a less positively charged nucleus than calcium (Z = 19 versus 20) the highest occupied energy level of potassium should be further from the nucleus, so it should have the largest atomic radius.

question_html: Which of the following statements is consistent with Avogadro's Law (where k is a constant)?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
@2 is correct. Avogadro's Law is concerned with the relationship between number of particles and the amount of substance (in mol). The volume of a gas is constant for a given amount (in mol) at constant P and T. Therefore V / n will be a constant.

The product of V and n will not be constant (answer @4); while answers @1 and @3 are concerned with the wrong relationships.

question_html:
This diagram below shows ice cubes floating on the surface of a glass of fizzy* drink. Determine in which of the following are the particles close together but still able to move relatively freely.

*a fizzy drink is carbonated (contains CO2 under pressure).

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: @3 is correct: the drink is a liquid and this is the state where the particles are close together but are still able to move relatively freely.. In @2 and @4 (the glass and the ice cubes) the particles are held in fixed positions; while in @1, which is a gas, the particles are moving randomly and are far apart from each other.

question_html:
Determine the sum of the coefficients when the following equation is balanced (using whole numbers only). 

 ____C2H6 (g) + ____O2 (g) → ____CO2 (g) + ____H2O (l)

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
@2 is correct: the balanced equation is:

                   2C2H6  (g) + 7O2 (g) → 4CO2 (g) + 6H2O (l)

therefore, the sum of the coefficients is 19. Note that the equation could also be balanced using a ½ for the oxygen (but this is not using whole-numbers).

question_html: Which of the following compounds is optically active?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Carbon atoms that are chiral centres have four different atoms or groups bonded to them. Chiral compounds show optical activity (they cause rotation of the plane of plane-polarised light). This molecule has a chiral carbon atom, whereas the other choices do not.

question_html: Which of the following compounds have optical activity?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Carbon atoms that are chiral centres have four different groups bonded to them. Chiral compounds show optical activity. The carbon atom bonded to the bromine atom is bonded to four different atoms or groups, therefore, it is a chiral, or asymmetric carbon.

question_html: Which of the following compounds has a carbon atom that is a chiral centre?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Carbons that are chiral centres have four different groups bonded to them. Chiral compounds show optical activity. The carbon atom bonded to the fluorine atom is bonded to four different atoms or groups, therefore, it is a chiral, or asymmetric carbon.

question_html:
The following diagram shows a pair of which of the following?

​

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Compounds which are mirror images of one another and cannot be superimposed (placed one on top of each other) are known as optical isomers.

question_html: What physical/chemical properties differ in a pair of optical isomers?

MCQ_set.answer_html: their interaction with plane-polarised light and with other chiral compounds
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The only differences between chiral compounds is their interaction with plane-polarised light and with other chiral compounds.

question_html: What is the relationship between the two enantiomers of a chiral molecule?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Molecules that are mirror images of one another and cannot be superimposed (placed one on top of each other) are known as enantiomers.

question_html: A sample of optical isomers has no effect on plane-polarised light. Determine the ratio of the enantiomers present.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A racemic mixture with equal amounts of both enantiomers has no effect on plane-polarised light as the equal and opposite rotations cancel each other out.

MCQ_set.answer_html: a pure sample of one of the enantiomers

question_html: How can you distinguish between optical isomers?

MCQ_set.answer_html: They interact differently with plane-polarised light. One isomer will cause clockwise rotation of the plane while the other isomer with cause anti-clockwise rotation
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The only differences between chiral compounds is their interaction with plane-polarised light and with other chiral compounds.

MCQ_set.answer_html: You can investigate the mechanism of reaction with a nucleophile

question_html: What is the main feature of a carbon atom that is a chiral centre in a molecule?

question_html: Which one of the following correctly explains why it is not possible to convert between the cis and trans isomers of an alkene?

MCQ_set.answer_html: In alkenes, there is a pi bond that prevents free rotation around the carbon-to-carbon double bond.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: To convert between the cis and trans isomers of an alkene, there needs to be rotation of the groups around the carbon to carbon double bond. The pi bond in the carbon to carbon double bond prevents this free rotation.

MCQ_set.answer_html: In alkenes, there is a sigma bond that prevents free rotation around the carbon-to-carbon double bond.
In alkenes, there is a hydrogen bond that prevents free rotation around the carbon-to-carbon double bond.
In alkenes, there is an ionic bond that prevents free rotation around the carbon-to-carbon double bond.

question_html: Why does the cis form of C2H2Cl2 have a higher boiling point than the trans form?

MCQ_set.answer_html: the cis form has a dipole moment as both Cl groups are on the same side of the molecule, therefore, it has an asymmetrical structure and so the intermolecular forces are stronger
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The cis form has a dipole moment as both Cl groups are on the same side of the molecule thus it has an asymmetrical structure and so the intermolecular forces are stronger. The Cl region is slightly negative while the H region is slightly positive.

MCQ_set.answer_html: the cis form has a dipole moment as both Cl groups are on the same side of the molecule, therefore, it has an asymmetrical structure and so the intermolecular forces are weaker

the trans form has a permanent dipole moment as both Cl groups are on the same side of the molecule, therefore, it has an asymmetrical structure leading to an increase in the strength of the intermolecular forces

the trans form does not have a permanent dipole moment as both Cl groups are on the different sides of the molecule, therefore, it has a symmetrical structure leading to an increase in the strength of the intermolecular forces

question_html: Why is it possible for alkenes to exhibit cis-trans isomerism?

MCQ_set.answer_html: There is no free rotation around the carbon-carbon bond because of the pi bond of the double bond.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: There is no free rotation around the carbon-carbon bond because of the pi bond. Therefore, in order for rotation to occur around the carbon-carbon bond the overlap between the p orbitals must be broken, requiring energy far in excess of that available at ambient temperature.

MCQ_set.answer_html: There is no free rotation around the carbon-carbon bond because of the sigma bond of the double bond.
There is free rotation around the carbon-carbon bond because of the pi bond of the double bond.
There is free rotation around the carbon-carbon bond because of the sigma bond of the double bond.

question_html: What statement best describes a stereoisomer?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Compounds with the same structural formulae but with a different spatial arrangement of the atoms
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: This is the definition of a stereoisomer.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Compounds with the same molecular formulae but different structural formulae
Compounds with different structural formulae and the atoms are arranged differently in space
Compounds with the same chemical formulae and can be interconverted by the rotation around a single bond

question_html: Which of the following best describes a condensation reaction?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A condensation reaction is one where two smaller molecules react to form a larger molecule releasing a small molecule (such as water) in the process.

MCQ_set.answer_html: A reaction in which two larger molecules combine to form a smaller molecule, with the loss of a large molecule such as water
A reaction in which a larger molecule breaks down to form two smaller molecules, releasing a molecule of water

question_html: When butanol and propanoic acid are heated with concentrated sulfuric acid what is the product?

question_html: What is the product formed when ethanol and butanoic acid are heated with concentrated sulfuric acid?

The general name of the compound formed is an alkyl alkanoate where the alkyl is from the alcohol and the alkanoate from the carboxylic acid. In this example, the alcohol is ethanol which becomes ethyl and the carboxylic acid is butanoic acid which becomes butanoate.

question_html: When an alcohol and a carboxylic acid are heated with concentrated sulfuric acid what is the product?

question_html: The –NH2 group is the functional group of which homologous series?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The functional group NH2 is of the amine homologous series.

question_html: The Arrhenius plot below depicts the relationship ln k = ln A –(Ea/RT). Which label on the graph corresponds to 1/T?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The graph plotted is ln k vs 1/T. D is the x-axis which is labeled as 1/T. The y-axis is labeled as ln k.

question_html: What is the effect of a catalyst on the rate constant, k?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
A catalyst is a substance that increases the rate of a chemical reaction without itself being used up in the process as it provides an alternative reaction pathway with a lower activation energy.  Assuming A is unchanged in the Arrhenius equation, 

\(k=Ae^{\frac{-E_a}{RT}}\)

a decrease in Ea will result in an increase in the value of k.

MCQ_set.answer_html: the rate constant k only changes with temperature
the rate constant k shows no change

question_html: Which of the following best explains how a catalyst increases the rate of reaction?

MCQ_set.answer_html: a catalyst provides an alternative reaction pathway of lower activation energy for the forward and reverse reactions
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A catalyst is a substance that increases the rate of a chemical reaction because it provides an alternative reaction pathway with a lower activation energy for both the forward and reverse reactions. A catalyst increases the rate of the forward reaction and reverse reaction by the same amount, so it has no effect on the position of equilibrium.

MCQ_set.answer_html: a catalyst provides an alternative reaction pathway of higher activation energy for the reverse reaction only
a catalyst provides an alternative reaction pathway of lower activation energy for the forward reaction only
a catalyst provides an alternative reaction pathway of higher activation energy for the forward reaction and reverse reactions

question_html: A species that is formed during one step and subsequently used up in a later step is known as which of the following?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A species that is produced by the reaction and then used up is known as an intermediate species. It is not shown in the overall chemical equation.

question_html: Which of the following best describes the rate-determining step of a reaction?

MCQ_set.answer_html: The slowest step, having the highest activation energy
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The rate-determining step of a reaction is the slowest step in the reaction. All other steps are fast relative to this step as it has the highest activation energy.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The fastest step, having the highest activation energy
The slowest step, having the lowest activation energy
The fastest step, having the lowest activation energy

question_html: What are the units of the rate constant, k, if the overall order of reaction is first-order?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
k = Rate / ( ( [A]m ) ( [B]n ) )

Thus substitute in the units for each species and cancel out.

k = mol dm–3 s–1 / ( [mol dm–3]1 )

question_html: What are the units of the rate constant, k, if the overall order of reaction is second-order?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
k = Rate / ( ( [A]m ) ( [B]n ) )

Substitute in the units for each species and cancel out.

k = mol dm–3s–1 / ( ( [mol dm–3]1 ) ( [mol dm–3]1 ) )

question_html: What are the units of the rate constant, k, if the overall order of reaction is third-order?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
k = Rate / ( ( [A]m ) ( [B]n ) )

Substitute in the units for each species and cancel out.

k = mol dm–3s–1 / ( ( [mol dm–3]2 ) ( [mol dm–3]1 ) )

question_html:
Deduce the rate expression for the reaction between A and B from the following table of values.

Experiment [A] / mol dm–3 [B] / mol dm–3 rate / mol dm–3 s–1
1 0.40 0.20 0.20
2 0.40 0.40 0.20
3 0.20 0.40 0.05
4 0.20 0.20 0.05

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
To determine the order of a reaction isolate two experiments where [A] in changing but [B] is kept constant. Then determine the order of reaction with respect to [A]. Do the same for the species B and then use the general rate expression and fill in the value for m and n.

rate = k([A]m)([B]n)

In this example, when [A] doubles, the rate quadruples (second-order, from experiments 2 and 3) but when [B] is doubled there is no change in the rate of reaction (0 order, from experiments​ 3 and 4). The rate expression is rate = k([A]2)([B]0).

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
To determine the order of a reaction isolate two experiments where [A] in changing but [B is constant. Then determine the order of reaction with respect to [A]. Do the same for the species B and then use the general rate expression and fill in the value for m and n.

rate = k([A]m)([B]n).

In this example, when [B] doubles, the rate doubles (1st order, from experiments 3 and 4) but when [A] doubles the rate quadruples (second-order, from experiments​ 4 and 1). The rate expression is rate = k([B]1)([A]2).

To determine the order of a reaction, isolate two experiments where [A] in changing but [B is constant, then determine the order of reaction with respect to [A]. Repeat this process for species B and then use the general rate expression and deduce the values for m and n for rate = k[A]m[B]n.

In this example, when [A] doubles (Experiments 1 and 2), the rate doubles (first-order in A), but when [B] doubles (Experiments 3 and 1) the rate quadruples (second-order in B). Therefore, the rate expression is rate = k[A][B]2.

rate = k([A]m)([B]n).

rate = k([A]m)([B]n).

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The order of a reactant is shown as the power of the reactants concentration. In a second-order reactant, when the concentration of a species is increased by a factor of two, the rate of reaction quadruples. From experiment 1 to experiment 2, the rate increases by a factor of four when the concentration of A doubles, i.e. the reaction is second order with respect to A.  From experiment 1 to experiment 3, the rate increases by a factor of nine when the concentration of A triples, i.e. the reaction is second-order with respect to A. Note that the rate does not respond to a concentration change in B: the reaction is zero- order with respect to B.

question_html: By doubling the [A] in a reaction mixture there is no effect on the rate of reaction. What is the order of reaction with respect to A?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The order of a reactant is shown as the power of the reactants concentration. If a species has no effect on the rate of reaction, it is zero-order.

question_html: By doubling the [A] in a reaction mixture you quadruple the rate of reaction, what is the order of this reaction with respect to A?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The order of a reactant is shown as the power of the reactants concentration. For a second-order reactant, if you increase the concentration of the reactant by a factor of 2, the rate of reaction quadruples (22).

question_html: By doubling the [A] in a reaction mixture you double the rate of reaction, what is the order of this reaction with respect to A?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The order of a reactant is shown as the power of the reactants concentration. In a first-order reaction, if you increase the concentration of that reactant by a factor of 2, the rate of reaction doubles.

question_html: Which of the following graphs shows how the rate varies with concentration for a zero-order reaction?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The order of a reactant is shown as the power of the reactants concentration. For a zero-order reactant a change in concentration of that reactant has no effect on the rate of reaction. This is shown by a straight line on the above graph.

question_html: Which of the following graphs shows how the rate varies with concentration for a first-order reaction?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The order of a reactant is shown as the power of the reactants concentration. For a first-order reactant, if you increase the concentration of a species by a factor of 2, the rate of reaction doubles.

question_html: What does the order of reaction refer to?

MCQ_set.answer_html: how the concentration of a species affects the rate of reaction
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The order of a reactant is shown as the power of the reactants concentration. For a first order reactant, if you increase the concentration of a species by a factor of 2, the rate of reaction doubles.

MCQ_set.answer_html: how the volume of a species affects the rate of reaction
how each species controls the rate of reaction
the number of molecules involved in the rate-determining step

question_html: For the titration of a weak acid with a strong base, which of the following indicators would be most suitable?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: When choosing an indicator, the pH range should be close to the equivalence point. For a titration of a weak acid with a strong base, the pH at the equivalence point is > 7. Therefore, phenolphthalein is the most suitable indicator.

question_html: For the titration of a weak base with a strong acid, which of the following indicators would be most suitable?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: When choosing an indicator, the pH range should be close to the equivalence point. For the titration of a weak base with a strong acid the equivalence point is pH < 7, therefore, the most suitable indicator is bromocresol green.

question_html: For the titration of a strong acid with a strong base, which of the following indicators would be most suitable?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: When choosing an indicator, the pH range should be close to the equivalence point. For a titration of a strong acid with a strong base, the pH at the equivalence point is 7. Therefore, bromomethyl blue is the most suitable indicator.

question_html:
What colour would the following indicator be in a solution with a pH of 1?

HIn (green) ⇌ H+ + In– (blue)

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: An indicator is a weak acid or base that is different colours in the protonated and deprotonated form. When you add an acid (H+), the position of equilibrium shifts to the protonated form (HIn) and you see the colour green. When you add a base (OH–) the position of equilibrium shifts towards the deprotonated form (In–) and you see the colour blue.

question_html:
The following pH indicator has a pKa of 7. What colour will the indicator be in a solution with a pH of 7?

HIn (red) ⇌ H+ + In– (blue)

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: An indicator is a weak acid or base that is different colours in the protonated and deprotonated form.When you add an acid (H+), the position of equilibrium shifts to the protonated form (HIn). When you add a base (OH–) the position of equilibrium shifts towards the deprotonated form (In–). When the pH is in the middle of the pH range of the indicator you see a mixture of the two colours.

question_html:
What colour would the following indicator be in a solution with a pH of 12?

HIn (red) ⇌ H+ + In– (blue)

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: An indicator is a weak acid or base that is different colours in the protonated and deprotonated form. When you add an acid (H+), the position of equilibrium shifts to the protonated form (HIn) and you see the colour red. When you add a base (OH–) the position of equilibrium shifts towards the deprotonated form (In–) and you see the colour blue.

question_html: Identify the point labeled A on the titration curve below.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The pKa of the weak acid is equal to the pH at the half-equivalence point.

question_html: Identify the region labeled B on the titration curve below.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The buffer region of the graph is the region where base is being added but there is little change in the pH.

MCQ_set.answer_html: the pKa of the weak acid

question_html: Identify the point labeled C on the titration curve below.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The equivalence point is where the acid and base have reacted in stoichiometrically equivalent amounts. At this point, the solution contains only salt and water.

question_html: In the titration curve of a weak acid and strong base, the pKa is equal to which of the following?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The pKa of a weak  acid is equal to the pH at the half-equivalence point.

MCQ_set.answer_html: the pH at a quarter of the equivalence point

question_html: In an acid-base titration, which of the following best describes the equivalence point?

MCQ_set.answer_html: when equal amounts (in mol) of H+ and OH– ions have reacted
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: At the equivalence point, equal amounts of H+ and OH– ions have reacted and the solution contains only salt and water.

MCQ_set.answer_html: when equal volumes of acid and base have been added
when the pH of the weak acid is equal to the pKa
when the pH of the weak base is equal to the pKb

question_html: The following pH curve shows the titration of which of the following?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: When a weak acid and weak base are titrated, the pH at the equivalence point is dependent on the relative strengths of the acid and base used. The vertical region of the graph is also less well defined.

question_html: What is the pH of a solution of ammonium chloride, NH4Cl?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The pH of the salt of a strong acid and weak base will be < 7. This is because the cation is able to hydrolyse water, producing the hydronium ion.

question_html: What is the pH of a solution of sodium ethanoate, CH3COONa?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The pH of the salt of a weak acid and strong base will be > 7. The anion is able to hydrolyse water, producing the hydroxide ion.

question_html: What is the pH of a solution of sodium chloride, NaCl, at 298 K?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The pH of the salt of a strong acid and a strong base will be neutral. Neither anion nor cation is able to hydrolyse water.

question_html: What is the pH of the solution of the salt of a weak acid and strong base?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The pH of the salt of a weak acid and strong base will be > 7. The anion is able to hydrolyse water, producing the hydroxide ion.

MCQ_set.answer_html: depends on the relative strength of the acid and base

question_html: What is the pH of the solution of the salt of a strong acid and weak base?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The pH of the salt of a strong acid and weak base will be < 7. The cation is able to hydrolyse water, producing the hydronium ion.

MCQ_set.answer_html: depends on the relative strength of the acid and base

question_html: What is the pH of the solution of a salt produced in the reaction between a strong acid and strong base?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The pH of the solution of a salt produced in the reaction between a strong acid and strong base will be approximately 7 at 298 K. This is because neither ion is able to hydrolyse a water molecule.

MCQ_set.answer_html: depends on the relative strength of the acid and base

question_html: What of the following will produce an acidic buffer solution?

MCQ_set.answer_html: 50 cm3 of 2.0 mol dm-3 NaOH and 100 cm3 of 2.0 mol dm-3 CH3COOH
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: To form an acidic buffer solution, react excess weak acid with a strong base so that there are equal amounts of the weak acid and its conjugate base remaining.

MCQ_set.answer_html: 100 cm3 of 2.0 mol dm-3 NH3 and 100 cm3 of 2.0 mol dm-3 CH3COOH
100 cm3 of 2.0 mol dm-3 NaOH and 50 cm3 of 2.0 mol dm-3 CH3COOH

question_html: Which of the following solutions would act as a buffer solution?

MCQ_set.answer_html: 100 cm3 of 1.00 mol dm-3 HCl and 100 cm3 of 2.00 mol dm-3 NH3
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: To form a buffer solution there should be equal amounts of the undissociated weak acid or base and its conjugate base or acid. In this solution, there are equal amounts of the weak base NH3 and its conjugate acid NH4+, therefore, it would act as a buffer solution.

MCQ_set.answer_html: 100 cm3 of 1.00 mol dm-3 HCl and 100 cm3 of 0.200 mol dm-3 NaOH
100 cm3 of 2.00 mol dm-3 HCl and 200 cm3 of 1.00 mol dm-3 NH3
200 cm3 of 1.00 mol dm-3 HCl and 100 cm3 of 2.00 mol dm-3 NaOH

question_html: Which of the following solutions forms a basic buffer?

MCQ_set.answer_html: 500 cm3 of 0.50 mol dm-3 HCl and 500 cm3 of 1.00 mol dm-3 CH3NH2
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: To form a basic buffer you add a weak base to a strong acid to produce a salt. The weak base should be in excess so that there are equal amounts of both weak base and its conjugate acid left in solution.

MCQ_set.answer_html: 500 cm3 of 1.00 mol dm-3 HCl and 500 cm3 of 0.50 mol dm-3 CH3NH2
500 cm3 of 2.00 mol dm-3 HCl and 500 cm3 of 2.00 mol dm-3 CH3NH2
500 cm3 of 0.50 mol dm-3 HCl and 500 cm3 of 0.50 mol dm-3 CH3NH2

question_html: Which of the following forms a buffer solution?

MCQ_set.answer_html: 200 cm3 of 0.1 mol dm-3 NaOH and 100 cm3 of 0.1 mol dm-3 CH3COOH
100 cm3 of 0.1 mol dm-3 NaOH and 200 cm3 of 0.1 mol dm-3 CH3COOH
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: To form a buffer you must add a weak acid/base to a strong base/acid to form the salt. You must use excess weak acid/base so that there is both weak acid/base and its salt left in solution. This is the only choice that results in both weak acid and salt.

MCQ_set.answer_html: 200 cm3 of 0.1 mol dm-3 NaOH and 200 cm3 of 0.1 mol dm-3 CH3COOH

question_html: Which of the following solutions forms a buffer?

MCQ_set.answer_html: 100 cm3 of 0.1 mol dm-3 HCl and 200 cm3 of 0.2 mol dm-3 NH3
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: To form a buffer you must add a weak acid/base to a strong base/acid to for the salt. You must use excess weak acid/base so that there is both weak acid/base and its salt left in solution.

MCQ_set.answer_html: 100 cm3 of  0.01 mol dm-3 HCl and 200 cm3 of  0.005 mol dm-3 NH3
100 cm3 of  0.1 mol dm-3 HCl and 200 cm3 of  0.05 mol dm-3 NH3
100 cm3 of  0.2 mol dm-3 HCl and 200 cm3 of  0.05 mol dm-3 NH3

question_html: A basic buffer is made up of which of the following?

MCQ_set.answer_html: a weak base and the salt of the weak base and a strong acid
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A basic buffer is made up of a weak base and the salt of the weak base and a strong acid (in other words, the weak base and its conjugate acid). It will have a pH > 7.

MCQ_set.answer_html: a strong base and the salt of the strong base and a strong acid
a weak base and the salt of the weak base and a weak acid
a strong acid and the salt of the strong acid and weak acid

question_html: An acidic buffer is made up of which of the following combined in appropriate molar ratios?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: An acidic buffer is made up of equal amounts of a weak acid and a salt produced by the reaction of the weak acid with a strong base. The resulting mixture will contain equal amounts of the weak acid and its conjugate base (in this example CH3COOH and CH3COO-). It will have a pH of less than 7.

question_html: Which of the following best describes a buffer solution?

MCQ_set.answer_html: A solution that resists changes in pH when small amounts of acid or base are added
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: This is the definition of a buffer solution. An example in biology is blood whose buffering capability is essential for life.

MCQ_set.answer_html: A solution that resists changes in pH when large amounts of acid or base are added
A solution that allows changes in pH when large amounts of acid or base are added
A solution that allows changes in pH when small amounts of acid or base are added

question_html: Which of the following best describes a species with a pKb value of 9.13?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A relatively high value for the pKb  indicates a weak base; the lower the pKb, the stronger the base. The pKb value in the question is that of phenylamine, C6H5NH2, which is a weak base.

question_html: Which of the following best describes a species with a pKb value of 0.20?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The lower the pKb, the stronger the base. The pKb value in the question is that of sodium hydroxide, NaOH, which is a strong base.

question_html: A solution has a pKa value of 4.76 at 298 K. Which of the following is correct?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
pKa = -log10(Ka)

Ka = 10–pKa

Ka = 10–4.76 = 1.74 × 10–5

The solution cannot be a strong acid as the concept of Ka is only applied to weak acids. The Kb of the solution is 5.75 × 10–10 , therefore Ka > Kb.

question_html: Which of the following best describes a species with a pKa value of –1.74?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The lower the pKa value, the stronger the acid. The pKa value in the question is that of nitric acid, HNO3, which is a strong acid. Note that strong acids can have negative pKa values.

question_html: Which of the following can be used to determine the pKa of a solution from the Ka?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: To determine the pKa from the Ka, this is the formula that must be used.

question_html: Which expression is used to calculate the hydrogen ion concentration, [H+], of a solution?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: This expression can be used to calculate the hydrogen ion concentration of a solution if the pH of the solution is known.

question_html: Which expression is used to calculate the pH of a solution?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
The pH scale is a logarithmic scale to the base 10. The equation used to calculate the pH is:

pH = –log10[H+]

Solution with a high [H+] will have a low pH value and vice-versa. 

The expression pH = –log10[OH–] is used to calculate the pOH of a solution and is only required in topic 18 (HL only).

question_html: Which of the following relationships is correct at 298 K?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Rearranging pH + pOH = 14 gives pOH = 14 – pH. This relationship is key in determining the pH of basic solutions whose calculations involve [OH–].

question_html: Which of the following relationships is correct?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: This fundamental relationship must be learned in order to carry out acids and bases calculations.

question_html: Which of the following relationships is correct at 298 K?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: This is part of a set of relationships that must be learned in order to do acid and bases calculations.

question_html: Which of the following is the general expression for the Kb of a weak base?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: This is the general equation for the dissociation of a weak base and is used to form the general Kb equation. B is the base and BH+ is its conjugate acid as the Bronsted-Lowry definition of a base is a proton acceptor. Note that H2O is not included in the expression.

question_html: Which of the following is the equation for the Ka of a weak acid?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: This is the general equation for the dissociation of a weak acid and is used to form the general Ka equation. HA is the weak acid and A– is its conjugate base. We can assume that [H+] = [A–].

question_html: Which of the following equations represents the reaction of a weak base with water?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: This is the general equation for the dissociation of a weak base and is used to form the general Kb equation. B is the base and BH+ is the protonated base as the Bronsted-Lowry definition of a base is a proton acceptor

question_html: Which of the following equations represents the reaction of a weak acid with water?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: This is the general equation for the dissociation of a weak acid and is thus used to form the general Ka equation. HA is the acid and A– is the deprotonated acid as the Bronsted-Lowry definition of an acid is a proton donor.

question_html: The pH of pure water at 298 K is 7.0 but at 323 K, the pH is 6.6. What does this tell us about the enthalpy change for the dissociation of a water molecule?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Energy is required to dissociate a water molecule into H+ and OH– ions. 

H2O (l) ⇌ H+ (aq) + OH– (aq)   ΔH = positive 

As the temperature increases, the position of equilibrium shifts to the right, increasing the concentration of H+ ions which results in a decrease in the pH of the pure water. However, the water is still neutral as the [H+] = [OH–]. Pure water only has a pH of 7.00 at 298 K.

question_html: Which of the following expressions represents the Kw of water?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
The Kw, the ionic product constant of water, is calculated as follows:

Kw = [H+][OH–]

Note that H2O is not included in the expression as it is present in large excess.

question_html:
Which species is missing from the following pathway?
Alkene → ................... → aldehyde

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Alkenes can undergo hydration to form an alcohol. Primary alcohols then can be oxidised to aldehydes.

question_html:
Which species is missing from the following pathway?
 Halogenoalkane → secondary alcohol → ....................

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Secondary alcohols can only be oxidised as far a ketone, it will not be fully oxidised to a carboxylic acid.

question_html: Which pathway to the formation of a carboxylic acid is correct?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Synthetic pathway: alkene → primary alcohol → aldehyde → carboxylic acid. In order for a carboxylic acid to be formed, you must have a primary alcohol. The intermediate product is an aldehyde.

question_html: State the class that the following organic molecule belongs to:

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Carboxylic acids have a COOH group on the terminal carbon. Be careful not to confuse the class with the functional group - the functional group in this molecule is the carboxyl group (COOH).

question_html: State the class that the following organic molecule belongs to.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Alkanes are saturated hydrocarbons with carbon to carbon single bonds only. The molecule in the question is 2,3-dimethylhexane, a branched alkane.

question_html: What is the best description of a weak acid?

MCQ_set.answer_html: an acid that only partially dissociates in solution
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Definition of a weak acid

MCQ_set.answer_html: an acid that dissociates fully in solution

section_title: Strong and weak acids and bases

question_html: What is the best description of a strong acid?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A strong acid fully dissociates in solution whereas a weak acid only partially dissociates in solution.

MCQ_set.answer_html: an acid that only partially dissociates in solution

section_title: Strong and weak acids and bases

question_html: Why does a change of one unit in the pH scale represent a ten times change in the [H+] of a solution?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The pH scale is a logarithmic scale that is dependent on the concentration of the acid/base in question. A change in one unit in the pH scale represents a ten times change in hydrogen ion concentration.

MCQ_set.answer_html: the pH scale is inversely proportional to the [H+]

question_html: What is the difference in the concentration of hydrogen ions, [H+], between two solutions of pH 2 and pH 8?

MCQ_set.answer_html: The solution with a pH of 2 is 1000000 times more acidic than the solution with a pH of 8
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The pH scale is logarithmic meaning that a change in one unit represents a 10 times change in hydrogen ion concentration. A solution with a pH of 2 is 1000000 times more acidic than a solution with a pH of 8; it has a [H+] of 10-2 vs 10-8 (10-2/10-8) = 1000000.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The solution with a pH of 2 is 1000000 times less acidic than the solution with a pH of 8
The solution with a pH of 2 is 6 times more acidic than the solution with a pH of 8
The solution with a pH of 8 is 10000000 times more acidic than the solution with a pH of 2

question_html: What is the difference in the concentration of hydrogen ions, [H+], between two solutions of pH 11 and pH 12?

MCQ_set.answer_html: The solution with a pH of 12 is 10 times less acidic than the solution with a pH of 11
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The pH scale is logarithmic meaning that a change in one unit represents a 10 times change in hydrogen ion concentration. A solution with a pH of 11 is 10 times more acidic than a solution with a pH of 12 - it has a [H+] of 10-11 vs 10-12 (10-11/10-12) = 10.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The solution with a pH of 12 is 10 times more acidic than the solution with a pH of 11
The solution with a pH of 12 is half as acidic than the solution with a pH of 11
The solution with a pH of 11 is 10 times less acidic than the solution with a pH of 12

question_html: What is the difference in the concentration of hydrogen ions, [H+], between two solutions of pH 2 and pH 7?

MCQ_set.answer_html: The solution with a pH of 7 is 100000 times less acidic than the solution with a pH of 2
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The pH scale is logarithmic meaning that a change in one unit represents a 10 times change in hydrogen ion concentration. A solution with a pH of 2 is 100000 times more acidic than a solution with a pH of 7; it has a [H+] of 10-2 vs 10-7 (10-2/10-7) = 100000.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The solution with a pH of 2 is 100000 times less acidic than the solution with a pH of 7
The solution with a pH of 7 is 5 times less acidic than the solution with a pH of 2
The solution with a pH of 7 is 10000 times less acidic than the solution with a pH of 2

question_html: What is the ratio of hydrogen ions, H+, between solutions of pH 5 and pH 7?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The pH scale is logarithmic meaning that a change in one unit represents a 10 times change in hydrogen ion concentration. A solution with a pH of 5 is 100 times more acidic than a solution with a pH of 7 - it has a [H+] of 10-5 vs 10-7 (10-5/10-7) = 100.

question_html: Calculate the concentration of hydrogen ions, [H+], in a solution of pH 7 (in mol dm-3 ).

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
[H+] = 10–pH 

[H+] = 10–7 = 0.0000001 mol dm-3

question_html: Calculate the concentration of hydrogen ions, [H+], in a solution of pH 8 (in mol dm-3 ).

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
[H+] = 10–pH 

[H+] = 10–8  mol dm-3

question_html: Calculate the concentration of hydrogen ions, [H+], in a solution of pH 1 (in mol dm-3 ).

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
[H+] = 10–pH 

[H+] = 10–1 = 0.1 mol dm-3

question_html: Calculate the concentration of hydrogen ions, [H+], in a solution of pH 12 (in mol dm-3 ).

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
[H+] = 10–pH 

[H+] = 10–12 mol dm-3

question_html: Calculate the concentration of hydrogen ions, [H+], in a solution of pH 5 (in mol dm-3 ).

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
[H+] = 10–pH 

[H+] = 10–5 = 0.00001mol dm-3

question_html: Which of the following pH values could be for a strong base?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A strong base will have a high pH of 12+ on the pH scale.

question_html: Which of the following pH values could be for a weak base?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A weak base will have a pH of between 8 and 11 on the pH scale.

question_html: Which of the following pH values represents a weak acid?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A weak acid will have a pH in the range of between 3 and 6. pH 1 is a strong acid, pH 7 is neutral and pH 8 is a weak base.

question_html: Which of the following pH values represents an acid solution with the highest concentration of hydrogen ions, [H+]?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The pH scale is an inverse scale - a high [H+] represents a low pH value and vice-versa.

question_html: What colour would a solution of pH 12 show when universal indicator is added?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Universal indicator shows a range of colours depending on the pH. For pH 12, a dark blue colour is seen. Yellow and orange show a pH of 2-6 and green is pH 7.

question_html: What is the colour of phenolphthalein indicator in a solution with a pH of 4?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Phenophthalein is colourless in an acidic solution and pink in an alkaline solution.

question_html: What colour would a solution of pH 2 show when universal indicator is added?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Universal indicator shows a range of colours depending on the pH. For pH 2, a red/orange colour is seen.

question_html: Which of the following general reaction equations is correct?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: acid + metal → salt + hydrogen is the general equation for the reaction between a metal and an acid.

question_html: Which of the following general reaction equations is correct?

MCQ_set.answer_html: acid + metal carbonate → salt + carbon dioxide + water
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: acid + metal carbonate → salt + carbon dioxide + water is the general equation for the reaction between an acid and a metal carbonate.

question_html: Which of the following general reaction equations is correct?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: acid + base → salt + water is the general equation for the reaction between an acid and a base.

question_html: Which statement best describes an alkali?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: An alkali is a soluble base. All alkalis are bases, but not all bases are alkalis (not all bases are soluble in water).

question_html: Which of the following is a Lewis base?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A Lewis base is a lone pair of electrons donor. Three of the oxygens in the phosphate group are negatively charged and have lone pairs of electrons on them. One of these can form a coordinate covalent bond with a proton, therefore, it is a Lewis base (the HPO42– ion is formed).

section_title: Lewis theory of acids and bases

question_html: Which of the following is an example of a Bronsted-Lowry conjugate acid/base pair?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The conversion between a Brønsted-Lowry acid/base or base/acid pair is the transfer of one proton.

question_html: Which of the following is an example of a conjugate acid–base pair?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A conjugate acid-base pair differ by a proton (H+).

question_html: Which of the following species in bold is acting as a Lewis base but not as a Brønsted-Lowry base?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: In this reaction, CN– is using its lone pair of electrons to form a coordinate covalent bond, therefore, it is acting as a Lewis base. It is not accepting a proton, so is not acting as a Brønsted-Lowry base

section_title: Lewis theory of acids and bases

question_html: Which of the following species in bold is acting as a Lewis acid but not as a Brønsted-Lowry acid?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: AlCl3 acts as a Lewis acid by accepting a lone pair of electrons from the chloride ion. AlCl3 is electron deficient and can accept a lone pair of electrons to complete the octet of the aluminium atom. The bond formed between AlCl3 and the chloride ion is a coordinate covalent bond. AlCl3 is not a Brønsted-Lowry acid as it is not a proton donor.

section_title: Lewis theory of acids and bases

question_html: Which statement best describes a Lewis base?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A Lewis base is defined as an electron-pair donor. Lewis bases are also nucleophiles or ligands.

section_title: Lewis theory of acids and bases

question_html: Which statement best describes a Lewis acid?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A Lewis acid is defined as an electron-pair acceptor. Lewis acids are also electrophiles.

section_title: Lewis theory of acids and bases

question_html: Which statement best describes a Bronsted-Lowry base?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A Bronsted-Lowry base is defined as a proton acceptor - it must have a lone pair of electrons to accept the proton.

question_html: Which statement best describes a Bronsted-Lowry acid?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A Bronsted-Lowry acid is defined as a proton donor - it must have a hydrogen atom to be able to donate a proton (H+).

question_html: What is the bond order of the nitrogen to oxygen bond in the nitrate ion, NO3–?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The sum of the individual bond orders is 1+1+2 = 4. There are 3 bonding positions in the ion. The bond order is 4/3 = 1.333

question_html: What is the bond order of the carbon to carbon bonds in benzene, C6H6?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The sum of the individual bonds orders is 1+2+1+2+1+2 = 9 (assuming that benzene has alternating single and double bonds as in the Kekule structure). There are six bonding positions in benzene, therefore, the bond order is: 9/6 = 1.5

question_html: Which one of the following molecules has delocalised electrons?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Delocalisation occurs when electrons are shared between more than two nuclei. Molecules with delocalised electrons have more than one possible Lewis structure, known as resonance structures. Ozone, O3, is one such example.

question_html: Which of the following species has delocalised electrons?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Delocalisation occurs when electrons are shared between more than two nuclei. Molecules with delocalised electrons have more than one possible Lewis structure, known as resonance structures. The ethanoate ion, CH3COO–, is one such example.

question_html:
Identify which of the following species contain delocalised electrons. 

I. C6H6

II. H2O

III. NH4+

IV. CO32–

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Delocalisation occurs when electrons are shared between more than two nuclei. Molecules with delocalised electrons have more than one possible Lewis structure, known as resonance structures. Benzene contains delocalised pi electrons that originate from the pi bonds between the carbon atoms. The carbonate ion also contains delocalised electrons .

question_html: If a molecule has a tetrahedral molecular geometry, what is the hybridisation around the central atom?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: If a molecule has a tetrahedral molecular geometry, the hybridisation of the central atom is sp3.

question_html: What is the hybridisation of the N atom in NH3?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The nitrogen atom has four electron domains (three bonding domains and one non-bonding domain), therefore, the hybridisation is sp3.

question_html: What is the hybridisation of C in CO2?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The carbon atom has two electron domains (both are non-bonding domains), therefore, the hybridisation is sp.

question_html: What is the hybridisation of N in NO3–?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The nitrogen atom in the nitrate ion has three electron domains (two single bonds and one double bond), therefore the hybridisation is sp2.

question_html: What is the hybridisation of S in SO2?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: There is a trigonal planar arrangement of electron domains around the S in SO2. Therefore, the hybridisation of the S atom is sp2.

question_html: What is the hybridisation of the carbon and nitrogen atoms in the nitrile group of ethanenitrile, CH3CN?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The hybridisation in the carbon atom and the nitrogen atom of the nitrile group is sp hybridisation (both atoms have two electron domains).

question_html: What is the hybridisation around the carbon atoms in CH2CHCH3?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The first carbon is sp2 hybridised, as it has three electron domains, all of which are bonding domains. The second carbon also has three electron domains, all of which are bonding domains, so it is also sp2 hybridised. The carbon on the right has four electron domains, all of which are bonding domains, so it is sp3 hybridised.

question_html: What is the hybridisation around the carbon atoms in CHCCH3?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The first carbon is sp hybridised, as it has two electron domains, both of which are bonding domains. The second carbon also has two electron domains, both of which are bonding domains, so it is also sp hybridised. The carbon on the right has four electron domains, all of which are bonding domains, so it is sp3 hybridised.

question_html: What is the hybridisation around the carbon atoms in CH2CCH2?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The first carbon is sp2 hybridised, as it has three electron domains, all of which are bonding domains. The second carbon has two electron domains, both of which are bonding domains, so it is sp hybridised. The carbon on the right has three electron domains, all of which are bonding domains, so it is sp2 hybridised.

question_html: Which of the following best describes the formation of a sigma bond?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A sigma bond is formed by the head-on overlap of atomic orbitals. This results in electron density between the nuclei of the bonding atoms.

question_html: Which of the following best describes the formation of a pi bond?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A pi bond is formed by the sideways overlap of p orbitals. This results in electron density above and below the plane of the nuclei of the bonding atoms.

question_html: What type of bond is formed by the sideways overlap of p orbitals?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A pi bond is formed by the sideways overlap of p orbitals. Head-on overlap of two p orbitals would produce a sigma bond, but sideways overlap produces a pi bond.

question_html: How many p orbitals remain unhybridised after sp hybridisation has taken place?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: sp hybridisation involves one s orbital and one p orbital mixing to form two sp hybrid orbitals. There are two remaining p orbitals which are unhybridised.

question_html: How many p orbitals remain unhybridised after sp2 hybridisation has taken place?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: sp2 hybridisation involves one s orbital and two p orbitals mixing to form three sp2 hybrid orbitals. There is one remaining p orbital which is unhybridised.

question_html: How many p orbitals remain unhybridised after sp3 hybridisation has taken place?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: sp3 hybridisation involves one s orbital and three p orbitals mixing to form four sp3 hybrid orbitals. There are no remaining unhybridised p orbitals.

question_html: Which of the following is the correct definition of hybridisation?

MCQ_set.answer_html: The mixing of atomic orbitals to produce degenerate hybrid orbitals to be used for bonding.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Hybridisation is defined as the mixing of atomic orbitals to produce degenerate hybrid orbitals to be used for bonding. Examples include sp3 hybridisation in methane, CH4, sp2 hybridisation is ethene, C2H4 and sp hybridisation in ethyne, C2H2.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The mixing of atomic orbitals to produce hybrid orbitals of different energies to be used for bonding.
The direct head-on overlap of atomic orbitals, resulting in electron density concentrated between the nuclei of the bonding atoms.
The sideways overlap of atomic orbitals, resulting in electron density above and below the plane of the nuclei of the bonding atoms

question_html: Predict the molecular geometry of XeO64– using VSEPR theory.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The molecular geometry is determined by the number of bonding and non-bonding domains around the central atom. Here there are six bonding domains around the central atom and these bonding domains repel each other to be as far apart as possible. The oxygen atoms have an octahedral arrangement around the central Xe atom.

question_html: Predict the molecular geometry of XeO4 using VSEPR theory.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The molecular geometry is determined by the number of bonding and non-bonding domains around the central atom. Here there are four bonding domains around the central atom and these bonding domains repel each other to be as far apart as possible. The oxygen atoms have a tetrahedral arrangement around the central Xe atom.

question_html: Predict the molecular geometry of I3– using VSEPR theory.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The molecular geometry is determined by the number of bonding and non-bonding domains around the central atom. Here there are two bonding domains and three non-bonding domains around the central atom (a total of five electron domains). This gives a linear molecular geometry.

question_html: Predict the molecular geometry of CCl4 using VSEPR theory.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The molecular geometry is determined by the number of bonding and non-bonding domains around the central atom. Here there are four bonding domains around the central atom. This gives a tetrahedral molecular geometry.

question_html: Predict the molecular geometry of SCl6 using VSEPR theory.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The molecular geometry is determined by the number of bonding and non-bonding domains around the central atom. Here there are six bonding domains around the central atom. This gives a octahedral molecular geometry.

question_html: Predict the molecular geometry of XeCl4 using VSEPR theory.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The molecular geometry is determined by the number of bonding and non-bonding domains around the central atom. Here there are four bonding domains and two non-bonding domains around the central atom (a total of six electron domains). This gives a square planar molecular geometry.

question_html: Predict the molecular geometry and bond angles of a molecule in which the central atom has five electron domains, all of which are bonding domains.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A molecule with five electron domains, all of which are bonding domains, has a trigonal bipyramidal molecular geometry with bond angles of 90o and 120o.

question_html: Which of the following explains why a catalyst does not affect the position of equilibrium?

MCQ_set.answer_html: A catalyst increases the rate of the forward and reverse reactions equally
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The addition of a catalyst is the only condition that will not alter the position of equilibrium.

MCQ_set.answer_html: A catalyst has no effect on the rate of the forward or the reverse reactions
A catalyst decreases the rate of the forward and reverse reactions equally
A catalyst provides an alternative reaction pathway with a lower activation energy

question_html: How does the value of the Kc change when a catalyst is added?

MCQ_set.answer_html: There is no change in the value of the Kc
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A system is in equilibrium when the rate of the forward reaction equals the rate of the reverse reaction. A catalyst works by providing a pathway with a lower activation energy. This will affect rate of the forward and reverse reactions equally - speeding both up - so the equilibrium position and value of Kc will not be changed.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The value of the Kcdepends on the relative activation energies of the forward and reverse reactions

question_html: Which statement best describes the effect of a catalyst?

MCQ_set.answer_html: A catalyst affects both the rate of the forward reaction and the reverse equally, therefore, has no effect on the position of equilibrium
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A system at equilibrium, when subjected to a change, will shift the position of equilibrium in order to minimise the affect of the change (Le Chatelier's principle).
