If you increase the temperature, it will shift in the endothermic direction, if you increase pressure it will shift to where there are fewer moles of gas/species, and if you add a species it will shift to use up this species and vice versa, all in order to minimise the effect of the change.

MCQ_set.answer_html: A catalyst favours the forward reaction therefore the position of equilibrium will shift towards the products
A catalyst favours the reverse reaction therefore the position of equilibrium will shift towards the reactants
The reaction which the catalyst favours is dependent on the relative activation energies of the forward and reverse reaction

question_html: Which of the following statements best describes Le Chatelier's principle?

MCQ_set.answer_html: A system at equilibrium, when subjected to a change, will shift the position of equilibrium in order to minimise the effect of the change
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A system at equilibrium, when subjected to a change, will shift the position of equilibrium in order to minimise the effect of the change (Le Chatelier's principle). If you increase the temperature, it will shift in the endothermic direction, if you increase pressure it will shift to where there are fewer moles of gas/species, and if you add a species it will shift to use up this species and vice versa, all in order to minimise the effect of the change.

MCQ_set.answer_html: A system before it reaches equilibrium, when subjected to a change, will shift the position of equilibrium in order to minimise the effect of the change
A system at equilibrium, when subjected to a change, will shift the position of equilibrium in order to maximise the effect of the change
A system before it reaches equilibrium, when subjected to a change, will shift the position of equilibrium in order to maximise the effect of the change

question_html: Which characteristic of a chemical reaction at equilibrium does the graph below illustrate?

MCQ_set.answer_html: the rate of the forward reaction is equal to the rate of the reverse reaction
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: When the rate of the forward reaction equals the rate of the reverse reaction, the reaction is at equilibrium. This is shown on the graph above as the point where the two lines meet.

MCQ_set.answer_html: the rate of the forward reaction is greater than the rate of the reverse reaction

question_html: Which feature of dynamic equilibrium does the graph below illustrate once equilibrium is reached?

MCQ_set.answer_html: The concentrations of reactants and products are constant
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Where the rate of the forward reaction is equal to the rate of reverse (the reaction is at equilibrium), the concentrations of reactants and products remain constant.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The rate of the forward reaction is greater than the rate of the reverse reaction
The concentrations of reactants and products are equal
There is a change in the macroscopic properties

question_html: Which of the following is correct for a reaction at equilibrium?

MCQ_set.answer_html: The rate of the forward reaction is equal to the rate of the reverse reaction and the macroscopic properties remain constant
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: At equilibrium, the rate of the forward reaction is equal to the rate of the reverse reaction and the macroscopic properties (such as colour) remain constant.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The rate of the forward reaction is greater than the rate of the reverse reaction and the macroscopic properties remain constant
The rate of the forward reaction is equal to the rate of the reverse reaction and the macroscopic properties are constantly changing
The rate of the reverse reaction is greater than the rate of the forward reaction and the macroscopic properties remain constant

question_html: A catalyst increases the rate of reaction as it:

MCQ_set.answer_html: provides an alternative pathway of lower activation energy so more particles have E ≥ Ea
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A catalyst provides an alternative pathway of lower activation energy so more particles then have E ≥ Ea. This results in an increase in the frequency of successful collisions between reactant particles and a higher rate of reaction.

MCQ_set.answer_html: provides an alternative pathway of higher activation energy so more particles have E ≥ Ea
provides an alternative pathway of lower activation energy so fewer particles have E ≥ Ea
provides an alternative pathway of higher activation energy so fewer particles have E ≥ Ea

section_title: Collision theory and rates of reaction

question_html: If the pressure of a gaseous reaction is decreased, what effect will it have on the rate of reaction?

MCQ_set.answer_html: The rate of reaction will decrease as there is a lower frequency of collisions between reactant particles
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: If the pressure of a gaseous reaction is decreased, the frequency of collisions between reactant particle will decrease and the rate of reaction will also decrease.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The rate of reaction will increase as there is a higher frequency of collisions between reactant particles
The rate of reaction will increase as there is a lower frequency of collisions between reactant particles
The rate of reaction will decrease as there is a higher frequency of collisions between reactant particles

section_title: Collision theory and rates of reaction

question_html: If you increase the concentration of a reactant, what effect does it have on the rate of reaction?

MCQ_set.answer_html: The rate of reaction increases as there are more particles per unit volume and a higher frequency of successful collisions between reactant particles
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: There are more particles in the same volume and they are more likely to collide so there is a higher frequency of successful collisions between reactant particles and a higher rate of reaction.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The rate of reaction decreases as there are more particles per unit volume and a higher frequency of successful collisions between reactant particles
The rate of reaction increases as there are more particles per unit volume and a lower frequency of successful collisions between reactant particles
The rate of reaction decreases as there are more particles per unit volume and a lower frequency of successful collisions between reactant particles

section_title: Collision theory and rates of reaction

question_html: What is the effect on the rate of reaction for a reaction involving gaseous reactants and products when the pressure is decreased?

MCQ_set.answer_html: The rate of reaction decreases as the particles are further apart
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: There are fewer particles in the same volume, therefore, they are less likely to collide and so there are fewer collisions per unit time. It is effectively the same as lowering the concentration of a reactant in reactions that take place in aqueous solution.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The rate of reaction increases as the particles are further apart
The rate of reaction decreases as the particles are closer together
The rate of reaction increases as the particles are closer together

section_title: Collision theory and rates of reaction

question_html: If the pressure of a gaseous reaction is increased, what effect will it have on the rate of reaction?

MCQ_set.answer_html: the rate of reaction increases as the particles are closer together
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: There are more particles in the same volume, therefore, they are more likely to collide and so there are more collisions per time period. It is effectively the same as increasing the concentration of a reactant in reactions taking place in solution.

MCQ_set.answer_html: the rate of reaction decreases as the particles are further apart
the rate of reaction increases as the particles are further apart
the rate of reaction decreases as the particles are closer together

section_title: Collision theory and rates of reaction

question_html:
Which of the following factors determine whether a collision between reactant particles will be a  successful collision?

I. particles must collide with kinetic energy ≥ Ea

II. particles must collide with correct orientation

III. particles must collide with kinetic energy ≤ Ea

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Collision theory states that the factors that determine if a collision is successful or not are that the particles must collide with the correct orientation and that the particles must collide with KE ≥ Ea.

section_title: Collision theory and rates of reaction

question_html:
According to collision theory, which of the following factors affect the rate of reaction? 

I. Number of particles with KE ≥ Ea

II. The geometry of collisions 

III. The frequency of collisions

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Collision theory states that the factors that affect the rate of reaction are the geometry of collisions, that the particles collide with KE ≥ Ea, and the frequency of collisions.

section_title: Collision theory and rates of reaction

question_html: Which of the following factors causes an increase in the rate of a reaction when the temperature is increased?

MCQ_set.answer_html: An increase in the number of particles with KE ≥ Ea
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Temperature is proportional to the average kinetic energy of the particles. Increasing the temperature increases the average kinetic energy, therefore, more particles have KE ≥ Ea which leads to an increase in the rate of reaction.

MCQ_set.answer_html: An increase in the number of particles with energy ≤ Ea
A decrease in the rate of collisions between reactant particles

section_title: Collision theory and rates of reaction

question_html: Which of the following explains why the rate of reaction increases when the temperature is increased?

MCQ_set.answer_html: the frequency of collisions increases and the collisions are more energetic
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: An increase in temperature increases the rate of reaction as the particles collide with higher frequency and have more energetic collisions (collide with higher energy), so it is more likely that there will be a successful collision.

MCQ_set.answer_html: the frequency of collisions decreases and the collisions are more energetic
the frequency of collisions increases and the collisions are less energetic
the frequency of collisions decreases and the collisions are less energetic

section_title: Collision theory and rates of reaction

question_html: Which of the following is the best definition of activation energy?

MCQ_set.answer_html: the minimum amount of energy that particles must possess for a collision that results in a chemical reaction
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Activation energy (Ea) is defined as the minimum amount of energy that particles must possess for a collision to result in a chemical reaction. It can be thought of as the energy barrier to the reaction; only particles with kinetic energy equal to, or greater than, the activation energy will react.

MCQ_set.answer_html: the maximum amount of energy that particles must possess for a collision to result in a reaction
the minimum amount of energy that particles must possess for a collision
the maximum amount of energy that particles must possess for a collision

section_title: Collision theory and rates of reaction

question_html: The [X] increases from 0.60 mol dm-3 to 0.75 mol dm-3 in 30 seconds. Calculate the average rate of reaction.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Rate of reaction = change in concentration / time = (0.75 – 0.60) / 30 = 0.005 mol dm-3 s-1

section_title: Collision theory and rates of reaction

question_html: In a reaction, the concentration of reactant X decreases from 1.0 mol dm-3 to 0.50 mol dm-3 in 10.0 seconds. Calculate the average rate of reaction.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Average rate of reaction = change in concentration / time = 0.50 / 10.0 = 0.050 mol dm-3 s-1

section_title: Collision theory and rates of reaction

question_html: If a reaction has a positive enthalpy change (+ΔH) and a decrease in entropy (–ΔS) what is the temperature dependence of ΔG?

MCQ_set.answer_html: The reaction is never spontaneous, irrespective of temperature
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
ΔG = ΔH – TΔS

ΔH is positive and ΔS is negative, so the TΔS term is negative as well; however –TΔS must be positive. Therefore, ΔG will always be positive, irrespective of temperature. As the temperature increases, the TΔS component becomes more dominant, but as T decreases, it becomes less dominant; however, the reaction will never be spontaneous.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The reaction is spontaneous at all temperatures
As T increases, the reaction becomes spontaneous
As T decreases, the reaction becomes spontaneous

question_html:
If a reaction has a negative enthalpy change, ΔH, and a negative entropy change, ΔS, what is the temperature dependence of ΔG?

ΔG = ΔH - TΔS

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: ΔG will be negative only at low temperatures; at high T, (TΔS), when subtracted from the negative ΔH, makes ΔG positive.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The reaction is spontaneous at all temperatures
As temperature increases, the reaction becomes spontaneous

question_html: If, for a reaction, the ΔH = –150 kJ mol-1 and the ΔS = 2500 J K-1 mol-1, calculate the ΔG for the reaction at 60 °C.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
ΔG = ΔH – TΔS where T must be in kelvin and ΔS must be converted from J K-1 mol-1 to kJ K-1 mol-1. 

ΔG = –150 – (333 × 2.500) = –982.5 kJ mol-1

question_html: Calculate the ΔG for a reaction (in kJ mol-1) at 34°C that has ΔH = –200 kJ mol-1 and ΔS = 2000 J K-1 mol-1.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
ΔG = ΔH – TΔS where T is in kelvin and ΔS must be converted from J K-1 mol-1 to kJ K-1 mol-1.

ΔG = –200 – (307 × 2.00) = –814 kJ mol-1

question_html: What thermodynamic condition must be fulfilled if a reaction is to be spontaneous?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: For a reaction to be spontaneous the ΔG must be negative.

question_html: Which of the following has the highest entropy?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Gases have the highest entropy of solids, liquids and aqueous solutions.

question_html: An increase in entropy is indicated by which of the following changes?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Evaporation represents an increase in entropy as gases have higher entropy than liquids. Condensation and deposition both represent a decrease in entropy as solids and liquids have lower entropy than gases.

question_html:
Using the enthalpy cycle below, determine the enthalpy change (ΔH) for the reaction:

                                                             CH4 + H2O  →  CO +  3H2

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Using Hess' Law, when the arrow opposes the direction you wish to go, then reverse the sign of the enthalpy change. Then add together the values:

–1246 + 452  = –794 kJ mol-1

The enthalpy on the left hand down arrow is the enthalpy of combustion of methane; the right hand arrow is the sum of the enthalpies of combustion of CO and H2.

question_html: In the energy cycle below for calculating the enthalpy of formation of propanoic acid, what type of enthalpies have been provided on the arrows?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The reactions with enthalpy values provided are those of the reactants and products of the top reaction burnt with an excess of oxygen. The values given are enthalpies of combustion which is defined as the enthalpy change when a substance is burnt in excess oxygen under standard conditions.

question_html: Using the enthalpy cycle below, determine the enthalpy of formation of propanoic acid, C2H5COOH.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Using Hess's law, the enthalpy change involving multiple steps can be determined. Where the arrow opposes the direction you wish to go then reverse the sign. Then add together the final values:

–458 kJ mol-1 + 177 kJ mol-1 = –281 kJ mol-1

question_html:
Using the enthalpy of formation values given in the table, calculate the enthalpy change of the following reaction.

CaCO3 (s) → CaO (s) + CO2 (g)

Compound Enthalpy of formation / kJ mol-1
CaCO3 –1207
CaO –636
CO2 –394

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Use the values in the table and the following equation: 

ΔH (reaction) = ∑ (ΔHf  products) – ∑ (ΔHf  reactants)

Substitute in the values, remembering to note the coefficient of each substance in the equation.

ΔH (reaction) = –1030 – (–1207) =  + 177 kJ mol-1

question_html:
Using the enthalpy of formation values given in the table, calculate the enthalpy change of reaction, ΔH, for the following reaction. 

3Mg (s) + NaClO3 (aq) → 3MgO (s) + NaCl (aq)

Substance  Enthalpy of formation / kJ mol-1
Mg 0
NaClO3 –50
NaCl –199
MgO –145

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Use the values in the table and the equation: 

ΔH (reaction) = ∑ (ΔHf  products) – ∑ (ΔHf  reactants).

Substitute in the values, remembering to note the number of moles of each substance in the equation.

ΔH (reaction) = (3 × –145 + –199) – (–50) = –584 kJ mol-1

question_html:
What type of enthalpy change does the following equation represent?
                                                    CH4 (g) + 2O2 (g) → CO2 (g) + 2H2O (l)

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: This equation shows the combustion of one mole of methane, therefore, it corresponds to the definition of enthalpy change of combustion - the enthalpy change when one mole of a substance is burnt completely in oxygen under standard conditions.

question_html:
Which enthalpy change does the following statement define?

'The enthalpy change when one mole of substance is burnt completely in oxygen under standard conditions.'

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The statement is the definition of the standard enthalpy of combustion, ΔHƟc. It is the enthalpy change when one mole of substance is burnt completely in oxygen under standard conditions.

question_html: Which of the following pairs of ions would result in the most endothermic lattice enthalpy?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The higher the charge on the ions, the more strongly they will attract one another and so the higher the lattice enthalpy. The ionic radius of aluminum is smaller than the other ions, so this also contributes to the more endothermic lattice enthalpy.

question_html: The enthalpy change when one mole of electrons are added to one mole of gaseous atoms under standard conditions is known as which of the following?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: This is the definition of first electron affinity; the enthalpy change when one mole of electrons are added to one mole of gaseous atoms under standard conditions.

question_html: The enthalpy change when one mole of electrons is removed from one mole of gaseous atoms under standard conditions defines which of the following?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: This is the definition of first ionisation energy; the enthalpy change when one mole of electrons is removed from one mole of gaseous atoms under standard conditions.

question_html: In a voltaic cell, which is the correct direction for the flow of electrons?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: In a voltaic cell, electrons flow from the anode (the negative electrode) to the cathode (the positive electrode).

MCQ_set.answer_html: from the salt bridge to the anode
from the cathode to the salt bridge

question_html:
Determine the sum of the coefficients in the balanced redox equation in acidic solution.

__H+ (aq) + __Cr2O72– (aq) + __I– (aq) → __Cr3+ (aq) + __I2 (aq) + __H2O (l)

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
The balanced redox equation in acidic solution is:

14H+ (aq) + Cr2O72– (aq) + 6I– (aq) → 2Cr3+ (aq) + 3I2 (aq) + 7H2O (l)

The two half-equations before combining are:

6e– + 14H+ (aq) + Cr2O72– (aq) → 2Cr3+ (aq) + 7H2O (l)

6I– (aq) → 3I2 (aq) + 6e–

When the electrons are canceled out and the two half-equations are combined, we get the balanced equation shown above. The sum of the coefficients is 33 (including the 1 in front of the Cr2O72– ion).

question_html: Which equation illustrates reduction?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Oxidation is the loss of electrons. Reduction is gain of electrons. The electron should be written as "+ e- " by convention not "- e- ". Remember the mnemonic 'OILRIG'.

question_html: Which equation illustrates the oxidation of a chromium atom?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Oxidation is the loss of electrons - the electrons are written on the right side of the equation. Note the correct use of state symbols for the Cr atom and the Cr3+ ion in solution.

question_html: Determine the enthalpy change for a reaction when the sum of the bonds broken have ΔH = 175 kJ and the sum of the bonds formed have ΔH = 325 kJ.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
The equation used here is:

ΔH = ∑ (bonds broken) – ∑ (bonds formed)

ΔH = (175) – (325)

ΔH = –150 kJ

question_html:
Using the table provided, determine the enthalpy change for the following reaction:

C2H4 (g) + H2O (g) → C2H5OH (l)

Bond Bond enthalpy/ kJ mol-1
C-C 347
C=C 612
O-H 464
C-O 358
C-H 414

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
ΔH = ∑ (bonds broken) – ∑ (bonds formed). The bonds broken are 4 C-H, 1 C=C and 2 O-H. The bonds formed are 5 C-H, 1 C-C, 1 C-O and 1 O-H.

ΔH = 3196 – 3239 = –43 kJ mol-1

question_html: Use the enthalpy cycle to calculate the change in enthalpy (ΔH) for the reaction: A + B → C + D.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Using Hess's Law, ΔH1 = ΔH2 + ΔH3, the enthalpy change can be calculated. Be careful, you must change 10 kJ mol-1 into -10 kJ mol-1 as you are using the reverse reaction.

ΔH1 = ΔH2 + ΔH3

ΔH1 = 500 + (–10) = 490 kJ mol-1

question_html:
Use the enthalpy cycle below to calculate the change in enthalpy (ΔH) for the reaction:

A + B → C + D

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Using Hess's Law, ΔH1 = ΔH2 + ΔH3, the enthalpy change can be calculated. Be careful, you must change +160 kJ into –160 kJ as you are using the reverse reaction.

ΔH1 = ΔH2 + ΔH3

ΔH1 = –260 + (–160) = -420 kJ

question_html: Use the enthalpy cycle below to calculate the ΔH for the reaction C + D → A + B.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Using Hess's Law: ΔH1 = ΔH2 + ΔH3. 

ΔH1 = 350 + (–450)

 ΔH1 = –100 kJ mol-1

Note that the sign of the 450 kJ is reversed as we go against the arrow to get from E + F to A + B.

question_html: Use the enthalpy cycle to calculate the change in enthalpy (ΔH) for the reaction: A + B → C + D

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Using Hess's Law, ΔH1 = ΔH2 + ΔH3, the enthalpy change can be calculated. Be careful, you must change 350 kJ to –350 kJ as you are using the reverse reaction.

ΔH1 = ΔH2 + ΔH3

ΔH1 = 450 + (–350) = 100 kJ mol-1

question_html: Which of the following represents the equation for the bond enthalpy of the H-I bond in hydrogen iodide (HI)?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Bond enthalpy is defined as the energy required to break one mol of bonds in the gaseous state, therefore, all species must be in the gaseous state (g).

question_html: Which of the following bond enthalpies is not an average bond enthalpy?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The H-H bond is only found between the hydrogen atoms in H2, therefore, it is not an average bond enthalpy. The other bonds are found in a range of different compounds and can be considered to be average bond enthalpies.

question_html: The average amount of energy required to break one mole of covalent bonds in a gaseous molecule under standard conditions describes which of the following?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: the average amount of energy required to break one mole of covalent bonds in a gaseous molecule under standard conditions. The idea of an average is key as the value is determined by calculating the enthalpy of one type of bond in many different molecules.

question_html: What is the best definition of average bond enthalpy?

MCQ_set.answer_html: the average amount of energy required to break one mole of covalent bonds in the gaseous state
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The idea of an average value is important as the value is determined by calculating the enthalpy of the same type of bond in many different molecules (in the gaseous state) and finding the average value.

MCQ_set.answer_html: the average amount of energy required to break one mole of covalent bonds
the amount of energy required to break one mole of covalent bonds in the gaseous state
the average amount of energy required to break one mole of ionic bonds in the gaseous state

question_html: Which statement best defines specific heat capacity, c?

MCQ_set.answer_html: the energy required to raise the temperature of one unit mass of substance by 1 degree (K or oC)
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: This is the definition of specific heat capacity. Note that the temperature can be in either Kelvin or Celsius.

MCQ_set.answer_html: the energy required to raise the temperature of 1 mol of substance by 1 K
the energy required to raise the temperature of 1 dm3 of a substance by 1 K
the energy required to raise the temperature of 1 dm3 of a substance by 1oC

question_html:
The following data was collected for a reaction taking place in an aqueous solution:

ΔT of solution = –5.00 oC

which of the following is correct for the change in temperature and the enthalpy change, ΔH?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The decrease in temperature shows that the reaction is endothermic. An endothermic reaction is one where energy is absorbed from the surroundings to the system resulting in a decrease in temperature of the surroundings (the aqueous solution) and is shown by a positive sign for the ΔH.

question_html:
The following data was collected for a reaction taking place in an aqueous solution:

ΔT of solution = +12.0 oC  

which of the following is correct for the change in temperature and the enthalpy change, ΔH?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The increase in temperature shows that this reaction is exothermic. An exothermic reaction is one where energy is released from the system to the surroundings resulting in a temperature increase and a negative value for the ΔH. Note that when a reaction is carried out in an aqueous solution, the solution itself is the surroundings.

question_html:
Calculate the value of q, the heat released in a calorimetry experiment, given the following information:

c H2O  = 4.18 J g-1 oC-1

ΔT of water in calorimeter = 3.00 oC

volume of water in calorimeter  = 20.0 cm3

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
The density of water is 1g cm-3, therefore, 20.0 cm3 = 20.0 g.

Using the equation q = mcΔT 

q = 20.0 × 4.18 × 3.00 = 251 J (rounded to 3 significant figures)

question_html:
Calculate the value of m (in g) given the following information:

c = 4.2 J g-1 oC-1

ΔT = 2.0 oC 

q = 8.0 J

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Rearrange q = mcΔT to solve for m:

m = q/(cΔT); then substitute in the values given:

m = 8.0 / (4.2 × 2.0) =  0.95 g

question_html:
Calculate the value of the specific heat capacity, c, given the following information:

q = 4.20 J

ΔT = 2.00 oC

m = 2.00 g

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Rearrange q = mcΔT to c = q/(mΔT) and then substitute in the values given:

c = 4.20 / (2.00 × 2.00) = 1.05 J g-1 oC-1

question_html: To what does the c refer to in the equation q=mcΔT?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: In the equation q=mcΔT, c refers to the specific heat capacity of the substance.

question_html: Deduce from the enthalpy level profile below the relative energetic stabilities of the products and reactants and the sign of the ΔH.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The reactants are more energetically stable than the products and ΔH = positive
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The reactants are lower in potential energy/enthalpy than the products; they are more energetically stable than the products. An endothermic reaction is one where energy is absorbed from the surroundings and has a positive enthalpy change, therefore ΔH = positive.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The products are more energetically stable than the reactants and ΔH = negative
The reactants are more energetically stable than the products and ΔH = negative

question_html: Deduce from the enthalpy level profile below the relative energetic stabilities of the products and reactants and the sign of the ΔH.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The products are more energetically stable than the reactants and ΔH = negative
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: An exothermic reaction is one where heat is released to the surroundings and is denoted by ΔH = negative. The products have lower enthalpy than the reactants and are also more stable than the reactants.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The reactants are more energetically stable than the products and ΔH = positive
The reactants are more energetically stable than the products and ΔH = negative

question_html: Which of the following set of conditions are required to measure the standard enthalpy change (ΔHƟ) of a reaction?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The standard enthalpy change  (ΔHƟ) is the enthalpy change measured under standard conditions - a pressure of 100 kPa (1 × 105 Pa), and a temperature of 298 K. Be careful not to confuse these conditions of STP (273 K and 1 × 105 Pa).

question_html: Which of the following is correct about a neutralisation reaction between hydrochloric acid (HCl) and sodium hydroxide (NaOH)?

MCQ_set.answer_html: An increase in the temperature of the solution is recorded and ΔH = negative
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A neutralisation reaction is always exothermic - the temperature of the solution (the surroundings) increases and the enthalpy change is negative.

MCQ_set.answer_html: A decrease in the temperature of the solution is recorded and ΔH = negative
An increase in the temperature of the solution is recorded and ΔH = positive
A decrease in the temperature of the solution is recorded and ΔH = positive

question_html:
Which of the following is correct about the following reaction?

CH4 (g) + 2O2 (g) → CO2 (g) + 2H2O (l)

MCQ_set.answer_html: Heat is lost from the system and ΔH = negative
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A combustion reaction is always exothermic. In an exothermic reaction, heat is lost from the system to the surroundings and ΔH = negative.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Heat is lost from the system and ΔH = positive
Heat is gained by the system and ΔH = negative
Heat is gained by the system and ΔH = positive

question_html: Which statement best describes an exothermic reaction?

MCQ_set.answer_html: A chemical reaction that results in the release of energy to the surroundings
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: An exothermic reaction is one where energy is released to the surroundings from the system  and is denoted by ΔH = negative.

MCQ_set.answer_html: A chemical reaction that results in energy being taken in from the surroundings
A chemical reaction that results in the release of energy to the system
A chemical reaction that results in energy being taken in by the system

question_html: In coloured transition metal complexes, where are electrons promoted between?

MCQ_set.answer_html: lower set of d orbitals to higher set of d orbitals
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: When ligands bond to the central metal ion, the d orbitals split into two sets, one set of higher energy and one set of lower energy. The d electrons absorb light and are promoted from the lower energy to higher energy d orbitals.

MCQ_set.answer_html: higher set of d orbitals to lower set of d orbitals
higher set of p orbitals to lower set of p orbitals
lower set of p orbitals to higher set of p orbitals

question_html: Using the diagram below, deduce if this complex ion is coloured.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: For visible light energy to be absorbed, an electron must be promoted between the split d sub-levels. This means that the d sub-level must be partially filled (there must be at least one half-filled d orbital). In this complex ion, the d sub-level is completely full, therefore, an electron cannot transition from the lower set to the higher set of d orbitals.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Depends on the energy gap between the two sets of d orbitals
Depends on the oxidation state of the central metal ion

question_html: Which catalyst is used in the hydrogenation of the alkenes?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Hydrogenation of alkenes to form alkanes requires a nickel (Ni) catalyst. The reaction is also carried out at high temperatures and pressures.

question_html: The formation of coloured complex compounds requires which of the following?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: For visible light to be absorbed, an electron must be promoted between the two sets of d orbitals. In order for this to occur the d sub-level must be partially filled.

MCQ_set.answer_html: a transition metal with an oxidation state of +2

question_html: From which region of the electromagnetic spectrum must light be absorbed for a compound to appear coloured?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: For a substance to appear coloured it must absorb light in the visible region of the electromagnetic spectrum.

question_html: Which oxidation state is commonly shown by all first-row transition elements, with the exception of scandium?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: All transition metals in period 4, with the exception of scandium, exhibit a +2 oxidation state. The common oxidation state of scandium is +3.

question_html: Which of the following atoms is considered a transition element?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A transition element is an element whose atom has an incomplete d sub-shell, or which can give rise to cations with an incomplete d sub-shell. Of these four choices here, only copper fits this description.

question_html: Which of the following metals will form coloured complexes?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Transition metals exhibit specific characteristics. They are typical metals (high melting points and densities), exist in multiple oxidation states, have coloured compounds, and the complex ions they form can act as catalysts.

question_html:
Which of the following are characteristics of transition metals?

I. form coloured compounds

II. have only one oxidation state

III. have high melting points

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Transition metals exhibit specific characteristics. They are typical metals (have high melting points), have variable oxidation states (not only one) and form coloured compounds.

question_html: Why is zinc not considered to be a transition element?

MCQ_set.answer_html: It does not have a partially filled d sub-level as an atom or ion
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Transition elements have an incomplete filled d-level of electrons by definition. Zn is not a transition element since neither the metal, with the electron configuration [Ar]4s2 3d10, nor the dipositive ion (the most common oxidation state of zinc) with the electron configuration [Ar]3d10 have an incomplete d sub-level.

question_html: Which of the following d-block elements is not considered to be a transition element?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Transition elements have an incomplete d sub-level of electrons as either an atom or a positive ion. Zn is not a transition element since neither the atom, with configuration [Ar] 4s23d10, nor the ion (Zn2+) with the electron configuration [Ar] 3d10 have an incomplete d sub-level.

question_html:
Which of the following can act as ligands? 

I. NH3

II. Cl–

III. CH4

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: To act as a ligand a species must have a lone pair of electrons to form a coordinate covalent bond with the central metal ion. CH4 cannot act as a ligand as there are no lone pairs of electrons on the carbon atom. Both NH3 and Cl– have lone pairs of electrons and can act as ligands.

question_html: What type of bond forms between a ligand and a central metal ion?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: As the ligand donates a lone pair of electrons, both electrons in the bond between the metal ion and the ligand originate from the ligand. The bond formed is a coordinate covalent bond.

question_html: Which of the following statements about ligands is correct?

MCQ_set.answer_html: A negative ion or neutral species which uses its lone pairs of electrons to form a coordinate covalent bond to a metal ion
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Ligands are species that are neutral molecules or negative ions that form coordinate covalent bonds with central metal ions, forming a complex ion.

MCQ_set.answer_html: A negative ion or neutral species which uses its lone pairs of electrons to form an ionic bond to a metal ion
A negative ion or neutral species which uses its lone pairs of electrons to form a metallic bond to a metal ion
A negative ion or neutral species which uses its lone pairs of electrons to form a hydrogen bond to a metal ion

question_html: Which of the following is the correct structure of silicon dioxide, SiO2?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The structure of SiO2 is much like diamond in that it has a giant covalent structure. This means that the atoms are bonded by covalent bonds but do not form individual molecules (such as H2O or CO2, for example).

question_html: Determine which of the following would cause an electron to transition from a lower to a higher energy level.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Passing an electric current through a sample of the element
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Passing an electric current through a sample of the element will cause the transition of an electron from a lower to a higher energy level. When electrons absorb energy, they transition to higher energy levels (in the form of light, heat or electrical energy). When electrons release energy, they transition to lower energy levels.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The bonding of two atoms to form a diatomic molecule

question_html: Deduce the wavelength of the electromagnetic radiation emitted when an electron transitions from a higher energy level to the second main energy level (n = 2).

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Visible light is emitted when an electron transitions from a higher energy level to the second main energy level (n = 2). UV is emitted when an electron transitions to the first main energy level (n = 1) and IR is emitted when an electron transitions to the third main energy level (n = 3).

question_html: Deduce the region that corresponds to the wavelength of the electromagnetic radiation emitted when an electron transitions from a higher energy level to the first main energy level (n = 1).

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: UV radiation is emitted when an electron transitions from a higher energy level to the first main energy level (n = 1).

question_html: After the 8th ionisation of an atom, no electrons remain. What is the element?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The 8th ionisation energy refers to the removal of the 8th electron; if no more electrons remain then there must have been only 8 electrons in the original atom. Oxygen only has 8 electrons.

question_html:
Deduce which of the following periodic trends increases across a period in the periodic table (from left to right).

I. Electron shielding
II. Ionisation energy
III. Nuclear charge
IV. Atomic radius

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: As the number of occupied energy levels does not increase across a period, there is little change in electron shielding. Ionisation energies increase due to increasing nuclear charge across the period. The atomic radius decreases across the period as the electrons are held more tightly due to the increasing nuclear charge.

question_html: Which of the following explains the decrease in first ionisation energy from nitrogen to oxygen?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Repulsion between electrons in a doubly occupied p orbital
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The electron removed from oxygen is in a doubly occupied p orbital. Repulsion between the two electrons means that it requires less energy to remove than an electron in a singly occupied p orbital (such as that found in nitrogen).

MCQ_set.answer_html: Electrons in the 2p sub-level require less energy to remove than electrons in the 2s sub-level
Repulsion between electrons in a doubly occupied s orbital
Electrons in the 2s sub-level require less energy to remove than electrons in the 2p sub-level

question_html: What is the variation in ionisation energies across a period?

MCQ_set.answer_html: the general trend is that the ionisation energy increases from left to right across a period
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: As you move across the period, the nuclear charge increases but the amount of electron shielding remains fairly stable. This electrons are held more tightly as you move across the period and so the ionisation energy increases.

MCQ_set.answer_html: the general trend is that the ionisation energy decreases from left to right across a period
there is very little change in ionisation energies as you go across a period
the general trend is that the ionisation energy increases and then decreases from left to right across a period

question_html: What is the trend in ionisation energy down a group in the periodic table?

MCQ_set.answer_html: the ionisation energy decreases down a group
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: As the size of the atom increases down the group, the outer electrons are further away from the nucleus and thus are not held as tightly. Less energy is therefore required to removed the outer electrons and so down a group the ionisation energy decreases.

MCQ_set.answer_html: the ionisation energy increases down a group
the ionisation energy fluctuates down a group
the ionisation energy remains fairly constant down a group

question_html:
The following equation represents which process?

M–(g) + e– → M2–(g)

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Affinity refers to the strength of attraction between two substances. Thus adding an electron to an atom gives the electron affinity. The higher the value, the less easy it is to add the electron. As the electron is being added to a negative species, it is the second affinity as it is the second electron to be added.

question_html:
The following equation represents which process?

M(g) → M+(g) + e–

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Ionisation refers to the removal of electrons from an atom. It is the first ionisation energy as the electron is being removed from a neutral atom.

question_html:
The following equation represents which process?

M(g) + e– → M–(g)

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Affinity refers to the strength of attraction between two substances. Thus adding an electron to an atom gives the electron affinity. The higher the value, the less easy it is to add the electron.

question_html: What is the relationship between the first and second ionisation energies of an element?

MCQ_set.answer_html: the second ionisation energy is generally higher than the first
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The higher energy electrons are removed first and so once an electron has been removed, this creates a positive ion. Outer electrons are attracted more strongly to by the positively charged ion and so are harder to remove thus more energy is required. Group 2 elements are an exception to this observation.

MCQ_set.answer_html: the first ionisation energy is negative but the second is always positive
the first ionisation energy is higher than the second ionisation energy
the second ionisation energy is exothermic but the first ionisation is endothermic

question_html: Identify the element with the following electron configuration: 1s2 2s2 2p6 3s2 3p4.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: s, p, and d sub-levels are filled up in successive order only once the lowest energy level has been filled. s orbitals hold a maximum of 2 electrons, the p sub-level can hold a maximum of 6 electrons and the d sub-level can hold a maximum of 10 electrons. The elements in the first 3 periods have only s and p orbitals and so their outer shells can hold a maximum of 8 electrons. But from the 4th period onwards, there are also d orbitals, therefore, up to 18 valence electrons are possible.

question_html: Identify the element with the following electron configuration: [Ar] 3d10 4s1.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
s, p,and d sub-levels are filled up in successive order only once the lowest energy level has been filled. s orbitals hold a maximum of 2 electrons, the p sub-level can hold a maximum of 6 electrons and the d sub-level can hold a maximum of 10 electrons. The elements in the first 3 periods have only s and p orbitals and so their outer shells can hold a maximum of 8 electrons. But from the 4th period onwards, there are also d orbitals, therefore, up to 18 valence electrons are possible.

The electron configuration of copper is an exception (4s is not completely filled), which is one that you must be aware of.

question_html: Identify the element with the following electron configuration: [Ar] 3d10 4s2 4p1.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: s, p,and d sub-levels are filled up in successive order only once the lowest energy level has been filled. s orbitals hold a maximum of 2 electrons, the p sub-level can hold a maximum of 6 electrons and the d sub-level can hold a maximum of 10 electrons. The elements in the first 3 periods have only s and p orbitals and so their outer shells can hold a maximum of 8 electrons. But from the 4th period onwards, there are also d orbitals, therefore, up to 18 valence electrons are possible.

question_html: Identify the element with the following electron configuration: 1s2 2s2 2p5

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: s, p,and d sub-levels are filled up in successive order only once the lowest energy level has been filled. s orbitals hold a maximum of 2 electrons, the p sub-level can hold a maximum of 6 electrons and the d sub-level can hold a maximum of 10 electrons. The elements in the first 3 periods have only s and p orbitals and so their outer shells can hold a maximum of 8 electrons. But from the 4th period onwards, there are also d orbitals, therefore, up to 18 valence electrons are possible.

question_html: Determine the maximum number of electrons that can be held in the d sub-level.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The d sub-level is composed of 5 atomic orbitals which can each hold a maximum of 2 electrons. When completely full, the d sub-level can hold  a maximum of 10 electrons.

question_html: Determine the maximum number of electrons that can be held in a single p atomic orbital.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: An individual p atomic orbital can hold up to a maximum of 2 electrons. The p sub-level is composed of three p atomic orbitals which gives a maximum of 6 electrons in the p sub-level.

question_html: Deduce which letter represents the atomic orbital from which electrons are removed when cobalt forms a 2+ ion (Co2+).

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Cobalt is a transition metal found in the first row of the d-block in the periodic table. Applying the Aufbau principle, the 4s sub-level fills first, followed by the 3d sub-level. When transition metals lose electrons to form positive ions, the electrons are lost from the 4s sub-level first, followed by the 3d sub-level.

question_html: Identify the correct order of atomic orbitals in decreasing energy (highest to lowest).

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The s orbital is has the lowest energy followed by the p orbital. The d orbitals are found in transition metals and f is the highest energy level atomic orbital. The correct order of increasing energy is s < p < d < f.

question_html: Identify the two types of atomic orbital shown in the diagram below.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The p orbitals are made up so two distinct regions at 180 degrees to one another. The s orbitals are spherical and contain only one distinct region.

question_html: Identify the type of atomic orbital shown in the diagram below.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: s atomic orbitals are spherical (circular when drawn in 2D).

question_html: The Pauli exclusion principle states which of the following?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Only two electrons can occupy the same atomic orbital and they must have opposite spins
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The Pauli exclusion principles states that only two electrons can occupy the same atomic orbital and they must have opposite spins. This is represented by arrows in boxes, with one arrow pointing upwards and one arrow pointing downwards.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Only two electrons can occupy the same atomic orbital and they must have the same spin
Electrons fill lowest energy atomic orbitals first

question_html: Hund's rule states which of the following?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Electrons occupy degenerate (same energy) atomic orbitals singly with the same spin before doubly occupying each orbital
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: According to Hund's rule, electrons occupy degenerate orbitals singly with the same spin before doubling up. This minimises the repulsion between electrons.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Electrons occupy atomic orbitals of different energies singly with the same spin before doubly occupying each orbital
Electrons occupy degenerate (same energy) atomic orbitals singly with opposite spins before doubly occupying each orbital
Electrons doubly occupy atomic orbitals of different energies with the same spin

question_html: The Aufbau principle states which of the following:

MCQ_set.answer_html: Electrons fill lowest energy atomic orbitals first
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The Aufbau rule states that electrons occupy atomic orbitals with the lowest energy first. The 1s orbital is the lowest energy as it is closest to the nucleus, therefore it fills first. The correct order is: 1s, 2s, 2p, 3s, 3p, 4s, 3d, 4p, 5s, 4d, 5p, etc.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Only two electrons can occupy the same atomic orbital and they must have opposite spins
Only two electrons can occupy the same atomic orbital and they must have the same spin

question_html: Which of the following metals has the highest melting point, Cu, K, Ba, Na?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Copper forms a 2+ ion but sodium and potassium only form 1+ ions. Barium also forms a 2+ ion but has a larger atomic/ionic radius than copper, therefore, the electrons are further away from the nucleus. In addition, copper, being a transition element, is able to use its 3d electrons for bonding which further increases the strength of the metallic bond and the melting point.

question_html: Which of these substances has a regular lattice of positive metal ions in a sea of delocalised electrons?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Given in the question is a definition for metallic bonding. This means the correct answer must be the only option that is a solid metal, which is Sodium (Na). NaCl is an ionic compound, SiO2 has a giant covalent lattice structure and O2 is a simple covalent molecule, so these are all incorrect answers.

question_html: Which of the following group 1 metals has the strongest metallic bond, Li, Na, K or Rb?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: All these metals form 1+ ions; however, the ionic radii increase down the group. This results in a weaker metallic bond between the lattice of positive metal ions and the delocalised electrons. Therefore, the metallic bonding in the metals gets weaker down the group, which results in a decreasing melting point.

question_html: What statement best describes the structure of metals?

MCQ_set.answer_html: A regular lattice of positive metal ions in a sea of delocalised electrons
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Metals consist of a lattice of positive metal ions in a sea of delocalised electrons. This structure gives metals their physical properties such as electrical conductivity.

MCQ_set.answer_html: A regular lattice of negative ions in a sea of delocalised electrons
A regular lattice of alternating positive and negative ions in a sea of delocalised electrons
An irregular lattice of ions surrounded by electrons

question_html: Which is the correct order of intermolecular forces of attraction in terms of increasing relative strength?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Relatively speaking, London dispersion forces are viewed as weaker than dipole-dipole attractions and hydrogen bonding. However, as molecules become increasingly large, the cumulative strength of London dispersion forces can exceed that of hydrogen bonding.

question_html:
Which of the following are allotropes of carbon?

I. Graphite

II. Fullerene C60 

III. Diamond

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Allotropes are different structural forms of the same element. Graphite, fullerene C60 and diamond are all allotropes of carbon. The different bonding and structures give them very different properties.

question_html: Which property of graphite is caused by the presence of delocalised electrons?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The delocalised electrons in graphite allow it to conduct electricity, therefore, it is used to make electrodes for use in electrolytic cells.

question_html: Identify the type(s) of bonds and/or intermolecular forces that are found in diamond.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: In diamond, each carbon atom forms 4 bonds with other carbon atoms resulting in a giant covalent structure, which consists of only covalent bonds. As it is a giant covalent structure, it does not consist of molecules, therefore, it does not have intermolecular forces (neither London dispersion forces nor dipole-dipole forces).

question_html: How many covalent bonds does each carbon atom form in diamond?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Carbon can form up to a maximum of 4 bonds as it has 4 valence electrons. In diamond each carbon atom forms 4 covalent bonds with four other carbon atoms in a tetrahedral arrangement (bond angle 109.5o).

question_html: Fluorine has an electronegativity value of 4.0 and hydrogen has an electronegativity value of 2.2. Which of the following correctly shows the partial charges in the molecule hydrogen fluoride (HF)?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: H is less electronegative than F, therefore, the F-H bond has a dipole, with F = δ- and H = δ+. As the molecule is not symmetrical the molecule is polar. Note that even though the difference in electronegativity is large, the bonding is still covalent as they are non-metal elements.

question_html: Oxygen has an electronegativity value of 3.4 and hydrogen has an electronegativity value of 2.2. Which of the following correctly shows the location of the positive and negative dipoles in a molecule of water (H2O)?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: H is less electronegative than O, therefore, the O-H bond has a dipole, with O = δ- and H = δ+. As the molecule is not symmetrical the molecule is polar.

question_html: Carbon has an electronegativity value of 2.6 and chlorine has an electronegativity value of 3.2. Which of the following correctly shows the location of the positive and negative dipoles in the C-Cl bond?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Cl is more electronegative than C, so the C-Cl bond has a dipole, with C = δ+ and Cl = δ-. The difference in electronegativity is 3.2 -2.6 = 0.6 units which makes it a polar bond.

question_html: On the Pauling scale, carbon has an electronegativity value of 2.6 and fluorine has an electronegativity value of 4.0. Based on this information, which of the following is correct?

MCQ_set.answer_html: CF4 is a non-polar molecule due to the geometry of the molecule
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The difference in electronegativity between carbon and fluorine means that the C-F is a polar bond. CF4 is composed of polar bonds, however due to the tetrahedral arrangement of the fluorine atoms, the bond polarities cancel out.

MCQ_set.answer_html: CF4 is a polar molecule due to the presence of 4 polar bonds
CF4 is a non-polar molecule due to the small difference in electronegativity between carbon and fluorine
CF4 is a polar molecule due to the small difference in electronegativity between carbon and fluorine

question_html: The electronegativity values of S and Cl are 2.6 and 3.2 respectively. The geometry of the molecule is shown below (note that this is not a Lewis structure as it does not show all of the lone pairs of electrons). Based on this information, which of the following correctly shows the positive and negative partial charges on the S and Cl atoms and the polarity of the molecule?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The difference in electronegativity means that S has a positive partial charge and Cl has a negative partial charge. The bond polarities do not cancel out because of the molecular geometry, which is bent.

question_html:
Determine which of the following molecules are polar.

I. HF  

II. CCl4

III. SO2

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: CCl4 is a non-polar molecule as it has a tetrahedral geometry, even though Cl has a partial negative charge (δ-) and C has a partial positive charge (δ+). The bond polarities cancel out and the molecule has no net dipole moment. SO2 and HF are polar molecules due to the difference in electronegativity and the molecular geometry of SO2, which is bent.

question_html:
Determine which of the following molecules is/are polar.

I. H2O  

II. CH4

III. NH3

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: CH4 is non polar as the C-H bond is considered to be a non-polar bond. H2O and NH3 are polar molecules due to the difference in electronegativity and the geometry of the molecules (bent for H2O and trigonal pyramidal for NH3).

question_html: Which of the following is correct in terms of carbon-oxygen bond length?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The C-O is the longest bond, as there are the fewest electrons in the bond, therefore, the electrostatic attraction between the electrons and the nuclei is weaker than in C≡O and C=O. This makes the C-O bond the longest. The C≡O bond has the most electrons in the bond, making it the shortest.

question_html: Which of the following is correct in terms of carbon-oxygen bond strength?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The C≡O is the strongest bond as there are the most electrons in the bond. In C≡O there are 6 electrons in the bond and the electrostatic attraction between the nuclei and shared electrons is strong, making the bond the strongest. The weakest bond is the C-O bond with the least number of shared electrons.

question_html: Place the following bonds in order of increasing length: C–C, C≡C, C=C.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The C-C is the longest bond as there is the least number of electrons in the bond, therefore the electrostatic attraction between the shared electrons and the nuclei is weaker than in C≡C. In C≡C there are 6 shared electrons in the bond so the electrostatic attraction is much stronger, making the bond the shortest. The C=C bond, with four electrons, in longer than a C≡C bond, but shorter than a C-C bond.

question_html: Place the following bonds in order of increasing strength (weakest first): C–C, C≡C, C=C.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The C-C is the weakest bond as there is the least number of electrons in the bond, therefore, the electrostatic attraction between the shared electrons and the nuclei is weaker than in C=C or C≡C. In C≡C there are 6 shared electrons in the bond and so electrostatic attraction is stronger, making the bond the strongest of the three.

question_html: Predict the molecular geometry of XeF2 using VSEPR theory.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The molecular geometry is determined by the number of bonding and non-bonding domains around the central atom. Here there are two bonding domains and three non-bonding domains around the central atom (a total of five electron domains). This gives a linear molecular geometry.

question_html: What is the molecular geometry of carbon tetrachloride, CCl4? Hint - draw the Lewis structure to help you.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The central carbon atom is bonded to four chlorine atoms by single covalent bonds. The carbon atom has four electron domains which are four bonding domains. Therefore, the molecular geometry is tetrahedral.

question_html: What is the molecular geometry and bond angle of CO2?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The central carbon atom has two electron domains (both are bonding domains). This gives the molecule a linear molecular geometry with a 180o bond angle.

question_html: Predict the molecular geometry of PF5 using VSEPR theory.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The molecular geometry is determined by the number of bonding and non-bonding domains around the central atom. Here there are five bonding domains and zero non-bonding domains around the central atom (a total of five electron domains). This gives a trigonal bipyramidal molecular geometry.

question_html: Which of the following correctly describes how two atoms are held together in a covalent bond?

MCQ_set.answer_html: the attraction between the bonding pairs of electrons and the positive nuclei
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A covalent bond is the electrostatic attraction between positive nuclei and shared pairs of bonding electrons.

MCQ_set.answer_html: the attraction between a lattice of positive metal ions and delocalised electrons
the attraction between the pair of bonding electrons and the negative nuclei

question_html: Covalent bonds usually form between which of the following?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Covalent bonds usually form between non-metals elements. These elements are found on the right hand side of the periodic table. Note that there are exceptions to this rule; one example being aluminium chloride which has a covalent bond despite being a metal and a non-metal atom bonded together.

question_html: Diamond, a giant covalent compound, has a melting point of approximately 4000 K (at 100 atm). What is the force/bond broken when a giant covalent compound such as diamond melts?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: In a giant covalent compound, there are only covalent bonds between the atoms. When a giant covalent compound such as diamond melts, the covalent bonds are broken. Unlike in molecular covalent compounds, there are no intermolecular forces to break. Note also that diamond only forms a liquid at very high pressures.

question_html: Which type of intermolecular force needs to be overcome to melt a non-polar hydrocarbon solid?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Non-polar molecules only have London dispersion forces between the molecules - there are no dipole-dipole attractions or hydrogen bonds. To melt a non-polar hydrocarbon solid only the London dispersion forces between the molecules need to be overcome. The term 'van der Waal's forces' refers to both London dispersion forces and dipole-dipole attractions together, so it is not a correct answer.

question_html: Which combination of elements typically form ionic bonds?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Ionic bonds occur between metal and non-metal elements only (in the form of ions).

question_html:
Which of the following best describes the bond formed between S and O?

The electronegativity values of S and O are as follows:

S = 2.6

O = 3.4

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Bonding between non-metals is covalent and the difference in electronegativity between S (2.6) and O (3.4) means that the bond is a polar bond.

question_html: Identify the type of bond formed between Sr and O.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Strontium is a metal and oxygen is a non-metal. The bonding between the two will be ionic.

question_html: What is the charge formed by the group 17 elements when they are ionised?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Non-metals form negatively charged ions because they gain electrons to achieve a full outer shell of electrons. Group 17 elements only need to gain one electron in order to achieve a full outer shell as they have seven valence electrons. The charge is 1- as they have one more electron than protons.

question_html: Which group in the periodic table typically forms 1+ ions?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Metals form positively charged ions. Metals lose electrons to achieve a full outer shell. The alkali metals only need to lose one electron to achieve a full outer shell as they have only one valence electron. The charge formed is 1+ as they have one less electron than protons.

question_html: Determine the charges on the ions formed from the following atoms: Mg, Ba and S.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Metals form positively charged ions and non-metals form negatively charged ions. The charge depends on the group that the element belongs to. Group 2 elements (Mg and Ba) lose two electrons to form 2+ ions. Sulfur, a group 16 element, gains two electrons to form a 2- ion.

question_html: Determine the charges on the ions formed from the following atoms: Sr, K and F.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Metals form positively charged ions and non-metals form negatively charged ions. The size of the charge depends on the group that the element belongs to. Potassium, a group 1 element, forms a 1+ ion, strontium, a group 2 element, forms a 2+ ion and fluorine, a group 17 element, forms a 1- ion.

question_html: Determine the charges on the ions formed from the following atoms: Na, Cl and Al.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Metals form positively charged ions and non-metals form negatively charged ions. The size of the charge depends on the group that the element belongs to. Sodium, a group 1 element, forms a 1+ ion, Cl, a group 17 element, forms a 1- ion and Al, a group 13 element, forms a 3+ ion. Note that ions are usually written with the sign after the numerical value.

question_html: What are the forces/bonds broken when an ionic compound melts?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Ionic compounds have high melting points because of the strong electrostatic attractions between ions. When an ionic compound melts, these attractions are broken and the ions are free to move in the molten liquid.

question_html: Which of the following best describes ionic bonding?

MCQ_set.answer_html: The electrostatic attraction between oppositely charged ions
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: An ionic bond is the electrostatic attraction between oppositely charged ions.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The electrostatic attraction between ions of the same charge
The electrostatic attraction between nuclei and shared pairs of valence electrons
The electrostatic attraction between a lattice of positively charged metal ions and delocalised electrons

question_html:
Deduce which of the following halide ions will be displaced when fluorine (F2) is added to aqueous solutions of each. 

I. Cl–

II. Br–

III. I–

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The more reactive halogen will displace a less reactive halide ion in solution. F2 is the most reactive halogen and will displace all other halide ions in solution.

question_html:
Deduce which of the following compounds will react with aqueous chlorine, Cl2 (aq). 

I. KCl

II. KBr

III. KI

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The more reactive halogen (Cl2) will displace the less reactive halide ion from solution. Cl2 is more reactive than bromine and iodine so it displaces Br-(aq) and I-(aq) from solution. Note that a halogen cannot displace its own ions from solution so Cl2 does not react with KCl.

question_html:
Deduce which of the following compounds will react with aqueous iodine, I2 (aq). 

I. KCl

II. KBr

III. KI

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The more reactive halogen will displace the ions of a less reactive halogen from solution. I2 is the least reactive halogen and so will not displace any of the halide ions from solution.

question_html: Which of the following states how the reactivity of the halogens changes down the group?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Fluorine is the most reactive halogen and iodine the least. The reactivity decreases down the group.

question_html: Determine which species are present in an aqueous solution of magnesium chloride, MgCl2 (aq).

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: When an ionic substance dissolves in water it will dissociate into its constituent ions. In the case of MgCl2 these are Mg2+ and Cl– ions.

question_html: Deduce the pH of an aqueous solution of sodium chloride, NaCl (aq) at 298 K.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: When NaCl dissolves in water, it does not react with the water but simply dissociates into its constiutent ions. There is no change in the concentration of H+ ions and no pH change.

question_html: Deduce the pH of the solution formed when sulfur trioxide (SO3) reacts with water.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
In general metal oxides are basic and non-metal oxides are acidic. When SO3 reacts with water, it forms sulfuric acid (H2SO4) according to the following equation:

SO3 (g) + H2O (l) → H2SO4 (aq)

An aqueous solution of sulfuric acid has a pH less than 7.

question_html: Which of the following best describes the oxide of aluminium?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Aluminium forms an amphoteric oxide, Al2O3, which can act as both as acid and a base.

question_html: The terms acidic, amphoteric and basic refer to which order of the following three period 3 oxides?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: In general metal oxides are basic and non-metal oxides are acidic. Aluminium oxide is amphoteric as it will react with both acids and bases (it can behave as both an acid or as a base). P4O10 reacts with water to form H3PO4 (which is acidic) and Na2O reacts with water to form NaOH (which is basic).

question_html: The terms 'ionic, ionic, and covalent' refer to which order of the following period 3 oxides?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Na, Mg and Al form ionic bonds with oxygen as the reaction is between a metal and a non- metal. Si to Cl form covalent bonds with oxygen as they are both non-metals.

question_html: Identify the chemical trend of the period 3 oxides (from sodium to chlorine) in terms of acid-base character.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: In general, metal oxides are basic and non-metal oxides are acidic. Aluminium oxide is amphoteric as it will react with both acids and bases (it can behave as both an acid or as a base). The trend across period 3 changes from basic, to amphoteric to acidic.

question_html: Identify the general trend in the bonding type of the period 3 oxides from left to right across period 3.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Na and Mg and Al form ionic bonds with oxygen as the reaction is between a metal and a non- metal. Si → Cl form covalent bonds with oxygen as both are non-metals.

question_html: Determine the correct order of the following elements in order of increasing atomic radius: Ca, Cl, K, S.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: As you move down the group, the atomic radius increases as there is an increase in the number of occupied energy levels.

question_html: Deduce the correct order of the following elements in order of decreasing atomic radius: Cl, N, Na and F.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: As you move down a group, the atomic radius increases as there is a larger number of occupied energy levels. As you move across a period (left to right) the atomic radius decreases because of increasing nuclear charge and the electrons are added to the same main energy level. N and F are in the same period (period 2) with F being further to the right (in group 17), therefore, it has the smallest atomic radius of the two. Na and Cl are both in period 3 with Cl being further right (in group 17) than Na (group 1). So Cl has the smaller atomic radius than Na but both of these have a larger atomic radius than N and F as they have more occupied energy levels.

question_html: Deduce the correct order for the following elements in order of decreasing atomic radius: S, K, Cl and F.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: As you move down the group, the atomic radius increases as there is a larger number of occupied energy levels. As you move across a period the atomic radius decreases. K has the largest number of occupied energy levels and fluorine has the least. Fluorine and chlorine are further to the right in the periodic table and have smaller atomic radii.

question_html: Determine the correct order for the following elements in order of increasing electronegativity.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The general trend of electronegativity is decreasing diagonally and downwards from fluorine (top right hand corner of periodic table) to francium (bottom left hand corner of table). Fluorine and oxygen are the two most electronegative elements. Aluminum, being a metal, has a lower electronegativity.

question_html: Identify the correct order for the following elements in order of increasing electronegativity.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The general trend of electronegativity is decreasing diagonally and downwards from fluorine (top right hand corner of periodic table) to francium (bottom left hand corner of table). Chlorine is the most electronegative element of the three and silicon the least.

question_html:
Determine which pairs are listed in the correct order of electronegativity. 

I. F > O

II. Ca > S

III. P > Cl

IV. Br > I

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The general trend of electronegativity is that it increases across a period (left to right) and decreases down a group. Fluorine has a higher electronegativity than oxygen and bromine has a higher electronegativity than iodine.

question_html: Identify which trend in the periodic table is illustrated by the graph below.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The atomic radius decreases across the period due to increasing nuclear charge and the electron shielding remaining more or less constant.

question_html: Which of the following shows the correct arrangement of the elements in period 3 in order of decreasing melting point?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The charge on the metal ions increases across period three (Na+, Mg2+, Al3+). There are more free electrons in the lattice and these electrons are attracted more strongly to the more highly charged ions. Therefore, the melting point increases in the first three metallic elements. Silicon is a non-metal element which has a giant covalent structure which gives it a very high melting point.

question_html: Which of the following correctly states the trend in melting point of the alkali metals down the group?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: As more energy levels around the nucleus fill with electrons, these electrons are further from the positively charged nucleus and are less strongly attracted to it. Consequently, the delocalised electrons in the metal are less strongly attracted to the metal ions and the melting point decreases.

question_html: Identify the correct order of the halogens in order of increasing atomic radii.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: As you move down the group, the atomic radius increases as there is an increasing number of occupied energy levels. Fluorine has the smallest atomic radius and iodine the largest.

question_html: Determine the correct order of the melting points of the group 17 elements (in increasing order).

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The molar masses of the molecules increase down the group which results in stronger intermolecular forces between the molecules causing an increase in melting point down the group.

question_html: Identify the correct order of the melting point of the group 1 metals (in increasing order).

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The metallic bond is the electrostatic attraction between the delocalised electrons and the lattice of positive metal ions. As the ionic radius increases, the distance between the nuclei of the metal ions and the delocalised electrons increases which decreases the strength of the electrostatic attraction. This results in a weaker metallic bond and a lower melting point. Therefore, the melting point decreases down group 1.

question_html: Which of the following correctly states the trend in atomic radii down a group and across a period in the periodic table?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Increases down a group and decreases across a period (left to right)
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Atomic radii decrease across a period (left to right) as there is an increase in nuclear charge across a period but little change in electron shielding (electrons are added to the same main energy level). It increases down a group as the number of occupied energy levels increases.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Increases up a group and decreases across a period (left to right)
Increases down a group and increases across a period (left to right)
Decreases down a group and increases across a period (left to right)

question_html: Which of the following correctly states the definition of electronegativity?

MCQ_set.answer_html: A measure of the attraction between an atom and bonding electrons
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The definition of electronegativity is the measure of the attraction an atom has for the bonding electrons in a covalent bond.

MCQ_set.answer_html: A measure of the repulsion between the valence electrons of an atom
The level of electron shielding in an atom

question_html: Which of the following correctly outlines why electronegativity increases across a period?

MCQ_set.answer_html: There is an increase in nuclear charge and a decrease in the atomic radius
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The nuclear charge relates to the number of protons in the nucleus. If there are more protons in the nucleus, the valence electrons will be attracted more strongly and the atom will have a stronger attraction for the pairs of electrons in the bond. The atomic radius decreases across a period because of increasing nuclear charge and the level of electron shielding remain fairly constant. Both factors lead to an increase in electronegativity across a period.

MCQ_set.answer_html: There are more electrons and more repulsion between electrons

question_html: Which of the following correctly explains why electronegativity decreases down a group?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Electronegativity is a measure of the attraction of an atom for a bonding pair of electrons. The larger the atomic radius, the weaker the attraction between the nucleus and the bonding electrons and the lower the electronegativity.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The nuclear charge increases down a group
The level of electron shielding decreases down a group

question_html:
Deduce which trends are seen as you move down a group in the periodic table.

I. increase ionic radius

II. increase in atomic radius

III. increase in ionisation energy

IV. increase in electronegativity

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Both ionic and atomic radius increase down a group because there are more occupied energy levels down a group. Electronegativity and ionisation decrease down a group as the atomic radius increases.

question_html: Which of the following correctly states how the elements are ordered in the periodic table?

MCQ_set.answer_html: In order of increasing number of protons
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The number of protons defines an element and the periodic table is ordered according to the number of protons (the atomic number) which increases by one across a period (from left to right).

MCQ_set.answer_html: In order of increasing number of neutrons
In order of increasing relative atomic mass
In order of increasing number of occupied main energy levels

question_html: Which of the following correctly states the trend in atomic radius as you move up a group and from left to right across a period in the periodic table?

MCQ_set.answer_html: Atomic radius decreases up a group and across a period
