MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Up a group, the atomic radius decreases as the number of occupied energy shells decreases. From left to right across a period the atomic radius also decreases as the nuclear charge increases and electron shielding remains constant.

MCQ_set.answer_html: Atomic radius increases up a group and decreases across a period
Atomic radius decreases up a group and increases across a period
Atomic radius increases up a group and across a period

question_html: Deduce the correct order of the following elements when placed in order of increasing relative atomic mass, Ar: Mg, Sn, F, C.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Generally speaking, Ar increases across a period and down a group. There are notable exceptions, for example, argon and potassium, where Z increases but Ar does not.

question_html: Identify the element with the electron configuration 1s2 2s2 2p6.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Neutral atoms have the same number of protons and electrons - this element has 10 electrons and 10 protons, therefore, it is neon (atomic number 10).

question_html: Identify the element with the electron configuration 1s2 2s2 2p6 3s2 3p3.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Neutral atoms have the same number of protons and electrons - this element has 15 electrons and 15 protons, therefore, it is phosphorus (atomic number 15).

question_html: Identify the element with the electron configuration 1s2 2s2 2p6 3s2 3p6 3d1 4s2 (or 1s2 2s2 2p6 3s2 3p6 4s2 3d1).

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: In a neutral atom, the number of protons is equal to the number of electrons. According to the electron configuration, this element has 21 electrons and therefore 21 protons. The element that has 21 protons is scandium (Sc) on the periodic table. Note that the electron configuration can be written with the 4s before the 3d or after it.

question_html: Deduce the difference (if any) between an emission line spectrum and a continuous spectrum.

MCQ_set.answer_html: In an emission line spectrum only certain wavelengths of visible light are seen whereas in a continuous spectrum all wavelengths of visible light are seen.
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A continuous line spectrum shows all the wavelengths (or frequencies) of visible light, from red to violet. An emission line spectrum shows only certain wavelengths of visible light and is seen as coloured lines on a black background.

MCQ_set.answer_html: In an emission line spectrum all wavelengths of visible light are seen whereas in a continuous spectrum only certain wavelengths of visible light are seen.
A continuous spectrum shows visible light of shorter wavelengths whereas an emission line spectrum shows visible light of longer wavelengths.
There is no difference - a continuous spectrum is identical to an emission line spectrum.

question_html: Deduce which of the following the emission line spectrum of an element can be used for.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Emission line spectra are specific to each element and can be used to identify different elements.

MCQ_set.answer_html: To determine the number of neutrons in the nucleus of an atom
To determine the number of electrons in an atom
To determine the relative atomic mass of a compound

question_html: Which of the following can be deduced from the emission line spectrum of an element?

MCQ_set.answer_html: The existence of discrete energy levels in an atom
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: An emission line spectrum shows only certain wavelengths of light emitted by an element. This provides evidence for the existence of energy levels within the atom as only certain energies, or wavelengths, of light are emitted. The wavelengths of light emitted depend on the energy difference between the energy levels in the atom.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The existence of a dense nucleus in an atom
The existence of isotopes of an element
The existence of protons in the nucleus of an atom

question_html: Which of the following can be deduced from the convergence limit of a series of spectral lines of an atom?

MCQ_set.answer_html: The point at which the atom has been ionised
MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The convergence limit represents the transition where an electron has escaped from the attraction of the nucleus. The electron has been removed from the influence of the nucleus and the atom has been ionised.

MCQ_set.answer_html: The existence of energy levels within the atom

question_html: Determine which of the following parameters is the basis by which substances are detected and identified in a mass spectrometer.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Substances are identified in a mass spectrometer according to their mass:charge ratio (m/z). The instrument is designed to detect positive ions - whether derived from atoms of an element or by the fragmentation of molecules.

Be careful, usually the machine is set up to analyse those ions with a single positive charge and so, in this case, the separation is by mass but the general principle is separation on mass:charge ratio.

question_html: A sample of an element X is made up of 11% of the isotope X-17 and 89% of the isotope X-13. Calculate the relative atomic mass, Ar, of element X.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Ar = ((11 × 17) + (89 × 13)) / 100 = 13.44

question_html: A sample of element Z is made up of 66.7% of isotope Z-15 and 33.3% of isotope Z-20. Determine the relative atomic mass, Ar of element Z.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: This can be done by inspection without a calculator. As the majority of the isotope is Z-15 we know that the Ar will be closer to 15 than 20. It will not be half-way, i.e. not 17.5 as both isotopes are not of equal abundance.

question_html: A sample of element X is made up of 80% X-13 and 20% X-11. Calculate the relative atomic mass, Ar, of X?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
To calculate the relative atomic mass of an element multiply the % abundance by the isotopic mass of each isotope, add them together and divide by 100. 

Relative atomic mass = ((80 × 13) + (20 × 11)) / 100 = 12.6

question_html: A sample of element Z, which has two isotopes, is made up of 75% Z-12 and 25% Z-13. Calculate the relative atomic mass, Ar of Z.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Relative atomic mass = ((75 × 12) + (25 × 13)) /100 = 12.25

question_html: Identify which sub-atomic particle(s) make up the isotopic mass of an isotope.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The isotopic mass of an atom is the combined mass of the neutrons + protons. This is the mass of the nucleus, and also the overall mass of the atom as electrons have negligible mass in comparison.

question_html: Deduce which main energy level has the highest energy in the atom shown in the diagram below.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Electrons are located in main energy levels denoted by n. Higher main energy levels have higher energy and are further from the nucleus of the atom.

question_html: An ion, X2-, has a 2- charge. The number of electrons in the ion is 10 and the number of neutrons is 8. Identify the element from which the ion was formed.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The 2- charge indicates that the particle is a negative ion. 2 electrons have been gained to form the ion; there are two more electrons present than protons. There must be 8 protons in the nucleus. The ion is derived from an atom with proton (atomic) number = 8; an atom of oxygen.

question_html: An ion formed from an atom has a 4+ charge. The number of electrons present in the ion is 21 and the number of neutrons is 30. Identify the element.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The 4+ charge indicates that 4 electrons have been lost from the atom. Originally there were 25 electrons (21+4 =25) in the atom. In a neutral atom, the number of protons is equal to the number of electrons, therefore, there must be 25 protons in the atom. The only element in the periodic table with a proton (atomic) number of 25 is manganese (Mn).

question_html: An ion formed from an atom has a 1- charge. The number of electrons present in the ion is 36 and the number of neutrons is 46. Identify the element.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The 1- charge indicates that there is one more electron than protons. If the number of electrons is 36, then the number of protons is 35 (36-1=35) Bromine has 35 protons (Z = 35), so it is the correct answer.

question_html: An ion formed from an atom has a 2+ charge. The number of electrons present in the ion is 10 and the number of neutrons is 12. Identify the element.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The 2+ charge indicates that the atom has lost 2 electrons and the ion has two fewer electrons than protons; therefore, Z = 12 (10+2) and the element is magnesium (Mg).

question_html: An atom of an element is made up of 29 protons and 35 neutrons. Identify the element.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The number of protons (the proton, or atomic number) is the identifying feature of an element. The only element in the periodic table with 29 protons is copper (Cu).

question_html: An atom of an isotope of strontium is made up of 38 protons and 49 neutrons. Identify the isotope.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The isotope strontium-87 consists of 38 protons and 49 neutrons - it has an isotopic mass of 87 (38+49).

question_html: The atoms of an element consist of 5 protons and 5 neutrons. Identify the element.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The number of protons (the proton number) is the identifying feature of an element. The only element in the periodic table with 5 protons is boron (B).

question_html: Using the graph below, identify the relationship between temperature and volume at constant pressure (k is a constant).

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: A straight line through the origin illustrates a relationship of direct proportionality between two variables (V  ∝ T)

question_html: Identify the equation relating pressure, P, volume,V, and temperature, T, for an ideal gas under two different sets of conditions.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: (P1V1)/T1=(P2V2)/T2 is the overall gas law equation for ideal gases where the units of T must be Kelvin.

question_html: Boyle's Law is the relationship between pressure and volume of an ideal gas at constant temperature. Which of the following is the correct relationship between pressure and volume at constant temperature?

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Pressure and volume are inversely proportional and thus P is proportional to 1/V

Therefore P = k/V (k is a proportionality constant); or PV = k.

question_html: Determine which of the following samples has the greatest mass (in g).

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Calculate the Mr of each substance and multiply by the amount (in mol). The masses obtained are:

CaSO4 = 204.23 g, O2 = 96.00 g, C = 36.03 g and F2 = 76.00 g

question_html: Determine which of the following samples contains the greatest number of carbon atoms.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: 28.0 g of graphite = 2.33 mol of carbon atoms. 23.0 dm3 of CO2 contains 1.01 mol of CO2 which is 1.01 × 6.02 × 1023 carbon atoms (less than 2 mol). Methane contains one C atom, therefore 1.00 mol of C atoms. The carbonic acid solution contains 0.1 mol of C atoms. Therefore, 28.0 g of graphite is the correct answer.

MCQ_set.answer_html: A 100 cm3 sample of a 1.00 mol dm-3 solution of carbonic acid (H2CO3)

question_html: Determine which sample of oxygen gas contains the largest number of O atoms.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Work through each possible answer assessing which are greater than one mole and which are less. Only 1.6 mol of O2 has greater than 1 mol of O2 atoms; thus this sample has the most atoms compared with the other three.

1.6 g < 1 mol; 1 mol of gas = 22.7 dm3 at STP, thus 1.6 dm3 < 1 mol; and one mol contains 6.02 × 1023 atoms which is much greater than the option of 1.6 × 1023 O atoms.

question_html:
Sulfur dioxide, SO2, reacts with oxygen according to the following equation:

2SO2 (g) + O2 (g)  → 2SO3 (g)

Calculate the volume of SO2 required to make 80 cm3 of SO3, assuming oxygen is the excess reactant.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: When working with volumes of gases, it is not necessary to convert to amount (in mol) if all components are gaseous. The molar ratio of SO2:SO3 is 1:1, therefore 80 cm3 of SO2 will produce 80 cm3 of SO3.

question_html:
Sodium hydroxide solution reacts with calcium chloride solution according to the following equation:

2NaOH (aq) + CaCl2 (aq) → 2NaCl (aq) + Ca(OH)2 (s)

30.0 cm3 of 0.500 mol dm-3 NaOH (aq) reacts with 20.0 cm3 of CaCl2 (aq). Calculate the concentration of the CaCl2 solution (in mol dm-3).

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Amount in mol of NaOH = 0.500 × (30.0/1000) = 1.50 × 10-2 mol

Amount in mol of CaCl2  = (1.50 × 10-2) / 2 = 7.50 × 10-3 mol

Concentration of CaCl2 solution = (7.50 × 10-3) / (20.0/1000) = 0.375 mol dm-3

question_html:
Sodium hydroxide (NaOH) reacts with sulfuric acid (H2SO4) according to the following equation:

2NaOH (aq) + H2SO4 (aq) → Na2SO4 (aq) + 2H2O (l)

Calculate the volume of 2.00 mol dm-3 H2SO4 required to react with 100 cm3 of 5.00 mol dm-3 NaOH.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Calculate the amount (in mol) of NaOH using n=CV

n = 5.00 × (100/1000) = 0.500 mol

Ratio of NaOH to H2SO4 is 2:1

Therefore, 0.500 mol of NaOH will react with 0.250 mol of H2SO4

Volume of H2SO4 = n/C = 0.250 / 2.00 = 0.125 dm3

Multiply by 1000 to convert to cm3 = 125 cm3

question_html:
Sodium hydroxide (NaOH) reacts with phosphoric acid (H3PO4) according to the following equation:

3NaOH (aq) + H3PO4 (aq) → Na3PO4 (aq) + 3H2O (l)

Calculate the concentration of the H3PO4 if 30.0 cm3 of 0.300 mol dm-3 NaOH reacts with 10.0 cm3 of H3PO4.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Amount (in mol) of NaOH: n=CV = 0.300 × (30.0/1000) = 9.00 × 10-3 mol

Molar ratio of NaOH to H3PO4 is 3:1

Therefore, 9.00 × 10-3 mol of NaOH reacts with 3.00 × 10-3 mol of H3PO4

Concentration of H3PO4 : C=n/V = 3.00 × 10-3 / (10.0/1000) = 0.300 mol dm-3

question_html: 0.200 mol of calcium fluoride, CaF2, is added to 250 cm3 of distilled water which is then made up to a total volume of 1.00 dm3. From this solution, 1.00 cm3 is removed. Calculate the amount (in mol) of fluoride ions, F–, removed from the solution.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
The concentration of the original solution is 0.200 mol dm-3. But as only 1.00 cm3 is considered, using the equation n = CV (dm3) = 0.200 × (1.00/1000) = 0.000200 mol CaF2.

One mol of CaF2 dissociates into one Ca2+ and  two F– ions when in solution, therefore, you must double the amount of F– ions present = 0.000400 mol.

question_html: 100 cm3 of magnesium chloride (MgCl2) solution is made with a concentration of 1.00 mol dm-3. Calculate the amount (in mol) of chloride ions, Cl-, present in the solution.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
One mol of MgCl2 consists of one mol of Mg2+ ions and 2 mol of Cl- ions, therefore, we need to multiply the amount in mol by two:

Using the equation n=CV

n = 1.00 × (100/1000) = 0.100 mol 

2 × 0.100 = 0.200 mol of Cl- ions.

question_html: Calculate the amount (in mol) of hydrochloric acid, HCl (aq), in 50.0 cm3 of a 2.00 mol dm-3 solution of HCl.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
Using the equation n=CV: 

n = 2.00 × (50.0/1000) = 0.100 mol

question_html:
Determine the stoichiometric coefficient of the sulfuric acid in the reaction of copper with concentrated sulfuric acid to form copper(II) sulfate and sulfur dioxide.

                               Cu (s) + __ H2SO4 (aq) → CuSO4 (aq) + 2H2O (l) + SO2 (g)

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: There are two moles of sulfur on the products side of the equation; therefore the coefficient of the sulfuric acid is two.

question_html:
Determine the sum of the stoichiometric coefficients in the reaction between sodium and bromine. The unbalanced equation is shown below:

__Na (s) + __Br2 (l) → __NaBr (s)

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The balanced equation is: 2Na (s) + Br2 (l) → 2NaBr (s) - the sum of the coefficients is 5. Note that if no coefficient is written, it is taken as being a 1.

question_html: Determine the mass of oxygen in 18.5 g of the organic compound, C4H10O.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: In one molecule of C4H10O, there is one atom of oxygen. Therefore, for every one mole of C4H10O there is one mol of oxygen. Mr of C4H10O = 74.14. The amount (in mol) of C4H10O = 18.5 g/74.14 g mol-1 = 0.250 mol; therefore, 0.250 mol of O would be present. 0.250 × 16.00 = 4.00 g.

question_html: Calculate the mass (in g) of oxygen in 3 moles of sulfuric acid molecules, H2SO4.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: In one molecule of H2SO4, there are 4 atoms of oxygen. Therefore, for every one mole of H2SO4 we have 4 moles of O. We are told we have 3 moles of H2SO4 which contains a total of twelve moles of oxygen atoms (3 × 4 = 12). To determine the mass of O, (Ar=16):  12 × 16 = 192 g

question_html:
Determine the limiting reactant when 12.00 g of carbon reacts with 12.00 g of oxygen according to the following equation:

                                                         C (s) + O2 (g) → CO2 (g)

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html:
First, convert from mass (in g) to amount (in mol).

This gives 0.9992 mole of C (12.00/12.01), and 0.3750 moles of O2 (12.00/32.00).

Divide each amount (in mol) by the coefficient in the balanced equation:

C: 0.9992 / 1 = 0.9992

O2: 0.375 / 1 = 0.375

The lowest number is 0.375, therefore, O2 is the limiting reactant.

question_html: Determine the mass (in g) of two molecules of CO2.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The key to this question is the reference to molecules. Avogadro's constant states that there are 6.02 × 1023 particles (atoms, molecules, ions) per mole of any substance. Therefore, to get the answer you must find the Mr of CO2, i.e. 44.01 Divide this by Avogadro's number to get the mass of one molecule (7.31 × 10-23 g) and then multiply by 2, as the question asks for the mass of two molecules.

question_html: Determine the number of carbon atoms in 0.500 mol of ethene (C2H4).

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: There are 2 carbon atoms in a molecule of ethene. For every mole of ethene there are two moles of carbon atoms. There are 6.02 × 1023 particles in a mole. This gives, overall, 6.02 × 1023 × 2 × 0.500 = 6.02 × 1023 moles of carbon atoms in 0.500 mol of ethene.

question_html: Calculate the number of chloride ions (Cl-) in 190.4 g of MgCl2.

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: The Mr of MgCl2 is 95.2, therefore, we have 2 moles of MgCl2, (190.4 / 95.2 = 2). Two moles of MgCl2 contains 1.20 × 1024 formula units of MgCl2. There are two Cl- ions per formula unit of MgCl2; therefore, there are 2.41 × 1024 Cl- ions in 190.4 g of MgCl2 (6.02 × 1023 × 2 × 2 = 2.41 × 1024).

question_html:
Calculate the mass (in g) of two moles of chlorine molecules.  

M Cl = 35.45 g mol-1

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Chlorine is a diatomic element, (Cl2). The molar mass of Cl is 35.45 g mol-1, therefore, the molar mass of Cl2 is 70.90 g mol-1 (2 × 35.45). The question asks for the mass of 2 moles; therefore, 70.90 × 2 = 141.8 g.

question_html: Determine the mass (in g) of one mole of atoms of the isotope carbon-14 (14C).

MCQ_set.answer_explanation_html: Carbon-14 is an isotope of carbon; the number 14 indicates the isotopic mass of the isotope. One mole of any substance contains the Avogadro constant of atoms which is 6.02 × 1023. One mole of carbon-14 atoms has a mass of 14.00 g (in other words, its molar mass is 14.00 g mol-1).
